The Ministry of Industry announced that the existing Foreign Exchange Regulation Act (FERA) would be strictly enforced. After the dilution of capital, to 40 per cent, or as prescribed, foreign com- panies would be treated on a par with Indian companies. For all approved foreign investments, there would be complete freedom of remittance of profits, royalties, dividends, and repatriation of capital, subject to gener- ally applicable rules and regulations. While majority interest in ownership and effective control should be in Indian hands, exceptions might be made if the under- takings were highly export-oriented and /or required sophisticated technology. In 100 per cent export-oriented cases, the Govern- ment might consider even a fully-owned foreign com- pany. Foreign investment and acquisition of technology necessary for India's industrial development would be allowed only on terms determined by the government to be in the national interest. In areas where foreign technological know-how was not needed, existing col- laboration agreements would not be renewed and foreign companies operating in such fields would have to modify their character and activities in conformity with national priorities within the framework of FERA. For the guidance of entrepreneurs, the Government would issue a revised list of industries where no foreign collaboration, financial or technical, was considered necessary. 206 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDONESIA (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Indonesian Rupiah has been established with the Fund. In the Jakarta foreign exchange Bourse, transactions in U.S. dollars have since August 23, 1971 been effected at rates w i th in 1 per cent either side of Rp 415 per US$1; on December 31, 1977 the buying and selling rates were Rp 414 and Rp 416, respectively, per US$1. Exchange rates for other cur- rencies are determined on the basis of the Jakar ta rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, and rates for the currencies concerned in international markets. In the Jakarta foreign exchange Bourse three calls for exchange are conducted each week under the manage- ment of Bank Indonesia. Bidding for exchange is restricted to the authorized foreign exchange banks, nonbank f inan- cial institutions, and licensed foreign exchange dealers. Bank Indonesia is committed to deal with any willing buyer or seller at the going rate. Representatives of the foreign exchange banks no t ify Bank Indonesia of their supply to the market and each presents a bid for the total of his bank's requirements at a particular rate. Bank Indonesia clears the market at the intervention rate. The Bank also offers authorized banks certain facilities for forward contracts in respect of aid exchange and for swap transactions in U.S. dollars. Administration of Control The implementation of exchange and trade control is entrusted to Bank Indonesia, the Ministry of Trade, the Ministry of Finance, authorized foreign exchange banks, and the customs authorities. Exchange control is ad- ministered by Bank Indonesia and the M in is try of Fi- nance. Exporters' licenses are issued by the Department of Trade offices in provincial capitals. Sabang is entirely outside the Indonesian exchange and trade control sys tem ,l but the Indonesian rupiah is legal tender there. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected through the authorized banks and are normally effected in convertible currencies. Export proceeds must be received in speci- fied currencies. 2 Indonesia has no operative payments agreements.3 1 With the exception that the prohibition on imports of certain auto- mobiles is applicable also in Sabang. 2 Australian dollars, Aus tr ian schillings, Belgian f ranc s, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Malaysian r ingg i t, Netherlands guilders, New Zealand dollars, Norwegian kroner, Por tuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Singapore dollars, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 3 Indonesia maintains an inoperative bilateral paymen ts agreement with the People's Republic of China. Nonresident Accounts There are no restrictions on the opening by foreign nationals of accounts in Indonesia in rupiahs or foreign currencies with authorized foreign exchange banks. No distinction for exchange control purposes is made between resident and nonresident accounts. However, no checks may be drawn on foreign currency accounts; if the account holder wishes to effect a withdrawal, a letter must be sent to the bank. Imports and Import Payments There is a registry of authorized importers and an in i t i al deposit is required for reg is tra t ion. Since Octo- ber 31, 1968, only Indonesian nationals may obtain an importer's license, but certain established foreign firms have retained their licenses and new foreign investors can obtain an importer's license restricted to the import of materials required for their own projects. Imports f rom Angola, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited, as are imports from all sources of any secondhand goods and of specified commodities. The latter include built-up sedans and station wagons; com- ponents for the assembly of luxury automobiles; built-up commercial vehicles and motorcycles; radio and tele- vision sets in built-up or semiknocked-down condition; built-up air conditioners, refrigerators, and electric sew- ing machines; sarongs; galvanized iron sheets; iron roof- ing sheets; mosquito sticks; matches; monosodium gluta- mate; mattresses; certain types of cotton yarn; and specified types of textiles, au tomob i le tires, batteries, p r in ted ma t ter, office supplies, an im al traps, bottles, and lamps and bulbs. Imports of cloves, fer t i l izers, rice, re f ined sugar, and wheat and wheat f lour are restricted to specified approved impor ters. Impor ts of ce r ta in com- mod i t ies for the "basic na t ional stockpile" are reserved for state en terpr ises; these curren t ly inc lude cement, new sp r in t, cer ta in types of paper, au tomob i le tires, asphalt, cotton weav ing ya rn, sheet i ron, r e in fo r c ing steel, raw ma ter ia ls for ma r i t ime indus t r ies, and pharma- ceutical raw materials. No licenses are required for impor ts. In pr inc ip le, all perm i t ted impo r ts may be paid for e i ther w i th general exchange (Devisa Umum) or aid exchange (Devisa Kredit)', textiles, however, may be paid for w i th general exchange only. For imports financed with aid exchange a compensa t ion payment is gran ted a f ter customs clearance; this payment ranges f rom Rp 20 to Rp 45 per U.S. dollar of the import va lue, depend ing on coun try of origin a n d / or donor coun t ry. Sight bankers' letters of credit are required for all private sector impo r t s4 with the exception of parcel imports, goods brought in by travelers of a value not 4 With effect f rom Janua ry 1, 1978, the opening of usance letters of credit is allowed in specific cases. 207 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution INDONESIA exceeding US$100, and imports specifically authorized by the Ministry of Trade or by the Investment Coordinat- ing Board in the case of goods constituting part of a foreign investment. A rupiah deposit of 100 per cent of the amount of the letter of credit must be lodged with Bank Indonesia when a letter of credit is opened for imports financed with aid exchange; for imports financed with general exchange, importers are required to make an advance deposit of at least 40 per cent of the letter of credit value when they submit applications for letters of credit to authorized banks, and to settle the balance upon receipt of the documents, upon arrival of the goods, or within 75 days of the opening of the letter of credit. The amount of the deposit against letters of credit for non- government imports financed with aid exchange is left to the discretion of the authorized bank if the latter purchases aid exchange forward f rom Bank Indonesia. If imports fa ll into certain categories which have been identified as "having met domestic demand sufficiently," a 100 per cent import deposit must be lodged at the t ime of opening the letter of credit, and 100 per cent of the import du ty must be paid in advance. Also, a financial guarantee amoun t ing to 100 per cent of the value of the letter of credit is blocked in the importer's account un t il completion of customs procedure (the deposit reverts to the Government in case of "physical or administrative smuggling"). Bank credit may not be used to meet these requirements. Most varieties of textiles, polyester fibers, reinforcing steel, and gunny bags are subject to these provisions. Import duties, which are almost w i thout exception ad valorem, are imposed on "check" prices ( ind ica t ive prices) determined by the Ministers of Trade, Indus try, and Finance on the recommendation of a Check Price Team. These prices are set to reflect c.i.f. prices and are changed when prices abroad d i f fer by more than 10 per cent f rom the check prices for the preceding three months. Sales taxes of 5, 10, and 20 per cent are levied on most imports on their c. & f. value plus import duty. Items which are exempt from import duties are also exempt from sales taxes. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted or subject to control. Proceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered. Travelers may take out and bring in any amount in foreign banknotes but only Rp 2,500 in Indonesian notes and coins other than gold and silver commemorative coins; Indonesian commemorative gold and silver coins issued in August 1970 may be taken out freely up to Rp 65,000 a person, while the limit applicable to gold and silver coins issued in October 1974 is Rp 130,000. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Angola, the People's Republic of China, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited, as are exports to all countries of gold ore and pure gold; fer- 208 tilizers (except urea and ammon ium su l fa te ); rawhides of cattle; certain categories of unprocessed or low- qua l i ty rubber; certain logs and timber; all types of waste paper ( f rom Java and M a d u r a ); scrap of bronze and copper (except from Irian J a y a ); iron scrap; steel scrap ( f rom Java, Madura, and Suma t ra ); rice; and various types of sugar. The prior authorization of the Minister of Trade is required for the export of flatbark crepe, cinchona bark, clove seeds, pepper seeds, silver, antiques of cu l tural value, and all goods produced from subsidized raw materials. Otherwise, all commodities may be freely exported by registered private firms and state trading firms. All exporters except certain m in ing companies and licensed "border-crossing" traders must require their buyers to open a bank letter of credit covering the value of the goods to be exported (see footnote 4 ). The exporter must surrender the fu ll fore ign exchange value prior to sh ipment if there is no banker's letter of credit. 5 For the principal export commodities other than pe- troleum, the sale prices must not be lower than "indica- tion" prices ("check" prices) determined periodically by the M in is ter of Trade. The fu ll proceeds f rom exports other than petroleum, products of certain m in ing com- panies, and goods exported by licensed "border-crossing" traders are subject to surrender (except in "border- crossing" trade, see be low). Exports of copra cake, sawn t imber, hides, rubber, coffee, palm kernels, palm oil, pepper, and a few other commodities are subject to a 5 per cent tax, and the ma jor m ineral products and unsawn timber to a 10 per cent tax. Certain commodities produced in border regions may be exported to Malaysia and the Philippines in exchange for certain eligible goods. In this "border-crossing" trade w i th Malaysia, the value of import or export shipments must not exceed M$600 a mon th, if transported overland, and M$600 a shipment, if transported by sea; for the Philippines, the value of imports or exports must not exceed the rup iah or peso equivalent of US$150 for a single tr ip if transported by sea-going vessel or US$1,500 if transported by boat. Capital Foreign capital invested in Indonesia is governed p r im a r i ly by the Foreign Capital Investment Law of Janua ry 10, 1967, as amended in August 1970, by Presidential Guidelines issued on Janua ry 22, 1974 and September 21, 1974, and by two Presidential Decrees promulgated on October 3, 1977. In principle, such investments may be unde r taken only through a jo int venture w i th an Indonesian partner. All investments in Indonesia require the approval of the Investment Coordi- nating Board (BKPM ). Enterprises that are wholly or largely operated in Indonesia as separate business un i ts must be incorporated under Indonesian law and must 3 There are separate a r rangemen ts for expor ts of orchids. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution have their domicile in Indonesia. The operating permit for foreign investment is usually valid for a maximum of 30 years. Among the inducements offered are exemption from, or reduction in, corporate and dividend taxes for a certain number of years. Investors are granted the right to transfer profits (a f ter settlement of taxes and financial obligations in Indonesia) and to make trans- fers relating to expenses connected with the employment of foreign nationals in Indonesia, and in respect of depreciation allowances after the expiration of the tax holiday f rom corporation tax. The law provides that no transfer permit shall be issued for capital repatriation as long as the investments benefit f rom tax relief; at present, however, foreign payments do not require a t rans fer permit. The exploration and development of petroleum resources are governed by the Petroleum Law of 1960. A Debt Investment Conversion Scheme (DIGS) exists for the benefit of foreign creditors holding nonguaran teed claims against Indonesia. Rupiahs covered by the Scheme are administered in two k inds of DICS-Rupiah Accounts, A and B, the former relating on ly to c la ims of which the creditor is the first holder. Private creditors w i l l ing to accept the terms of the Scheme and prepared to make investments under the Foreign Capital Investment Law of 1967 are paid in rupiahs in settlement of their claims. These claims are t rans fe rab le to other potential investors in Indonesia, but only the original creditor's DICS rupiahs may be used, in the creditor's own projects that have been approved under the Foreign Capital Invest- ment Law of 1967, for the purchase of foreign exchange for the import of equipment and raw ma ter ia ls necessary for the establishment and operation of those projects. There are no limitations on the rem i t tance to Indonesia of capital in the form of foreign exchange or in com- modities. Both residents and nonresidents may hold foreign currency deposits w i th foreign exchange banks. However, foreign exchange banks, nonbank financial ins t i tu t ions, and private companies are subject to Bank Indonesia directives w i th respect to borrowing abroad, the acceptance of deposits f rom nonresidents, and the issuance of certificates of deposit to nonresidents. A 30 per cent reserve requirement is applicable to the foreign currency liabilities of fore ign exchange banks; ° no deposit requirements are applicable to the foreign bor- rowings of nonbank financial ins t i tu t ions or private com- panies. Certain borrowing abroad is subject to clearance by Bank Indonesia, and all foreign borrowing is subject to reporting to Bank Indonesia and /or the M in is t ry of Finance. The prior approval of the M in is ter of Finance is required before any public enterprise or public sector body may accept a loan f rom abroad. Indonesian citizens and residents of foreign na t iona l i ty may freely transfer, negotiate, import, and export securi- ties denominated in rupiahs or in fore ign currency. 6 The reserve requirement was lowered to 15 per cent with effect f rom January 1, 1978. INDONESIA Gold Indonesia has issued six commemorative gold coins, which are legal tender. Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold and gold coins in Indonesia. Exports of gold ore and pure gold, unless made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities, are prohibited. Travelers may freely take out Indonesian commemorative gold and sil- ver coins issued in August 1970 up to Rp 65,000 a per- son, and gold and silver coins issued in October 1974 up to Rp 130,000 a person; amounts in excess require the prior approval of Bank Indonesia. Imports of gold are free of license but require prior notification to the Ministry of Industry and are subject to an extra levy of Rp 25 per US$1. Changes during 1977 January 1. Not for Redistribution IRAN (Position on December 31,1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0108055 gram of fine gold per Iranian Rial, corresponding to R ls 82.2425 = SDR 1. The exchange rate is maintained on the basis of this par value equivalent. Iran has availed itself of wider mar- gins, and the intervention currency is the U.S. dollar. On December 31, 1977 the official rate of Bank Markazi Iran (the Central Bank) for the U.S. dollar, the only currency that is officially quoted, were Rls 70.35 buying, and Rls 70.60 selling, per US$1. The Central Bank also publishes daily exchange rates for 14 other currencies l for purposes of the calculation of import registration fees and import duties; these rates are based on the official rates for the U.S. dollar and the London market rates for the currencies concerned. There is a dual exchange market, consisting of a com- mercial market (or official rate market) with fixed U.S. dollar rates and a noncommercial market with fluctu- ating rates. Both markets operate w i th in the bank ing sys- tem. The Central Bank stands ready to purchase f rom the commercial banks, at official rates, any foreign exchange proceeds from exports of goods and services. Import payments must in principle be settled in the offi- cial rate market. Also settled at official rates are basic allocations for certain authorized current payments (travel, study, and medical treatment abroad) and, on the supply side, any export proceeds and other current receipts converted by public sector agencies (including the National Iranian Oil Company). Transactions over clearing accounts denominated in U.S. dollars are in all cases settled at the official buying and selling rates. Pro- ceeds from exports other than petroleum, petroleum products, and natural gas, as well as the proceeds from exports of services, may be sold either in the official or the noncommercial market. All other payments and receipts are settled at the noncommercial market rate. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Central Bank. In principle, all foreign exchange transactions must take place through the Central Bank or authorized banks. Imports and exports are governed by regulations issued annually by the Ministry of Commerce after being approved by the Council of Ministers. Foreign trade relations with the Republic of China are under the con- trol of the National Iranian Trading Corporation within the Ministry of Commerce. Prescription of Currency Transactions with seven of the ten countries with which Iran has bilateral payments agreements 2 must be 1 Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds ster- ling, Swedish kroner, and Swiss francs. 2 Albania, Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, conducted through agreement accounts denominated in U.S. dollars, while those with the People's Republic of China, the German Democratic Republic, and North Korea must be conducted through accounts denominated in Iran ian rials. Settlements with Mexico may optionally be made through a clearing account denominated in U.S. dollars. Settlements with the other member countries of the Asian Clearing Union (Bangladesh, Burma, India, Nepal, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka) in respect of current transactions (other than those relating to petroleum, natural gas, and their products) may be effected in the Asian monetary unit or in the currency of one of the countries that are parties to the individual contract con- cerned. Payments to and from Pakistan and Turkey relating to visible trade (excluding border trade, petro- leum and petroleum products, and defense materials) are settled over clearing accounts maintained by the respective central banks in U.S. dollars. Payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Settlements with other coun- tries normally are settled in the quoted currencies (see footnote 1). Nonresident Accounts Foreign nationals are permitted to maintain accounts freely, in rials as well as in foreign currencies, with authorized banks; rial accounts may be used both for payments in Iran and for conversion into foreign cur- rencies through the noncommercial market. Foreign nationals as well as Iranian physical or juridical persons may maintain sight or time deposits in foreign currencies in Iran; these accounts may be used for transfers abroad or for sales to authorized banks. Imports and Import Payments All imports into Iran are subject to control by the Government. The import policy is re-examined annu- ally, and a new Import List, effective for the next Iran ian year, is published by the Ministry of Commerce. The Import List distinguishes between "authorized," "unauthorized," and "prohibited" goods. "Authorized" imports, consisting of goods whose importation is con- sidered essential are divided into two main categories: (1) imports for which orders may be placed without prior approval by government agencies,3 and (2) imports that are subject to prior approval by government agen- cies (generally the Ministry of Commerce) before the import order is placed. "Unauthorized" imports are goods whose importation is not considered essential, including goods whose local production is sufficient to meet domestic demand. Commodities may be shifted German Democratic Republic, Hungary, North Korea, Poland, Romania, and U.S.S.R. 3 Exports and imports of goods that are not included in the bilateral export/import list for countries with which Iran has bilateral trade and payments agreements require special approval by the Ministry of Commerce. 211 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAN from the "authorized" list to the "unauthorized" list, and vice versa, as and when deemed necessary. For "pro- hibited" goods, no authorizations are given; these com- prise only a few items such as opium and firearms. Imports of "authorized" goods without payment through the official exchange market require prior approval by the Ministry of Commerce and the Central Bank. However, these imports are permitted without limitation, provided that registration is made before the order is placed. Such imports up to US$5,000 are per- mitted without prior registration but are subject to a registration fee; payments may be made either through the commercial or the noncommercial exchange market. In addition, permission is given for the following: imports destined for official charitable institutions or government organizations; machinery; spare parts and raw or intermediate materials for productive entities, up to US$1,000 a shipment; and all other imports of "authorized" goods up to US$300 a shipment. Im- ports on this basis are exempt f rom the import registra- tion deposit. Imports of gifts, whether of "author- ized" or "unauthorized" commodities, are restricted to R ls 20,000 a person a year. Specified commodities, such as cigarette paper, sugar, tobacco, and wheat are imported under state monopoly. Payments may be made either against bills for collec- tion or documentary letters of credit. Payments against bills for collection may be made without prior authoriza- tion for goods (ma in ly capital goods and raw materials) listed in the Schedule attached to Circular No. 116 of August 3, 1965 (Iran ian date 12 /5 /2524 ). Payments for imports of other goods may also be made against bills for collection without prior permission from the Central Bank, provided that the bills are settled w i th in n ine mon ths. All orders for imports must be registered w i th the Central Bank through an authorized bank; registration is effected against a pro forma invoice. Impor ts f r om Rhodesia are prohibited and special regulations apply to certain commodities when originat- ing in Hong Kong. At the time of registration of imports, a fee of 1 per cent of the amount of the import order, calculated on the basis of the official selling rate, is collected by author- ized banks. Imports brought in under the Law for the Attraction and Protection of Foreign Investment in Iran are exempt f rom the fee. For some goods, importers must lodge with the Central Bank, through an authorized bank, a deposit of 15 per cent of the c.i.f. value; this is done at the t ime of registration. Most food items and certain other commodities are exempt f rom the registra- t ion deposit. The deposit is re fundab le upon presentation of the customs clearance certificate after the respective goods have been cleared through customs, or if and when the order is canceled. The Central Bank may permit, when necessary, the shifting of imports from the category in wh ich an advance import deposit is required to the exempt category and vice versa. 212 Authorized banks make payments for permitted imports against the presentation of shipping documents. Approval of the shipping documents by the authorized banks represents approval of the foreign exchange transfer. Most imports are subject to commercial benefit taxes, which are either specific or ad valorem and are in addi- tion to any applicable customs duty. The ad valorem commercial benefit tax ranges f rom 1 per cent to 200 per cent. Monopoly taxes are included in the commercial benefit taxes. The authorities specify in the Import List the commercial benefit taxes for each year. These taxes are paid to the customs before customs clearance. The clearance through customs is authorized upon the presen- ta t ion of shipping documents endorsed by the authorized banks, specifying that payment has been made or will be made, and, when required, that the special import authorization has been received f rom government agen- cies prior to lading of goods in the country of origin. Payments for Invisibles Payments for all current invisibles may be made freely through the noncommercial market. In addition, there are certain allocations at the official rate for travel, study, and medical treatment abroad. Payments for invisibles related to imports are made on the same basis as payments for the f.o.b. value of those imports. Official exchange is granted to importers for insurance of imports against bills for collection; for imports covered by documentary letters of credit, insur- ance must be taken out in Iran. Official exchange is not granted to exporters for insurance of Iranian exports sold f.o.b. Official exchange also is not granted for the payment of other insurance premiums, although reinsur- ance premium payments are permitted. Authorized banks are permitted to remit interest on importers' sup- pliers' credit not exceeding 8.5 per cent; higher interest rates require special permission from the Central Bank. Foreign nationals working in Iran as technical assist- ants, whose employment has been recognized as neces- sary by the Government, may remit at the official rate about 50 per cent of their net salaries; any additional amounts may be remitted through the noncommercial market. The basic travel allowance for Iranian and for- eign nationals —the equivalent of R ls 50,000 a person a trip —may be made available by authorized banks at the official rate upon presentation of a valid passport and exit permit; each accompanying member of the passport holder's fam i ly is entitled to the same allowance, and there is no limit on the number of times a person may avail himself of this facility. Additional funds in respect of personal or business travel may be purchased freely in the noncommercial market. Banks may sell, at the official rate, up to the equivalent of Rls 200,000 a person to Iran ian nationals traveling or residing abroad, for medical treatment; additional foreign exchange at the official rate can be obtained against medical bills certified by an Iranian consulate abroad, and any fur ther amounts ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution may be purchased in the noncommercial market. Iranian physical and juridical persons may freely make remit- tances abroad from domestic current accounts in which they retain foreign exchange received from sources abroad, including export proceeds; balances in such accounts are freely transferable. Iranian nationals leaving the country are required to pay a travel tax of R ls 10,000 for each single-journey exit permit. The tax is imposed also for pilgrimage travel. For fam i ly members traveling on the same pass- port (w ife and children from 7 to 18 years of age), the rate is Rls 2,500 a person. Iran ians resident abroad and students studying abroad but visiting home temporarily are exempt from the tax. Travelers leaving Iran may take with them Rls 20,000 in Iranian banknotes. Travelers of foreign nationality may not export foreign currency in excess of the amount they imported less the amounts they have sold to author- ized banks, as recorded in their passports; they may, however, convert up to Rls 50,000 into other currencies at the official rate, upon presentation of their visaed passport, and may freely convert any additional amount in the noncommercial market. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports of some commodities require licenses. The commercial benefit tax and customs duty charged at the time of import of raw materials contained in manufactured goods for export may be returned to the exporter after the export has taken place. Certain minor exports are granted incentive payments by the Center for the Promotion of Exports. The Central Bank offers preferential discount facilities for export bills. The foreign currency proceeds of commodities other than petroleum, petroleum products, and na tural gas may be retained abroad; if they are repatriated, they may be kept as foreign currency deposits with domestic banks or sold to the bank ing system either in the official exchange market or in the noncommercial mar- ket. Authorized banks normally accept export proceeds only in U.S. dollars and other quoted currencies (see footnote 1), but they are permitted to accept other cur- rencies at their discretion. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles may be retained in a foreign currency account with an authorized bank, where they remain at the free disposal of the account holder. Travelers may freely bring in Rls 20,000 in Iran ian banknotes; higher amounts require the prior approval of the Central Bank. The repatriation of Iranian banknotes through the mail also requires Central Bank approval. Capital Iranian nationals may retain in domestic foreign currency accounts any capital receipts accruing in foreign IRAN exchange; transfers abroad from such accounts may be made freely, as may domestic transfers to other Iranian nationals. Private outward transfers of capital may be made through the noncommercial market, irrespective of their purpose. Retransfer abroad of foreign capital at the official selling rate is permitted with Central Bank approval, provided that the inflow had been specifically authorized by the Central Bank and was registered with the Central Bank. Authorized banks may freely accept inflows of foreign exchange from abroad (both deposits and borrowings) and may lend the foreign currency to residents or sell it in the noncommercial market for rials; the rial counterpart may be lent to residents, but such lending is subject to the applicable credit ceilings. At the end of 1977 the net short-term foreign liabilities of the commercial banks were subject to a reserve requirement of 30 per cent. In accordance with the Law for the Attraction and Protection of Foreign Investment in Iran (1955) and regu la t ions imp lemen t ing the law, foreign capital invested in approved development or productive activities in industry, mining, agriculture, or transport may be repa- triated, together with net profits (in accordance with Article 1 of the law and the provisions contained in the implementing regulations), in the form of foreign ex- change and /or goods. Transfers of exchange must be made at the official market selling rate prevailing on the date of transfer. However, the Central Bank has the option of buying the exchange or accepting it as a deposit to be converted into rials at a rate mutually agreed upon in a separate agreement, and this rate remains applicable to the funds when they are repatri- ated. Capital imported under this law in the form of foreign exchange must be in currencies acceptable to the Central Bank; the exchange is converted into rials at the buy ing rate prevailing on the date of application for conversion. All conversions must take place in the official market (capital, profits and dividends, amortiza- tion, and liquidation proceeds). Foreign participation in domestic enterprises is subject to ceilings. In invest- ment areas with special technological requirements, foreign participation is limited to 35 per cent. In sectors with lower technological requirements the ceiling is less than 35 per cent. However, in newly founded joint ownership companies, the foreign partner may apply for a higher share in ownership for up to five years, unless he immediately limits his share to the legal maximum. Gold No Iranian gold coins are legal tender.4 Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold and silver in any form in Iran, and there is a free mar- ket for both. Authorized banks may import and export gold and silver (bullion only, which for gold must be at least 995/1000 fine) with prior approval of the Central 4 Article 2 ( d) of the Monetary and Banking Act prohibits the use of gold coins as legal tender. 213 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAN Bank, against settlement through the official rate mar- ket, and sell these metals to any person in Iran. The import and export of gold for monetary purposes or for international settlements is reserved for the Central Bank, while the import for industrial and dental use is effected by professional organizations, at the official rate and subject to supervision by the Central Bank. The Central Bank accepts gold bullion on deposit from domestic banks as well as nonbank residents and issues gold certificates against such deposits. Travelers may freely import and export gold bullion up to 1 kilogram a person a trip; the Central Bank is empowered to approve larger quantities. The export of Iranian gold coins for numismatic purposes requires prior approval by the Central Bank. Imports of gold are free from customs duty but are subject to a commercial benefit tax of 5 per cent and an import registration fee of 1 per cent. Bank Melli Iran and other commercial banks give daily quotations for domestic sales. Changes during 1977 March 21. New trade regulations for 1977-78 abol- ished commercial benefit taxes on the import of laying hens, lead and zinc blocks for printing shops, and com- puters. Commercial benefit taxes were reduced on imports of cotton yarn (from Rls 50 to R ls25 a kilo- gram, certain cotton textiles ( f rom Rls90 to R ls70 a kilogram), space heaters ( f rom 40 per cent to 30 per cent of va lue ), coffee grinders ( f rom 40 per cent to 20 per cent of va lue ), meat grinders ( f rom 25 per cent to 20 per cent of va lue ), and nonelectric refrigerators (from 35 per cent to 15 per cent of value). The trade regulations also provided for an increase in the number of items for which the prior authorization of the Ministry of Commerce was required. Imports of iron and steel were to be effected through the Foreign Transactions Company, a subsidiary organization of the Ministry of Commerce. June 15. Not for Redistribution IRAQ (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Iraqi Dinar. The parity for the U.S. dollar, which is the intervention currency, is ID 1 = US$3.3778, and Iraq avails itself of wider margins. Transactions in the official market are carried out in any of the listed cur- rencies l or in Iraqi dinars through nonresident accounts in Iraq. The Central Bank of Iraq quotes official rates for the listed currencies, other than the U.S. dollar, for its transactions w i th authorized dealers only. Administration of Control Exchange control authority is vested in the Board of Adm in is tra t ion of the Central Bank; this a u t h o r i ty is executed through the Foreign Exchange Committee, which has delegated certain approval au thor i ty to the Department of Foreign Exchange of the Central Bank and to licensed dealers. Foreign exchange transactions must take place through a licensed dealer un less other- wise authorized by the Board of Adm in i s t ra t ion. All branches of the Raf ida in Bank, the sole commercial bank, are licensed dealers. Import policy is determined by the Council for the Regulation of Trade. A foreign exchange budget, including an import pro- gram, is established annually, and foreign exchange allo- cations under the import program are supervised by the Import Program Committee. Prescription of Currency Settlements with foreign countries normally must be made in any of the listed currencies. Transactions per- mitted in the listed currencies may a l terna t ive ly be settled in Iraqi dinars through nonresident accounts. Payments to and receipts from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The opening of a nonresident account requires the approval of the exchange control authorities. Nonresi- dent accounts are divided into ordinary nonres ident accounts, which arise from transactions in respect of current payments, and special nonresident accounts, which arise from transactions in respect of capital trans- fers. Iraqi nationals who have been work ing abroad for at least a year or who become residents a f ter hav ing been nonresidents may open accounts in foreign curren- cies with banks in Iraq and credit these with up to 50 per cent of their foreign savings. Balances in such accounts may be used for a variety of purposes, includ- ing imports for the holder's personal use, imports of certain capital goods, or meeting expenditures abroad 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish k rone r, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Ne ther lands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish k rone r, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. for travel, medical treatment, and study purposes; pay- ments from these accounts up to the equivalent of ID 500 a year do not require central bank approval. Imports and Import Payments Imports of many commodities, including ju te, sugar, tea, edible oil, certain medical supplies, machine tools, and automobiles, are a government monopoly. All pri- vate imports are subject to licenses except those for development projects benefiting f rom Law No. 157 of 1973; in principle these are issued in accordance w i th an annual import program, but some imports take place outside the program. Imports of all goods from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa and all imports from Hong Kong other than certain essential goods are prohibited. Imports of some commodities on a protection list are in principle prohibited from all sources. A tax of up to 15 per cent is levied on the amount of any supplementary import licenses above a private importer's annual quota. To finance the Export Subsidy Fund, a tax of 0.5 per cent is levied on imports of capi- tal goods and a tax of 0.75 per cent on imports of con- sumer goods. All imports subject to import duty are also subject to a customs surcharge of 15 per cent of the applicable customs duty. Licensed dealers make exchange available upon pre- sentation of the exchange control copy of the import license, except in some instances where reference has to be made to the Central Bank. Payments for Invisibles With the exception of certain payments f rom foreign currency accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above ), all payments for invisibles require permission. Exchange is usually granted for educational and medical expenses abroad, freight on exports effected on a c. & f. basis, insurance premiums, royalties, etc. Exchange is not granted to merchants for the insurance abroad of their imports or exports. Licensed dealers are permitted to transfer up to 50 per cent of annual income accrued to Arab and foreign nationals resident in Iraq, unless the par t icu lar contract extends this l im it to 75 per cent, subject to the approval of the Central Bank. There is a basic exchange allowance for tourist and business travel of ID 300 a trip for each person 12 years of age or over (ID 150 for children under 12 ), for trips of a month or less to Arab countries, socialist countries, Iran, and Turkey; for trips of over a month the allow- ance is increased to ID 400 (ID 200 for children under 12), and for subsequent trips in the same calendar year these allowances are reduced to 50 per cent of the basic allowance. For travel to other countries, the basic allow- ance is ID 500 a tr ip for each person 12 years of age or over for trips not exceeding one month, ID 600 for 215 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IRAQ longer trips, and 50 per cent of the basic allocation for subsequent trips in the same calendar year. Travelers may take out ID 5 in Iraqi currency notes, which is considered part of the basic travel allowance, and the balance of that allowance in travelers checks. Residents on a pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia are permitted to take out the equivalent of ID 200 in listed currencies or in Saudi Arabian riyals (ID 100 for persons over 5 and under 18). On leaving the country, Iraqi nationals must pay an exit tax of ID 20, except when traveling to Gu lf coun- tries or on an official mission. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica and exports of certain goods to all other countries are pro- hibited. The Council for the Regulation of Trade has authority to prohibit the export of any commodity when supply falls short of domestic demand. The export of certain items is reserved for the Marke t ing and Services Corporation. All other exports are licensed freely. Exporters must generally undertake to repatriate their foreign exchange proceeds through a licensed dealer and to surrender them w i th in six months after shipment. Proceeds from exports of dates taken by sailing boats to countries of the Gulf area (excluding I ran ), India, and Pakistan are exempt from these requirements when the amount does not exceed ID 600 in value or 25 tons in weight. Exports of certain goods are subsidized through an Export Subsidy Fund. The extent of financial sup- port may not exceed 25 per cent of the value of the goods, and commodities whose import content exceeds 40 per cent are ineligible. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts in excess of ID 50 f rom invisibles must be surrendered within three months to a licensed dealer. Travelers may bring in foreign exchange, including currency notes (other than Israel cu r rency ), in unlimited amounts, provided that the funds are declared on an exchange control fo rm; amounts not intended to be taken out of the coun try are exempt from declaration. Travelers may br ing in ID 25 in Iraqi notes. Capital Nonresidents may import capital freely, except from Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa, but they must deposit it with a licensed dealer; such deposits may be converted into local currency at the official rate, and repatriation to the country of origin is permitted. With m inor excep- tions, foreign companies starting operations in Iraq must use Iraqi capital to the extent of at least 51 per cent of their total capital. The transfer of profits (net of income tax) f rom foreign investments is limited to 10 per cent per ann^m of the paid-up capital for trad ing companies, to 20 per cent of the paid-up capital for industrial com- panies, and to 50 per cent of total profit for service 216 companies. These percentages are applicable for each year separately. They also apply to profits on capital resulting from the mandatory reinvestment of profits in excess of the transferable percentage. Arab capital invested in Iraq is exempt from these percentage limita- tions and interest payments are not subject to ceilings. All transfers of capital abroad by residents, whether Iraqis or foreigners, require exchange control approval; such transfers are severely restricted. Special facilities allow Arab investors to bring in convertible currency free ly through a licensed dealer for specified investment purposes; such capital and any net profits may be trans- ferred abroad in convertible currency. Similar facilities permit Iraqi nationals to bring in convertible currency through a licensed dealer and deposit the funds in for- eign currency accounts, balances in which are freely transferab le abroad. Under the Industrial Promotion Law (No. 22 of 1973 ), certain incentives and guarantees may be granted to approved investments of domestic or foreign capital in Iraq. Under the Iraqization Law of June 1961, all branches of foreign firms and all foreign-owned firms except banks 2 must have a majority of equity capital held by Iraqi nationals; this law does not cover export agencies and operations requ ir ing special skills. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in Iraq in any form other than gold bars. Imports and exports of gold in any form require the approval of the Central Bank. Since 1961, the Ra f ida in Bank has held a monopoly over the import and domestic distribution of gold needed for industrial purposes; it sells gold to registered goldsmiths only, under a quota system based on their past turnover of gold. Travelers may freely b r ing gold into Iraq, provided that it is declared at the point of en try on a foreign exchange form. Changes during 1977 April. To reduce congestion at customs warehouses, importers were given two months to register, clear, or store goods instead of four months as previously. For goods imported by air the comparable period was set at one month f rom the date of arrival. Goods not cleared within the prescribed period were liable to be sold by auction. April 5. The import program for 1977 came into effect. It made provision for imports valued at ID 1.756 billion, compared with an initial allocation of ID 1.382 billion for 1976. Not for Redistribution IRELAND (Position on January 2, 1978) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Irish Pound. Since June 23, 1972, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the Irish pound within prescribed margins, except for sterling. The Cen- tral Bank of Ireland quotes the pound sterling at par with the Irish pound, and transactions in sterling are free of commission. The Bank also quotes buy ing and selling rates for other currencies, which are approximately equal to the rates quoted against sterling in London. On December 31, 1977, the Central Bank's buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were US$1.9200 and US$1.9170, respectively, per Irish pound. Certain capi- tal transactions involving investment currency (see sec- tion on Capital, below) take place at d i f fe rent effective rates; on January 2, 1978 the investment currency pre- mium was 32.25 per cent (based on the spot exchange rate of US$1.9245 per Irish pound ). Forward transac- tions between authorized banks and their customers must have an underlying commercial transac t ion. On February 15, 1961, Ireland fo rma l ly accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Exchange control is operated by the Central Bank. Much of the authority for approving no rmal payments is delegated to commercial banks authorized for this pur- pose. Import licenses, where necessary, are issued by the Department of Indus t ry and Commerce if the goods are of an industrial nature, or by the Depar tment of Agri- culture and Fisheries if they are agricultural in character. Import licensing is not used for exchange control pur- poses. Import and export controls are administered by the Revenue Commissioners. Prescription of Currency Irish exchange control regulations distinguish between (1) the Scheduled Territories, consisting of Ire land, Northern Ireland, Great Britain, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, and Gibraltar, and (2) the rest of the world. How- ever, some Irish regu la t ions are in terms of Irish resi- dents (residents of I re land) only. I re land is a Scheduled Territory for purposes of the exchange control regula- t ions of the Un i ted K ingdom. Nonresident Accounts Accounts of persons resident in the Scheduled Terri- tories are treated as resident accounts. Accounts in Irish pounds or sterling of persons resident in countries out- side the Scheduled Territories are treated as nonresident accounts and, w i th the exception of Rhodes ian Accounts, are designated External Accounts. These may be credited w i th payments authorized for t rans fer to countries out- side the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia, w i th transfers f rom other External Accounts, with the pro- ceeds in Irish pounds or sterling of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency sold by a resident of a country outside the Scheduled Territories to an author- ized bank in Ireland, and with the proceeds of Irish cur- rency notes (the crediting of notes in denominations exceeding <£ Ir 10 requires specific app rova l) or sterling notes received f rom outside the Scheduled Territories. Balances on these accounts may be transferred free ly to other External Accounts, used for payments to residents of the Scheduled Territories, or converted through an authorized bank in Ireland in to any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. Au thor ized banks may operate foreign currency accounts in the name of non- residents in any foreign currency. Gold Residents may freely hold, buy, borrow, sell, or lend gold coins in Ireland. Dealings in gold bullion are restricted, and no dealings take place in Ireland. Although there are no import restrictions, residents require specific exchange control permission to purchase gold coins or bullion outside Ireland. Specific exchange control permission also is required for the export of gold coins and bullion outside Ireland. Specific permission to buy or export gold coins or bullion normally is given only for bona fide numismatic or industrial purposes, respectively. Residents of Ireland are not permitted to hold gold abroad. Changes during 1977 In addition to the changes listed below, certain changes in quantitative regulations were made in accord- ance with EEC decisions, regulations, and directives; most of these related to textiles. January 17. An 8 per cent devaluation of the Irish "green pound" became effective. February 15. Knitted car seat covers and knitted steering wheel covers became importable free of excise duty. These special charges were terminated on Ju ly 4 when the EEC system of monetary compensation amoun ts was extended to include these products. April 1. A further devaluation of 6.3 per cent of the Irish "green pound," became effective. June 23. The Central Bank informed licensed banks that 50 per cent of any net capital inflow to banks occur- ring after May 18, 1977 should be deposited with the Central Bank. Inflows of capital in connection with the financing of major industrial projects, whether public or private, would be exempted both from the 50 per cent deposit requirement and the primary and secondary liquidity ratio requirements. Inflows that might tempo- rarily arise from acceptances already arranged would also be exempt. July I. A final alignment of 20 per cent to the com- mon external ta r i ff of the EEC took place. Not for Redistribution ISRAEL (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.120370 gram of fine gold per Israel Pound. No announced margins are ma in ta ined for foreign currencies. Since October 28, 1977 authorized banks are permitted to deal in foreign exchange with residents and with their correspondents in fore ign mar- kets. The monetary authorities do not in principle inter- vene in the exchange market. At the end of the trading day the Bank of Israel publishes an average of the quota- tions of the day as a representative rate. On Decem- ber 31, 1977 the representative rate for the U.S. dollar was I£15.39 per US$1. Administration of Control Exchange control is the responsibility of the Controller of Foreign Exchange and is administered by the Depart- ment of Foreign Exchange Control of the Ministry of Finance, in cooperation with other government agencies and is carried out through authorized banks. Prescription of Currency Payments and receipts must be effected in the currency and manner prescribed by the exchange control authorities. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents' funds are held either in foreign cur- rency accounts or in local currency accounts. The open- ing of nonresident foreign currency accounts does not require prior approval. The holder may freely effect t rans fe rs f rom his fore ign currency account. He may also convert funds held in the account into local cur- rency at the market rate of exchange. There are no restrictions on the opening by a non- resident of a local currency account and on the local use of such fund s, including transfers between nonresidents. Nonresident holders of a local currency account may convert at the market rate of exchange up to US$3,000 for each visit to Israel, which may be transferred abroad, together with an amount of local currency not exceeding I <£ 1,000. Funds representing the sales proceeds of real estate and other investments may be transferred in their entirety if the original investment had been made with foreign currency or State of Israel Development Loan bonds. Resident Accounts in Foreign Currency Residents may maintain foreign currency deposits with authorized banks in Israel on either ( 1) PATAM accounts, which may be held by all recipients of foreign exchange or foreign currency acquired from a bank or (2) PAZAK or TAMAM accounts which may be held by recipients of restitution payments and certain disability pensions. PATAM accounts are demand or time deposit accounts in foreign currency placed with authorized banks, which 222 must redeposit, respectively, 90 per cent or 80 per cent, of the foreign currency funds with the Bank of Israel. Balances in these accounts are transferab le between resi- dents and may be used to pay for any bona fide inter- national current transaction. PAZAK or TAMAM accounts also are demand or time deposit accounts in convertible currencies with author- ized banks, which must redeposit all of these foreign currency funds with the Bank of Israel. Two thirds of convertible exchange receipts derived f rom personal resti- tu t ion payments and from pensions of disabled soldiers who served du r ing World War II may be credited to PAZAK accounts; the remaining one third may be credited to TAMAM accounts. Funds deposited in both types of accounts are free of taxation. The permitted uses of TAMAM accounts include the fo l low ing: ( 1) the purchase through the authorized bank holding the account of foreign securities denominated in convertible foreign currency that are registered on a stock exchange in specified foreign countries; (2) pay- ment of premiums on existing l ife insurance policies denominated in foreign currency; (3) payment of expenses in connection with travel and subsistence abroad in excess of the basic travel exchange allocation of the equivalent of US$3,000 a trip; and (4) payment of legal expenses resulting from restitution claims. As stated above, holders of TAMAM accounts may pur- chase abroad foreign securities denominated in con- vertible currency and registered on a stock exchange in specified foreign countries. Foreign securities thus ac- quired may be traded freely between residents. If the original buyer resells for foreign currency securities bought w i th TAMAM account funds, he may deposit the proceeds in a TAMAM account. Residents who are not holders of TAMAM accounts may deposit the foreign exchange proceeds from the sale of foreign securities in PATAM accounts. Imports and Import Payments A few imports are prohibited f rom all sources and all imports f rom Rhodesia are prohibited. Since October 28, 1977 almost all imports of goods are free of licensing and administrative or quantitative restrictions. A few imports remain on a Restricted List and are subject to approval. This list includes mainly some meat and dairy products, sugar, tobacco, chemicals, and pharmaceutical products. Oilseeds and edible fats are imported exclu- sively by or for account of the Government of Israel. Exchange to pay for authorized imports is granted auto- matically by the banks upon presentation of proof of the bona fide nature of the import transaction. A value- added tax is levied on almost all imported and domes- tically produced goods, other than capital goods and travel tickets. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Payments for Invisibles Exchange for payments abroad on account of invis- ibles is provided automatically upon proof of the na ture of the transaction. The exchange allowance for tourist travel is the equivalent of US$3,000 a traveler for each journey. No limits apply with respect to credit cards. Resident travelers may take out part or all of the travel allowance in Israel banknotes. Nonresident travelers leaving Israel are permitted to repurchase through authorized dealers fore ign currency up to US$3,000 and may, in addition, take out up to I <£ 1,000 in Israel bank- notes. Commercial banks are authorized to sell abroad unlimited amounts of Israel currency. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Most exports do not require licenses, although for some commodities export licensing is retained for the purpose of quality control. Export proceeds in foreign currencies must be surrendered or held in a PATAM account. Exporters may retain in a deposit account abroad an amount equivalent to 10 per cent of their tu rnover in the preceding year. For inputs directly imported by an exporter there is a system of rebates of customs duties, wharf charges, etc. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds f rom invisibles must, in general, be surrendered. Alternatively, they may be kept in foreign exchange on PATAM accounts. Any resident is free to accept specified convertible currencies f rom tourists in payment for services and commodities other than commercial exports, securities, and real estate. One third of the foreign exchange received by resi- dents of Israel as restitution payments and as pensions by disabled soldiers who served in World War II may be retained in TAMAM accounts, and the other two thirds may be held in PAZAK accounts. For 20 years af ter entering Israel, new immigrants are exempt f rom the requirement to surrender their foreign exchange to the Treasury, and they may hold these foreign currencies freely with authorized banks in Israel or with banks abroad. There are no limits to the amounts of Israel banknotes or foreign currency that may be brought in by travelers. Capital Foreign exchange representing incoming capital and belonging to a resident may be held in a PATAM account. Capital brought into Israel for the purpose of investment may, subject to approval, be granted preferential treat- ment in accordance with the Law for the Encouragement of Capital Investments of May 23, 1976, which, inter alia, permits a nonresident who has made an investment in foreign currency to transfer all his profits abroad in the same currency at the official rate. Current policy is to grant "approved" status only to enterprises in selected fields of production that fu lf i ll one of the fo l low ing con- ditions: (1) that they are established either in "priority ISRAEL areas" or in less developed areas; (2) that they are export oriented, i.e., either at least 50 per cent of output is exported or existing productive capacity is increased by at least 50 per cent while at least 50 per cent of the additional output is exported; (3) that, although for economic reasons the enterprise cannot be established in a priority area or in a less developed area, its produc- tion is geared to import-substitution; or (4) that the project aims at facilitating the absorption of immigrants. There is no difference between an "approved invest- ment" and any other investment made by a nonresident in foreign currency insofar as his right to transfer abroad the pr inc ipal or the interest or profits on his investment are concerned, and repayments and amortization of capi- tal may also be transferred. However, there are differ- ences as regards other benefits, such as income tax concessions and grants. Investments made by nonresidents prior to January 1, 1958 and investments made by nonresidents in foreign exchange after that date can be transferred abroad. Proceeds accruing f rom the repatriation or liquidation of foreign assets held by residents are treated in the same way as proceeds from invisibles. Any resident may retain real estate abroad, but not money, securities, or the income from such assets; in addition, new immigrants may retain their liquid assets for 20 years. Transfers abroad of a capital nature by residents other than new imm igran ts are generally not permitted. Owners of TAMAM and PATAM deposits are entitled to purchase foreign securities registered at stock exchanges in specified foreign countries. Foreign securities pur- chased by debit of a TAMAM or PATAM deposit can be sold and the proceeds may be recredited to the respective accounts. A general license allows nonresidents to purchase in Israel real estate, shares, and debentures. In order to repatriate the principal or profits of these investments, proof is required to be presented to an authorized dealer that they were made in foreign currency. Direct loans in any form to nonresidents are subject to licensing, but loans to a resident by a nonresident may be made freely if the funds are credited to a PATAM account. Gold Residents, including private persons, may freely hold gold in any form either in Israel or abroad. Gold can be bought or sold only from or to an authorized dealer. Other residents are forbidden to trade in gold or to take it out of Israel. Imports of gold are permissible only if an import license is obtained. Changes during 1977 January 2. A Cabinet decree eliminated the provision that limited to 8 per cent the cumulative amount of deprecia- tion of the exchange rate in each four-month period without Cabinet approval. August 10. Residents were allowed to keep up to one third of their foreign currency earnings in special accounts f rom which they may draw up to US$ 1,000 for each fam i ly member a year, to pay for travel and other expenses abroad, in addition to the regular travel allow- ance and without paying the 15 per cent surcharge. Businessmen were allowed to keep, in special accounts, all the money earned abroad and to draw up to US$1,500 for travel purposes. Previously, the authorization for the use of these accounts applied only to registered exporters. September 20. The buying rate for the Israel pound was changed to I ,£10.30 = US$1. The max imum rate of tax rebate for exports was increased to I<£3 .21 per US$1 of exports. These were the last of a series of changes effected since Janua ry 1, 1977, when the rates had been I£8.77 per US$1 and I<£2 .63 per US$1, respectively. October 28. A comprehensive reform of the exchange system was effected. The rate of the Israel pound ceased to be determined with respect to a composite of cur- rencies, and Israel introduced a floating exchange rate regime. Most foreign exchange restrictions were removed. The ma in changes were that the temporary surcharges of 15 per cent on imports and some invisible payments were abolished; the system of indirect tax rebates to exporters was terminated; the tax on foreign travel of I £.1,000 plus 15 per cent of the price of the ticket was abolished; the travel allowance for tourists was increased from US$700 to US$3,000 a person a trip; and the structure of foreign currency accounts was simplified. The new sys- tem distinguished only between nonresident and resident accounts, with two additional types of accounts reserved for recipients of restitution payments. No restrictions were placed on the use of balances in these accounts for the mak ing of payments for current transactions. Previ- ously, nonresident accounts in local currency could be only Registered Accounts, Tourist Demand Deposit Accounts, or a few other accounts holding funds derived from former investments eligible for transfer. Balances in resident accounts under the previous system could only be used to make authorized payments and were, as a rule, not transferable between residents. The licensing require- ment for imports of goods and invisibles was almost entirely eliminated. Import duties that were 12 per cent or more were reduced by 20 per cent. Restrictions on the import of Israel banknotes were lifted. Export of domestic currency by residents was limited to the maxi- mum amount permitted by the travel allowance, and up to I £1,000 in the case of nonresidents. No limits were placed on the sale abroad of Israel currency by com- mercial banks. November 6. The bilateral payments agreement with Portugal was terminated with effect from November 1. 224 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System On March 30, 1960 an initial par value for the Italian Lira was established of Lit 625 per US$1. On Decem- ber 20, 1971, a central rate of Lit 581.50 = US$1 was established. On February 13, 1973, however, Italy notified the Fund that for the time being the exchange rate for the lira for current transactions on the official market would not necessarily be confined within the announced limits either in respect of the U.S. dollar or in respect of EEC currencies. The rate for the U.S. dollar on December 30, 1977 was about Lit 871 per US$1. Different effective exchange rates arise from most out- ward transfers of resident-owned capital, for which a noninterest-bearing deposit of 25 per cent or 50 per cent must be lodged with the Bank of Italy. The monetary authorities do not in principle intervene in the forward exchange market; forward premiums and discounts are normally left to the interplay of market forces, although the Bank of Italy may from time to time offer the commercial banks certain swap facilities. Author- ized banks are allowed to engage in spot exchange trans- actions in any currency, and in forward exchange trans- actions up to 360 days in major convertible and externally convertible currencies,1 when dealing with other banks, or up to 180 days when dealing with nonbanks. The permissible amount of forward transactions against lire is subject to a limit on net transactions set ind iv idua l ly for each bank. Forward cover is freely permitted only for commercial transactions; cover in respect of financial transactions requires authorization. Public corporations which have been instructed to borrow abroad on behalf of the Bank of Italy receive fu ll forward cover for their debt service payments. Italy formally accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as f rom February 15, 1961. Administration of Control The exchange control system is operated by the I ta l ian Exchange Office (Uff ic io Italiano dei Cambi or UIC) on the basis of instructions issued by the Ministry of Foreign Trade. All sales and purchases of exchange must be effected through banks authorized for this purpose. Import and export licenses, when required, are issued by the Ministry of Finance at the request of the Ministry of Foreign Trade. Certain imports and exports require the prior visa of the National Foreign Trade Institute. Issues of securities by nonresidents require the prior approval of 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian (Luxembourg) francs, Canad ian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen, Ne the r- lands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. These currencies are referred to in the Italian regulations as convertible cur- rencies or conto valutario currencies. the Ministry of Foreign Trade and are subject in addition to the rules governing the issuing in Italy of Italian securi- ties. Payments to and from the Republic of San Marino or Vatican City are not subject to exchange control. Prescription of Currency Settlements with foreign countries must normally be made in convertible currencies or in lire on Foreign Accounts. For settlements with Egypt, there are special arrangements under a debt liquidation agreement. Capital Accounts may be credited with transfers f rom Foreign Accounts, from Special Accounts, and f rom other Capital Accounts, and w i th the proceeds f rom the liquidation of foreign investments in I ta ly not made und er the provisions of Law No. 211 or Law No. 43 (see be low). Capital Accounts may be debited for trans- fers to any other Capital Account or to Foreign Accounts, and for the purchase of investments not made under Law No. 43, including purchases of personal property or real estate in Italy. Imports and Import Payments Imports are governed by a Ministerial Decree of May 6, 1976. The import regulations vary with the country of origin. Countries are grouped in three ma jor areas: Zone A, which is subdivided into subzones A /1 (EEC countries, Guadeloupe, French Gu iana, Mar- tinique, and Reun ion ), A /2 (overseas countries and territories, EFTA countries, and other coun tr ies associ- ated with the EEC), and A /3 ( th ird coun t r ies ); Zone B (CMEA countries, Albania, People's Republic of China, North Korea, and Viet N am ); and Zone C ( J a p a n ). The import control procedures distinguish between goods that may be freely imported without quan t i ta t ive restric- tion and goods that require a special license. Import liberalization is virtually complete for subzones A /1 and A /2, while very few quantitative restrictions rema in for subzone A /3. Many types of goods from Zones B and C are heavily restricted. For imports f rom countries in Zone B, as well as Egypt and Yugoslavia, the country of origin must also be the country of shipment. All imports of Rhodesian origin are prohibited. Imports from non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to variable import levies that have replaced all previous barriers to imports. Common EEC regula- tions are also applied to imports from non-EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products. For imports not exceeding Lit 1 million in value, no exchange control form is required; for imports f rom Lit 1 million to Lit 2 million in value, a form completed by the importer is required; for imports over Lit 2 million in value, an import document completed by an author- ized bank is required. Where settlement takes place more than 360 days after importation, the importer must choose an authorized bank as his bank of domicile, through which he must carry out all payments operations. Deferred payments for imports are permitted freely if settlement is to take place, to the extent of at least 90 per cent, within 360 days af ter importation, and the balance within 24 months after importation; such pay- ments require the prior approval of the UIC if the settlement is to take place between 12 months and 24 months after importation. In all other cases, the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade is required; where, according to the contract, settlement is to take place more than 360 days after the date of importation, the approval of the UIC (in some cases the Ministry of 226 Foreign Trade) is required to make the payment prior to the due date set in the contract. Advance payments for imports require special approval when they are to take place more than 60 days before importation. Ad- vance paymen ts in excess of Lit 2 million must be made w i th foreign currency borrowed f rom authorized banks. When prepayments for imports exceed Lit 10 million, an advance deposit of 5 per cent is required. For all authorized imports, the authorized banks pro- vide exchange or permit payment in Italian lire to a Foreign Account, provided that appropriate payment terms are observed (see section on Capital, below). International postal money orders may be used for im- port payments, subject, in the case of payments to Swit- zerland, to a limit of Lit 30,000 for each remitter and fo re ign beneficiary. Payments for Invisibles In pr inc ip le, paymen ts abroad for invisibles require licenses issued by the exchange control authorities. How- ever, the authorized banks may sell fore ign exchange for p aym en ts for invisibles provided that the necessary docu- men ts are submitted, except for tourist travel and travel for business, study, or health reasons; their authority to sell exchange for fam i ly remittances is limited to Lit 35,000 a transfer. Exchange is granted freely for rem i t tances of earnings or investments. Residents may use in terna t ional postal money orders for payments, subject, in the case of payments to Switzerland, to a limit of Lit 30,000 for each remitter and foreign bene- ficiary. Certain transactions (but not the related payments) in respect of services are subject to approval by the Ministry of Foreign Trade or the Ministry of Industry. These transactions can be divided into two groups: ( 1) con- tracts which require a permit if they involve residents of specified coun t r ies4 and (2) contracts which require a permit regardless of the nationality of the nonresidents involved. The first group includes transactions giving rise to expenditures for chartering ships (excluding char- ters for a single t r ip ); repairs to ships which are not u rgent and not necessary for safety of operation; news agencies and newspaper correspondents ( f or amounts exceeding L i t5 million a month for the same payee); purchases of publication rights; in fo rma t ion agencies, etc. ( f or amoun ts exceeding Lit 5 million for each con- t rac t ); copyrights (for amounts exceeding Lit 5 million a year for each contract); services of professional workers and company managers ( for amounts exceeding L i t5 m i l l ion ); and services of entertainers and athletes ( f or amounts exceeding Lit 5 m i l l ion ). The second group includes transactions giving rise to expenditures for pro- duction abroad of films, utilization of films, scripts, synch ron iza t ion, etc.; collaboration in cinematography; 4 Albania, Bhutan, Bulgaria, Cambodia, People's Republic of China ( inc lud ing Mongolia), Cuba, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hunga ry, North Korea, Poland, Romania, U.S.S.R., Viet Nam, and ( for cha r te r ing ships only) Yugoslavia. ©International Monetary Fund. Residents traveling to foreign countries may obtain f rom the banks exchange equivalent to Lit 750,000 a person a year for tourism, business, medical treatment, and education (the corresponding amount for group travel also is Lit 750,000); the UIC grants foreign exchange above these allowances (except for t o u r i sm ), provided that it is satisfied that this is jus t if ied in the light of the duration and purpose of the trip. The amount that may be taken out in the form of foreign banknotes or travelers checks is Lit 100,000, while up to Lit 650,000 may be taken out in letters of credit, foreign payment orders, or non transferab le checks drawn on foreign banks. The limit on the amount of Italian bank- notes that can be taken out is Lit 100,000. To the extent that he refra ins f rom obtaining an allocation of foreign exchange, a resident traveler may take in addition a proportionate amount in Italian banknotes, up to Lit 100,000.6 Nonresident travelers may take out any amount in foreign banknotes that they have previously declared upon entry, subject to a l im it of the equivalent of Lit 200,000 a person if an oral declaration is made, as well as Lit 100,000 in I ta l ian banknotes. However, the export of Italian banknotes in denom ina t ions larger than Lit 50,000 is prohibited. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to any country of a few commodities in a special list (Tabella Esport) require export licenses. For exports not exceeding Lit 1 million in value, no exchange control form is required; for exports f rom Lit 1 million to Lit 2 million in value, a fo rm completed by the exporter is inu red; for exports exceeding Lit 2 million in value, an export document completed by an author- ized bank is required. If settlement takes places more than 360 days before exportation or more than 120 days after exportation, the exporter must effect the payments operations related to his export transactions through an authorized bank as his bank of domicile. Advance payments for exports may be received freely if exportation is to take place w i th in 360 days; in all other cases, such receipts require the prior approval of the UIC. Deferred payments for exports are permitted if settlement is to take place to the extent of at least 90 per cent within 120 days a f ter exportation, and the balance within 24 months after exportation. For settle- ments between 120 and 360 days a f ter exportation, the approval of the UIC is required.
