ITALY or shorter than five years, and on whether the transaction w i ll be covered by state insurance.7 Unless special approval is obtained for different terms of payment, 90 per cent of exchange receipts must be collected w i th in 120 days of shipment and offered for sale to an authorized bank within 7 days of receipt, while 10 per cent must be collected within 24 months of ship- ment. Proceeds in U.S. dollars, Canadian dollars, Japa- nese yen, and externally convertible European currencies may be retained by authorized banks on behalf of the recipients in Ordinary Foreign Currency Accounts (Conti Valutari Ordinari) for 7 days, during which period such balances may be used for permitted trans- actions or be sold to authorized banks; the banks are allowed to sell these currencies to residents for author- ized transactions or to negotiate them freely with the UIC or among themselves.8 Af ter expiration of the retention period, unused balances must be sold to the UIC at the lowest exchange rate quoted during the reten- tion period (these rates are determined daily on the basis of the average closing rates in Milan and Rome ). Export proceeds may also be received by international postal money order, up to Lit 600,000 for each payment, and in certain circumstances, in foreign banknotes that are accepted in the country of issue for credit to bank accounts, balances in which are convertible at official market rates. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from current invisibles are subject to the same collection, retention, and surrender requirements as receipts f rom exports. Shipping and insurance com- panies and travel and fo rwa rd ing agencies may keep Opera t ing Accounts (Conti Autorizzati) in U.S. dollars, Canad ian dollars, Japanese yen, and externally con- vertible European currencies; unutilized balances must be surrendered periodically. Residents may not retain any fore ign banknotes left over f rom trips abroad but must sell them to an authorized bank. Persons may br ing in any amount in foreign banknotes and Lit 100,000 in Italian banknotes, in denominations not larger than Lit 50,000. Capital Inward and outward movements of nonresident capi- tal are free. However, loans of any k ind from nonresi- dents to residents and from residents to nonresidents require specific authorization from the Ministry of the Treasury or the Ministry of Foreign Trade, respectively, except, with regard to OECD countries, long-term loans (other than loans from financial institutions to nonresi- den ts) for establishing or ma in ta in ing lasting economic relations and loans to relatives up to the third degree of 7 The SACE was established in Ju ly 1977 and commenced operations in October. 8 Foreign currency may be retained in Ordinary Foreign Currency Accounts until the seventh day after the date on which the individual exchange receipt concerned was credited to the account. 227 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ITALY relationship, and, with regard to EEC countries, short- term (up to one year and not exceeding Lit 250 million) and medium-term (up to five years and not exceeding Lit 250 million) financial loans (i.e., loans not connected with commercial operations or the performance of serv- ices); for none of these is any kind of authorization required. Repayment of such loans may be made freely. A deposit requirement applies to outward transfers of resident-owned capital for direct investments, portfolio investments, financial loans, purchases of real estate, and personal capital movements. The transferor must lodge a lira deposit equivalent to 50 per cent of the amount transferred (25 per cent for investment fund securities, but mutual funds investing entirely in Italian securities are exempt) in a noninterest-bearing account with the bank effecting the transfer. In addition, when foreign investments are transferred between residents against lire, the transferee is subject to the deposit requirement, regardless of the date when the investment was made. The deposits are released only when, and to the extent that, disinvestment operations occur, and their release requires the prior approval of the Bank of Italy. Purchases by residents of certain bonds issued by speci- fied EEC ins t i tu t ions are exempt. Outward direct invest- ment transactions have f rom time to t ime been given an ad hoc exemption. Foreign investment in Italy is, in principle, governed by Law No. 43 and subsequent implementing regula- tions. Foreign investments of any kind, including both direct and portfolio investment and the purchase of real estate, are permitted freely, and no restrictions are applied to their repatriation. Direct investment in OECD countries by physical or juridical persons (other than participation by a financial institution that has its main office in Italy in a foreign company not having the same corporate purpose) is permitted in any form and without any limit.9 Direct investment in other countries may be made only by juridical persons in firms that are in the same line of business as that of the Italian firm making the investment and under the supervision of the UIC; other types of direct investment in such countries require special authorization from the Ministry of Foreign Trade. The general license to make these investments also covers the reinvestment of earnings and the use for this purpose of the liquidation proceeds of previous investments (af ter crediting the proceeds of the disinvestment to bank accounts similar to those established for proceeds from exports and invisibles; see section on Proceeds from Invisibles, above). Residents are free to buy and sell, through the Bank of Italy or the authorized banks, any foreign securities issued or payable abroad and quoted on foreign stock exchanges, and to deal in such securities among them- 9 Financial investment, i.e., investment not intended to establish permanent relations, is not considered direct investment. The regula- tions governing direct investment are also not applicable to participa- tions in "holdings" abroad of any kind. 228 selves against payment in lire. Such foreign securities, except securities of Lit 100,000 or less, have to be deposited with an Italian bank or with a bank abroad for account of an Italian bank. The purchase by resi- dents of shares of foreign financial institutions of any kind (including mutual f u n d s ), as well as convertible bonds issued by such institutions, requires prior approval by the UIC. In practice, however, a resident is able to purchase freely shares of foreign funds that have received authorization from the Ministry of Foreign Trade to sell their shares in Italy, since that authorization is in fact valid also for the individual resident subscriber. Such authorization is given only to funds meeting certain requirements, including the investment of at least 50 per cent of their portfolio in Italian securities and the estab- lishment of a branch office in Italy. Residents do not require authorization to purchase real estate in EEC countries. All issues of securities by nonresidents on the Italian capital market require the prior approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade, and are subject to the rules governing the issue of domestic securities. These rules include the prior approval of the Bank of Italy, and, for issues above Lit 500 million, that of the Ministry of the Treasury, the Ministry of Industry, and the Interministerial Credit Committee. Issues are normally restricted to interna- tional ins t i tu t ions. Transfers in connection with donations, inheritances, and dowries may be made freely. The transfer of prop- erty of residents leaving Italy permanently is allowed in two stages: the equivalent of Lit 5 million a person is allowed upon presentation of specified documents to an authorized bank at the time of leaving Italy, and the remainder is subject to examination of the documents by the UIC, when residence has been established abroad. In relations with EEC countries, the reciprocal grant- ing of credits for commercial transactions or the per- formance of services, with a ma tur i ty longer than the time limits that banks are authorized to approve and up to five years, may be effected after examination of the documents by the UIC. This applies also in relations with Austria, Finland, Norway, Sweden, and Switzerland. Loans and credits (the latter only beyond a certain duration, generally 180-360 days) not connected with commercial transactions or with the performance of services require the approval of the Ministry of Foreign Trade and are severely restricted. However, financial loans may be granted to or by residents of EEC coun- tries as indicated above. The export of Italian and foreign securities is per- mitted only when they are owned by nonresidents and have been purchased against U.S. dollars, Canadian dol- lars, Japanese yen, or externally convertible European currencies, or against funds on a Foreign Account or a Capital Account. The net external position of the banks is subject to control by the UIC. This control encompasses (1) the ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution spot position vis-a-vis nonresidents in foreign currencies and lire together; and (2) the overall position, spot and forward combined, in all foreign currencies; a balanced foreign currency position on a daily basis is required separately in (a) U.S. dollars, (b) EEC currencies, and (c) all other conto valutario currencies combined. Authorized banks are not subject to any ceiling on their net foreign liability position but are prohibited from maintaining a net foreign asset position; in addition, outstanding net forward transactions against lire are subject to a ceiling set individually for each bank. Gold Residents may freely hold and negotiate gold in any form in Italy, with the exception of unrefined gold imported under ministerial license for industrial pur- poses. The monetary authorities may freely acquire unrefined gold abroad. Agent banks may acquire unre- fined gold abroad upon submission of licenses issued by the Ministry of Foreign Trade to Italian firms for indus- trial use. Exports of wrought and semimanufactured gold, other than jewelry, are subject to licensing. Imports of unrefined gold are in principle subject to value-added tax but at the end of 1977 the rate of tax was zero per cent. Imports of gold coins for numismatic purposes are subject to value-added tax at 18 per cent. Changes during 1977 January 3. The Section replaced the National Insurance Institute ( INA) and was entitled to authorize export credits for periods of one to five years. 229 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IVORY COAST (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange System No par value for the currency of Ivory Coast has been established with the Fund. The unit of currency is the CFA Franc,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French franc. Exchange transactions in French francs, the intervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place on the basis of CFAF 1 = F 0.02; the BCEAO levies a com- mission of 0.10 per mill for transfers f rom countries outside the West African Monetary Union and one of 2.50 per mill for transfers to such countries; commission is not charged on transfers within the Union. Exchange rates for foreign currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French f ranc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West African Monetary Union, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. Administration of Control With the exception of measures relating to gold, Ivory Coast's exchange controls do not apply in financial relations with (1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Operations Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Cen- tral African Empire, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Mali, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Ivory Coast itself, are considered foreign countries. Exchange control is administered by the Directorate of Finance in the Ministry of Economy, Finance, and Planning, which also supervises borrowing abroad, the issuing, advertising, or offering for sale of foreign securi- ties in Ivory Coast, foreign inward direct investment, and all outward investment in foreign countries. The BCEAO is authorized to collect any information neces- sary to compile the balance of payments statistics, either direct or through the intermediary of banks, other finan- cial institutions, the Postal Administration, and notaries public. All exchange transactions relating to foreign countries must be effected through authorized banks or the Postal Administration. Import and export licenses are issued by the Directorate of External Trade in the Ministry of Commerce. Prescription of Currency Ivory Coast is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury; settle- i rThe CFA f ranc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de TAfrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 230 ments with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any other Operations Account country. Settlements with The Gambia, Ghana, Liberia, Nigeria, and Sierra Leone normally are made through the West African Clearing House. Settlements with all other countries are usually made through correspondent banks in France in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs through Foreign Accounts in Francs. All settlements with Rhodesia are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations pertaining to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO banknotes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Abidjan by authorized banks' foreign correspondents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that maintains an Operations Account with the French Treasury, is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports f rom Portugal (with the exception of port w ines ), Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Imports f rom the People's Republic of China and the U.S.S.R. are made on a barter basis or as compensation transactions. Certain imports are prohibited (e.g., a spe- cified type of coffee-husking machine and wheat flour) or subject to import license or prior authorization (e.g., paints, matches, and detergents). Imports of rice are related to domestic production so that imports are made complementary to purchases of domestically produced rice. All other imports may be made freely f rom any country, subject pnly to the submission of a declaration of in tent to import. With minor exceptions, imports by sea or air, when valued at CFAF 500,000 or more, are subject to preshipment inspection in order to control their price, quan t i ty, and quality. All import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000; transactions of lower value must be domiciled if a financial transaction is to be undertaken before customs clearance. The import licenses or import attestations entitle importers to pur- chase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than one month before shipment if a documentary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodi- ties have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles Payments to Rhodesia are prohibited. Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution the Operations Account countries are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to approval. Pay- ments for invisibles related to trade are permitted freely when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require authorization. Transfers of income accruing to nonresidents in the form of profits, dividends, and royalties are also permitted freely when the basic transaction has been approved. Any resident may make payments abroad freely at any time through an author- ized bank, up to the equivalent of CFAF 50,000 w i th- out submitting any documentation. Residents traveling to countries other than France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries may obtain an exchange allocation for tourism of an amount equivalent to CFAF 175,000 a person a year (CFAF 87,500 for children under t e n ); any foreign exchange remaining in excess of CFAF 5,000 after return to Ivory Coast must be surrendered. The transfer of the full basic salary of a foreigner working in Ivory Coast is permitted upon presentation of the appropriate pay voucher, provided that the transfer takes place within three months of the pay period. Resident and nonresident travelers to foreign countries may take out BCEAO banknotes up to CFAF 25,000. Travelers to other French Franc Area countries may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes, but if traveling to a country that is not a member of the West Afr ican Mone- tary Union, the amount taken out must be declared to the customs if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers to foreign countries may freely take out foreign banknotes and coins up to the equivalent of CFAF 175,000, as well as any travelers checks, etc., issued abroad. Subject to documentation, they may also take out any amount of travelers checks, etc., in foreign currency established in their name after conversion of foreign currency into CFA francs or drawn against a Foreign Account in Francs or a foreign currency in Ivory Coast. Nonresidents who have made a currency declaration upon entry or are able to show the proper banking notices may take out higher amounts. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia and South Africa are pro- hibited. Most exports are free of license and require a declaration only. Exports of processed and unprocessed agricultural commodities, however, require the visa of the Directorate of External Trade. The due date for pay- ments in respect of exports to foreign countries must be not later than 180 days after the arrival of the goods at their destination. The proceeds must be collected and, if the contract is invoiced in a currency other than that of a country of the French Franc Area, surrendered on the exchange market, within two months of the due date. All export transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled w i th an authorized bank when valued at CFAF 500,000 or more. IVORY COAST Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from transactions in invisibles with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries may be retained. All amounts due from resi- dents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries from foreign assets must be collected and surrendered within two months of the due date or the date of receipt. Resident and non- resident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue maintaining an Operations Account, as well as any amount of foreign banknotes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area; residents bringing in foreign banknotes or other foreign means of payment must sell any amount in excess of CFAF 5,000 to an authorized bank within eight days and must make a declaration to the customs upon entry. Capital All capital movements between Ivory Coast and Rho- desia are prohibited. Capital movements between Ivory Coast and France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries are free of exchange con- trol; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval, but capital receipts from such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over foreign inward direct investment, over all outward investment in foreign coun- tries, and over the issuing, advertising, or offer ing for sale of foreign securities in Ivory Coast. Such operations require prior authorization by the Minister of Economy, Finance, and Planning as do issues by Ivory Coast com- panies. Exempt from authorization, however, are opera- tions in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee f rom the Ivory Coast Government and (2) shares similar to securities whose issue, offering, or sale in Ivory Coast has previously been authorized. With the exception of controls relating to foreign securities, these measures do not apply to relations with France (as defined above), Monaco, member countries of the West African Mone- tary Union, and the Operations Account countries. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and insti- tutions, and over publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special controls also apply to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All investments abroad by residents of Ivory Coast require prior authorization by the Minister of Economy, 231 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution IVORY COAST Finance, and Planning.2 Foreign direct investments in Ivory Coast,3 must be declared to the Minister of Econ- omy, Finance, and Planning before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postpone- ment of the projects. The liquidation of investments, whether direct investments or not, in Ivory Coast or abroad must similarly be declared in advance. Both the making and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Ivory Coast investments abroad or foreign invest- ments in Ivory Coast, must be reported within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enter- prise. Mere participation is not considered as direct investment, provided that it does not exceed 20 per cent of the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Economy, Finance, and Planning. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct invest- ment, which are subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance transactions abroad, to finance imports into or exports from Ivory Coast, or, by approved international trading houses, to finance international merchanting transac- tions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; and (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount outstanding of these loans, including the 8 Including those made through the intermediary of foreign com- panies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Ivory Coast and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of com- panies in Ivory Coast. 3 Including those made by companies in Ivory Coast that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Ivory Coast of foreign companies. new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 50 million for any one borrower, and provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate. The repay- ment of loans constituting a direct investment is subject to the formalities prescribed for the liquidation of direct investments. The repayment of other loans requires authorization only if the loan itself was subject to prior approval. Lending abroad is subject to exchange control authorization. Law No. 59-134 of September 3, 1959 provides tax and customs duty benefits and other special privileges for new enterprises recognized as having priority status. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Ivory Coast. Imports and exports of gold from or to any other country require prior authorization by the Minister of Economy, Finance, and Planning, which is rarely granted. Exempt from this requirement are (1) imports and exports by the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufac- tured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold articles up to a weight of 250 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports and exports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Changes during 1977 January 1. In the 1977 Finance Law (Lot de Finances de 1977), the duty rates charged on imports of groups and classes of commodities formerly subject to the 20.5 per cent and the 18.5 per cent rates were adjusted to 22 per cent and 10 per cent, respectively. The standard rate of value-added tax was raised to 18 per cent. 232 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System 1 The par value is 0.900364 gram of fine gold per Jamaica Dollar. On February 20, 1973, a central rate of J$l = US$1.10 was established, corresponding at the time to J$1.09668 = SDR 1 or 0.810328 gram of fine gold per Jamaica dollar. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar and Jamaica avails itself of wider mar- gins. With effect from April 27, 1977 the exchange market was split into a "basic" market, where essential imports and transactions of the Government and most transactions of the bauxite sector are conducted at the rate of J$l = US$1.10, and a "special" market, where all other transactions are conducted at a depreciated rate. The depreciated rate has been set at J$l = US$0.78125 since October 21, 1977.2 The Bank of Jamaica's dealings against Jamaica dol- lars are confined to transactions in Canadian dollars, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars, to purchases of Cana- dian, U.K., and U.S. banknotes, and to purchases of certain Caribbean and European banknotes (see below). It deals in other currencies only against sterling and U.S. dollars. The Bank buys and sells U.S. dollars at par, plus a commission of 0.1875 per cent on the selling side. Exchange rates for currencies other than the U.S. dollar are based on the Bank of Jamaica's buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar and the rates against the U.S. dollar for the currencies concerned in international markets. The Bank of Jamaica sets daily official buying and selling rates for dealing with the banks in sterling and Canadian dollars on the basis of the previous day's closing quotations in New York. On the basis of these rates, the Bank also fixes daily rates at which commer- cial banks must deal with their customers in transactions involving Jamaica dollars against Canadian dollars, pounds sterling, or U.S. dollars. The Bank of Jamaica is authorized by law to fix its buying and selling rates of exchange. For currencies other than currencies of member countries of the Carib- bean Common Market (CARicoM)3 and for spot dealings with commercial banks, the Bank of Jamaica charges no commission on purchases but 0.1875 per cent on sales. For CARICOM currencies the rates for spot dealings with commercial banks reflect a commission charge of 0.125 per cent on both purchases and sales. The commercial banks apply a commission charge (prem ium) of 0.375 per cent on sales of non-CARicoM currencies and a commission charge (discount) of 0.125 per cent on purchases of these currencies. For CARICOM currencies, the commercial banks apply a commission charge of 0.25 per cent on both sales and purchases. Under an arrangement with the Central Banks of Trinidad and Tobago and Barbados and with the East Caribbean Currency Authority, the Bank of Jamaica purchases banknotes issued by these monetary authorities and repatriates them against settlements made through the CARICOM multilateral clearing facility. Jamaica formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 22, 1963. Administration of Control The Bank of Jamaica administers exchange control on behalf of the Minister of Finance, subject to certain limitations in respect of which the approval of the Minister is required. The commercial banks are desig- nated as authorized dealers. Except for the allowance for tourist travel, for which the commercial banks have authority to provide foreign exchange, and transfers from External Accounts, foreign exchange payments require the specific approval of the Bank of Jamaica. Commercial banks act only as agents of the Bank of Jamaica; they sell all foreign exchange receipts to the Bank of Jamaica and in turn purchase foreign exchange from the Bank of Jamaica against documentation. Im- port licenses are issued by the Trade Administrator, who is responsible to the Minister of Marketing and Commerce. Prescription of Currency Payments to all countries may be made by crediting Jamaica dollars to an External Account or in any foreign currency.4 Receipts from all countries must be received by debit of an External Account or in any foreign cur- rency. Special regulations apply to settlements with Rhodesia, and all payments to Rhodesia require specific authorization. Nonresident Accounts The commercial banks are empowered to open External Accounts in Jamaica dollars for nonresidents except residents of Rhodesia, provided that no credit of Jamaica dollars is made to the accounts without the specific approval of the Bank of Jamaica. The funds on these accounts may be transferred freely between non- residents. External Accounts may be credited with pay- ments by residents of Jamaica approved by the exchange control authorities, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from the sale to an * All currencies other than the Jamaica dollar are considered foreign currencies. All foreign currencies have been designated as specified currencies. 233 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA authorized dealer of gold or foreign currencies. They may be debited for payments to residents of Jamaica, for transfers to other External Accounts, and for the purchase of foreign currencies. Accounts which are credited with funds that may not be placed at the free disposal of nonresidents of Jamaica (including the proceeds from the sale of undeveloped land) are designated Blocked Accounts. Blocked funds may be used without limitation by nonresidents for local expenditure while they are in Jamaica and for invest- ment in Jamaica dollar securities and /or local mort- gages. Applications for the release of funds in Blocked Accounts in excess of J$ 1,000 a calendar year, for use in Jamaica by the nonresident owner must be referred to the Bank of Jamaica. Imports and Import Payments A small number of goods may be imported freely from v ir tua l ly'a ll sources under an open general license.5 All other imports require specific licenses, irrespective of origin. For some goods, licenses are not norma l ly issued unless they originate in member countries of the CARicoM.6 Imports are subject, in principle, to a global annual ceiling. Imports originating in Rhodesia or South Africa are prohibited, and all imports originating in the People's Republic of China or Cuba require indi- vidual import licenses. Certain food items may be imported only by a public sector agency, the Jamaica Nutrition Holdings Limited. Payments for imports are subject to prior registration with the Bank of Jamaica and all payments for imports are subject to the licensing requirements, if any, being met; the importer must present a copy of the settlement invoice or other evidence of purchase and value, together with documentary evidence that the goods either have been shipped or are about to be shipped, or that he is under contract to make prepayment up to six months prior to shipment; specific exchange control approval is required for advance payments. Certain goods are subject to a consumption tax, whether they are imported or manufac tured domestically. Where such goods are imported, the tax is collected at the port of entry and is calculated on the sum of the value accepted for customs and the customs duty. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles require the approval of the exchange control authorities. Foreign exchange is not, as a rule, made available for remittances of income from emigrants' property in Jamaica, remittances for family maintenance, and cash gifts. In the case of transfers from emigrants' income and payments for family maintenance, limited exceptions may be approved by the Minister of Finance on humanitarian grounds. In 5 For these goods, the open general license applies to all countries except Rhodesia and South Africa. Goods imported under the license must be consigned from one of the permitted countries and must also originate in a permitted country. 6 For import licensing purposes, the Bahamas are also trea ted as a CARICOM country. 234 accordance with the present wage and salary guidelines, payments of profits and dividends are permitted subject to a limit of 7 per cent of the net worth of the company, whether foreign or domestic, or a branch operating in Jamaica. A basic exchange allowance of J$72 a person for each 12-month period for foreign travel other than for busi- ness or professional reasons is made available to residents by authorized dealers. The sale of foreign exchange for travel for business and professional reasons is subject to the specific approval of the Bank of Jamaica and to daily limits of J$85 a day for the United States and J$105 a day for Europe. The number of days for which the approval is granted is determined on the merits of each case. Expenses for hotel accommodation, meals en route, etc., that are settled in Jamaica in do- mestic currency must be deducted from the travel allocation. Non-Jamaicans working in Jamaica under a work permit are allowed to remit abroad 30 per cent only of their gross salary. Remittances in respect of interest on private non- guaranteed debt and certain insurance-related trans- actions are approved for transfer on a delayed basis. Payment of interest on private nonguaranteed debt is approved on a three-month lag basis. Payments and transfers for certain transactions related to insurance (claims payable for risks written abroad, life insurance premiums, the ma tur i ty proceeds of policies held by nonresidents, and deposit premiums on reinsurance treaties) are approved for remittance without delay. For other transactions related to insurance, payments and t rans fe rs are subject to specified delays ranging f rom a m in imum of 6 months for facultative reinsurance prem iums up to a max imum of 9 months for some rein- surance balances and prem ium adjustments. Payments for group insurance (other than l i fe insurance) con- nected with a resident's membership in a professional association are subject to the approval of the Bank of Jamaica. Foreign exchange was not, as a rule, made available from December 22, 1976, when the exchange market was closed, until the end of June 1977 for payments and transfers in respect of royalties, trademarks, commis- sions and fees, and head office and management ex- penses. Remittance schedules were subsequently estab- lished for those payments and transfers that fell due before the end of June 1977. Payments and transfers that fell due a f ter June 30, 1977 are approved for remittance without undue delay. Under the present exchange control regulations, the compulsory waiting periods and nonapproval of pay- ments falling due have resulted in an accumulation of payments arrears. In addition, since the beginning of June 1977, further arrears have accumulated at times in respect of payments and transfers for imports and other transactions approvable under the exchange control regulations. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Residents going abroad may take with them Jamaica banknotes not exceeding J$20 and other banknotes not exceeding the equivalent of J$50. Bona fide requests for additional amounts are approved by the Bank of Jamaica. Nonresidents may take out the foreign currency notes they brought in. Exports and Export Proceeds All goods valued at not more than J$200 (f.o.b.) may be freely exported by post or air express to any country not on the prohibited list.7 Where the value exceeds J$200, the goods may still be exported to all countries except those on the prohibited list, but a specific license is required for the export of certain agricultural products, ammunition, explosives, firearms, antique furn i ture, ready-made garments, gold bullion, mineral and metal ores, and antique paintings. Exporters are required to surrender their exchange proceeds to authorized dealers within three months from the date of shipment. How- ever, with the approval of the exchange control authori- ties, certain exporters may retain an agreed portion of their settlement of overseas commitments, as may be necessary for their operations; such retained export pro- ceeds must not be sold to other nonbank residents. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in foreign currencies must be sold to an authorized dealer. Residents returning to Jamaica may bring in Jamaica banknotes up to J$20 a traveler, provided that this amount was declared on leaving the country, and all travelers may bring in any amount of foreign banknotes; resident travelers are required to sell their holdings of foreign currencies to an authorized dealer upon return. Tourists are required to settle their hotel bills in foreign currencies unless they can prove that they had purchased an equivalent amount of Jamaica dollars from an authorized bank in Jamaica. Capital Outflows of resident-owned capital are restricted, irrespective of their destination. Investments abroad by residents and the purchase of local assets by residents from nonresidents require the approval of the exchange control authorities and are not approved unless they result in tangible benefits for Jamaica. Foreign exchange is not made available to residents to make cash gifts to nonresidents. With the exception of certain types of investment in real estate, all approved direct investments in Jamaica by nonresidents are granted "approved status," under which the investor is given written assurance that he will be able to repatriate at any time his original investment plus any capital gain. In order to obtain approved status, the investor must apply to the Bank of Jamaica. 7 The list comprises Albania, Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Ge rman Democratic Republic, Hungary, Poland, Rhodesia, Romania, South Africa, and U.S.S.R. Exports to these countries require specific licenses. In practice, no licenses are issued for exports to South Africa, and exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. JAMAICA Nonresidents are normally not permitted to take up security in respect of loans made to Jamaican com- panies owned or controlled by them. Domestic bank credit to nonresidents and to nonresident-controlled companies is subject to selective credit controls; for this purpose, firms are considered to be nonresident- controlled when the controlling interest is held bene- ficially, either directly or indirectly, by persons resident outside the CARICOM area. Such lending is subject to approval by the Bank of Jamaica. In general, foreign nonresidents are not permitted to raise local mortgages. However, nonresidents working in Jamaica under a work permit may acquire a house to live in, with the permissible amount of mortgage restricted to 50 per cent. Foreign nonresident owners of land in Jamaica, when selling to residents, are allowed to remit from Jamaica, in the first instance, the amount they paid originally from funds brought into Jamaica; the balance of the sale price can be remitted annually in ten equal installments, subject to a minimum remittance in any one year of J$ 10,000, except where the owner had received a previous undertaking that the investment in land carried "approved status." Foreign nonresident owners of houses built on residential lots are treated similarly, provided that the nonresident seller can satisfy the Bank of Jamaica as to the amount spent in Jamaica in acquiring the lot and constructing the building. Except for special cases, which may be approved by the Minister of Finance on humanitarian grounds, no foreign exchange is made available for remittances of capital or income to Jamaican nationals who have emigrated abroad and to beneficiaries under wills and intestacies. A maximum of J$4,000 a year may be allowed by the Minister of Finance on humanitarian grounds. Under the exchange control guidelines of January 19, 1977, payments and transfers in respect of the amortiza- tion of private nonguaranteed debt are approved for remittance in the calendar quarter following the quarter in which they fall due. However, payments and transfers for this purpose have not normally been approved. Gold Two commemorative gold coins of J$20 and J$100 are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Jamaica for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Finance; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. All commercial imports of jewelry are prohibited. 235 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAMAICA Changes during 1977 January 1. A new system specifying eligible process- ing or manufacturing activities replaced the 50 per cent value-added criterion in the determination of eligibility for duty-free treatment under the CARICOM agreement. January 5. It was announced that the import ceiling for 1977 was J$600 million. January 6. The foreign exchange market was reopened on a limited basis for outstanding import payments, essential business and official travel, other "essential" travel subject to a limit of J$150 a person, and service payments of public sector debt and private debt with a public guarantee and of all debt to governments and official entities of the CARICOM countries. In addition, commercial banks were authorized to sell foreign exchange for maintenance and education allowances already approved and for emergency medical treatment. The foreign exchange market remained closed for all other transactions. January 19. New exchange control guidelines came into force, which provided, inter alia, for the following: (1) The Bank of Jamaica became the sole agency for buying and selling foreign exchange. Commercial banks would act only as agents of the Bank of Jamaica; they would sell all foreign exchange to the Bank of Jamaica and in turn would purchase foreign exchange from the Bank of Jamaica against documentation. (2) Foreign exchange would not be sold for capital and income remittances to emigrants, for students seeking educa- tion other than higher professional and technical edu- cation certified as such by the Ministry of Education, for beneficiaries of wills, for gifts, and, from May 1, for the maintenance of dependents abroad. Limited exceptions could be made by the Minister of Finance on humanitarian grounds. (3) Payments for royalties, trademarks, commissions and fees, insurance and rein- surance premiums, and head office and management expenses were to be blocked for the period to June 30, when new guidelines were to come into effect. (4) Divi- dends or profits payable to nonresident shareholders or parent companies of branches operating in Jamaica would be subject to the general guidelines limiting divi- dends and profits to 7 per cent of the net worth of a company. (5) Remittances of principal and interest on private nonguaranteed foreign indebtedness would nor- mally be allowed in the quarter following the quarter in which these payments accrue. (6) With effect from April 1, a person with a work permit would be allowed to remit abroad only 20 per cent of his gross salary. (7) Residents were required to obtain permission from the exchange control authorities before purchasing local assets from nonresidents. (8) Exchange would be granted for "essential" business travel and for travel on behalf of public entities, the latter being subject to the approval of the Ministry of Finance. Allowances for tourist travel would be limited to J$50 a person. February 9. Notice to Importers No. 2977 added 128 items to the list of banned imports. The new items added to the list included automobiles and a wide range of foodstuffs and consumer goods. February 10. Notice to Importers No. 2975 removed 9 categories of goods from the list of items not requiring a specific license for their importation into Jamaica. The 19 categories of goods that might be imported without a specific license were listed in Notice to Importers No. 2976. February 17. New guidelines came into effect for the remittance of payments and transfers for transactions related to insurance. Certain specified payments and transfers would be approved for remittance without undue delay, while other payments would be approved for remittance on the basis of specified delays. April 27. The exchange market was split into a "basic" market, where essential imports and transactions of the Government and most transactions of the bauxite sector were to be conducted at the rate of J$l = US$1.10, and a "special" market, where all other trans- actions were to be conducted at a depreciated rate of J$l = US$0.80. The allowance for tourists was raised from J$50 a year to J$70 a year; for business travel the allocations of J$60 a day to the United States and J$75 a day for Europe were raised to J$82.50 and J$103, respectively, to maintain their foreign currency value. May 1. The limit on salary remittances by persons holding work permits was raised from 20 per cent to 30 per cent of their gross annual salary to maintain unchanged the foreign currency value of remittances following the change in the exchange rate applicable to such remittances. August 1. Payment for imports of crude petroleum was transferred from the "basic" to the "special" market. October 21. The "special" exchange rate was changed from J$l = US$0.80 to J$l = US$0.78125. The allowance for tourist travel was raised to J$72 a year; the business travel allowances were increased to J$85 a day for the United States and J$105 a day for Europe. 236 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAPAN (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.00246853 gram of fine gold per Japanese Yen. A central rate of ¥ 308.00 = US$1 has been established, and Japan avails itself of wider mar- gins. Since February 14, 1973, the authorities have not maintained the exchange rate of the yen w i th in any announced margins. The interbank rate for the U.S. dol- lar on December 30, 1977 was about ¥.240 per US$1. Authorized banks may freely carry out spot and forward exchange transactions with nonresident banks and among themselves; their forward transactions w i th resident cus- tomers must have a permitted underlying transaction. Japan formally accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreemen t, as from April 1, 1964. Administration of Control The exchange control system is operated by the Min- istry of Finance, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry (M IT I ), and the Bank of Japan as the Government's agent. However, most of the authority for verifying normal payments is delegated to authorized banks referred to as foreign exchange banks. Import and export licensing is handled by MITI. Long-term inward direct investments require the approval of the Minister of Finance and other appropriate ministers. In some exceptional cases, outward direct investments require the approval of the Minister of Finance. Prescription of Currency Payments to all countries may be made in any cur- rency, including yen, and receipts also may be obtained in any currency. Settlements in yen with foreign coun- tries must be made through a Nonresident Free Yen Account. All payments to Rhodesia require prior approval by the Minister of Finance or the Minister of International Trade and Industry; in many cases such payments are prohibited or restricted for security reasons. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident Free Yen Accounts may be opened by any nonresident with any authorized bank in Japan and may be credited with the yen proceeds f rom exports of goods to Japan and from other authorized transactions, with yen proceeds from sales of all foreign currencies, with transfers from other Free Yen Accounts, with interest accrued on balances in these accounts, with the proceeds f rom the sales of debentures and beneficiary certificates, with the countervalue in yen of authorized outward payments, and with credit balances f rom Non- resident Yen Deposit Accounts, which were abolished in June 1977. There are no restrictions on payments from these accounts, and balances may be converted freely into any foreign currency. Imports and import Payments Imports f rom Rhodesia are in principle prohibited. Other imports are subject either to individual licensing by the authorized banks or, if liberalized, to declaration to such banks. Most private imports are liberalized. There are two procedures for imports requiring payment in foreign currencies: (1) The Import Quota System (covering imports of goods on the "negative list," which comprises 80 items; 27 of these have been notified to the GATT as residual restrictions, while the other 54 items have been notified as falling under the state trad- ing, national security, public health, and moral protec- tion provisions of the GATT; one item classified in the Customs Cooperation Council Nomenclature (CCCN), four-digit, is counted tw ice ); once the importer has ob- tained an import quota f rom MITI, he receives an import quota certificate which entitles him to receive an import license from an authorized bank automatically upon appli- cation. Practically all import quota certificates are issued by MITI on a global basis, without regard to the country of origin or the currency of settlement. (2) Under the Declaration System, imports are free of quantitative restriction and licensing and require only a declaration by the importer to a foreign exchange bank. All items may be imported from any country except Rhodesia. Items under state trading include certain dairy prod- ucts, certain cereals, salt, raw silk, and raw and manu- fac tured tobacco. Payment for imports under one of the "standard" methods of settlement for imports can be made freely; otherwise, the prior approval of MITI must be obtained. Standard settlement requires that import prepayment be limited to goods not exceeding ¥ 1.8 million in value (with the exception of machinery imports, for which prepayment up to one half of their value is permitted) and that payment be made no more than four months af ter customs clearance. Payments for Invisibles All payments to Rhodesia are subject to the approval of the Minister of Finance or the Minister of Inter- national Trade and Industry. Payments to other coun- tries for invisibles are subject to verification by foreign exchange banks without any limitation. Payments for donations to nonresidents, except relatives abroad, are referred to the Bank of Japan for the purpose of con- trolling illegal payments; upon verification of the authen- ticity of the payments, they are approved. Residents may purchase freely foreign currencies for payments in connection with travel abroad up to US$3,000 a person a trip; amounts in excess of US$3,000 a person a trip require the verification of a foreign exchange bank. A traveler is permitted to pay in yen or in foreign cur- rency, before departure, the cost of transportation to and from his destination and for all side trips. 237 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution JAPAN Residents may freely and at any time make payments abroad up to US$3,000 a remittance, for virtually any purpose other than import payments, repayments on loans, technical assistance payments, etc.; the corre- sponding amount for current invisibles related to trade is also US$3,000 for each remittance. Certain insurance and technical assistance contracts require approval, but when a license for a contract has been granted, any pay- ment resulting from the contract may be made freely. Both residents and nonresidents may take out freely up to ¥ 100,000 in Japanese currency. A nonresident may freely purchase foreign currencies up to the equivalent of US$3,000; for larger amounts, verification is required. Exports and Export Proceeds With minor exceptions, exports to Rhodesia are pro- hibited. All exports (except exports without exchange) must be certified by a foreign exchange bank ("bank certification"). Licenses are not generally required, except for goods subject to the following restrictions: restrictions on cer- tain goods to control their export to specified communist countries; restrictions on goods in short supply in the domestic market (e.g., some staple foods); and restric- tions designed to forestall the imposition of import restrictions by other countries (e.g., on sewing machines and certain textiles). Exports under processing and consignment sale contracts and exports for which settle- ment is not under the "standard" method also require individual licenses. Export restraint may be exercised by virtue of the Export and Import Trade Law and an export trade control order issued under the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Control Law. Export restraint may be applied either globally or to specified destinations, and it may cover export volumes, prices, and other condi- tions. At the end of 1977, there were 60 export cartels under the provisions of the Export and Import Trade Law. Of these, 44 required prior notice of exporters' agreements in respect of export transactions, 16 required prior approval of manufacturers' agreements on domes- tic transactions in goods for export, and 9 were rein- forced by an export license requirement. In addition, 19 items were subject to export license under the For- eign Exchange and Foreign Trade Control Law. There are also a number of informal arrangements for the voluntary restraint of exports of certain items to speci- fied markets, with or without guidance by MITI. Under the "standard" method of settlement for exports, the value of the exported goods must, in gen- eral, be settled by drawing a bill of exchange payable within five months after sight or within six months af ter shipment. There are no surrender requirements for foreign currency earnings. In cases where exporters receive payment in advance, an individual license is required for conversion of the proceeds into yen when they exceed the equivalent of US$500,000, or receipt is more than one year in advance. 238 Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts under the "standard" method of settlement may be accepted without a license. Under this method, receipts for the value of services, etc., must be obtained within one year before, or within six months after, ren- dering the service, etc. Contracts for services performed for nonresidents when payment is to be received by a "nonstandard" method are subject to individual licensing. Both residents and nonresidents may bring in freely any amount in foreign or Japanese currency. Capital Foreign investments in Japan are generally subject to approval. All acquisitions of stocks, bonds, debentures, beneficiary certificates, and claims in the form of loans by foreign investors are, in principle, subject to valida- tion or license.1 However, acquisitions of stocks for port- folio investment are automatically approved by the Bank of Japan. All acquisitions must be made against yen proceeds from the sale of foreign exchange or its equiva- lent, if the investor wishes to obtain remittance rights upon validation. Stocks in the form of stock dividends f rom earned surpluses or revaluation of assets may be acquired freely, but application for remittance rights must be made within three months from the date of acquisition. At present, the acquisition of Japanese securities by nonresidents is not restricted, although subject, in the case of shares, to the foreign ownership limits. The following are deemed to be the same as yen pro- ceeds f rom the sale of foreign exchange, if they are reinvested in Japan and if approval had been obtained for their acquisition: proceeds from the redemption after maturity of debentures, beneficiary certificates, or claims in the fo rm of loans; dividends on stocks and interest on debentures or on claims in the form of loans; distributed profits from beneficiary certificates; receipts from technological assistance contracts; and pro- ceeds f rom sales of stocks, debentures, and beneficiary certificates. In the event of expropriation or compulsory sale of a fore ign investment, the amount paid because of expro- priation may be repatriated freely. The remittance of the proceeds from the sale of vali- dated stocks (sha res ), as well as the transfer abroad of earnings on foreign investments acquired with foreign currency, is permitted freely. Proceeds from the sale of bonds, debentures, and beneficiary certificates may be deposited in Nonresident Free Yen Accounts, which are freely transferab le. There are no special rules prescrib- ing that the yen proceeds from sales of securities by nonresidents must be either reinvested in securities or converted into foreign currency for t rans fer abroad. When foreign companies wish to establish a branch or a plant in Japan, they must in fo rm the Ministry of Finance and MITI in advance through the Bank of 1 On Ma rch 16, 1978, nonresidents were prohibited f rom purchasing Japanese securities of less than five years and one mon th to maturity. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Japan. When branches or plants established by foreign companies wish to bring in funds from their main offices abroad, or to remit their profits and principal abroad, they are required to obtain licenses. Licenses are given automatically if application papers and the required documents are presented. Foreign direct investment in Japan generally requires approval by the Minister of Finance and other appro- priate ministers and, in certain important cases, by the Foreign Investment Council. Foreign ownership up to 100 per cent is permitted in new or existing enterprises in all but four industries. In three of these four indus- tries, investment is subject to case-by-case screening and in one, foreign ownership is permitted automatically up to 50 per cent. The present liberalization applies both to the establishment of new firms and, provided in all cases that the firm concerned consents, to takeovers of existing firms or participation in existing firms. Purchases by nonresidents of real estate in Japan for residential or other nonprofit purposes and of offices require approval by the Bank of Japan, which is given automatically; purchases of real estate for other pur- poses require approval by the Minister of Finance, which is usually given automatically. Licenses are not required in certain cases such as the acquisition of real estate for the purpose of residential or executive use by foreign diplomatic establishments. The leasing of real estate in Japan by nonresidents for residential use is also free. The transfer abroad of capital by residents and the making of investments abroad are subject to approval, but generally approval is either automatic or freely given for outward direct investment, purchases of real estate abroad, and outward portfolio investment. For- eign borrowers may issue yen bonds on the Japanese capital market; the t im ing and amount of issue is con- trolled by Japanese underwriters with guidance f rom the Ministry of Finance.2 Japanese emigrants and emigrants of foreign nationality may remit any amount f rom their assets to any country subject only to verification by a foreign exchange bank; if the amount of the rem i t tance is less than US$3,000, the remittance may be made without verification. Foreign currency loans to residents for certain types of long-term capital outflows can be extended by government institutions and foreign exchange banks. Outward financial credits and loans are subject to licensing. The issuing of bonds abroad denominated in foreign currencies, including issues for conversion into yen for domestic use, also is subject to licensing; du r ing 1977 such issues were permitted liber- ally. The issue of yen-denominated bonds on the Euro- bond market requires approval of the Minister of Finance, and in 1977 three such placements were approved. Securities acquired with approval under the Law JAPAN Concerning Foreign Investment may be imported and exported freely. Foreign exchange banks are subject individually to controls over their overall net position in foreign cur- rency ( the ir oversold or overbought position). Japanese banks are not allowed oversold spot positions and limits are applied to the net oversold spot positions of foreign banks operating in Japan. Banks are also subject to ma tu r i ty t rans fo rma t ion control so that increases in medium-term and long-term loans must be matched, in principle, by fund ing of one year or greater maturity. Deposits held in Nonresident Free Yen Accounts are subject to a reserve requirement of 0.25 per cent; increases in aggregate balances on these accounts above the average level in October 1977 are subject to a reserve requ irement of 50 per cent.3 Gold Residents, including domestic producers of gold, may freely hold gold and purchase and sell it in domestic transactions. The import of gold bullion containing more than 45 per cent of gold in weight normally is perm i t ted, provided a payments license is obtained from the Bank of Japan. Imports of other gold bullion, gold coins, and articles of gold are freely permitted, subject only to verification by a foreign exchange bank. Resi- dent or nonresident travelers may bring in up to one kilogram of gold bullion a person a tr ip and up to the equivalent of US$3,000 in articles of gold and gold coins. Gold bullion, gold coins, and articles of gold acquired by donation or inheritance may be imported freely, subject only to verification by the customs author- ities. Exports of gold bullion, gold coins, and articles of gold by residents require licenses from the Minister of Finance. Changes during 1977 February 3. The Ministry of Finance announced the fol- lowing revisions of exchange control procedures for transactions in invisibles: ( 1) The amount of foreign currency which could be freely remitted for transactions in invisibles was raised from US$1,000 to US$3,000, and remittances in excess of this amount would be sub- ject to verification by foreign exchange banks only for amounts above US$1,000. (2) The limitations on remittances for donations to relatives abroad were elimi- nated. (3) Japanese nationals traveling abroad would be able to take out freely up to US$3,000, and, for greater amounts, would be subject only to verification by a foreign exchange bank; previously, amounts up to US$1,000 were subject to such verification, while amounts over US$3,000 required approval by the Bank of Japan. (4) The amount of foreign currency which a nonresident, when leaving the country, can purchase without the approval of a foreign exchange bank was raised to US$3,000 from US$1,000. (5) The require- ment of validation by the Bank of Japan for payments on overseas contracts, such as purchases of television rights, was eliminated. May 18. May 27. The Ministry of Finance announced the following changes in the exchange control regulations: (1) Beginning June 1, the control over conversions by banks of foreign currencies into yen would be replaced by control of spot foreign exchange positions. Oversold spot positions would not be allowed for Japanese banks although it was stated that these would be allowed in principle at some time in the fu ture. Banks' interoffice free yen accounts were partially excluded f rom the con- trol over spot foreign exchange positions. (2) Beginning 240 in July 1977, Japanese foreign exchange banks would have greater freedom to extend medium-term and long- term loans in foreign currencies. (3) The control over short-term loans to nonresidents by Japanese foreign exchange banks was abolished on May 27. June 20. MITI announced a liberalization of import procedures. The limit on goods that might be imported without verification by banks was raised from ¥ 308,000 to ¥ 1 million; the limit on the value of goods that might be imported with only the approval of the customs office was raised from ¥ 1 million to ¥ 3 million; MITI approval would no longer be required for contracts for consignment sales; and contracts for Japanese companies to engage in trade between foreign countries also would not require MITI approval, although companies were still required to report to MITI. June 27. The exchange control regulations were fu r ther modified, as follows: (1) Partially convertible deposit accounts of nonresidents were abolished. The proceeds f rom sales of debentures and beneficiary certifi- cates sold within six months f rom the date of validated acquisition, which had been the primary source of credits to these accounts, could be deposited in fully convertible free yen accounts. Current balances on non- residents' deposit accounts would be transferable to free yen accounts. (2) The restrictions on the purchase of foreign securities with maturities of one year or less by Japanese residents were abolished. (3) The ceiling of US$20,000 on the foreign currency deposits that may be held by residents was abolished. (4) The restrictions on the maturity or amount of foreign currency deposits held abroad by Japanese security, insurance, and trans- portation companies were abolished. (5) The acquisi- tion by Japanese residents of real estate abroad which was not being put to direct use had been restricted but this restriction was abolished. (6) The requirement that the Ministry of Finance must approve any purchases of foreign stock under stock-sharing plans for Japanese employees of foreign-affiliated companies was abolished. July 1. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Foreign Exchange Control Department of the Central Bank of Jordan, which also issues exchange permits; the Central Bank has, however, delegated to authorized banks the issuance of exchange permits for import paymen ts and, w i th in permitted annual limits, for paymen ts for educa- tional expenses of Jo rdan ians s tudy ing abroad and for various other purposes. An Import Committee compris- ing representatives of the Ministries of Indus t ry and Trade and of Finance and Customs and the Central Bank reviews import policy. In add i t ion, an Economic Security Committee is empowered to amend existing regulations or issue new ones concerning economic policy. Prescription of Currency All settlements in respect of trade with Egypt must be made in U.S. dollars through clearing accounts under a special bilateral payments arrangement with that coun- try. Payments to other countries may be made in any currency. Proceeds from exports (except of Jordan ian goods to neighboring Arab countries or up to JD 500, excluding fru i ts and vegetables, to other countries) and invisibles must be collected, and surrendered where required, in any convertible currency through an author- ized bank in Jordan or in Jordan dinars f rom a nonresi- dent account with an authorized bank in Jordan. Nonresident Accounts Subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank, authorized banks may open nonresident accounts in domestic currency. These accounts must be fed with 1ln addition to U.S. dollars and pounds sterling, the Central Bank maintains official quotations for Belgian f rancs, deutsche m a rk, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Ne the r lands gu i lders, Swedish kroner, and Swiss francs. 242 approved fund s; the approval of the Central Bank is necessary for transfers f rom resident to nonresident accounts, but transfers between nonresident accounts are permitted freely. Imports and Import Payments Imports of certain i t em s2 from any source, some imports f rom Roman ia, and all imports f rom Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. All other imports, unless cov- ered by an agreement between Jordan and the exporting countries (i.e., agricultural products f rom neighboring coun t r ies ), require import licenses if their c. & f. value exceeds JD 100. These are granted freely by the Minis- try of Indus try and Trade, except for certain i tem s3 which are subject to scrutiny by the Minister of Industry and Trade (whose prior approval is also required for imports of indus t r ial machinery and of all materials needed for the establishment or expansion of an indus- tr ial firm) or scrutiny by the appropriate ministry. Importers of tea and certain other goods must obtain a specified m in imum proportion of their requirements f r om Ind ian sources. Imports that require an import license also require an exchange perm it which is granted automatically when an import license has been obtained; the importer hold- ing an exchange permit may either open a letter of credit or pay against documents. A fee of 0.10 per cent is levied on exchange permits for imports, except those made by government departments and certain approved ins t i tu t ions. The use of suppliers' credit is subject to prior Central Bank approval, which normally is given for essential imports only. Most imported commodities are subject to an import du ty of 4 per cent of the c. & f. value, payable on the issue of the import license. In add i t ion, a surcharge of 15 per cent of the duty-paid va lue is levied on most imports to finance social we lfare and the development of certain public facilities. Payments for the following types of invisibles are generally permitted within certain limits: remittances to residents' depend- ents; reasonable living expenses of Jordanian nationals abroad; expenses of Jordanian residents traveling abroad; expenses for education; expenses for medical treatment; business expenses abroad; and insurance payments in accordance with special regulations.4 No limit exists on the remittance of income accrued to nonresidents or savings of foreign nationals who intend to return to their own countries, but the prior approval of the Central Bank is required. The exchange allowance for business and tourist travel is the equivalent of JD 5,000 a person (JD 500 for chil- dren under 18). These allowances are granted annua l ly for one or more trips. For fam i ly support, an annual allowance of JD 5,000 for each beneficiary is permitted, once a year; however, remittances by postal order may be made for amounts not exceeding the equivalent of JD 10 a month to any one person resident abroad (JD 100 a month for Kuwait) and are not subject to this ceiling. The policy in respect of payments for invisibles is, in general, liberal and nondiscriminatory. In practice, the Central Bank does not restrict remit- tances of income accruing to nonresidents or of savings of foreign nationals returning to their own country. In addition to any travel allocation, residents traveling abroad may take out up to JD 300 in any combination of Jordanian and foreign notes and coins. Furthermore, all travelers may take out checks, travelers checks, or letters of credit issued by authorized banks in Jordan in accordance with exchange permits authorized by the Central Bank. Tourists and other nonresidents may also take out foreign currency notes and coins and any other foreign means of payment that they had previously brought in and declared to the customs authorities at the time of entry. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Export proceeds must be collected and the foreign exchange surrendered within six months of shipment. Exempt are the proceeds from exports of Jordanian products to neighboring Arab countries, or up to JD 500 f rom such exports (excluding f ru i ts and vegetables) to other coun- tries. Exporters are not permitted to ma in ta in bank balances abroad for any purpose. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts f rom invisibles must be sur- rendered to an authorized bank or, if bankno tes and travelers checks are received, to an authorized exchange JORDAN dealer. Travelers entering Jordan may bring in any amount in Jordanian and foreign notes and coins.5 Any person regarded for exchange control purposes as resi- dent in Jordan may be required by the Central Bank to surrender to an authorized bank any foreign currency at his disposal. Capital Capital may be imported freely, but exports of capital require approval and are not normally allowed, except that the Central Bank is prepared to examine applica- tions by banks, insurance companies, industrial or trad- ing firms, and contractors for permission to transfer funds abroad for specified investment or operating pur- poses. Current income resulting from nonresident invest- ments in Jordan may be transferred abroad. Under the Law for the Encouragement of Investment, profits from approved foreign investments may be remitted, without limitation, in any convertible currency approved by the Central Bank. After two years, repatriation of the capi- tal is permitted in three equal annual installments in any convertible currency approved by the Central Bank. The Investment Committee may approve more liberal provi- sions, and exchange permits are granted accordingly. The Companies Registration Law provides various bene- fits for foreign companies establishing branches in Jordan for the purpose of conducting business outside the country; such branches may also be granted nonresi- dent status for exchange control purposes. Premium Development Bonds denominated in Jordanian dinars may be purchased with convertible currencies by non- residents; maturity proceeds, premiums, and interest are transferable in U.S. dollars at the official rate of exchange. Gold The Central Bank has issued three gold coins. These coins, although legal tender, do not circulate and are available only to nonresidents and domestic numismatists. Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Jordan for num isma t ic or investment purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authori- ties and authorized industrial users are not, in principle, allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Licenses for imports of gold in any fo rm other than jewelry are issued by the Ministry of Indus t ry and Trade on the recommendation of the Central Bank, while exports of gold in any form require a license f rom the Central Bank. Licenses are not nor- ma l ly granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Changes during 1977 March 15.
