Not for Redistribution KENYA (Position on December 31,1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.103133 gram of fine gold per Kenya Shilling. A central rate of KSh 9.66000 = SDR 1 has been established, and Kenya avails itself of wider margins. The Central Bank of Kenya deals with the Government and with authorized banks in Tanzania shillings and Uganda shillings against Kenya shillings at par; in principle, the authorized banks also deal with the public in these currencies at par.1 In transactions with authorized banks, the Central Bank stands ready to issue Kenya shillings in exchange for U.S. dollars and to supply U.S. dollars in exchange for Kenya shil- lings, at rates based on the Fund's daily calculation of the U.S. dollar-SDR rate. The Central Bank deals with the Government and commercial banks, on the basis of the daily closing rates in New York, in deutsche mark, French francs, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs, and, on the basis of their U.S. dollar cross rates, in Burundi francs and Zambian kwacha. The Central Bank does not deal in other foreign currencies, except occasionally on behalf of the Government. The Central Bank deals up to six months forward in sterling and U.S. dollars with commercial banks, to cover their con- tracts with exporters and importers; commercial banks may cover their forward exchange contracts in other foreign currencies against U.S. dollars or pounds sterling in outside markets. Administration of Control The Minister of Finance and Economic Planning has delegated the administration of exchange control to the Central Bank. Authority for approving payments for imports of goods not listed in Import Schedules I-IV with an invoiced value not exceeding K Sh 4,000, many payments in respect of current invisibles, and some capi- tal payments is delegated to the authorized banks. Import and export controls are administered by the Director of Trade and Supplies in the Ministry of Com- merce and Industry. The responsibility for issuing import and export licenses rests with the Director, to whom applications must be submitted by the importer or the exporter in Kenya before orders are placed abroad or exports are shipped. Applications for the allocation of foreign exchange permits for imports also must be submitted to the Director of Trade and Sup- plies; applications are screened by the Foreign Exchange Allocation Committee, composed of representatives of the Central Bank, the Treasury, and the Director of Trade and Supplies of the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. Orders for imports of goods on open general license must be preregistered with the Director of Trade and Supplies before shipment. The government-owned 1A11 deaings in Tanzania and Uganda banknotes are suspended. Kenya National Trading Corporation, Ltd. has a monop- oly over the import of specified commodities, and the export of certain agricultural commodities is controlled by State Marketing Boards. Together with Tanzania and Uganda, Kenya is part of the East African Community. However, the Com- munity was dissolved, in effect, early in 1977. On August 5, 1977, Kenya decided to treat residents of Tanzania and Uganda on the same basis as other non- residents for exchange control purposes, and thus dis- continued the favorable treatment that had previously been given to trade and exchange transactions with these countries. Prescription of Currency Payments to residents of countries other than Rho- desia and South Africa may be made in Kenya shillings to the credit of an External Account in Kenya or in any foreign currency except Rhodesian currency. Receipts from countries other than Rhodesia may be obtained in Kenya shillings from an External Account in Kenya or in any marketable foreign currency. Settlements with Rwanda are made through special accounts. All pay- ments and transfers to Rhodesia are prohibited. Remit- tances to South Africa also are prohibited, with the exception of pensions payable by the Government of Kenya or by the East African Community organizations. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Kenya shillings held by residents of coun- tries other than Rhodesia and South Africa with author- ized banks in Kenya are, with exchange control approval, designated External Accounts. They may be credited freely with authorized payments to such countries by residents of Kenya, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any cur- rency (other than Rhodesian and South African cur- rency) and gold by nonresidents to authorized dealers. External Accounts may be debited freely for payments to residents and nonresidents. Nontransferable funds of nonresidents are credited to Blocked Accounts. Subject to prescribed procedures, balances on Blocked Accounts (other than those in the beneficial ownership of residents of South Africa or Rhodesia) may be used for approved domestic expendi- tures and for the purchase in Kenya of specified bonds issued by the Kenyan Government or by local authorities and officially quoted in Kenya; 2 the redemption pro- ceeds of these securities, which must have a life of five years at the time of acquisition, are transferable, and interest is freely transferable to nonresidents as and when it accrues. 2 Such securities must be payable in Kenya shillings and they must not be redeemable earlier than five years from the date of acquisition. 245 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KENYA Imports and Import Payments Some imports from all sources are prohibited for reasons of public policy; imports of certain other goods are not being licensed. All imports from Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Many goods may be freely imported from other sources under open general license, but others require a specific license. Certain items are imported only by the Kenya National Trading Corpora- tion, Ltd. These include sugar, salt, rice, edible oils, blankets, and cotton piece goods. In addition to the open general import license, there are four commodity schedules for imports. With minor exceptions, all private sector imports of commodities in Schedules I, II, III, and IV require a license for the allocation of foreign exchange, issued by the Director of Trade and Supplies through the Central Bank; appli- cations must be submitted before firm orders are placed. Imports of goods on open general license require an exchange allocation license, which is given automatically, and must be preregistered with the Director of Trade and Supplies before firm orders are placed. All goods in the first three schedules require a specific import license from the Director of Trade and Supplies. Once the specific import license has been obtained, for- eign exchange is granted freely for goods in Schedule I and on the basis of quotas reflecting past imports for goods in Schedule II. No foreign exchange is granted for Schedule III items. For items in Schedule IV, a specific import license is not required but foreign exchange is allocated on a quota basis. From time to time, exemptions may be granted from the quotas estab- lished under Schedules II and IV and f rom the prohibi- tions of Schedule III. Applications for foreign exchange allocation licenses for imports are subject to a charge of 1 per cent of the amount of the application. When an exchange allocation license has been obtained from the Central Bank or when such a license is not required, authorized banks are permitted to pro- vide exchange automatically, but normally not prior to customs entry. Prior exchange control approval must be obtained for imports of capital goods on deferred payment terms, and for imports of machinery and equip- ment when the value is regarded as a contribution toward capital or to be accounted for on a loan basis. With the exception of imports f rom Tanzania and Uganda, most imports with a pro forma invoice value in excess of KSh 20,000 are subject to preshipment inspection as to quality, quantity, and price by the General Superintendence Company acting for the Cen- tral Bank. A "Clean Report of Findings" must be obtained before shipment, and authorized banks in Kenya may not issue shipping guarantees for the clear- ance of imports until this "Clean Report" has been received. The buying and confirming commission with respect to imports into Kenya may not exceed 3 per cent of the value of the import. The interest rate on suppliers' credit normally is limited to 11 per cent per annum. 246 Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are controlled. Authorized banks are empowered to approve specified categories of current payments without limitation or up to established limits. Amounts above these limits as well as other current payments may be approved administratively, and most current payments are in fact unrestricted. Fees for education up to the equivalent of K Sh 24,000 a person for a full scholastic year 3 and fees for other specified purposes may be approved by an authorized bank upon presentation of evidence of debt. The Cen- tral Bank may approve higher remittances for education expenses. Foreign nationals who come to work in Kenya as employed persons (as well as certain categories of the self-employed, such as doctors and dentists) for not more than four years may remit abroad as savings up to 33V3 per cent of their monthly salaries but not more than K Sh 4,000 a month; in addition, they may remit funds to cover maintenance, education expenses, etc., provided that their total remittances including savings do not exceed 50 per cent of their monthly salaries. Expatriates who have stayed for over four years may continue to remit from salaries as above, but in that case are not entitled to transfer additional savings upon emigration. Remittances to South Africa, other than certain pensions, are prohibited. Nonresident individual property owners may remit up to K Sh 20,000 of net rental income in each 12-month period. Any excess of net rent over the permitted trans- fer is placed in a Blocked Account and may be invested in approved securities with at least five years to maturity, after which period the redemption proceeds may be remitted to the nonresident beneficiary. Real estate com- panies deriving income solely from rent are permitted to transfer annually up to 10 per cent of the book value of their properties as at September 25, 1970, or an amount not exceeding 10 per cent of issued capital. Where income is derived from rent as well as other sources, applications must be made to the exchange control authorities for approval of remittance of such incomes. The basic allowance for travel by adults holding round-trip tickets is KSh4 ,000 a person (K Sh 2,000 for children between 3 and 12 years of age) every two years, which may be taken out in foreign banknotes. Holders of one-way tickets are entitled to a basic travel allowance of K Sh 2,000 for adults and KSh 1,000 for children. The basic allowance is not available for travel to Rhodesia or South Africa. Business travelers to Tan- zania and Uganda are granted an allowance of up to K Sh 400 a night for a maximum period of ten days at a time. There is a pilgrimage allowance of K Sh 6,000 for adults which is available only to persons who have not utilized the basic travel allowance within the pre- ceding two years. Nonresident travelers may take out 8 Authorized dealers are not allowed to remit any funds for educational support to students at primary or secondary schools who were not abroad in the 1975-76 academic year. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution foreign currency notes up to the amount they brought in upon entry. Residents of Kenya traveling abroad on international flights and holding re turn tickets may carry up to K Sh 100 with them for local expenses on re turn, but otherwise the export of Kenya banknotes is prohibited. Exports and Export Proceeds Export transactions must be registered with the Cen- tral Bank. Exports of certain foods tuffs and agricultural products require licenses and may be subject to restric- tion in order to ensure sufficient supplies for consump- tion in Kenya. Exports of tea, certain minerals, precious stones, and strategic materials are also subject to licens- ing. Most other goods may be exported without licenses. Coffee is exported through the Coffee Marketing Board. All exports to Rhodesia and South Afr ica are prohibited. Export proceeds in foreign currencies must be col- lected within three months of exportation and offered to an authorized bank in Kenya for conversion into Kenya shillings.4 Exports of manu fac tu red goods to countries other than Tanzania and Uganda are eligible for special incentives. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts f rom invisibles in foreign currencies must be sold to an authorized bank. Nonresidents must settle hotel bills in fore ign currency or against an External Account. Travelers may br ing in freely fo re ign cur- rency notes, except those of Tanzania and Uganda. The import of domestic banknotes is prohibited, except that residents re turn ing to Kenya may br ing in up to K Sh 100 previously taken out by themselves. Capital Capital transfers to all countries are restricted. Trans- fers to Rhodesia or South Afr ica are not allowed. With the exception of expatriate employees who have opted for remittance of savings f rom salaries, persons leaving Kenya permanently may transfer their assets up to the equivalent of K Sh 50,000 for each fam i ly unit; they may additionally every 12 months thereafter, dur ing a period of five years, apply for the release of K Sh 20,000 from their Blocked Accounts. All rema in ing funds must be credited to a Blocked Account; they may then be invested in approved securities, and redemption proceeds become transferable, provided that redemption does not take place earlier than five years from the date of pur- chase. If assets in Kenya are valued at K Sh 1 million or more, they must be liquidated before any exchange control approvals are sought and the proceeds must be invested in prescribed securities. The investment of foreign funds in Kenya is not gen- erally restricted, but to ensure eventual repatriation it is necessary to obtain f rom the Treasury a "certificate of approved enterprise" for the investment. KENYA domestic investment in specified types of production requires approval. Local borrowing by nonresident- owned or nonresident-controlled companies, as well as borrowing by residents from nonresidents, requires exchange control approval and is restricted. All imports and exports of securities require approval. Approval is granted for the purchase by nonresidents of Kenyan securities on a recognized stock exchange, pro- vided that payment is received in an appropriate manner. The income from such securities is remittable, but the proceeds on resale must normally be credited to a Blocked Account unless they are reinvested. Residents are not normally permitted to purchase foreign securities and may not send as a cash gift more than K Sh 200 a year without specific exchange control approval. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Kenya for num isma t ic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require exchange control approval. The import of the following items from all sources is subject to individual licensing: jewelry of gold, silver, or platinum; gold- smiths' or silversmiths' wares, including set gems; bul- lion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coins. Imports of gold jewelry, as Schedule III items, require specific import licenses and foreign exchange is not allocated for them; import licenses for gold bullion (ingots, bars, or sheets) are issued restrictively and only to goldsmiths, and imports of gold coins are not being licensed. Not for Redistribution KOREA (Position on December 31,1977) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Korean Won has been estab- lished with the Fund. The exchange rate is maintained around W484 per US$1. On December 31, 1977 the buying and selling rates of the Bank of Korea for the U.S. dollar were W 483.10 and W 484.90, respectively, per US$1, and the telegraphic transfer buying and selling rates of the foreign exchange banks were W 4 83 and W485, respectively, per US$1. Exchange certificates valid for 30 days may be issued by the foreign exchange banks against all foreign exchange earnings in prescribed currencies surrendered by residents. In practice, most foreign exchange pro- ceeds are exchanged for won at the buying rate posted by the foreign exchange banks. Exchange certificates may be changed into equivalent foreign means of pay- ment. Forward exchange transactions may be under- taken by the foreign exchange banks, but only in pre- scribed currencies. Transactions with a maturity of up to one year may be concluded with the Bank of Korea, foreign banks, and other foreign exchange banks. Administration of Control The Ministry of Finance initiates policy with respect to prescription of currency and method of settlement, foreign exchange operations, payments for nonmerchan- dise transactions, and capital transactions and transfers. It also prepares and administers the Foreign Exchange Supply and Demand Plan, which sets overall ceilings on the amounts of foreign exchange that may be used in each period. The Bank of Korea, as the Government's agent, executes most of the above functions; it also regu- lates operations in the exchange market and is author- ized to intervene in it. The Bank has been delegated authority to control payments related to invisibles and certain capital transactions. The foreign exchange banks, as well as the branch offices in Korea of foreign banks, are authorized to engage in commercial international banking and in specified foreign exchange dealings. The trade program for imports financed f rom Korea's own foreign exchange resources (KFX) is prepared by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. Imports financed by foreign loans are programmed separately by the Economic Planning Board in consultation with the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. Import licenses are issued by the foreign exchange banks. Prescription of Currency All settlements between Korea and other countries are made in convertible currencies. The proceeds of exports must be obtained in prescribed currencies.1 The 1 Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Bahrain dinars, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Italian lire, Kuwaiti dinars, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Saudi Arabian riyals, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, U.A.E. dirhams, and U.S. dollars. methods of payment on account of other settlements require the approval of the Bank of Korea. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents, including Korean workers abroad, may maintain foreign currency deposit accounts with foreign exchange banks. Remittances from such accounts and withdrawals in the form of currency notes upon depar- ture from Korea may, in general, be made freely. The approval of the bank where the account is held is required for remittances from balances that have accrued from remuneration for services in Korea, fares paid for travel by air or ship, or insurance premiums received in Korea, or from exchange deposited in accordance with a decision of the Ministry of Finance (except exchange registered at the customs on entry or remitted f rom abroad). The deposits may be disposed of by sale to a foreign exchange bank at the prevailing exchange rate, and they may be debited for salaries paid to foreign employees. Foreign residents and nonresidents (including Korean workers abroad) are permitted to hold demand, notice, and time deposit accounts in prescribed currencies with foreign exchange banks. Certain residents of Korean nationality, such as the airline, overseas construction, and some insurance com- panies, as well as enterprises in which foreign capital is invested, may maintain deposit accounts in foreign cur- rencies with foreign exchange banks. Companies regis- tered to operate in the Masan and Iri Free Export Zones also may maintain deposit accounts in foreign currencies with the foreign exchange bank within the zones. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. All imports require licenses; for certain imports (see below) licenses are issued upon application. No licenses are issued for any goods originating in the People's Republic of China, Cuba, North Korea, or Viet Nam and for certain imports f rom all other countries. Imports are divided into two categories: those paid for with Korean foreign exchange (KFX imports) and those paid for with foreign loan funds. KFX imports are classified as automatic approval, restricted, or pro- hibited items. All commodities may be imported freely (i.e., applications for import licenses are automatically approved) unless they are in a list of restricted or pro- hibited items, subject to the general limits set by the Foreign Exchange Supply and Demand Plan. Automatic approval items (on December 31, 1977 these were 561 out of 1,097 basic items in the Customs Cooperation Council Nomenclature —CCCN) consist mainly of essential consumer goods not produced domestically and certain raw materials and capital goods. Restricted items (484) in a negative list are subject to individual licenses. 249 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KOREA Prohibited items (52) are mainly luxury goods, items prohibited for reasons of public health or morals, and some domestically produced goods. Imports of raw mate- rials for the production of exports are normally approved automatically, irrespective of their classification. Import licenses are granted only to registered traders; to maintain the status of a registered trader, a minimum value of US$1 million of exports is required each year for ordinary exporters. The commercial terms of payment on which imports may be contracted are regulated, and advance import deposits are required for most types of goods imported by the private sector. These are met, for KFX imports, by deposit of local currency at the time of opening the letter of credit and, for imports not on letters of credit, at the time of applying for import licenses. Advance deposits are retained until the bill of lading is released. Advance deposits for KFX imports range between zero and 100 per cent, according to the nature of the import and the commercial terms of payment (sight letter of credit (sight L /C ), deferred letter of credit (usance L /C ), documents against acceptance ( D / A ), or documents against payment (D / P) te rms ). The customs tariff is a "flexible" tar iff. Furthermore, the Government may alter import duty rates admin- istratively by up to 50 percentage points. The Govern- ment also has authority to impose import surcharges of up to 30 per cent on all dutiable imports, but by the end of 1977 had not invoked this authority. A defense sur- charge of 2.5 per cent ad valorem is levied on most goods, whether locally produced or imported. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require individual licenses. Payments for invisibles connected with foreign trade and for certain other items such as banking charges, insur- ance premiums, communication fees, and periodicals are licensed automatically. There are certain standard allocations for business travel. In addition, exporters are authorized to use certain exchange earnings for the expenses of their overseas branches. Residents traveling abroad may purchase foreign exchange up to the equiva- lent of US$150 a day or up to US$2,000 as a monthly allowance for living expenses and may also purchase additional foreign exchange for extra expenses. Korean currency notes in excess of W 500,000 and foreign cur- rency notes may not be exported without special per- mission. Nonresidents must register foreign exchange in specified currencies that they bring into Korea if the amount exceeds the equivalent of US$10,000. Upon leaving the country, foreign residents may acquire up to US$5,000 in foreign exchange per family if they have stayed in Korea for more than two years, and US$2,500 per family in other cases. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to certain specified countries are prohib- ited, as are exports of certain goods (such as raw cot- 250 ton, platinum ores, wood charcoal, pulp, and waste paper) to all other countries. Certain exports on a restricted list require individual licenses. All other exports may be made freely under an automatic approval procedure. The export proceeds in foreign exchange must either be surrendered to a foreign exchange bank at its posted customer rate or be exchanged into equiva- lent foreign exchange certificates. Exporters are not permitted to retain their export proceeds as foreign cur- rency demand or time deposits with foreign exchange banks. Proceeds from Invisibles All proceeds derived from invisibles, in general, must either be sold to a foreign exchange bank for won or be exchanged for equivalent foreign exchange certificates. Travelers may bring with them any amount of foreign exchange, but the import by travelers of Korean cur- rency in excess of W 500,000 is restricted. Capital All capital remittances require approval. Foreign capital investment, loans from abroad, and imports of capital goods on a long-term basis can secure a guar- antee of repayment and repatriation under the Foreign Capital Inducement Law. No limits are placed on the conversion and remittance of legitimate profits and divi- dends, or on the repatriation of the original capital invested, but proposed remittances must be notified to the Economic Planning Board 90 days prior to the end of the fiscal year. Gold Certain commemorative gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may freely buy, hold, and sell gold in any fo rm in Korea. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the Bank of Korea; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users. Domestically produced gold may be disposed of in the free market. The free market price at public gold auctions was about W 3,011 a gram at the end of 1977. Changes during 1977 January 1. The first phase of the tariff reform aiming at a un i tary tariff rate of 20 per cent by 1981 became effective. At the same time, the system was simplified by reducing the number of tariff positions from 3,996 to 2,521, and the number of rate categories from 17 to 11. January 21. Certain qualified Korean nationals were permitted to hold up to US$3,000 in cash and travelers checks, arising from unused overseas traveling expenses without surrendering it to a foreign exchange bank. Previously, nationals had been allowed to retain up to US$1,000. January 21. The limit on the allowance for traveling expenses was raised to US$200 a day for the Middle ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution East, US$150 a day for other areas, or up to US$2,000 as a monthly allowance for living expenses. March 14. The maximum amount of advance export receipts allowed for each company was reduced from 50 per cent to 40 per cent of the value of its exports during the previous year (it was further reduced to 20 per cent with effect from May 14); the maximum annual interest rate paid on such funds was reduced from the London interbank offered rate (LIBOR) plus 1.75 per cent to LIBOR plus 0.75 per cent. April 1. The Kuwaiti dinar, the Bahrain dinar, and the U. A. E. dirham were added to the list of designated currencies. May 12. Interest rates on time deposits in foreign currency were reduced from LIBOR plus 2 per cent to LIBOR plus 1 per cent for deposits with a maturity of more than one year, from LIBOR plus 1.75 per cent to LIBOR plus 0.5 per cent for six months to one year deposits, and from LIBOR plus 1.5 per cent to LIBOR plus 0.25 per cent for three-six month deposits. Eleven items and nine subitems were transferred from the restricted list to the automatic approval category and two items were shifted from the prohibited list to the automatic approval list. July 1. The advance import deposit rate on luxury goods was reduced from 200 per cent to 150 per cent, the rate on imports for general use was reduced f rom 100 per cent to 70 per cent, and the rate on raw mate- rials for exports was reduced from 15 per cent to 10 per cent. July 1. The Tariff Drawback Special Act was amended to allow a reduction in the tariff rate for imported raw materials when 90 per cent or more would be used for exports. August 8. The categories of persons permitted to use credit cards when traveling overseas were extended; the list of purposes for which credit cards could be used was expanded. August 8. The limit on the amount that could be carried by workers traveling abroad was increased f rom US$300 to US$1,000. For individuals invited to make overseas trips, the ceiling on the amount they could carry was increased from US$200 to US$1,000. Upon leaving the country, foreign residents who have stayed in Korea for more than two years would be permitted to acquire up to US$5,000 in foreign exchange for each family instead of the previous limit of US$2,500, and those who have stayed less than two years would be permitted to acquire up to US$2,500 in foreign exchange for each family instead of the previous limit of US$1,000. September 8. Nine new items were added to the list of products eligible for import on a short-term credit basis. October 1. The advance import deposit rate on luxury goods was reduced from 150 per cent to 100 per cent KOREA and the rate on imports for general use was reduced from 70 per cent to 40 per cent. October 12. For the remainder of 1977, Korean firms engaged in overseas construction and service projects were required to deposit remittances to Korea in special foreign currency deposits bearing the same interest rate as foreign exchange time deposits. Such accounts would also be used for advance receipts of export proceeds, except in the case of small firms whose advance export deposits amounted to less than US$500,000. Foreign currency deposits would be released at any time for overseas construction purposes and for the repayment of loans. November 1. It was announced that Type 3 foreign exchange loans by branches of foreign banks in Korea to local enterprises for the import of raw materials would no longer be permitted. Such financing would now be available only from Korean banks. November 2. The repayment period for import credits was reduced from 150 to 120 days. Also, the time period allowed for effecting exports after receipt of a prepayment would no longer be extended beyond six months. November 2. Interest rates were reduced on foreign exchange time deposits, usance bills, and import credits. For one-year deposits, interest rates were fixed at LIBOR plus 0.5 per cent, for six-month to one-year deposits, LIBOR plus 0.125 per cent, and for deposits of not more than six months, LIBOR plus 0.0625 per cent. November 2. The Bank of Korea was no longer em- powered to give exemption on required advance import deposits equivalent to the reserve requirement on foreign currency deposits (15 per cent for demand deposits and 10 per cent for savings deposits). November 18. The Trade Plan for the second half of 1977 was adjusted so that 16 items and 43 subitems were transferred from the restricted list to the automatic approval category and one item was shifted from the prohibited list to the automatic approval list. The 1976 import value of the items shifted to the automatic approval category was US$320 million. December 1. The Trade Plan for the first half of 1978 was announced. In addition, numerous subitems were shifted from the restricted list to the automatic approval list. The net liberalization was equivalent to US$862 million in 1976 import value terms. As regards exports, the number of banned items for export was reduced f rom 11 to 9, and the number of items on the restricted list was reduced from 240 to 237, so that the number of automatic approval items increased from 846 to 851. Not for Redistribution KUWAIT (Position on December 31,1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Kuwaiti Dinar, corresponding to KD 1 = US$3.37778, and Kuwait avails itself of wider margins. Since March 18, 1975 the exchange rate for the Kuwaiti dinar has been maintained on the basis of its value in terms of a weighted average of currencies. Since March 1976, the U.S. dollar has been the intervention currency. The Central Bank of Kuwait quotes daily buying and selling rates for U.S. dollars; on December 31, 1977, its rates for the U.S. dollar were KD 0.27991 buying, and KD 0.28027 selling, per US$1. On April 5, 1963, Kuwait notified the Fund that it was prepared to formally accept the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control There is no exchange control and residents and non- residents may freely purchase and sell foreign currencies in Kuwait. Dealings in the currencies of Israel, Rho- desia, and South Africa are prohibited. General and individual import licenses are issued by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. A limited control over exports is administered by the Customs and Ports Adm in is tra t ion of the Ministry of Communications. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements. All settlements with Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents may freely open accounts in Kuwaiti dinars and foreign currencies. The use of such accounts is not restricted. Imports and Import Payments Import licenses are required for all private imports other than foodstuffs; licenses are issued freely, except for wheat, flour, and asbestos pipe. Registered importers handling a variety of commodities may obtain a general license valid for one year. Other importers must obtain specific licenses for individual commodities, which also are valid for one year. All imports f rom Israel, includ- ing imports of Israeli manu fac tu re and those that con- tain Israeli materials or are manu fac tu red by companies financed by Israeli capital or by companies ma in ta in ing a relationship with Israeli firms that is deemed beneficial to Israel, are prohibited. All imports f rom Rhodesia and South Africa also are prohibited. Imports of a few items (mainly oxygen, certain steel pipes, pork or foodstuffs containing pork, alcoholic beverages, and used trucks and buses not using gasoline for fuel and over ten years old) are prohibited from all sources. To be registered, the importer must be either a Kuwaiti citizen or a firm in which all partners are Kuwaiti nationals or a shareholding or limited liability company in which Kuwaiti nationals own at least 51 per cent of all stock. Commercial imports normally are limited to registered importers. Imports from any permitted source may be paid for freely. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles may be made freely, except to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa. There are no limita- tions on the export of domestic or foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of live sheep and poultry and of certain other items (such as sugar, fats, rice, meat, eggs, fish, milk, cheese, butter, olive oil, fresh fruits, vegetables in any fo rm, beans, lentils, chick-peas, jams, and cement) are prohibited in time of emergency or shortage in Kuwait. These items may be exported in limited quantities only, under a special license issued by the Ministry of Com- merce and Industry. Exports of arms, ammun i t ion, and scrap metal require licenses. Licenses are not required for other exports or re-exports. All exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re-exports, except that these must not accrue in Israel pounds, Rhodesian dollars, or South African rand; the proceeds need not be repatriated or surren- dered, and they may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Proceeds from Invisibles No requirements are attached to the use or disposal of receipts in any currency other than Israel pounds, Rhodesian dollars, or South African rand. Travelers entering Kuwait may bring with them any amount in Kuwaiti or other banknotes except in Israeli, Rhodesian, and South African currencies. Capital There are no exchange control obligations on the transfer to Kuwait of resident or nonresident capital in any currency. Government agreement is necessary for the participation of nonresident capital in corporations in Kuwait, and a license is required for the establishment and operation of industries in Kuwait; at least 51 per cent of ownership of new Kuwaiti companies must be held by nationals. No restrictions are imposed on outward capital pay- ments by residents or nonresidents to other countries except Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa. Gold The monetary authorities and merchants registered with the Ministry of Commerce and Industry may import and export gold in any form, provided that such gold is 253 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution KUWAIT not less than 18-karat fine; gold jewelry, however, may not be imported or sold unless it is properly hallmarked. Kuwaiti nationals may freely, and without license, pur- chase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Other residents may, on arrival or departure, bring in and take out their holdings of gold in any form, without restriction or license. Jewelry and precious metals in any form, manufactured or unmanufac tured, are subject to import duty at 4 per cent. Changes during 1977 February 10. The Bank of Kuwait and Bahrain— 50 per cent owned by Bahraini interests and 50 per cent by Kuwaiti institutions —was granted permission to open a branch. This was the first bank with a foreign share- holding allowed to operate in Kuwait since the British Bank of the Middle East was taken over five years ago. June 5. The assets in Kuwait of the American Independent Oil Company were nationalized. October 30. The Government issued a decree-law amending Law No. 32 of 1968, providing that the Kuwaiti dinar would no longer have a fixed gold equiva- lent, that the procedures for fixing the exchange rate of the d inar would be specified by a later decree, and that the requirement of a minimum percentage of gold cover for the dinar was canceled. 254 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LAO PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System l No par value for the Kip of Liberation2 has been established with the Fund. On December 31, 1977, the official exchange rate of the National Bank of Laos (the central bank) for U.S. dollars was KL 200 = US$1; on that date, the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were KL 198 and KL202, respectively, per US$1. The official exchange rate applies to all exchange transac- tions, except for purchases of foreign exchange from foreign diplomatic missions and international organiza- tions in the Lao People's Democratic Republic which receive an exchange premium of 100 per cent for amounts under US$1,000 and 150 per cent for transac- tions involving US$1,000 or more. Administration of Control The Lao Bank for Foreign Trade, which is a subsidi- ary of the National Bank, handles all foreign exchange transactions related to foreign trade and services. All other transactions are handled by the National Bank. All applications for imports have to be approved by the Ministry of Foreign Trade and the Ministry of Finance. Most foreign trade has been nationalized. Export trans- actions are subject to authorization granted by the Min- istry of Finance. Exchange control is administered by the National Bank. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are imposed on receipts or payments, but in principle the National Bank provides and accepts only U.S. dollars, French francs, deutsche mark, pounds sterling, and Swiss francs. Imports and Import Payments Only essential imports are permitted, based on need and the availability of funds. Imports of all other goods are effectively prohibited. No foreign exchange is released for nongovernmental transactions. There is no approved list of imports, but priority is given to agricul- 1 From May 1, 1978, a unitary rate of KL 400 per US$1 is applied to all transactions. aThe kip of liberation replaced the Lao kip on June 15, 1976 at the rate of KL 1 = K 20. tural equipment, Pharmaceuticals, and basic consumer goods of primary necessity. Payments for Invisibles There is a foreign exchange budget detailing the Gov- ernment's payments in foreign exchange during the fiscal year; for such payments the National Bank makes exchange available at the official rate. Payments for all other invisibles are subject to prior authorization by the Ministry of Finance. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of gold and silver are prohibited, except when made by or on behalf of the monetary authorities. All other exports are subject to authorization. The fu ll pro- ceeds from all exports must be surrendered to the National Bank. An official agency, the Societe Nationale d'Exportation et d'Importation, is the sole exporter. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange converted by foreign embassies, missions, representatives, and institutions to cover their official expenses in the Lao People's Democratic Repub- lic must be surrendered, as must all other receipts f rom invisibles. Capital There is no foreign investment code. All outward capital transactions are prohibited. Gold With the exception of the monetary authorities, resi- dents are prohibited from buying or selling gold in any form. Changes during 1977 September 19. The Lao Bank for Foreign Trade announced that with immediate effect exchange pre- miums of 100 per cent and 150 per cent would be given to sales of foreign exchange by foreign diplomatic mis- sions and international organizations for amounts under US$1,000 and over US$1,000, respectively. 255 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LEBANON (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The currency of Lebanon is the Lebanese Pound. All exchange transactions including those in clearing dollars, take place at the free market rate, which for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1977 was LL3.00 per US$1. There also exists a "moving parity" used for the calcu- lation of duties and taxes levied on amounts invoiced or expressed in foreign currency, particularly customs duties. There are no restrictions on foreign payments. Prescription of Currency No restrictions are imposed on exchange payments abroad or receipts in Lebanon. Some transactions with certain countries with which Lebanon has payments agreements 1 specifying the method or channel of pay- ment may be made through specific accounts denomi- nated in U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few goods (mainly arms and ammuni- tion, narcotics, and similar products) are either pro- hibited or reserved for the Government. All imports f rom Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Imports of wheat and wheat derivatives, as well as of certain agri- cultural products that are produced locally, are either prohibited year-round or du r ing a specified period of the year. The former group includes wheat, which may in principle be imported only by the State, and citrus fruits, apples, olives (excluding canned olives weighing less than 2 kilograms) and peanuts; the latter group of products consists of squash, eggplant, green beans, watermelons, pears, peaches, and apricots. Imports of certain other agricultural products and all seeds require a license. Import licenses are also required for certain finished goods, sanitary ceramic wares, and copper elec- tric and telephone wires and cables. All other commodi- ties may be imported freely without license. Exchange to pay for imports may be obtained freely through the free market. A municipalities tax of 3.5 per cent is levied on the value of all goods imported, except those originating in an Arab country. A stamp tax is appli- cable to all imports except gold and banknotes at the following rates: LL 2 per LL 1,000 for import values up to LL 100,000, LL1.5 per LL 1,000 for import values between LL 100,000 and LL 400,000, and LL 1 per LL 1,000 for import values exceeding LL 400,000. A surcharge of 10 per cent of the applicable import duty is levied on specified textiles and garments. Import surcharges are also levied on motor vehicles, jewelry, watches, and alcoholic beverages. The rates of sur- charge on motor vehicles, based on weight, are 20 piastres a kilogram up to 1,500 kilograms; 30 piastres 1 Czechoslovakia, Egypt, and Poland. There are also inoperative payments agreements with Guinea and Romania. 256 a kilogram between 1,500 kilograms and 2,000 kilo- grams; and 40 piastres a kilogram for vehicles over 2,000 kilograms. The rate of surcharge on watches and jewelry is 5 per cent and that on alcoholic beverages is LL4 a liter (or LL 145 for a case of whisky containing 12 bottles). Payments for Invisibles No restrictions are placed on payments for invisibles. Exchange may be obtained freely through the free market. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain goods (mainly arms and ammuni- tion, narcotics, and similar products) to any destination, and all exports to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports of rice, as well as of wheat and its derivatives, to any country, and all exports to North Korea require a license. Exchange receipts from exports may be retained, used, or sold freely in the free market. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles may be retained, used, or sold freely in the free market. Capital There are no limitations on capital payments or re- ceipts. Exchange may be obtained or sold freely through the free market. Banks are prohibited from paying interest on nonresident-held deposits denominated in Lebanese pounds. They have been requested not to extend credit in Lebanese pounds to nonresidents unless this serves to finance foreign trade transactions. Banks' foreign currency credits to residents are subject to deposit requirements, and their net foreign currency positions (claims and liabilities separately) are subject to limitation. Under a "free zone" banking facility, the commercial banks are exempt from reserve require- ments and fees for deposit insurance in respect of for- eign currency deposits of nonresidents. Under a National Investment Insurance Scheme, new foreign investments are insured against losses arising f rom noncivil risks, including war. Compensation is paid on losses exceeding 5 per cent of the insured value. Gold Residents may freely hold gold in any form at home or abroad and may freely negotiate gold in any form with residents and nonresidents at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form are freely permitted and do not require a license but must be officially recorded. The import, export, and domestic sale of foreign gold coins must be covered by a certifi- cate indicating the gold content and weight, issued by the Office for the Protection of the Consumer. ©International Monetary Fund. Under this legislation, new investments (fore ign and domestic) would be insured against losses arising f rom noncivil risks, including war. April 1. LEBANON 257 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LESOTHO (Position on December 31,1977) Exchange Rate System Lesotho's currency is the South African Rand. The par value of the rand is 1.04550 grams of fine gold per rand. The South African Reserve Bank on December 31, 1977 quoted a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.1500 per R l. Exchange rates for other cur- rencies are based on the South African Reserve Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar against the rand and the London market rates for the currencies concerned against the U.S. dollar. Exchange Control Territory Lesotho forms part of the Rand Monetary Area, which is a single exchange control territory comprising Lesotho, South Africa, and Swaziland. No restrictions are applied to payments within the Rand Monetary Area; these are uncontrolled and unrecorded. In relation to countries outside the Rand Monetary Area, Lesotho applies ex- change controls that are similar to those of South Africa and Swaziland. Administration of Control The Commissioner of Financial Institutions in the Ministry of Finance controls all external currency trans- actions. Lesotho's trade licensing arrangements are designed mainly to raise revenue and to prevent tax eva- sion; permits are issued by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. Licenses for financial institutions and insurance agents are issued by the Commissioner of Financial Institutions. Imports and Import Payments Lesotho is a member of a customs union w i th Bo- tswana, South Africa, and Swaziland, and there are no import restrictions on goods originating in any country of the customs union. Imports from South Africa do not require licenses and include an unknown quantity of goods originating outside the customs union; imports from countries of the customs union are recorded, how- ever, for statistical purposes. Insofar as Lesotho imports goods direct from countries outside the customs union, such imports are usually licensed in conformity with South Africa's import regulations; Lesotho, however, reserves the right to restrict certain imports. Import permits are valid for all countries and entitle the holder to buy the foreign exchange required to make the import payment upon customs entry. There are no bilateral payments arrangements. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments to nonresidents for current transactions, although subject to control, are not normally restricted. Authority to approve some types of current payments has been delegated to authorized dealers up to estab- lished limits, such as the basic exchange allowance for 258 tourist travel (the equivalent of R 2,000 in a calendar year for an adult and R 800 for a child) and a smaller annual allocation for travel to neighboring countries. Certain tax incentives for inward direct investment are provided by the Pioneer Industries Encouragement Act, 1969, to manufac tur ing activities approved by a Pioneer Industries Board. Capital Applications for outward transfers of capital are con- sidered on their merits. The rulings on applications for inward and outward capital transfers may depend on whether the applicant is a temporarily resident foreign national, a nonresident, or a resident. Emigrant families whose net assets do not exceed R 20,000 may transfer R 10,000 outside Lesotho as a settling-in allowance, and those with larger assets may transfer 50 per cent of the total, up to R 30,000 for a fam i ly or R 10,000 for an individual. Any excess must be credited to a Blocked Account although emigrants may use such blocked funds up to an amount of R 30,000 a fam i ly or R 10,000 a single person to subscribe to non- resident bonds. The free transfer of income from an emigrant's blocked assets is limited to an annual maxi- mum of R 100,000 a fam i ly unit. An emigrant family or a person may export only one automobile, with a maxi- mum value of R 10,000, provided the automobile was purchased at least one year prior to emigration. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold coins that are legal tender. Changes during 1977 March 31. Three changes were made in the control of transfers of money by emigrants: (1) Whereas an unmarried emigrant previously received a settling-in allowance equal to that of a family unit, the allowance for a single person was reduced to a maximum of R 10,000, and a further R 10,000 might be invested in nonresident bonds. Also, donations received by emi- grants during the three years preceding their date of emigration were excluded from their total assets for the purpose of calculating their settling-in allowance. (2) The free transfer of income derived from an emigrant's blocked assets and /or from a trust fund in Lesotho was limited to a maximum of R 100,000 a fam i ly unit a year. (3) An emigrant family or a person may export only one automobile, with a maximum value of R 10,000, provided the automobile had been purchased at least one year prior to emigration. March 31. Nonresident beneficiaries of Lesotho lega- cies would no longer be able to freely transfer R 20,000 for each beneficiary; instead, legacies would be subject to the restrictions applicable to securities rand. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBERIA (Position on December 31,1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.736662 gram of fine gold per Liberian Dollar, and the parity rate for the U.S. dollar is $1 = US$1. U.S. currency is legal tender in Liberia and circulates along with Liberian coinage. There is no exchange control and there are no restrictions on foreign exchange transactions. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Settlements with the Central Bank of West Afr ican States (for Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta) and The Gambia, Ghana, Mali, Nigeria, and Sierra Leone are no rma l ly made through the West African Clearing House. Imports and Import Payments There is no general system of import control. A few items (e.g., arms and ammun i t ion, explosives, used clothing, and Pharmaceuticals) require prior licenses. Orders for the importation of paints, toilet tissues, paper napkins, and kitchen towels are channeled through the Ministry of Commerce, Industry, and Transportation which must approve such imports. Imports of cement are not being licensed. Also, imports of certain goods (e.g., pornographic literature, narcotics other than for medicinal purposes) and all imports from Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. In practice, petroleum is imported only by the Liberian Re f in ing Company. Exports and Export Payments Exports to Rhodesia and South Afr ica are prohibited. Export licenses are required for precious metals, precious stones, ivory, agricultural products other than rubber, and certain other items, such as arms and ammun i t ion and explosives. Licenses are generally issued freely and no licenses are required for direct exports by foreign concession holders; licenses serve mainly to enforce taxa- tion or, for agricultural products, to assure certification of quality and origin and to safeguard the export monop- oly of the Liberian Produce Marketing Corporation. The surrender of export proceeds is not required, and exchange receipts are freely disposable. An export tax is levied on diamonds. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles There are no limitations on payments for or receipts from invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents. Under an Investment Incentive Code of 1966 (as amended in 1973), enterprises undertaking new invest- ment projects may be granted a five-year 90 per cent duty exemption on imports of raw materials and ma- chinery, total tax exemption on reinvested profits, a 50 per cent exemption on distributable profits, and a protec- tive tariff on competing imported products. The five- year incentive may be renewed for a fu r ther two years in certain circumstances. Gold Residents may freely and without license purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form are subject to licenses issued by the Minister of Lands and Mines; import licenses are issued freely but export licenses are granted restrictively. Changes during 1977 April 25. The Government announced measures to control the importation of toilet tissues, paper napkins, and kitchen towels. In fu tu re, orders should be chan- neled through the Ministry of Commerce, Industry, and Transportation. April 26. The Ministry of Commerce, Industry, and Transportation announced that paints would be sub- pected to import control. All orders were to be channeled through the Ministry. October 7. As a result of the harmonization of cus- toms duties with Sierra Leone under the Mano River Union, new customs tariff regulations were issued amend- ing the rates of duty payable on almost all items. In general, tariff rates were increased. 259 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SOCIALIST PEOPLE'S LIBYAN ARAB JAMAHIRIYA (Position on December 31, 2977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.48828 grams of fine gold per Libyan Dinar. The parity for the U.S. dollar, the inter- vention currency, is LD 0.296053 = US$1, and the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya avails itself of wider margins. The Central Bank of Libya publishes daily buying and selling rates for 15 currencies.1 It deals with commer- cial banks only in pounds sterling and U.S. dollars, at rates fixed daily. The Central Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1977 were LD 0.29531 buying, and LD 0.29679 selling, per US$1; for the pound ster- ling the rates were LD 0.56475 buying, and LD 0.56759 selling, per £ stg. 1. The commercial banks are permitted to buy or sell other currencies against pounds sterling and U.S. dollars through their foreign correspondents. The banks may not deal among themselves in foreign currencies. Neither authorized banks nor importers or exporters are allowed to enter into forward commitments in foreign currencies. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Central Bank, which has delegated some of its powers to the authorized banks. Policy relating to import and export licensing is determined by the Secretariat of Trade, which also issues import and export licenses; for certain imports the approval of another Secretariat (Interior, Health, or Agriculture and Agrarian Reform) is required. Foreign trade has largely been nationalized (see section on Imports and Import Payments, below). Prescription of Currency Settlements with other countries are made in convert- ible currencies, usually U.S. dollars or pounds sterling. All settlements with Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts A nonresident, as defined by the Central Bank, who is gainfully employed in the country is permitted under the existing exchange control regulations to open and maintain a nonresident account in Libyan dinars with any authorized bank. Legitimate earnings of such non- residents, including overtime payments, can be credited to their nonresident accounts. Similarly, authorized banks have authority to credit interest earned on bal- ances in these nonresident accounts. All other credits to nonresident accounts require the prior approval of the Central Bank. For debits on such accounts see sec- tion on Payments for Invisibles, below. 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Lebanese pounds, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, Tunisian dinars, and U.S. dollars. 260 Funds brought in by nonresident contractors under- taking contracts in their own names are required to be kept in "special resident accounts" with a bank. Pay- ments received by such contractors in respect of their contracts may also be credited to these accounts. Remit- tances from these accounts are subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank after submission of the prescribed evidence. Nonresident-owned capital that is not permitted to be transferred abroad is credited to blocked accounts. With the approval of the Central Bank, funds in blocked accounts (with certain exceptions) may be used for expenditures in the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya up to LD 500 a year to cover the cost of visits by the owner of the funds or a close relative; for payment of legal fees, taxes, etc.; for remittances to the owner of the funds in his country of permanent residence, up to LD 1,000 in a calendar year; and for remittances in cases of hardship. When the funds have been in a blocked account for five years, they qualify for remit- tance in full to the owner in his country of permanent residence. The blocked accounts of persons (with cer- tain exceptions) who have left the country permanently are being released in installments; balances credited prior to March 31, 1966 have been released. Imports and Import Payments Import transactions are governed by Law No. 64 of 1971, which stipulates that import and export activities for trading purposes shall be confined to Libyan nationals and to Libyan companies whose capital is wholly owned by Libyan nationals. Certain imports may be made under open general license. The import of some items, including alcoholic beverages and narcotics, is pro- hibited. Many imports are effected only by the appro- priate public sector companies and institutions.2 The work of commercial agents, including import agents, for the following goods and services is reserved for specified government agencies and joint stock com- panies: cement, iron, wood, and lime used in construc- tion; concentrated fodder and fertilizers; livestock and meat; financial, banking and air travel services; repair and maintenance of docks; and information, publica- tion, and advertising. The Central Bank has a monopoly over the import of unworked gold. All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. The Government exercises direct control over certain imports from various countries. 2 These include petroleum and petroleum products, motor vehicles, telecommunications equipment, certain electrical equipment and parts, batteries, agricultural machinery, paving machinery and equipment, cinematographic films, prepared fodder, lime, certain insecticides, medical equipment and supplies, Pharmaceuticals, footwear, cotton textiles, threads, soaps, detergents, tobacco, cigars, cigarettes, cigarette paper, sugar, salt, tea, rice, barley, wheat, flour, coarse legumes, tomato paste, fresh fruit, canned fish, livestock, meat, dried and con- centrated milk, coffee and its products, cocoa, and natural and vege- table fats. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Exchange permits required for imports are readily granted by the authorized banks, provided that there is a firm contract and any necessary import license has been obtained and, if the import is to be made on a letter of credit basis, that a marine insurance policy from an insurance company in the Libyan Arab Jama- hiriya is submitted before the letter of credit is estab- lished. However, no letter of credit in respect of the import of consumer durable goods may be opened by an authorized bank without obtaining a cash margin of 25 per cent of the import price. Importers must present to the bank granting the exchange permit, within two months of customs clearance, a customs declaration confirming clearance and stating the valuation. The approval of the Exchange Control Department of the Central Bank is required for advance payments. De- ferred payments (for up to 90 days after customs clear- ance) and payments for consignment shipments may be approved by the authorized banks. Imports are subject to customs duty and to customs surcharges totaling 15 per cent of the applicable customs duty. Payments for Invisibles The authorized banks are empowered to approve applications by residents to remit foreign exchange up to LD 100 in a calendar year for meeting genuine per- sonal commitments abroad of a noncommercial nature, including family assistance and gifts. They may also approve allocations for travel as indicated below, as well as transfers abroad to residents undertaking studies abroad, of foreign exchange for maintenance, up to limits prescribed for various countries, plus tuition fees, an allowance for books, etc. Remittances from nonresi- dent accounts maintained by nonresident workers and technicians may be approved by authorized banks up to 60 per cent of net salary each month; for those workers whose contracts specify that lodging and /or board will be made available free of charge by the employer, remittances up to 90 per cent of net salary are permitted. A nonresident wife or the wife of a non- resident, when employed in the country, are each per- mitted to remit abroad up to 90 per cent of net salary each month. Banks may issue travelers checks and for- eign currency notes to nonresident workers and techni- cians within the limits mentioned. Applications for amounts in excess of these limits must be submitted to the Central Bank. Such nonresidents may take with them when going abroad on vacation or on final depar- ture certain goods, the value of which is not deducted from the balances in their nonresident accounts; a non- resident may also export one automobile during his stay in the country. All other payments for invisibles, as well as payments in excess of the approval authority dele- gated to the banks, require prior approval from the Cen- tral Bank. Applications are considered on their merits. LIBYAN ARAB JAMAHIRIYA Persons leaving the country may take with them Libyan currency notes not exceeding a total of LD 20 (LD 10 for children under 12); these may not be spent or exchanged outside the country, but are intended for immediate expenses upon return. Residents leaving for personal travel abroad, including tourist travel may, in addition, take out foreign exchange in the form of for- eign currency notes, travelers checks, and letters of credit not exceeding a total value of LD 300 (LD 150 for children under 12) in a calendar year as a basic travel allowance; the exchange may be obtained from any authorized bank in the Libyan Arab Jamahiriya. Additional amounts may be granted in special circum- stances. During 1977 pilgrims were entitled to a special quota of LD 800 in addition to the basic travel allow- ance. For business travel, residents may take out the equivalent of LD 1,000 a trip, subject to a maximum of LD 2,500 in a calendar year. All fares may be settled in Libyan dinars. Temporary residents may take out any travelers checks or foreign currency notes which they had previously brought in and declared to the customs. Exports and Export Proceeds Export licenses are required only for fish, raw wool, hides and skins, and for commodities which are not of Libyan origin. Export proceeds must be received through an authorized bank within six months of ship- ment. Exports of nonmonetary gold (other than for processing abroad), vegetable oils, and scrap metals are prohibited; exports or re-exports of wheat, wheat flour, crushed wheat, barley, rice, tea, sugar, and maca- roni, which are subsidized commodities, are also pro- hibited. All exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange receipts from invisibles must be surrendered. Travelers checks or foreign currency notes may be cashed only at an authorized bank or at an exchange office licensed by the Central Bank. Travelers entering the country may bring with them Libyan currency notes, not exceeding LD 20, and other currency notes, travelers checks, letters of credit, securi- ties, coupons, and other negotiable instruments in unlim- ited amounts. Capital Under the provisions of Foreign Capital Investment Law No. 37 of July 31, 1968, foreign capital invested in projects deemed to contribute to the economic devel- opment of the country, as well as profits thereon, and salaries of foreign staff employed on such projects, may be transferred freely to the country of origin, provided that the paid-up capital is not less than LD 200,000 and that at least 51 per cent of the shares are held by foreign nationals. Foreign participation in industrial ventures set up after March 20, 1970 is permitted only 261 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution LIBYAN ARAB JAMAHIRIYA on a minority basis, and only if it leads to increased production in excess of local requirements, introduction of the latest technology, and cooperation with foreign firms in exporting the surplus production. Insurance companies and foreign shareholdings in banks have been nationalized. Commercial firms have been Libyanized in varying degrees and 51 per cent or more of the Libyan interests of the international oil companies have been nationalized. Real estate may be sold only to Libyans, other than in exceptional circumstances. The net sales proceeds a f ter tax of real estate belonging to foreign nationals are transferab le, subject to the prior approval of the Central Bank. Nonresident-owned capital that is not permitted to be transferred abroad is credited to blocked accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above ). Residents require the prior approval of the Central Bank to borrow funds abroad. As a rule, residents require prior permission to purchase real estate abroad or to invest abroad in securities. Residents taking up per- manent residence abroad are permitted to transfer up to LD 5,000 for a fam i ly; applications may be submitted for the release of the balance of their assets over a number of years. The investment of national capital abroad is governed by Law No. 25 of April 20, 1973. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form other than bars. The Central Bank has a monopoly over the import of unworked gold. It sells bars to domestic goldsmiths in limited quantities, to meet genuine commercial needs, at prices announced f rom time to time. Provided that a license is obtained from the Ministry of Economy, goldsmiths may have such gold processed abroad, after which it must be reimported. Bars purchased from the Central Bank must be melted and processed before they can be sold to the public. Exports of unworked gold not for proc- essing are not permitted unless made by or on behalf of the Government. Unworked gold is subject to an import duty of 15 per cent. The Central Bank quotes seven other currencies.1 Its buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1977 were FMG 234.07 and FMG 236.43, respectively, per US$1.
