Not for Redistribution MEXICO (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0589330 gram of fine gold per Mexican Peso. Since September 1, 1976 the exchange rate has not been maintained within announced margins. On December 31, 1977 the closing rates for the U.S. dollar, the intervention currency, were Mex$22.72 buy- ing, and Mex$22.73 selling, per US$1. Banks may freely engage in exchange transactions between the peso and any other currency. An exchange cover scheme is. avail- able for selected transactions; it is operated by the Bank of Mexico along the lines of a swap arrangement. On November 12, 1946, Mexico notified the Fund that it was prepared formally to accept the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Prescription of Currency There are no obligations prescribing the method or currency for payments to or from nonresidents. Jn accordance with payments agreements with Iran and Yugoslavia, payments for direct commercial transac- tions and related expenses with those countries handled through the Mexican banking system may, with the prior authorization of the Bank of Mexico, be made through special accounts denominated in U.S. dollars. Payments between Mexico and Argentina, Bolivia, Bra- zil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Paraguay, Peru, Uruguay, and Venezuela may be settled through accounts main- tained with each other by the Bank of Mexico and the central banks concerned, within the framework of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system. Similar arrange- ments exist for payments between Mexico and the Dominican Republic and between Mexico and Cuba. Payments to Costa Rica, El Salvador, Guatemala, Hon- duras, and Nicaragua in respect of trade and invisibles may be settled in U.S. dollars in accordance with a reciprocal credit agreement between the central banks of those countries. Imports and Import Payments Payments and transfers abroad may be made freely. A few imports are prohibited. All imports must be accompanied by an exporter's declaration of shipment. For some goods, irrespective of origin, import licenses from the Ministry of Commerce are required before firm orders are placed; the issuance of such licenses may be subject to quantitative restriction. For specified com- modities, "open end" import licenses (permisos abiertos) may be granted that permit limited importation during a specified period of time, such as six months or a year; subject to screening of the importer's performance, repeated renewal of the license is possible. Applications for import licenses are screened by the Ministry of Com- merce with the aid of committees composed of import- ers, producers, and consumers. Import licenses for certain goods, including leather goods, alcoholic beverages, cigarettes, and automobiles and their spare parts, are subject to an overall annual limit. Imports of certain goods for which licenses from the Ministry of Commerce are required (such as unas- sembled automobiles and trucks, iron and steel pipes, firearms, watches, synthetic fibers, some types of jewelry, radio and television sets, and alcoholic beverages) are subject to the payment of a fee of usually between 1 per cent and 6 per cent of the value of the import trans- action, the proceeds of which are allocated to a fund handled by the Mexican Foreign Trade Institute (IMCE) for the promotion of exports.. For a small number of luxury items, no licenses are granted. Imports by offi- cial Mexican agencies are subject to prior approval by IMCE af ter screening by the Institute's Import Commit- tee of the Public Sector (CISP); this approval is not given if a reasonably competitive domestic equivalent is available at a price differential of 15-20 per cent. Vir- tually all imports are subject to an import surcharge of 2 per cent ad valorem, the proceeds of which accrue to an export trust fund established with the Bank of Mexico. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are not restricted. The con- tracting of insurance for persons in Mexico, or on prop- erty of Mexican ownership, or where the risks are for the account of persons in Mexico or may occur in Mexico, is permitted only with Mexican companies or with branches of foreign companies established in Mexico in accordance with Mexican law. Exports and Export Proceeds Certain exports require licenses. No exchange con- trol requirements apply to export proceeds. Rebates of indirect taxes by means of a system of CEDIS (certifi- cados de devolucion de impuestos) are granted on ex- ports of certain manufactured and semimanufactured products (and of certain services). Proceeds from Invisibles No exchange control requirements apply to proceeds from invisibles. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresi- dents. New foreign investment in the capital of Mexican banking or insurance companies and investment funds is prohibited. Certain sectors, such as petroleum, basic petrochemical production, radioactive minerals, electric- ity and nuclear energy, certain mining activities, rail- roads, and telecommunications, are reserved to govern- ment investment. Investment in a number of activities is reserved exclusively for Mexican individuals or cor- 281 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MEXICO porations (rad io and television, the public transpor ta t ion system, forestry, etc., as well as any other areas specified by the Federal Gove rnmen t ), while new investments in other sectors must have a ma jo r i ty participation of Mexican capital. Foreign investments in Mexico must be registered with the Na t ional Foreign Investment Register in the M in is try of Commerce. Applications by foreign na tu ral or jur id ical persons to acquire more than 25 per cent of the capital of a Mexican company require the prior authorization of the appropriate minis- try, a f ter the Na t ional Foreign Investment Commission has granted the necessary registration. All acquisitions of stock in Mexican companies by foreigners must be registered w i th in 30 days with the Na t ional Foreign Investors Registry. Borrowing abroad (or w i th in Mexico in foreign cu r rency) by the public sector and by state- owned banks is subject to approval by the M in is t ry of Finance and Public Credit. Borrowing abroad by pri- va te banks is subject to certain requirements imposed by the Bank of Mexico; these banks are perm i t ted to accept foreign currency denominated deposits f rom resi- dents as well as nonresidents. Only investment banks are allowed to accept time deposits in U.S. dollars. On March 22, 1977 the net yield on such deposits was fixed at 1 percentage point above the corresponding Eurodol- lar rate in London. There is a 15 per cent tax on sales of newly mined gold. Producers of gold unde r tak ing not to sell it at prices exceeding in terna t ional quotations plus normal marke t ing costs are eligible for an automatic subsidy of up to 100 per cent of the tax, when selling newly mined gold in Mexico to private banks or to gold- smiths or manu fac tu re rs in Mexico. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.175610 gram of fine gold per Moroccan Dirham. The Bank of Morocco quotes daily buying and selling rates for the French franc; its rates for the f ranc are determined in the light of quotations for certain major currencies on the exchange market in Paris and taking into account the geographic distribu- tion of Morocco's foreign trade transactions. The Bank of Morocco also quotes buying and selling rates for spe- cified "convertible currencies," l based on quotations in the leading foreign exchange markets abroad and the Bank of Morocco's daily quotation for the French franc. In addition, the Bank quotes daily buying and selling rates for the Tunisian dinar. The rates of the Bank of Morocco for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1977 were DH 4.3149 buying, and DH 4.3390 selling, per US$1 and those for the French f ranc were DH 0.91828 buying, and DH 0.92104 selling, per F 1. All sales and purchases of foreign currency are cen- tralized in the Bank of Morocco, but the authorized banks are permitted to offset purchases and sales on behalf of private customers in each currency separately. The authorized banks must purchase f rom or sell to the Bank of Morocco each day the balances of their pur- chases and sales in each currency; transactions are effected at rates fixed by the Bank. Compensation between banks is not permitted so that no foreign exchange market exists in Morocco. The Bank of Morocco also establishes buying and selling rates for transactions with travelers in banknotes, travelers checks, and letters of credit expressed in French francs, CFA francs, the "convertible currencies," and specified other currencies; 2 the authorized banks sell to the Bank of Morocco their excess holdings of banknotes and replen- ish them at the Bank when necessary. Forward exchange transactions are not permitted. Foreign currency repatriated in the fo rm of transfers to a bank or postal account by Moroccan workers abroad is eligible for a premium of 5 per cent payable on the dirham equivalent. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Exchange Office, an agency under the Ministry of Finance. This Office has delegated the execution of certain exchange control measures to authorized banks. Import certifi- cates and export licenses are issued by the M in is t ry of Commerce; they must be countersigned by the Exchange 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian f rancs, Canad ian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, Italian lire, Netherlands gu i lders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds s ter l ing, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 Finnish markkaa, Iranian rials, Kuwa i ti d ina rs, Lebanese pounds, Libyan dinars, Saudi Arabian riyals, and U.A.E. d irhams. Libyan dinars are traded only by the agencies of the Bank of Morocco. Office. Import commitments for liberalized goods are signed by the importer himself; they do not require the visa of the Exchange Office unless the country of origin of the goods is not the country of shipment, or the goods are bought on a c.i.f. basis. A part of the port of Tangier is designated as a free trade zone and is exempt f rom taxation and from trade, customs, and exchange control. Although Morocco's regulations still make a distinc- tion between the French Franc Area and the area of convertibility, Morocco applies exchange control also to transactions with the former.3 Prescription of Currency For prescription of currency purposes, countries are classified as follows: (1) the French Franc Area coun- tries; (2) the payments agreement group, comprising countries with which Morocco maintains bilateral pay- ments agreements;4 and (3) all other countries, the "area of convertibility." Settlements with the French Franc Area are made in French francs or, with the exception of settlements for imports, in dirhams through French Franc Area Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, below); certain noncommercial settlements with Algeria, how- ever, are made in dirhams or Algerian dinars through special accounts at the two central banks, and all settle- ments with Tunisia are made through accounts denomi- nated in convertible dirhams or Tunisian convertible dinars. Settlements with the payments agreement group are made through the payments agreement accounts. Imports originating in countries in the area of converti- bility may be paid for only in "convertible currencies" negotiated by the Bank of Morocco.5 Other settlements with countries in the area of convertibility may be made only in "convertible currencies" negotiated by the Bank of Morocco or through Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams. Nonresident Accounts The various types of nonresident accounts are as follows: 1. French Franc Area Accounts are held in Moroccan currency in the names of residents of countries of the French Franc Area. These accounts may be used for settlements w i th residents of countries in the French Franc Area, except for the payment for imports (and 3 Since February 1967, France has applied to Morocco its controls on foreign investments in France and on French investments abroad. The exchange controls imposed by France on November 25, 1968 in its financial relations with foreign countries are applied also to Morocco. 4 Gu inea, Mali, and U.S.S.R. The agreement with Mali is inopera- tive. 5 Until f u r t h er notice, special regulations apply to payments for imports of Egyptian origin; 40 per cent of such payments must be e f fec ted th rough the account established under the terminated bilateral paymen ts agreement and 60 per cent in "convertible currencies." 283 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO related invisibles) from those countries.6 They may be freely credited with and debited for sales or purchases of French francs (except banknotes) sold to or bought from the Bank of Morocco. Transfers between French Franc Area Accounts may be made freely. 2. Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are reserved for residents of countries in the area of con- vertibility. These accounts may be credited freely with authorized payments due to residents of countries in the area of convertibility (but not in respect of imports or related invisibles) and with dirhams obtained f rom the sale to the Bank of Morocco of "convertible currencies" negotiated by it, excluding banknotes. They may be debited freely for payments in Morocco and for pur- chases from the Bank of Morocco of "convertible cur- rencies." Transfers between Foreign Accounts in Con- vertible Dirhams may be made freely. 3. Payments Agreement Accounts are held by the Bank of Morocco for central banks (or similar institu- tions) of the countries with which Morocco ma in ta ins bilateral payments agreements (see footnote 4 ); they are used only for settlements w i th these countries, including settlements for imports and exports. 4. Capital Accounts, which may be held by any non- resident, are credited with funds that may not be trans- ferred abroad. These include the proceeds f rom the sale on the Casablanca Stock Exchange of Moroccan securities and proceeds from the contractual or acceler- ated redemption of such securities. Transfers between Capital Accounts related to countries either in the area of convertibility or the French Franc Area, or the same country in the payments agreement group, are per- mitted freely. Capital Accounts may be debited freely for purchases of specified government bonds and for personal expenses of the account holder and his immediate relatives dur ing visits to Morocco, up to DH 150 a person a day, subject to a limit of DH 5,000 a year for each account. All other operations through Capital Accounts require indi- vidual approval. 5. Suspense Accounts are used for holding nonresi- dent funds not available for credit to any of the accounts mentioned above. Balances on these accounts may be used freely to pay taxes due in Morocco, but all other debits to these accounts require approval. 6. Two Foreign Accounts in Convertible Dirhams are held by the Bank of Morocco for the Central Bank of Algeria and the Central Bank of Tunisia. Only cer- tain noncommercial transactions between Morocco and Algeria are settled through the account opened in the name of the Central Bank of Algeria. 6 Imports from the French Franc Area, unless covered by special credit arrangements, must be paid for with French francs purchased f rom the Bank of Morocco. 284 Imports and Import Payments Imports are admitted in accordance with an annual General Import Program, divided into three categories and applicable to all countries, with the exception of Rhodesia from which all imports are prohibited. Goods in List A may be imported freely. Goods in List B are restricted, in some cases by a global quota, or are sub- ject to state trad ing; for a large number of List B items, no quotas are established, and imports are approved according to need, licenses usually being issued upon application (SB items). In principle, the importation of goods in List C is not permitted; among the items on this list are certain motor vehicles, certain precious metals, and gold jewelry. To import goods in List A, the importer signs an import commitment (engagement d importation), which does not require administrative approval unless the goods are imported f rom a country other than that of origin or are purchased on a c.i.f. basis,7 but for goods in List B, an import certificate (autorisation d'importation or certificat d'importation) must be obtained. Wheat, sugar, tea, and fertilizers are imported by official agencies. For all imports the import title —import certificate or import commitment —must be domiciled (registered) with an authorized bank, which may make payments upon submission of the required documents. Import certificates require the visa of the Exchange Office before the foreign exchange is made available. Import commitments require this visa only when the country of origin and the country of shipment of the goods con- cerned differ or when imports are contracted for on a c.i.f. basis. Import certificates must be domiciled within 15 days f rom the date that the Exchange Office approves the license. Import commitments must be domiciled at the time of their subscription. Special procedures are applicable to specified imports financed by foreign aid or loans. Most imports from countries in the payments agree- ment group are made in accordance with quotas estab- lished in the respective trade agreements. Imports can also be licensed under compensation transactions. Payments for Invisibles Payments for most current invisibles require the approval of the Exchange Office, but in several instances the approval authority has been delegated to the banks. The authorized banks are permitted to make payments and settle expenses incidental to the commercial trans- action covered by the relevant import or export docu- ments. Earnings after tax on approved nonresident investments in Morocco are transferable to the investor's country of residence. The transfer of dividends on non- resident-owned shares of Moroccan companies having their ma in office in Morocco requires the approval of the Exchange Office. Undistributed profits relating to 7 C.i.f. imports of List A goods require prior exchange control approval. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution the financial year 1968 or later remain transferable indefinitely. Some payments are subject to limitations. A foreign employee may transfer to his country of origin, subject to the initial approval of the Exchange Office, 50 per cent of his monthly wages or salary if his fam i ly does not reside in Morocco, or 30 per cent if he is single or his fam i ly lives in Morocco,8 except for the medical and paramedical professions, such transfers are subject to a limit of DH 1,000 a month. Subject to a monthly limit of DH 300, the same percentages of earnings may also be transferred by foreign nationals engaged in agricul- tural, industrial, or commercial activities, or in skilled crafts. Foreign nationals employed in the hotel sector or the mining sector are authorized to transfer between 60 and 80 per cent of their monthly salaries or wages. An allocation of foreign exchange equivalent to DH 100 a person a year is granted to residents of any nationality for travel abroad, provided that they do not make peri- odic transfers abroad. There is a special allocation for pilgrimages. Residents of foreign nationality may acquire exchange for tourist travel up to the equivalent of DH 2,500 a year for each passport by selling to an authorized bank a corresponding amount in foreign exchange (other than banknotes) from their own for- eign assets not subject to surrender requirements. For business travel by persons other than exporters a standard allowance of DH 250 a day is granted, up to DH 5,000 a person a trip and within an annual ceil- ing fixed individually by the Exchange Office; exporters may obtain up to DH 300 a day, up to DH 7,500 a person a trip, within a ceiling of 3 per cent of the for- eign exchange repatriated during the preceding calendar year. The allocation issued for business travel may be added to the allocation issued for tourist travel. Moroc- can students pursuing higher studies abroad may obtain monthly allocations of foreign exchange up to DH 1,000 for students in higher education who do not hold scholar- ships, and of DH 1,500 for doctoral students who do not hold scholarships. There is also a quarterly allocation of DH 1,000 as a supplement for scholarship students. Students are granted an annual installation allowance, fixed at DH 2,000. For family maintenance, the Exchange Office grants a monthly allocation generally of DH 300. The export of Moroccan banknotes is prohibited. Exports and Export Proceeds Most exports may be made freely, although export licenses are required for a few items, and exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. All fruits, fresh vegetables, canned goods, raw cotton, and cotton by-products may be exported only by a state trading agency, the Office of Marketing and Export (Office de Commercialisation et 8 For all wages and salaries of the private sector, from August 1977 monthly transfers which exceed by more than DH 150 the amount transferred in June 1977 require prior authorization by the Exchange Office. (Previously, the authorized excess amount was DH 100.) MOROCCO d'Exportation —OCE) which is also in charge of wine exports. All exporters must sign an undertaking to repatriate and surrender foreign exchange proceeds. The surrender to the exporter's bank must take place within one month from the date the payment is due. The date on which the payment is due is the maturity date fixed in the commercial contract; this date must not be set, in prin- ciple, more than 90 days after the date of arrival of the merchandise at the place of destination. When the exporter's bank receives the advice of credit in foreign currency from abroad, it must surrender the foreign exchange immediately to the Bank of Morocco. Proceeds from Invisibles Residents of Moroccan nationality and Moroccan companies must repatriate exchange receipts accruing from all their noncommercial claims and surrender them to an authorized bank. Other residents must surrender noncommercial receipts only if the receipts result f rom current transactions, and only when they accrue in for- eign currencies other than those of the French Franc Area. Moroccans working abroad must surrender such currencies within one month of re-entry, but are per- mitted, when leaving again, to repurchase 15 per cent of the amount surrendered (the currencies so purchased may also include French f r an c s ); they are entitled to a bonus of 5 per cent on the dirham equivalent of any foreign exchange repatriated in the form of transfers to a bank or a postal account. The importation of Moroc- can banknotes is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may freely bring in foreign banknotes; imports of foreign currency brought in in excess of the equivalent of DH 5,000 must, however, be declared to the customs authorities. Resident travelers also may bring in any amount in foreign banknotes, but these must be sur- rendered within 30 days of re-entry. Capital Residents of Moroccan nationality, as well as com- panies established in Morocco, are obliged to declare to the Exchange Office all foreign-held assets exceeding DH 250, and to repatriate and surrender certain of these assets. The disposal of other foreign-held assets requires permission. The transfer of capital abroad by residents must be approved. Remittances in respect of the assets of emigrants and transfers of gifts are not normally approved, nor is investment by private individuals in foreign securities or real estate. Exchange allocations for the transfer of inheritances are limited to DH 35,000 a beneficiary. Transfers of assets by persons re turn ing to their own country vary with the length of their stay in Morocco, f rom DH 35,000 a fam i ly with fam i ly resi- dence of 3 to 5 years to DH 250,000 a fam i ly where the period of residence has been 15 years or more. New foreign investments in specified sectors of the economy may benefit f rom the provisions of the Invest- 285 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution MOROCCO ment Code of August 15, 1973. The Code provides various tax concessions and other incentives. It guaran- tees the transfer of dividends distributed to nonresidents and of proceeds from the liquidation of the capital brought in by the foreign investor. Investments financed with funds held in Capital Accounts (see below) also are eligible for the benefits of the Code; proceeds f rom the liquidation of investments financed in this manner become transferable after a m in imum investment period of 5 years. Foreign investments approved under the previous Investment Code (of February 10, 1961) continue to benefit from the retransfer guarantee for the liquidation proceeds. Proceeds from the liquidation of other invest- ments are credited to Capital Accounts. Operations through Capital Accounts that may be effected with approval include purchases on the Casa- blanca Stock Exchange of Moroccan and non-Moroccan securities; purchases of Moroccan securities not quoted on the Casablanca Stock Exchange or of participation in a Moroccan firm; subscriptions to either; investments of any kind, including purchases of businesses or office buildings; lending to residents; payment of local expenses in excess of DH 5,000 du r ing the account holder's stay in Morocco; any such payments to beneficiaries other than the holder of the account or a close relative; any such payments from an account held by a foreign jur id i- cal person; gifts to social, cultural, or religious institu- tions; subscriptions to capital increases of Moroccan companies whose shares are quoted on the Casablanca Stock Exchange; subscriptions at the time of issue to long-term or short-term securities with a fixed yield issued by a Moroccan public entity; custody charges and commissions on securities; and payment of the costs of maintenance, repairs, real estate taxes, and insurance on real estate located in Morocco. Subject to approval, Capital Accounts may also be debited for investments in Morocco, within the framework of the 1973 Invest- ment Code, provided that the amounts debited do not exceed 50 per cent of the investment under taken by the nonresident and 25 per cent of the company's total capital. Balances held in "original" Capital Accounts by non- resident persons of foreign nationality and not exceeding DH 10,000 on May 31, 1975 have been declared trans- ferable abroad as follows, subject to prior authoriza- tion by the Exchange Office: balances not exceeding DH 3,000, dur ing 1976; those between DH 3,001 and DH 7,000, dur ing the first half of 1977; and those between DH 7,001 and DH 10,000, during the second half of 1977. Certain government bonds acquired with funds f rom Capital Accounts are freely negotiable between nonresi- dents. These are 5.5 per cent, seven-year bonds on which interest and redemption proceeds are transferable. 286 All other transactions in securities involving nonresident interests, as well as the import and export of securities, require approval. Banks are permitted to engage in short-term borrowing abroad; they may accept con- vertible currency funds from nonresidents for credit to Special Deposit Accounts, provided that these funds are reinvested abroad in the same currency and for the same ma tur i ty period; the rate of interest paid by banks on deposits received must not exceed that received by them on the placing made for their account. Gold A commemorative gold coin with a face value of DH 250 has been issued, which is legal tender. Resi- dents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Morocco for num isma t ic or investment purposes. Ten different types of foreign gold coins are traded on the Casablanca Stock Exchange, which does not, however, deal in gold bars. Imports of gold are subject to authorization by the Directorate of Customs and Indirect Taxes. Every year the Ministry of Finance fixes a quota for the impor- tation of gold ingots, which is then allocated among jewelers and industrial users of precious metals. Gold jewelry is included in import list C. Exports of gold are prohibited. Changes during 1977 January. Notice to Importers No. 01-77 was pub- lished containing the General Import Program for 1977. Commodities listed under 18 tariff headings or sub- headings were shifted f rom the liberalized category (List A) to the restricted category (List B) that required licensing. However, no quota limits were set for the items moved to List B, and it was provided that they would be licensed in accordance with need. The items included organical chemical products, paper pulp, cer- tain electric cables, and motorcycles and bicycles im- ported in completely knocked-down condition. August 20. Following the imposition by the EEC of restrictions on imports of certain textiles f rom Morocco, commodities included under Chapters 50-62 of the Brussels Tariff Nomenclature (mainly textiles and textile fibers) were shifted f rom the unrestricted category (List A) to the licensed category (List B ). November 15. The annual exchange allocation for installation expenses for the benefit of Moroccan stu- dents abroad was raised f rom DH 1,000 to DH 2,000. The allocation for students in higher education who do not hold scholarships was raised from DH 834 a month to DH 1,000 a month; for doctoral students not holding scholarships the allocation was raised from DH 834 to DH 1,500 a month; for scholarship students, the allo- cation (in addition to the scholarship) was raised to DH 1,000 a quarter f rom DH 600 a quarter. ©International Monetary Fund. Residents may free ly purchase Ind ian rupees f rom Nepalese banks and they may hold any amount of Ind i an notes and coins, but the Ind ian rupee is not legal tender. Within Nepal there are 105 add i t ional authorized dealers licensed to purchase for- eign currencies; any sale of such currencies other than Indian rupees is subject to the prior approval of the Nepal Ras tra Bank. All import and export transactions w i th payments agreement countries, as well as all barter trade, are conducted through a state trading agency, the Na t ional Trading Ltd. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements apply to outgoing payments to countries with which no payments agreement is in force and these may be made in the foreign currency supplied by the Nepal Rastra Bank. Paymen ts to, and receipts from, other member countries of the Asian Clearing Union except India (Bangladesh, Bu rma, I ran, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka) in respect of cu r rent transactions (other than those re la t ing to petro- leum, na tu ral gas, and their products) may, but need not, be effected in Asian monetary units through the Asian Clearing Union. Payments for imports f rom Ind ia norma l ly are settled in Indian rupees, but the Nepal Ras tra Bank sometimes makes convertible cur- rencies available for such imports at the recommenda- tion of the M in is try of Finance. The proceeds of exports to India are obtained in Indian or Nepalese rupees; the proceeds of exports to other countries must be received in any of the convertible currencies quoted by the Nepal Rastra Bank. Nonresident Accounts The Nepal Rastra Bank permits nonresidents to open "convertible rupee accounts" with Nepalese banks; bal- ances on these accounts may be freely t rans fe r red abroad. Ind ian na t iona ls are allowed to open current accounts in Ind ian rupees w i th Nepalese banks. Foreign curren- cies brought into or received in Nepal by nonresidents, which are converted into Nepalese rupees and deposited w i th a Nepalese bank, may be reconverted for transfer out of the country, subject to prior permission of the Nepal Ras tra Bank. Imports and Import Payments All imports of goods except those originating in India require import licenses. Imports of vegetable oil, mar- garine, animal fa t, beef, woolen carpets, arms and ammun i t ion, explosives, chemicals to be used for explo- sives, and wireless transmitters are prohibited. Under the Trade and Transit Treaty, Nepal and India agreed to freedom of trade between themselves in Nepalese and Indian goods; Indian goods may in principle be imported freely (although some are subject to a permit system in order to prevent their re-exportation and cer- t a in others are subject to export ceilings in I n d i a ); reim- bursement of tax is made by the Government of India 287 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NEPAL to the Government of Nepal on direct imports from Indian manufacturers of commodities subject to excise duty in India. With the exception noted below, applications to the Ministry of Finance for foreign exchange to pay for imports from countries other than India are considered on their merits; any application must, however, be in accordance with the annu al foreign exchange budget.3 Exporters entitled to import goods with exporters' exchange entitlements are, within the limits of their entitlement, granted a license automatically for goods specified by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, be low); the entitlements are transferable and may be used by other holders.4 Many imports payable in convertible currencies and most government imports are effected through state trading agencies, mainly the National Trading Ltd. and the Agricultural Input Corporation. All imports settled through the banking system must be made on a letter of credit basis; only imports from India may be settled outside the banking system. Certain imports from all sources are subject to import surcharges. Payments for Invisibles Payments to India may be made freely in Indian rupees, but for accounts of Rs 500 or over the purpose of the payment must be indicated. Payments for freight and insurance are given the same treatment as the related import payments. For travel to countries other than India for medical treatment, foreign exchange is allowed as recommended by a panel of doctors; students studying at their own expense in these countries are allowed up to US$2,160 a year for board and lodging, while payments for tuition fees are allowed as required. Payments for other invisi- bles depend on the essentiality of the transaction and the availability of foreign exchange. Nepalese and Indian currencies may be taken out freely to India by Nepalese and Ind ian nationals only; the export of these currencies to countries other than India is prohibited. Foreign banknotes other than Ind ian banknotes may not be taken out by residents without permission. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of old coins, gold and silver, and coins and jewelry made of these metals, cows and buffaloes, and rhinoceros horn are prohibited. There is also a tem- porary prohibition on exports of oilseeds and edible oils. The re-export to India of non-Nepalese goods is not permitted, and re-exports to any destination of goods imported from Ind ia are prohibited.5 All other goods, except rice, may be exported freely to India. All exports to other destinations require export licenses. Eight regional Rice Export Corporations have a monopoly over exports of rice. The exchange proceeds of exports, except Indian rupees, must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an authorized bank at the official buy ing rate of exchange, w i th in six months of shipment. The exporter receives f rom the Nepal Rastra Bank an exporter's exchange entitlement corresponding to a specified pro- portion of his eligible export proceeds in foreign cur- rencies other than Indian rupees; the entitlement may be used to obtain exchange at the official rate for the import of goods specified by the M in is try of Industry and Commerce. An export valuation committee deter- m ines for each commodity the max imum unit value which can appear on an application for an exporter's exchange entitlement. Unit values are defined on a c.i.f. basis; a marg in of 15 per cent above the un it value fixed by the committee is permitted to allow for price va r ia t ion in ind iv idual contracts. Foreign exchange surrendered in excess of earnings calculated on this basis is not eligible for an exporter's exchange entitle- men t. En t i t lemen ts are negotiable. Exporters engaged in bilateral trade (i.e., the National Trad ing Ltd. when selling to countries with which Nepal m a i n t a i ns payments agreements) are granted entitle- men ts corresponding to 100 per cent of their export earn ings; in principle, 40 per cent of these earnings may be used for imports of their choice from the partner coun try wh i le the rema in ing 60 per cent must be used to import specified commodities f rom the partner country. For virtually all exports to convertible currency coun- tries, exchange entitlements are granted at ratios of 45 per cent or 60 per cent. At least 10 per cent of the en t i t lement must be used to purchase items on a list of development goods, up to 70 per cent may be used to purchase consumer goods, other than specified luxury i tems, and up to 20 per cent may be spent on any type of goods including luxuries. 5 Und er the Trade and Transit Treaty with Ind ia, prohibitions also apply to (1) the export to India of manufac tured products containing materials imported f rom countries other than India in excess of 50 per cent of the ex-factory value, and (2) the export to countries other than Ind ia of manu fac tu red products containing materials imported f rom India exceeding 50 per cent of the ex-factory value. (Under the Treaty similar provisions also apply to India.) ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Proceeds from Invisibles With the exception of Ind ian rupees, foreign exchange proceeds derived f rom transactions in invisibles must be surrendered to the Nepal Rastra Bank or an authorized bank at the official rate of exchange. Nepalese and Indian currency may be brought in from India only, and by Nepalese and Indian nationals only; the import of these currencies f rom countries other than India is prohibited. When extending their visas tourists are required to produce evidence that they have converted a minimum of US$5 at the official rate of exchange for each day's stay. Nonresidents other than Ind ian nationals are not allowed to bring in Nepalese or Indian bank- notes. Other foreign banknotes may be brought in freely by residents and nonresidents, but residents and Indian nationals must declare any fore ign banknotes they bring in. Capital No conditions are laid down concerning receipts and remittances in respect of capital transactions, but official exchange is not normally provided for capital rem i t- tances by Nepalese nationals. Nepalese citizens, whether resident in Nepal or not, are prohibited f rom mak ing any type of investment in foreign countries except investment specifically exempted by government notice; the exemptions include investments abroad by any bank- ing or f inanc ial ins t i tu t ion incorporated in Nepal and the purchase of shares of foreign companies under a rights issue. The Indus tr ial Enterprise Act, 1974 provides cer ta in incentives for foreign investment in Nepal. Foreign investors who obtain an inves tment guaran tee may remit yearly profits of up to 25 per cent of the total profit on the foreign capital invested and, in any one year, up to 10 per cent of the principal; if the exchange s i tua t ion permits, profits in excess of 25 per cent are remittable. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any fo rm in Nepal. No import licenses for gold are issued under the Exporters' Exchange En t i t lement Scheme. Imports of gold f rom any coun t ry other than NEPAL India require a license and are subject to an import duty of NRs 6.65 a troy ounce; such imports are not normally allowed. Exports of gold may be made only by the mone tary authorities and require prior approval by the Ministry of Finance. Domestic dealings in gold do not require a license but are subject to a sales tax of 10 per cent. Changes during 1977 January 26. Export duties on 179 items were abol- ished. Import duties were reduced by 10 per cent to 50 per cent on a large number of consumer goods. May 29. Restrictions were imposed on the export of clarified bu t ter from the Lumbini zone. July 4. Import duties were increased from the exist- ing 1 per cent ad valorem rate to 10 per cent on goods imported under the recommendation of the Tourist Department and the Department of Industry. August 8. An export valuation committee was estab- lished to ascertain world market prices for exported commodities. Export earnings surrendered in excess of the earnings calculated on this basis were not eligible for export bonuses. However, a marg in of 15 per cent above the prices fixed by the committee was permitted to allow for fluctuations in individual contracts. September 13. The permissible categories of imported goods for export entitlement holders were expanded to inc lude w r i t ing paper, exercise booklets, toilet paper, tissue paper, hardboard, and other goods as specified by the Government from time to time. November 26. The Government made available con- vertible currency equivalent to NRs 100 million for imports under a special import licensing program. Applications for these special import licenses were accepted un t il December 25, 1977. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.245489 gram of fine gold per Netherlands Guilder. On September 17, 1973, the Netherlands established a central rate of f. 3.35507 = SDR 1, corresponding at the time to 0.264874 gram of fine gold per Netherlands guilder. The Netherlands avails itself of wider margins. A max imum margin of 2.25 per cent is maintained for exchange rates in the official market between the Netherlands guilder and the Belgian franc, the Danish krone, the deutsche ma rk, the Luxembourg franc, and the Norwegian krone. No announced margins are maintained for other currencies.1 The authorized banks' buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar on December 30, 1977 were f. 2.27875 and f. 2.28125 respectively, per US$1. Authorized banks are freely permitted to buy and sell convertible and inconvertible currencies, both spot and forward, against convertible currencies, including non- resident guilder accounts, and inconvertible currencies; they are free to deal with residents and nonresidents, whether banks or nonbanks. Forward exchange con- tracts are not limited as to delivery period nor is an under ly ing transaction required. Residents are free to conclude spot transactions with other residents, inc lud ing authorized banks, and they may conclude forward trans- actions w i th authorized banks 2 for any period. Nonbank residents are free to hold foreign currency accounts at home and are permitted to hold accounts in the ir own names with banks abroad; overdrafts on the latter accounts normally are not allowed in excess of f. 300,000 a year. The Kingdom of the Netherlands forma l ly accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as from February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory Transactions w i th the Netherlands An t i l les are subject to the same exchange controls as transactions with other countries. Vis-a-vis any third countries with which paymen ts agreements might be in force, the Ne the r lands and the Netherlands Antilles will, if so stipulated, con- stitute the Netherlands Monetary Area. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Ne ther lands Bank on behalf of the Ministers of Foreign A f fa i rs, Finance, Economic Affa irs, and Agriculture. Import and export licensing are handled by the Central Impor t- Export Agency (CDIU) and the delegated offices, under 1 The currencies quoted in the Amsterdam market include Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Norwegian kroner, pounds s ter l ing, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 As f rom January 1, 1978, the intermediation of authorized banks is no longer obligatory in those forward currency transactions in which the guilder is not involved. 290 directives f rom the Directorate-General for Foreign Economic Relations. Capital transactions are licensed by the Netherlands Bank; transit trade transactions in strategic goods and scrap are licensed by the CDIU.3 Commercial banks are authorized to handle exchange transactions w i th in the scope of general and special licenses granted by the licensing authorities. For all current payments to, or receipts from, nonresidents exceeding f. 3,000, and for all capital payments or receipts, nonbank residents as well as nonauthorized banks have to indicate, by submitting an exchange con- trol f o rm, the na tu re of the unde r ly ing transaction as well as the currency and amount paid or received. Separate regulations govern the reporting of settlements where no t r an s f er of money is involved. Prescription of Currency In effecting payments to nonresidents or collecting receipts f rom them, residents may make use of guilders or any foreign currency. If such payments are made f rom, or are received in, the Netherlands they must use the intermediation of authorized banks or of other domestic institutions or persons designated by the Netherlands Bank. Residents are free, however, to open and ma in ta in bank accounts abroad, to which receipts may be credited and payments debited; in that case, they must notify the Netherlands Bank, and receipts and payments are to be reported to the Bank in accordance with the relative regulations. There are specific regulations for payments in respect of certain direct imports from Egypt.4 All payments and credits, whether direct or indirect, f rom the Netherlands to Rhodesia are prohibited unless a license is granted by the Netherlands Bank. Payments in any foreign currency between residents may be made freely. There are no bilateral payments agreements in force. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents are free to open and keep nonresident accounts with authorized banks in the Netherlands in guilders or any foreign currency, to effect payments to, or collect receipts f rom, residents. All current payments or receipts are freely permitted, as well as transfers of balances to and from other nonresident accounts. A number of capital payments or receipts, however, are subject to license f rom the Netherlands Bank (see section on Capital below). Transit t rade (me rchan t ing) involving Rhodesia is prohibited. 4 F i f ty per cent of these paymen ts are used to settle Ne the r lands claims outstanding under the indemnity agreement with Egypt. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Netherlands, some of which are permitted under general license, and Special Accounts through which external payments must be made, subject to special licenses (which are granted only for the exceptional cases re- ferred to in the relevant UN Resolution). Imports and Import Payments Imports f rom the Belgian-Luxembourg Economic Union are free from import licenses. Virtually all im- ports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Import licenses are required for imports originating in Hong Kong, Japan, and state trading countries, and for the import of goods of unknown origin. In addition, import licenses are required for a limited number of products, mainly in the agricultural, steel, and textile sectors, when not of EEC origin. Except for imports from Rhodesia, prac- tically all imports that require an import license are free from quantitative restriction. Most imports f rom Eastern European countries are formally liberalized. Commodi- ties corresponding to a small number of tar iff headings or subheadings are subject to quantitative restriction when originating in Japan. Imports f rom non-EEC countries of most products covered by the Common Agricultural Policy of the EEC are subject to import levies that have replaced all previous barriers to imports; common EEC regulations are also applied to imports from non-EEC countries of most other agricultural and livestock products. Payments for imports may be made freely, provided that the method of payment conforms with the relative exchange control regulations. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of imports of commodities, but they require prior approval f rom the Netherlands Bank to accept credit for periods in excess of those that are customary in the trade concerned; such permission is not normally granted. Payments for Invisibles Payments abroad for invisibles are permitted freely. Residents may take out any amount in foreign and domestic banknotes and coins or documents of value for travel purposes; these may be used for traveling ex- penses abroad as well as for purchases for which pay- ment in cash is customary in the trade concerned. Payments for interest, dividends, and contractual amorti- zation due to nonresidents are permitted freely by crediting the appropriate nonresident account. Nonresidents may export all unu t i l ized documents of value for travel purposes as well as fore ign and Nether- lands banknotes and coins which they have imported or have obtained in the Netherlands by draw ing on their accounts or exchanging other currencies. Exports and Export Proceeds Virtually all exports to Rhodesia are prohibited; those which are permitted require an export license. For exports to other countries, export licenses are required only for a few commodities, mos t ly of a strategic char- NETHERLANDS acter, and for some agricultural products, iron and steel scrap, and certain nonferrous metals. Residents may freely grant credit in respect of exports of commodities, but they require prior permission from the Netherlands Bank to accept payment in advance of delivery in excess of the customary practice in the trade concerned; such permission is not normally granted. The surrender of export proceeds is not obligatory. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no requirements attached to receipts by residents from current invisibles. Nonresidents may bring into the Netherlands for travel purposes any amounts in Netherlands or foreign banknotes and documents of value; these may be used for traveling expenses in the Netherlands as well as for purchases for which payment in cash is customary in the trade concerned. Capital Most external capital transactions either enjoy blanket freedom or are permitted by general license. The main capital transactions of nonbank residents still subject to case-by-case review are (1) financial borrowing from nonresidents exceeding f. 300,000 a year; (2) the issue of interest-bearing domestic securities, and the sale of such unlisted securities, to nonresidents; (3) lending to nonresidents exceeding f. 10 million a year to the same nonresident; and (4) the acquisition of unlisted foreign securities bearing interest in guilders. At the end of 1977, borrowing abroad by nonbank residents continued to be restricted for reasons of mone- tary, credit, and exchange rate policy, while capital exports continued to be liberally permitted. In general, the inward transfer of foreign capital (other than for portfolio investment in listed securities or the purchase of real estate, see below) is permitted only if the capital constitutes a direct investment. In addition to foreign participation in the capital of companies, direct invest- ment is considered to include intercompany financial loans with a fixed term of at least five years from the foreign parent company. Under certain conditions, loans f rom other affiliated foreign companies are also being licensed. Other financial borrowing —whether through issues of bonds and notes abroad or through borrowing f rom foreign banks —is, in principle, not allowed unless the proceeds are kept abroad and used for investments abroad (which are considered to include purchases of ships and a ircraf t). However, companies working on the Netherlands' part of the Continental Shelf, whether foreign owned or resident owned, are allowed to take up foreign bank loans (with a fixed term of at least five years) up to two thirds of their financing requirements. Resident units of international companies are free to maintain current accounts with their head offices or subsidiaries abroad for the purpose of intercompany settlements; changes in the accounts are to be reported to the Netherlands Bank in accordance with the relative regulations. Short-term foreign bank 291 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution NETHERLANDS credit for the financing of imports is licensed (when there is no domestic credit restriction in force) if it is directly connected w i th a specific import transaction; for long-term financing, importers are referred to the domes- tic credit market. Sales to nonresidents, including central banks, of Netherlands treasury paper and bank accept- ances denominated in guilders are prohibited. Lending by nonbank residents to nonresidents (whether affiliated companies or others) is free up to f. 10 million a year to the same nonresident; larger amounts are normally permitted on application. Public issues on the domestic capital market on behalf of nonresidents are scheduled, and if necessary limited, by the Netherlands Bank in accordance w i th the market's capacity to absorb issues. In the private placement sector of the capital market (the market for debt certificates or onderhandse leningen), institutional investors are liberally permitted to extend loans to nonresidents. The max imum size of each loan is set at f. 75 million and the m in imum largest ma tu r i ty at ten years, with repayment to take place in at least five equal installments. The lenders are to deliver in foreign currency. A queue system w i th an issue calendar for nonresident borrowers is used to ensure an orderly market. Participation by residents in the capital of companies abroad is free. The inward or outward transfer of proceeds f rom the sale or liquidation of direct investments is free. Repay- ment of licensed loans may be made or received freely, provided that any re levant s t ipu la t ions in the license are complied with. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in all stocks and bonds listed on the Amsterdam stock exchange take place at official market exchange rates and are unrestricted. Residents may freely purchase officially listed securities abroad. Transactions between residents and nonresidents in unlisted stocks are free. However, residents are not allowed to purchase unlisted fixed-interest securities (such as notes) on the Euro- market denominated in guilders and issued by non- residents. Nonbank residents are licensed to issue bonds and notes abroad only if the proceeds are not brought into the Netherlands (see above). The proceeds of securities sold in the Netherlands by nonresidents (except Rhodesians) are transferable in any currency, irrespec- tive of the seller's country of domicile or residence. Non- residents may have their securities, domestic or foreign, exported to them; securities held in the Netherlands are not subject to deposit. Nonresidents may freely purchase real estate in the Netherlands for personal use or investment, and residents may freely purchase real estate abroad. Extension of payments within the framework of such transactions is also freely permitted. Gifts and donations to nonresidents are free.5 Emi- grants may export any amount in foreign and domestic 5 Charitable gifts and donations for religious purposes are included in the Netherlands definition of current payments. 292 currency. They acquire nonresident status upon leaving the Netherlands and may upon departure have remitted to them their total assets in the Netherlands. Nonresi- dents inheriting f rom estates in the Netherlands may have the proceeds transferred to them freely. The curtailment of external borrowing is also applied to the authorized banks. Any net foreign indebtedness on their part is restricted by the "five million regulation," which prescribes that the total of each bank's spot foreign liabilities (regardless of denomination or ma tur i ty) must not at any time exceed its total spot foreign assets by more than f. 5 million. Banks are required to report to the Netherlands Bank twice a month the totals of their spot assets and liabilities, broken down into guilders and all foreign currencies combined. In addition, banks are encouraged to maintain a balanced total position (i.e., spot plus forward position) in each foreign currency. They are required to report their spot position, as well as their forward position with residents and nonresidents, respectively, in each foreign currency at the end of each month; for deutsche mark, pounds sterling, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars, the same data must also be reported at mid-month. Moreover, copies of all forward exchange contracts with nonresidents are forwarded to the Nether- lands Bank. Banks are free to lend to foreign banks and, for maturities up to one year, to foreign nonbanks; longer-term lending is permitted under general license. Banks are free to pay customary rates of interest on nonresident-held guilder demand deposits, and to estab- lish guilder time or savings deposits on their books in the names of nonresidents. Thus, their freedom to accept deposits from nonresidents (including foreign currency demand or time deposits) and to borrow abroad is unre- stricted, provided the limit set by the "five million regu- lation" is observed. All capital transfers by nonbank residents, whether free or permitted under license, must be notified to the Balance of Payments Department of the Netherlands Bank. This includes suppliers' credits granted or received for periods in excess of one year; prepayments exceeding f. 250,000 received for exports must be reported as such. Totals of security transac t ions must be reported periodically by securities brokers and authorized banks or, if transactions take place through a foreign bank account, by the resident parties concerned. Authorized banks must report their own investments and loans as well as monthly totals of foreign exchange dealings and deposit transactions. Gold Certain prewar gold coins are legal tender but do not. circulate. The Netherlands Bank engages in gold trans- actions only with monetary authorities and international financial institutions. Neither the bank nor any govern- ment agency imports or markets gold for industrial use. Authorized banks and nonbank residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold ( f ine gold, gold coin, and gold alloys) in the Netherlands or abroad. Imports and ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution exports of gold do not require exchange licenses or import and export licenses. There is a free gold market in Amsterdam. Domestic sales of gold coins, if legal tender in the country of issue, are free of value-added tax; those that are not legal tender are subject to value- added tax at 4 per cent. The value-added tax on medal- lions and commemorative coins is 18 per cent. Com- mercial imports of gold jewelry and of articles containing minor quantities of gold, such as watches, require import licenses only when originating in Hong Kong, Japan, or state trading countries. Changes during 1977 January 1. The private placement market was re- opened with effect from January 3, subject to the follow- ing conditions: The maximum size of each loan was set at f. 75 million and the m in imum largest ma tur i ty at ten years, with repayment to take place in at least five equal installments. Lenders would be required to deliver in foreign currency. A calendar of issues would be established to maintain orderly market conditions. September 1. The form of the exchange control regu- lations was considerably simplified through superimposi- tion of a "positive" system on the Exchange Control Decree of 1945 (which, in principle, made all external payments subject to permission). By ministerial order exemption was granted from all prohibitions contained in the Decree, unless explicitly stated otherwise in special exchange control orders or notices. Consequently the existing implementing regulations and permissions were revoked; at the same time new regulations were published ma in ta in ing the existing s i tua t ion. These regulations were embodied in the fo l low ing orders and notices: (1) An exchange control order designed to permit continued control over transit trade in strategic goods in conformity with international obligations. (2) An exchange control order stipulating that the export of certain valuable paintings and other works of NETHERLANDS art would continue to be conditional upon permission of the Minister of Cultural Affairs, Recreation and Social Work. (3) An exchange control notice under which certain forms of capital exports, such as the placing of foreign issues in the Netherlands, remained subject to permission so as to allow regulation of the domestic capital market. (4) An exchange control notice under which capital inflows on account of borrowing, as well as some other transactions remained subject to permission so as to enable the authorities to counter undesirable upward pressures on the guilder's exchange rate. The ceiling on such inflows would be raised to f. 300,000 per year per resident. (5) An exchange control notice stipulating that residents should, in principle, continue to effect their in te rna t ional payments through authorized banks in the Netherlands so as to facilitate an overall view of the payments situation which would be helpful to the deter- mination of exchange control policy. Rules in respect of the reporting of payments transactions and other settlements —for balance of payments statistics —were contained in a separate exchange control instruction. (6) An exchange control notice containing formal regulations on the concept of residential status. (7) An exchange control notice under which the Netherlands Bank maintained the authority to prevent takeovers, by foreign banks, of banks established in the Netherlands. September 1. The prohibition on the acquisition by authorized banks and exchange dealers of Italian bank- notes of high denomination was not continued under the new exchange control regulations. October 12. The central rate is Ant. f. 1.7900 per US$1, and the Netherlands Antilles avails itself of wider marg ins. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar. Exchange transactions between commercial banks and the public take place at An t. f. 1.79 buying, and Ant. f. 1.81 selling, per US$1, plus a tax of 0.8 per cent on sales of exchange, mak ing the effective selling rate for the U.S. dollar Ant. f. 1.8245 per US$1.2 The offi- cial buying and selling rates for certain other currencies are set daily on the basis of rates for the U.S. dollar abroad. The Bank of the Netherlands Antilles (the central bank) deals w i th commercial banks at interbank rates. It does not normally deal with the public. Commercial banks require the approval of the central bank to invest or hold foreign currency balances,3 but authorized banks have been granted general permissions for these purposes. Administration of Control Exchange licenses, where required, are issued by the central bank. Import licenses are issued by the Depart- ment of Economic A f fa i rs. The commercial banks are permitted by the central bank to provide foreign exchange for most current transactions without prior approval. The central bank may grant an exemption f rom the obligation of surrendering foreign exchange, insofar as the assets or moneys concerned were acquired f rom nonresidents as principals; the foreign exchange may then be held or used freely until fu r ther notice. Prescription of Currency Payments may be made in any currency except Neth- erlands Antilles guilders. Receipts may be accepted in any convertible currency except Netherlands Antilles guilders. For statistical purposes, all payments made by residents through the authorized banks in fore ign exchange as well as all receipts through the authorized banks, must be reported to the central bank. Certain commodities are subject to import surcharges in Aruba, Bonaire and Curasao. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles are not restricted. For most types of current invisibles remittances may be made freely through the authorized banks. Such licenses are freely granted when no capital transfer seems to be involved. Nonresidents may take with them on departure any fore ign currency which they brought in on arrival. The export of Netherlands Antilles banknotes is limited to Ant. f. 200 a person. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require licenses, which are usua l ly granted. New industrial companies pri- marily engaged in exporting may be granted nonresident status by the central bank, which confers on the com- pany concerned exemption from exchange control (except in its transactions with residents), including exemption from the requirement of surrendering their foreign currency receipts. Such exemption may also be granted to companies concerned with investment, patent holding, shipping, and insurance. Outward flows of resident-owned capital are subject to control, and certain capital transactions by or on behalf of residents are restricted. Life insurance con- tracts in foreign currency between residents and foreign insurance companies for a minimum term of ten years are licensed up to an amount which is fixed annua l ly, depending on the foreign exchange position, but outward transfers of capital by life insurance companies are not restricted; contracts expressed in domestic currency are freely permitted in any amount by virtue of general per- missions granted to individual foreign insurers. Invest- ment by residents in real estate situated abroad requires a license. Investment in officially listed foreign securities (i.e., securities issued outside the Netherlands Antilles or payable or optionally payable in the currency of a country other than the Netherlands Antilles) is freely allowed by a general permission; purchases of mutual f u nd shares are prohibited. Authorized banks may freely borrow foreign currency abroad f rom nonresidents ( inc lud ing residents with non- resident s ta tus), or accept foreign currency deposits NETHERLANDS ANTILLES from nonresidents, for relending to nonresidents or redeposit abroad; their borrowing from nonresidents for relending to residents is restricted for monetary policy reasons and banks require central bank approval to incur a net foreign liability position. Nonresidents are not normally permitted to acquire balances in Nether- lands Antilles guilders. Local borrowing in domestic currency by nonresidents (including resident companies regarded as nonresidents for exchange control purposes) is restricted. Gold A commemorative gold coin of Ant. f. 200 is legal tender. Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in the Netherlands Antilles for numismatic and investment purposes; authorized banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents. Resi- dents other than the monetary authorities and author- ized industrial users are not allowed without special permission to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry or coins, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the central bank; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports of coins by authorized banks, and for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and indus- trial users.
