Administration of Control The State Bank has delegated au tho r i ty to a numb er of banks and financial in s t i tu t ions to deal in all fore ign currencies, to supervise su r render requ i remen ts, and to sell exchange for specified purposes w i th in l im i ts pre- scribed by the State Bank. The Chief Controller of Imports and Exports is responsible for the issue of licenses and the imp lemen ta t ion of impo rt and export policies. Certain foreign trade t ran sac t ions are conduc ted through var ious state t r ad ing agencies, such as the Trading Corporation of Pak is tan, Ltd. (TCP ), the Cot- ton Export Corporation, Ltd. (CECP), the Rice Export Corporation, Ltd. (RECP ), and the Edible Oil Cor- poration, Ltd. (EOCP). Prescription of Currency Exchange receipts and paymen ts abroad must be effected through an authorized fore ign exchange dealer, in principle in any convertible currency or in Pak is tan rupees f rom or to nonresident rupee bank accounts. Cer- tain settlements with specified countries are channeled through special accounts. Letters of cred it for impor ts from all other countries must be established in U.S. dollars, pounds sterling, the domestic currrency of the beneficiary, or in the currency of the coun try of origin or shipment. No exchange control is exercised over t ransac t ions with A fghan is tan, and settlements are made in Pakistan rupees or in Afghan currency. Trade t ransac t ions under "barter" agreements are settled through special accounts in inconvertible currencies. Trade in specified commod i- ties with Bu lgar ia, the People's Republic of Ch ina, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Nor th Korea, Poland, Sweden, and the U.S.S.R. is settled through special nonconvertible accounts. The special accounts w i th the People's Re- public of China are ma in ta ined in nonconvertible Paki- stan rupees; those w i th Poland, Sweden, and the U.S.S.R. are in U.S. dollars; and the special account with North Korea is denom ina ted in deutsche mark. A special trade and paymen ts arrangement w i th the German Democratic Repub l ic, w i th an indicative commodity list only, pro- vides for payments to be effected through a clearing account ma in ta ined in U.S. dollars. Payments to and f rom Iran and Turkey relating to v is ib le trade (excluding border trade, Iran ian oil, and defense ma te r ia ls) are settled through clearing accounts ma in ta ined by the respective central banks in U.S. dol- lars. Under a credit arrangement with the Central Bank of Ceylon, all trade w i th Sri Lanka is settled through a c lear ing U.S. dollar account. Paymen ts to, and receipts f rom, member countries of the Asian Clearing Un ion other than Bangladesh and Iran (i.e., Burma, India, Nepal, and Sri Lanka) in respect of cu r rent transactions (other than those relating to pe tro leum, na tural gas, and their products) may be effected in Asian monetary units through the Asian Clearing Union; for settlements with Sri Lanka, this arrangement is applicable to invisibles only. Payments between Pakistan and the Republic of Ch ina, Israel, Rhodesia, and South A f r i ca are suspended. Nonresident Accounts The accounts of individuals, firms, or companies resi- dent in countries outside Pakistan are designated as non res ident accounts.1 Authorized banks are permitted to open nonresident accounts for nonbank nonresidents w i thout the prior approval of the State Bank where the accounts are to be opened w i th funds received from abroad through banking channels or w i th rupee funds which have been accepted for remittance abroad. Debits and credits to nonresident accounts for specified pur- poses may be made by authorized banks without the prior approval of the State Bank. Accounts of residents of India, other than the accounts of the Ind ian Embassy and its personnel, are blocked. Pak i s tani nationals residing abroad and foreign na- tionals, whe ther resident abroad or in Pakistan, may open foreign currency accounts w i th banks in Pakistan w i thout prior approval of the exchange control authori- ties. There are no restrictions on the currencies in which the accounts may be denominated; credit balances may be transferred abroad, and interest on such accounts is exempt f rom income tax. A deposit holder wishing to make payments in Pakistan must first convert the 1 Different rules apply to nonresident rupee accounts of individuals, firms, or companies, on the one hand, and to nonresident rupee accounts of banks, on the other hand. 313 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PAKISTAN foreign exchange drawn from his account into Pakistan rupees. If a Pakistani national ho ld ing such an account returns to Pakistan, he may retain the account unless his stay exceeds six months; thereafter the account must be closed and the exchange surrendered. Banks in Pakistan receiving such deposits must sell the foreign exchange to the State Bank. Imports and Import Payments Permitted imports are classified in two lists: a free list and a tied list. Items on the free list may, in prin- ciple, be procured without restriction, while items on the tied list may be procured only from tied sources under credits, barter trade, loans, or the U.S. P.L. 480 program. Items not on either list are effectively prohibited for import except under certain circumstances by export industries, as mentioned below. All imports require licenses, except goods imported by the Central Govern- ment for defense or other purposes, goods in transit, personal baggage, certain imports over the land routes from Afghan is tan and Iran, and certain other items permitted under a Ministry of Commerce Notification. Generally, licenses remain valid for 12 months. In cases where machinery is specifically manufac tured, the validity period can be up to 24 months. Licenses for imports of a value up to PRs 500 incur no fee, but licenses above that amount up to PRs 100,000 are sub- ject to a fee of 1 per cent of the value of the license, and licenses above PRs 100,000 are subject to a fee of 2 per cent of the value of the license exceeding PRs 100,000, payable at the time of the issue of the license. The basic two-list import regime is subject to certain supplementary qualifications, the most important of which are as follows: (1) Imports f rom the Republic of China, Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited, as are imports of goods originating in these countries but shipped f rom third countries. (2) In order to facilitate barter t rad ing and aid utilization and to secure economies through bulk imports, the import of specified items is restricted to the TCP and the EOCP, unless the items are procured with U.S. aid. (3) The import of certain other items is restricted to the public sector or to industrial consumers. (4) In conform i ty with Regional Cooperation for Development arrangements between Iran, Pakistan, and Turkey governing procurements from jo int industrial ventures, the import of nine items, including six chemical items, is restricted to procure- ment from Turkey. Also, dates may be imported only f rom Iraq. (5) Special provisions exist for the import for export industries of items on the tied list f rom non- tied sources and items not on either import list. (6) Private sector importers, other than those importing goods for personal use, who apply for import licenses for goods valued at PRs 20,000 or more, must be mem- bers of approved trade organizations. ( 7) Licenses for permissible imports of indus tr ial plant and equ ipment are restricted to a c. & f. value of PRs 1.5 million for 314 imports against cash and PRs 2 million for imports under tied credit and under bilateral payments arrangements (larger plant and equipment are to be procured under the auspices of the financing institutions and with the approval of the Ministry of Indus t ry ). Except for imports of books, periodicals, and news- papers, irrevocable letters of credit must be opened for all commercial imports. In principle, such letters of credit have to be opened within 60 days after registration of the license with the State Bank for private and public sector imports except for private sector cash imports where licenses lapse af ter 45 days. For imports under tied loans or credits which require the contract to be approved by the Economic Affa irs Division or any other specified agency, licenses for both private and public sector imports remain valid for the opening of a letter of credit for 30 days af ter final approval of the contract. Oil companies and refineries are free to open letters of credit for the import of crude oil and petroleum and oil and lubricant products within the validity period of the underlying license. Remittances are not normally permitted before shipping documents are received, but in special cases, e.g., machinery and other capital goods for which deposits have to be paid to foreign manu- facturers, the State Bank may authorize advance pay- ments for a part of the value of the goods. No import payments are permitted for goods originating in or con- signed f rom the Republic of China, Israel, Rhodesia, or South Afr ica. The State Bank requires banks to take m in imum margins against import letters of credit (except for imports of industrial or agricultural ma- chinery as well as their components and spare parts, edible oils, tea, raw materials licensed under the Export Performance Scheme, crude oil and petroleum products, and synthetic fibers and ya rns) at the following rates: 10 per cent for raw rubber and raw ju te; 25 per cent for milk, cream, butter, medicines, spices, secondhand clothing, electric bulbs, industrial raw materials, un- exposed films, and construction and engineering equip- ment; and 40 per cent for all other items. Irrespective of origin, certain goods are subject to an import surcharge of 25 per cent ad valorem. These include cocoa, coffee, many domestic appliances, and passenger automobiles. A 10 per cent surcharge is levied on the c.i.f. value of all imports except petroleum products, tea, tractors, certain specified machinery, and items exempt from import duty. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles are controlled by the State Bank and in many cases require its prior approval. No remittances are permitted to the Republic of China, Israel, South Africa, or Rhodesia. Under authority delegated to them, authorized dealers may sell exchange or make remittances in accordance with detailed regu- lations. Certain remittances of a personal na ture are subject to annual quotas, but most are approved at the discretion of the State Bank. Remittances by Pakistani ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution their require special families abroad nationals to authorization. Payments for invisibles connected with imports are generally given the same treatment as that accorded the underlying trade transaction. Except with respect to certain aid shipments, transport insurance must be taken out with insurance companies in Pakistan. Commissions, brokerage, or other trade charges paid to foreign im- porters or agents by Pakistani exporters are generally limited to a maximum of 5 per cent of the invoice value, except for cotton, rice, and cement, for which separate regulations apply. The remittance of dividends declared out of current profits is allowed freely to foreign shareholders where the investment was made with the Government's ap- proval. Profits of branches of foreign companies may be remitted freely to their head offices. The same applies to head office expenses charged to a branch's profit and loss account and accepted for tax purposes by the Pakistani income tax authorities. On an administrative basis, the State Bank approves an exchange allocation of US$500 a person a tr ip for private travel; this alloca- tion can be taken up once every two years. Additional exchange for business travel, medical treatment, educa- tion, and sponsored cultural trips may be granted on an individual basis. There are also specific allowances for pilgrims' travel to Saudi Arabia and other Middle East- ern countries. Exporters w i th annual export earnings in excess of PRs 2.5 million are entitled to a renewable six- month blanket permission for the purchase of travel tickets and travel exchange of US$50 a day up to US$1,500 for each business trip. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign currency not exceeding the amounts they brought in and PRs 20 a person in Pakistan currency notes. Residents leaving for Afghanistan may take out PRs 50 in Pakistan cur- rency notes and coins and any amount of A fghan cur- rency. Nationals working abroad who visit Pakistan may retain for three months the foreign exchange they brought in. When leaving Pakistan they may take with them the unspent balance of foreign exchange up to the equivalent of US$50 a person and larger amounts if the currency notes were declared on entry. Those Pakistanis whose stay in Pakistan exceeds three months may take out foreign exchange, including foreign currency notes up to a value of US$50 a person, not exceeding US$500 a family. Residents traveling to other foreign destina- tions may take out PRs 20 a person in Pakistan cur- rency and any amount in foreign currency notes and travelers checks granted by authorized banks under permissions issued by the State Bank. Pakistan currency notes in denominations of PRs 50 or higher may not be taken out. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of specified commodities to any destination, and all exports to the Republic of China, Israel, Rho- PAKISTAN desia, and South Africa are prohibited.2 Exports of most other commodities are allowed freely. However, export licenses are required for specified items which are subject to m in imum export prices (such as sports goods, surgical equipment, and bunker o i l ), export quotas (maize, onions, gram, and split g ram ), or quality controls (such as batteries, electric bulbs and appliances, and oil cakes). The CECP has a monopoly over exports of cotton; rice is exported through the RECP, and cement through the State Cement Corporation. A few chemicals may be exported only by the TCP. The State Bank requires a declaration by the exporter that, when payment is received in accordance with the prescribed method, he will surrender the exchange within a certain period of time. After ascertaining that the exporter's declaration meets all conditions, the authorized dealer certifies the export form for shipment. Export- ers are obliged to collect and surrender export proceeds within four months of shipment; the State Bank may, on the merits of each case, allow an extension of this period. The surrender of Afghan currency accruing f rom exports to Afghan is tan is not required. Export financing at concessional rates is provided for all exports (except raw cotton, wool, rice, hides and skins, and leather wet b lue) on the basis of confirmed irrevocable letters of credit or firm export orders or on the basis of the previous year's export performance. The rate of income tax and corporate profit tax is reduced by 50 per cent on all income and profits derived f rom exports, except raw cotton and goods that may be specified from time to time by the Central Board of Revenue. Industrial units established under the Pay-As-You- Earn Scheme are permitted to utilize up to 50 per cent of the f.o.b. value of exports for the servicing of sup- pliers' credit on imports of plant and machinery. Export duties are levied on raw cotton, oil cakes, molasses, and semi-tanned hides and skins. Proceeds from Invisibles With the exception of Afghan currency, which may be retained, incoming foreign exchange derived f rom invisibles must be surrendered within one month. Travelers may bring in PRs 20 in Pakistan currency notes a person and Rs 5 in coins that are legal tender in India; Pakistan currency notes in denominations of PRs 50 and above may not be imported. There is no limitation on the import of other currency notes and coins. Capital Investments in Pakistan by nonresidents are subject to approval. In order to encourage industrial develop- ment in Pakistan, the Government follows a liberal policy toward foreign entrepreneurs, who, with the 2 Prohibited exports include beef, mutton, grains, flour, da iry prod- ucts, edible oils, blood meal, meat meal, corn gluten meal, sesame oil cake, certain citrus fruits (unless g r ad ed ), and certain hides and skins. 315 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PAKISTAN approval of the Government, may start any industry in the private sector without any conditions being laid down regarding the participation of local capital. It is expected, however, that local rupee expenditure will ordinarily be met from local equity capital. Repatriation facilities are as follows: ( 1) Foreign capital invested in approved industries established af ter September 1, 1954 may be repatriated at any time to the extent of the original investment, and current profits may be transferred without restriction to the country of origin of the capital. (2) Profits reinvested in approved industrial projects with the approval of the Government may be treated as investment for the purpose of subse- quent repatriation. (3) Appreciation of any capital investment under (1) and (2) may also be treated as investment for the purpose of subsequent repatriation. These repatriation facilities do not apply to the purchase of shares on the stock exchange unless the purchase is an integral part of an approved investment project, or to capital invested in Pakistan before September 1, 1954. Guarantees provide for just and fa ir compensation in the currency of the country of origin of the investment in the event of nationalization of any project. Foreign nationals in Pakistan or abroad may register their investments in National Prize Bonds issued by the Government of Pakistan; the principal and the prize winnings may then be repatriated at any time. Transfers of capital abroad by resident nationals are, in general, not permitted; the purchase of foreign securi- ties by resident Pakistanis requires approval by the State Bank and is seldom permitted. Detailed rules govern the transfer of capital by persons emigrating or retiring from Pakistan, depending upon the nationality of the person concerned and the country to which the transfer is to be made. Foreign nationals temporarily residing in Pakistan are treated as nonresidents for purposes of transfer of securities. General permission has been given in connection with the issue, sale, or transfer of Pakistan securities, excluding shares of public or private limited companies, in favor of nonresidents, provided that the securities are registered at the address in Pakistan of the purchaser and investment is made on the basis of nonrepatriation of capital and re turn. Paki- stan securities held by nonresidents may be transferred to other nonresidents against payment abroad, with the same facilities in respect of remittance of capital and earnings as those obtained by the transferor. A general permission has also been issued allowing fore ign na- tionals temporarily resident in Pakistan to make invest- ments in units of the National Investment Trust, subject to certain stipulations. Exports of securities are subject to approval. Proceeds accruing from the liquidation of nonresident capital assets that are not covered by repatriation arrangements must be credited to blocked accounts. Subject to ap- proval by the State Bank, balances on blocked accounts may be invested in approved government securities 316 payable in Pakistan rupees or placed on time deposit with banks. A general permission allows Pakistani nationals resi- dent abroad to acquire securities in Pakistan by remit- tance of foreign exchange or to the debit of their non- resident accounts in Pakistan; dividends or interest thereon, as well as the proceeds upon sale, must be credited to nonresident accounts and cannot normally be transferred abroad. Pakistani nationals require the prior approval of the State Bank to sell movable or immovable assets held abroad, and the liquidation proceeds must be repatriated to Pakistan through nor- mal banking channels. Gold The export and import of gold are prohibited unless authorized by the State Bank. No such permission is granted, but there are no restrictions on the internal sale and purchase of nonmonetary gold. Changes during 1977 January 20. Not for Redistribution PANAMA (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.736662 gram of fine gold per Panamanian Balboa. The parity rate for the U.S. dollar is B 1.00 = US$1, and Panama does not avail itself of wider margins. U.S. currency notes and coins circulate freely in Panama, and local currency is represented only by limited amounts of silver balboas and subsidiary coins, a commemorative silver coin of B 20, a com- memorative platinum coin of B 150, and two commemo- rative gold coins of B 100 and B 500. Exchange trans- actions by commercial banks are based ma in ly on New York market quotations. Panama has no exchange restrictions on foreign payments, with the exception of a prohibition on payments to Rhodesia other than those for pensions or for human i ta r ian, educational, medical, or informational purposes. On November 26, 1946, Panama notified the Fund that it accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control Most import and export licenses are issued by the Price Regulation Office, a semiautonomous institution of the Panaman ian Government. The Price Regulation Office is responsible for the implementation of restric- tions on imports of commodities that compete with national production and on certain exports. The Minis- try of Commerce and Industry determines the import quotas for commodities listed in trade agreements, and the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock Development, jointly with the Price Regulation Office, those for certain agricultural commodities. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Imports and Import Payments Imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Quotas are imposed on imports of commodities competing with present or prospective domestic production; some of these are not being licensed. Import licensing also applies to imports of various foodstuffs. Other imports are free. Imports by the public sector, however, are subject to special requirements. Payments abroad may be made freely. A tax of 7.5 per cent of the f.o.b. value is levied, in addition to import duty, on private sector imports of all dutiable goods other than specified pharmaceutical prod- ucts and foodstuffs, for which the rate is 2.5 per cent and 3.5 per cent, respectively; books are exempt. Most imports are also subject to a tax of 5 per cent calculated on the sum of the c.i.f. value and all other import taxes and charges; among the exemptions are fuels, lubricants, and related products, as well as foodstuffs, specified medicinal and pharmaceutical products, and imports into the Free Zones. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are prohibited, except those for humanitarian, educational, medical, or informational purposes. Authorization is required for exports of coffee, coconuts, copra, and beef cattle, andT for certain manu- factured products in short supply. Merchandise on which export taxes are imposed is also subject to licens- ing. Export taxes are levied on gold, silver, platinum, manganese, and other minerals, sugar, bananas, coco- nu ts, scrap metals, pearls, animal wax, nispero gum, ipecac root, and rubber. Exports of cement, certain foods tuffs, firearms, and ammun i t ion are prohibited. Certain non trad i t ional exports are eligible for tax credit certificates. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles Payments for and proceeds f rom invisibles are not restricted, except for most payments to Rhodesia. A travel tax of 4 per cent is levied on air and sea tickets bought in Panama or on such tickets purchased for travelers starting their tr ip in Panama. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents, except for most payments to Rhodesia. Several foreign- controlled banks are authorized to conduct business only with nonresidents. Gold Panama has issued two commemorative gold coins with face values of B 100 and B 500, which are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may freely hold gold in any form at home or abroad and may freely negotiate gold in any form with residents or nonresidents at home and abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry carried as personal effects by travelers are subject to license if made by residents other than the monetary authorities; import licenses are issued freely by the Ministry of Commerce and Industry and export licenses are granted by the Ministry of Finance and Treasury. Exports of unworked gold produced in Panama are subject to an export du ty of 1 per cent ad valorem, and exports of gold coins (other than U.S. coins, which are exempt) to a du ty of 0.5 per cent. Changes during 1977 No significant changes took place. 319 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PAPUA NEW GUINEA (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The currency of Papua New Gu inea is the K ina. The kina was pegged to the Aus t ra l ian dollar un t il Decem- ber 16, 1976. With effect f rom December 17, 1976, the direct link with the Aus tra l ian dollar was discontinued and a flexible exchange rate a r rangement was adopted, whereby the exchange ra te for the k ina is de term ined on the basis of a predetermined set of rules. The Bank of Papua New Gu inea deals w i th local banks in Aus- tralian dollars, Japanese yen, and U.S. dollars only. On December 30, 1977, the fixed b u y i ng and se l l ing ra tes of the Bank of Papua New Gu inea for the Au s t r a l i an dollar were $A 1.1580 and $A 1 .1551, per K 1, and its buy ing and se l l ing rates for the U.S. dollar were US$1.3213 and US$1.3187, per K 1. The correspond- ing rates for the pub l ic posted by the au tho r ized dealers were $A 1.1608 buy ing, and $A 1 .1523 selling, per K 1, and US$1.3241 buy ing, and US$1.3159 selling, per K 1. The exchange ra te of the Bank of Papua New Gu inea for the U.S. do l lar is set da i ly on the bas is of the m idd le rate quoted by the Reserve Bank of Au s t ra l ia. Papua New Gu inea fo rma l ly accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree- ment, as f rom December 4, 1975. Administration of Control The Bank of Papua New Guinea adm in is te rs exchange control according to the Foreign Exchange Regulations issued in November 1973. Overall policy is determined by the Government w i th the advice of the Bank of Papua New Guinea and the Department of Finance. The Bank of Papua New Gu inea delegates extensive powers to the commercial banks operating in Papua New Guinea, which have been appointed authorized dealers in foreign exchange. Export licensing is adm in is tered by the Depar tment of Foreign Relations and Trade. Prescription of Currency Contractual comm i tmen ts to persons resident outside Papua New Gu inea, which are expressed in a foreign currency, may only be met by payments in foreign cur- rency. l Export proceeds may be received in any fore ign currency or in k ina f rom an overseas bank 's account in Papua New Guinea. Nonresident Accounts The Bank of Papua New Gu inea controls all credits to nonresident bank accounts; funds credited to such accounts may be withdrawn w i thout fu r ther forma l i ty. Only in exceptional circumstances is approval given for a nonresident bank account to be denom ina ted in a foreign currency. 1 Foreign currencies are defined as all currencies other than the kina. 320 Imports and Import Payments No restrictions are placed on payments for imports, except for goods imported f rom Rhodesia. Authorized dealers have powers to approve most transactions with- out completing application forms or referr ing to the Bank of Papua New Guinea. Approval is given for pay- ment to be made under extended credit terms for items such as capital equ ipmen t. There are no import licensing requirements. Payments for Invisibles Approval is readily given for most payments for invisibles, provided that supporting documentation can be produced. The remittance overseas of life insurance premiums on new policies wr i t ten a f ter December 31, 1975 in the names of permanent residents is not per- m i t ted. No absolute limits are imposed on travel funds, although applications for exceptionally large amounts are referred to the Bank of Papua New Guinea for consideration. Travelers may not take or send out of Papua New Guinea domestic currency in excess of K 200 in notes and K 5 in coin; however, domestic coins issued for num isma t ic purposes may be taken out freely. Overseas visitors are free to take out any currency which they brought in and had recorded on arrival. Exports and Export Proceeds Residents of Papua New Guinea may export goods w i thout exchange control forma l i ty (except to Rhodesia) on condition that they comply with the terms of the General Authority issued by the Bank of Papua New Gu inea. The essential conditions of this Authority are that payment for goods exported is received within six months of the date of export and that the proceeds are sold to an authorized dealer in Papua New Guinea. Where exporters are not in a position to comply with the conditions of the General Authority, they must apply to the Bank for a Specific Authority. No authority is needed for certain excepted categories of goods; these include sundry items such as passengers' personal effects. Export licenses are required for all types of goods under the Exports (Control and Va lua t ion) Act. Special pro- visions are in force for the export of prescribed goods (logs, pearls, tuna fish, and wood chips). Proceeds from Invisibles Approval is required only for the disposal of foreign currency proceeds other than by sale to an authorized dealer in Papua New Guinea. Overseas visitors may bring in any amount of currency for travel expenditure. Capital Outward transfers of overseas-owned capital are allowed w i thout l im i t; advance comm i tmen ts, however, are given only in exceptional circumstances. Persons ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution who have been declared to be temporary residents by an authorized dealer or the Bank of Papua New Guinea may repatriate their surplus earnings without limit. New investment outside Papua New Guinea by per- manent residents and by companies and other organiza- tions operating in Papua New Guinea is subject to certain limitations. Where an investment is for portfolio reasons, the amount which may be invested in a 12-month period is limited to K 10,000 for individuals, K 25,000 for private companies, and K 100,000 for public com- panies. Investment may only be in the fo rm of market- able company securities and real estate. Foreign investments other than those in bank- ing and insurance are also subject to approval by the National Investment and Development Authority. Not for Redistribution PARAGUAY (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System On March 1, 1956, a new par value for the Para- guayan Guarani was established by Paraguay with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. Exchange transactions take place in a dual exchange market. Transactions in the official exchange market (mercado libre bancario) are concerned with exports and imports (except unrecorded border t rade ), certain current in- visibles, all government transactions, registered private capital transactions, and related profit remittances. These must be carried out through the Central Bank of Paraguay ( for all government transactions) or an authorized commercial bank, at a rate of 0 126 per US$1, subject to taxes and commissions. All other transactions are channeled through the fluctuating free market (mercado libre fluctuante), unless settlements are effected under reciprocal credit agreements with LAFTA countries. Transactions in the free market are conducted through licensed foreign exchange houses at a fluctuating rate, which on December 31, 1977 was 0 133 per US$1 buying and 0 137 per US$1 selling. All purchases and sales of exchange by banks are subject to a tax of 1.5 per cent, except transactions with foreign embassies and diplomats; transactions with meat packing plants; and transactions relating to invest- ments in Paraguay under the terms of Investment Laws Nos. 216/70 and 550/75. In addition, banks charge a commission of 2 per cent on all sales of foreign ex- change. A tax of 10 per cent is levied on outward remittances of profits and dividends, and a tax of 30 per cent on remittances of interest, royalties, rents, honorariums, commissions, and other income accruing to nonresidents f rom Paraguayan sources. There are no forward exchange facilities. The authorized banks, but not the exchange houses, must sell 30 per cent of their daily gross foreign ex- change receipts in specified currencies 1 to the Central Bank. Administration of Control The Central Bank determines foreign exchange policy and supervises the foreign exchange transactions carried out by commercial banks and authorized foreign ex- change houses. Prescription of Currency Payments between Paraguay and Argentina, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru, and Uruguay must be made through accounts which the Central Bank of Paraguay and the other central banks concerned main- tain with each other, within the framework of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system. There are no other prescription of currency requirements. Imports and Import Payments Imports of a few commodities are prohibited.2 Im- ports of wheat and wheat flour are effected by the Ministry of Industry and Commerce. Certain other items require a license from the Ministry of Interior; these are mainly narcotics and arms and ammunition. All other imports are free of quantitative restriction and licensing. Imports of most commodities are subject to an advance deposit of 100 per cent of the f.o.b. value, which is retained for 120 days, or, for nonexempt com- modities imported through the Spanish free zone in Paraguay, 90 days. Advance deposits are not required for public sector imports, imports by foreign diplomats and by foreign staff of certain international organiza- tions, petroleum and petroleum derivatives, certain machinery and agricultural equipment, wheat, and news- print from any source, imports from neighboring coun- tries and Uruguay, and imports f rom other LAFTA countries of items included in the Paraguayan concession list (the National List). The Central Bank has authority to grant exemptions on a case-by-case basis. Surcharges, calculated on the c.i.f. value, are payable on most imports even if no foreign exchange payment takes place. An import surcharge of 36 per cent applies to most general imports from any source; however, for goods originating in LAFTA countries and included in the Paraguayan National List the rate ranges from 3 per cent to 30 per cent, and for certain other LAFTA goods (ma in ly Pharmaceuticals) in a special list the rate is 8 per cent. Fuel derived from petroleum is subject to a surcharge of 15 per cent (10 per cent for neighboring countries and Uruguay). A surcharge of 0.5 per cent, the proceeds of which go to the Small Farmers' Credit Agency, is levied on imports of all goods other than wheat and wheat flour, crude petroleum and its deriva- tives, and Pharmaceuticals. There is an additional sur- charge of 5 per cent on imports f rom all sources of telephone and telegraph equipment, television receivers, and radios and record players and their parts and acces- sories. Commodities that are exempt from surcharge generally are also exempt from advance deposit. Surcharges are collected by the banks at the time of delivery of the documents for customs clearance or when the import payment is made, whichever is earlier. The following are the principal exemptions from surcharge: wheat; crude petroleum; equipment for petroleum ex- ploration and exploitation; agricultural tractors; imports for the Government; imports for religious, charitable, 1 Argentine pesos, Belgian francs, Brazilian cruzeiros, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 2 These include sugar, rice, flour, and certain other agricultural prod- ucts and foodstuffs, certain petroleum products, cement, certain yarns and textiles, dry cell batteries, and certain wires and wire products. 322 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution cultural, or educational purposes; imports by foreign diplomats and certain international organizations; Span- ish agricultural and industrial machinery and implements imported through the Spanish free zone in Paraguay; agricultural machinery and equipment for the National Wheat Program; books and periodicals; and imports for investments under Investment Laws Nos. 216/70 and 550/75. Imports of investment goods and of raw mate- rials for export industries receive exemption on a case- by-case basis. In addition to the above surcharges, a tar iff surcharge is levied on certain imports. On goods that are not exempt, the rate of surcharge is generally 12 or 24 per cent (8 or 16 per cent for certain goods subject to LAFTA concessions) and the surcharge is levied on either the c.i.f. value, calculated as the f.o.b. value plus 10 per cent for imports f rom neighboring countries and Uruguay, or, for imports f rom other countries, the true market value upon arrival in customs. Exempt from this complementary import duty are public sector and diplomatic imports; raw materials and equipment for the production of goods that are subject to in ternal con- sumption taxes; imports under the Investment Laws and all imported goods taxed under the Internal Consump- tion Tax Law. Imports are also subject to sales tax at 5 per cent or 10 per cent. In add i t ion to those mentioned above, the following charges are levied on either the c.i.f. value of imports or the true market value upon arrival in customs: a consular fee of 5 per cent, an import clearance fee of 1 per cent, and a customs surcharge of 1.5 per cent, except for wheat and certain other commodities; the proceeds of the customs surcharge go to the Institute of Technology and Standards. Imports of construction materials are subject to an add i t ional customs surcharge of 1 per cent, the proceeds of which go to the Institute of Housing and Urban iza t ion. Imports of specified goods ( inc lud ing television sets and precious metals) may not be financed with foreign credit. Imports on credit for a term of more than six months require approval f rom the Central Bank. This approval is norma l ly granted only for imports of machinery and other capital goods. Import payments must be made through banks, at the official market rate of exchange. Import payments are free f rom formal restriction, but certain delays arise f rom time to time as a result of weekly releases of fore ign exchange to the private commercial banks by the Central Bank. Paymen ts through the LAFTA clear- ing system are made promptly. Payments for Invisibles Payments for all current invisibles may be made freely through the free market. There are allocations at the official rate for a few invisibles, such as payments related to study abroad, while trade-related invisibles may be settled in accordance with documents submitted. The PARAGUAY General Banking Law limits the remittance of profits through the official market to 30 per cent of any one year's profits for commercial banks and financial insti- tutions and to 60 per cent for investment, development, and mortgage banks; the remaining profits must be rein- vested in the financial sector or in other specifically authorized activities, and 20 per cent of such reinvested amounts may be transferred abroad annually. Travelers may take out any amount in foreign or domestic currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of logs and rough beams and a few other items are prohibited. Meat exports are subject to annual export quotas and certain other exports, such as hides and skins, require licenses in order to ensure adequate domestic supplies. All other exports are free of license but some require a certificate issued by the Institute of Technology and Standards. The proceeds of exports must be collected within 180 days a f ter completion of shipping formalities, and the exchange sold to an author- ized commercial bank For all exports the Central Bank establishes m in imum export prices denominated in U.S. dollars. Export proceeds corresponding to either these prices or the invoiced value, whichever is higher, must be surrendered in the official exchange market; however, for coffee exports the equivalent of 50 per cent of the m in imum export price must be sold to the bank ing sys- tem, while the balance remains at the free disposal of the exporter. Advance receipts of export proceeds must also be sold to authorized banks. Export taxation is based on a list of assumed export values (aforos) pub- lished by the Ministry of Finance. Most exports are subject to taxes, payable in guaranies, rang ing f rom 1.5 per cent to 7.5 per cent of the aforo value; most exports are also subject to an additional tax of 1.5 per cent of the aforo value. Exports of meat products are exempt f rom export taxes. Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange proceeds f rom invisibles may be retained or sold in the fluctuating free market. Travelers may b r ing in any amount in foreign or domestic currency. Capital Movements of registered capital take place in the official exchange market through authorized banks, and all other capital movements are channeled through the free market. All inward and outward transfers must be recorded by the authorized banks and exchange houses. Authorized banks may grant exchange at the official market rate for transfers of registered capital, subject to presentation of appropriate documentation. Other out- ward transfers of capital require the prior approval of the Central Bank. Investment Law No. 550/75 em- powers the Government to grant special tax, customs, import surcharge, and advance deposit concessions to proposed investments, provided that these are duly regis- 323 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PARAGUAY tered and approved. Capital imported and registered under the Investment Laws may be retransferred in installments of up to 20 per cent f rom the third year after the beginning of production, in the currency origi- nally imported. Gold In practice residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, in Paraguay or abroad, and ex- change houses may freely deal in gold coins, gold bars, and gold leaf with residents and nonresidents. Exports and imports of gold in any form other than jewelry require the prior approval of the Central Bank, for which nonbank residents and industrial users are eligible; payments for gold imports by industrial users must be made through authorized banks at the official exchange rate, and payments for imports by others must be made through exchange houses at the fluctuating free market rate. Not for Redistribution PERU (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System On December 18, 1946, a par va lue for the Pe ruv ian Sol was established with the Fund. However, exchange transactions no longer take place at rates based on that par value. On the basis of Decree-Law No. 21953 of October 7, 1977, the exchange rate for the sol is to be determined by supply and demand .1 All exchange trans- actions must be conducted through the b a n k i ng system, and the Central Reserve Bank has the preferred right to purchase foreign exchange at the average ma rket buy ing rate at the close of the preceding business day. Banks operating in the exchange ma rket are requ ired to l im it the marg in between the ir buy ing and selling rates on any given day to not more than 0.5 per cent. No commis- sions are charged by the Central Reserve Bank on any exchange transactions. On December 31, 1977, the buy- ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were S/. 130.0 and S/. 130.7, respectively, per US$1. All foreign exchange receipts must be sold to the bank ing system or be deposited in fo re ign currency ac- counts. These exchange certificates are denom ina ted in U.S. dollars, are va l id for three days, and must e i ther be used by the original holder to effect paymen ts or transfers or be sold to the bank ing system. If not utilized w i th in th .ee days, the certificates are canceled and the correspond ing amount is credited to the bearer at the average buy ing rate at the close of the preced ing business day m inus a d iscount of 2 per cent. Not for Redistribution PERU Imports and Import Payments Goods not included in the List of Permitted Imports may not be imported (except for goods f rom Andean Pact countries and g i f t s ). Moreover, the import of a large number of manufac tures included in the Na t ional Register of Manu fac tu red Products requires the approval of the Ministry of Industry, Tourism, and Integration and of the customs authorities, which is granted only in exceptional circumstances unless the goods originate in a country of the Andean Pact. For goods on the List of Permitted Imports that are also on the National Register of Manufactured Products, the importer must show that local production is insufficient in quantity or quality. Each import transaction of the private sector requires a specific import license, which is issued automatically by the Directorate of Foreign Trade provided the im- porter is listed in the National Registry of Importers, the goods are included in the List of Permitted Imports, and the requirements described above with regard to the National Register of Manufac tured Products are met. Imports f rom countries of the Andean Pact, however, do not require an import license and need only be regis- tered with the Directorate of Foreign Trade. Also, im- ports of raw materials and intermediate goods for the production of nontraditional exports are exempted from import duties and do not require a specific import license, provided that the appropriate sectoral m in is t ry determines that such imports qua l ify under the Tem- porary Admission Regime. Certain agricultural commodities, such as rice and wheat, may be imported only by the Fish Meal Market- ing Agency ( E PCHA P ), and crude petroleum and petro- leum derivatives only by PETROPERU, a government agency. Certain industrial raw materials and fertilizers may be imported only by the National Enterprise for Industrial Marke t ing (ENC I ). All private and public sector imports are subject to certain m in imum external financing terms except food- s tu f fs and pharmaceutical products, import shipments valued at less than US$2,000 up to an annual total of US$25,000 for each importer, and imports paid for with foreign currency certificates of deposit issued by the bank ing system. For imports of capital goods va lued at over US$10,000 f.o.b., at least 80 per cent of the value must be financed abroad through loans either f rom suppliers or f rom other foreign creditors or f rom the Peruvian state development banks, to be repaid in ac- cordance with prescribed m in imum credit terms of f rom two to five years. State development banks may only provide such financing for national enterprises. All other imports, including the remaining 20 per cent of the value of capital goods which is not covered by the medium-term financing requirement, are subject to a m in imum external financing requirement of 180 days. Imports of capital goods must be covered by irrevocable documentary credits and the intermediating bank must 326 guarantee refund ing of the foreign currency if the im- port is not effected by the time the relevant documentary credit expires. All goods, whether imported or produced domestic- ally, are subject to a sales tax, levied at a general rate of 20 per cent, a maximum rate of 40 per cent, prefer- ential rates between 2 per cent and 8 per cent, and reduced rates corresponding to effective rates of between 11 per cent and 15 per cent; there is also a list of exempted items. A maritime freight tax of 4 per cent of the ocean freight charges is levied on goods imported by sea other than certain agricultural and medical prod- ucts, books, and coins. Public sector imports must, in principle, be shipped in Peruvian vessels. Payments for Invisibles Authorization of the Central Reserve Bank or other agencies is required for most payments for invisibles, but the sale of foreign exchange is generally authorized freely provided genuine current payments are involved. Remittances of net profits, including depletion and depreciation allowances, require a resolution of the M in is try of Economy and Finance, a prior tax clearance, and a visa of the Central Reserve Bank. Remittances of profits on fore ign capital invested in Peru are limited to 20 per cent a year, although a higher percentage may be permitted in exceptional cases.4 In compliance with the foreign investment regime approved by the countries of the Andean Pact, new foreign investments must be authorized and registered with the appropriate agency, in most instances CONITE. All payments for royalties, patents, trademarks, and licenses require the prior ap- proval of CONITE. Foreign-owned enterprises may not enter into new contracts to pay royalties to a foreign parent company or its affiliates. The effective interest rate on a new loan from a foreign parent com- pany or its aff i l ia te may not exceed by more than 3 per cent the prevailing interest rate for first-class assets in the money market of the country in whose currency the transaction is denominated. Central Reserve Bank ap- proval is required for purchases of exchange for pay- ments of interest on certain loans, for remittances for social and human i ta r ian purposes, for income, insurance, and pension remittances to nonresidents, and for expen- ditures of agencies, branches, and offices of nonresident firms. Interest payments by public sector entities require the approval of the General Directorate of Public Credit. The annual limit on purchases of foreign exchange for tourism is US$1,000 a person (US$500 a year for children under 12). For business travel the limit is US$100 a person a day up to a limit of US$1,500 a trip, plus US$500 a trip for representation expenses; approval of the Central Reserve Bank is required for business travel allocations. For both tourist and business travel there is a 30 per cent tax on all passages and fares and 4 Companies exporting at least 80 per cent of their production to countries outside the Andean Pact and mining companies are exempt. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution a flat travel tax of S/. 2,000 for the first five days spent abroad and S/. 200 for each additional day. Student remittances require the approval of the National Insti- tu te of Scholarships and Educational Loans (!NABEC) and are generally limited to US$500 a month. Limits are also established for medical travel and for certain other types of travel. Family remittances by Peruvian residents are limited to US$100 a month and require the authorization of the Central Reserve Bank. Foreigners resident in Peru may remit up to 50 per cent of their annual income to cover specified foreign obligations, but those who avail themselves of these provisions are required to waive all rights to purchase foreign exchange under other provisions of the exchange laws. The Cen- tral Reserve Bank may authorize purchases of exchange in excess of the above limits in jus t if ied cases. Nonresidents visiting Peru for purposes of tourism or business may, upon leaving the country, purchase up to US$50 in foreign exchange on presentation of evidence that at least that amount in foreign exchange had been converted into soles in the preceding 30 days. The ex- port of domestic currency in excess of S/. 1,000 by travelers is prohibited, but the Central Reserve Bank may grant exemptions in special circumstances. Exports and Export Proceeds The Banco Minero del Peru has a monopoly over the export of uncut precious stones and pearls, and MINEROPERU and the Banco Minero over exports of gold and silver. M INPECO has a monopoly over mineral exports, EPCHAP has a monopoly over exports of fish meal, fish oil, coffee, and cotton, and EPSEP over exports of fish for human consumption. All exports are subject to license, and all export proceeds, as well as export prefinancing loans, must be surrendered to the Central Reserve Bank within ten working days of receipt. Tra- ditional exports must be sold against an irrevocable letter of credit confirmed by a bank established in Peru. In special cases, and with the authorization of the Central Reserve Bank and the Directorate of Foreign Trade, exports may be sold against sight draf ts, provided that payment is received within 180 days of shipment. Exporters of non trad i t ional exports or local hand icraft articles are granted transferable tax credit certificates (certificados de reintegro tributario or CERTEX) equiva- lent to 30 per cent of the c. & f. value (the f.o.b. value is used when the goods are shipped in fore ign vessels).5 These certificates may be used by the exporter in pay- ment of his tax obligations or may be sold to other tax- payers, who may use them for the same purpose. The Banco de la Nacion administers an export credit guar- antee program and the Industrial Bank provides or arranges export finance for non trad i t ional exports. Tra- ditional exports are subject to a tax of 15 per cent. For 5 In addition, 2 per cent is allowed for new exports, 10 per cent for exports from outside the Lima-Callao area, and 10 per cent for goods considered to be priority exports. PERU exports by public sector marketing enterprises, the goods and services tax, as well as the nontraditional exports tax, is determined in foreign exchange at the time of shipment; the corresponding tax in soles is determined at the exchange rate prevailing on the date payment is received. Proceeds from Invisibles All proceeds from invisibles must be sold to the bank- ing system or deposited in authorized foreign exchange accounts within ten working days of receipt. Travelers may not bring in more than S/. 1,000 in Peruvian cur- rency, but the Central Reserve Bank may grant excep- tional treatment in special circumstances. Capital All outward capital transfers require approval. For transfers derived from foreign direct investment the ap- proval of CONITE is required, while for most other trans- fers the appropriate agency is the Central Reserve Bank. Loan amortization payments of the private sector are authorized by the Central Reserve Bank and those of the public sector by the General Directorate of Public Credit. Banks may receive funds originating abroad in the form of drafts, checks, or bank transfers for deposit to foreign currency accounts maintained in the name of residents or nonresidents. They may also issue foreign exchange certificates of deposit against such funds. These funds and the accrued interest thereon may be freely disposed of by the depositor and both are exempt from income and inheritance taxes until December 31, 1979. Under an exchange amnesty, residents may repa- triate foreign assets without specifying the origin of such funds, and without facing penalties for having vio- lated exchange laws in effect prior to October 7, 1977. Such repatriated funds are exempt f rom all taxes, in- cluding income taxes. All foreign investments in Peru require the prior approval of the appropriate authorities so that such investments are directed to projects considered essential for the country's development. If a fore ign company, incorporated in Peru as of July 1, 1971, wished to benefit f rom the du ty-free program of the Cartagena Agreement, it was required to agree, by June 30, 1974, to the gradual acquisition by national investors of shares in the com- pany so as to transform it into a mixed or national company during a maximum period of 15 years following the entering into effect of this regime. For this purpose, mixed companies are defined as those in which national investors hold between 51 per cent and 80 per cent of the capital, while national companies are those in which at least 80 per cent of the capital is owned by national investors. Since June 30, 1974, the required participation of national investors in the capital of an enterprise has been not less than 15 per cent; this participation must be raised to at least 45 per cent after 10 years and 327 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution PERU to at least 51 per cent at the end of the 15-year period. In the case of foreign companies established in Peru a f ter June 30, 1971, the 15 per cent par t ic ipa t ion by na t ional investors must be secured at the t ime of the in i t ia t ion of produc t ion. Foreign inves tmen ts in firms engaged in basic indus t r ies or in m i n i ng activities ( i n- c lud ing petroleum p roduc t ion) and in f irms that export at least 80 per cent of the ir p roduc t ion to coun tr ies out- side the Andean Common Market are exempt f rom the requ irement of gradual t r a n s f o rm a t i on in to mixed com- pan ies; however, these enterprises do not benef it f r om the du ty - f ree program of the Ca r tagena Agreemen t. Foreign en terpr ises may not have access to domestic cred it on terms longer than 3 years. Inves tment in the m i n i ng sector is governed by the General M in ing Law. Compan ies ho ld ing m i n i ng con- cessions may enter in to m i n i ng con trac ts w i th the Gov- e rnment providing for special incen t ives and gua ran tees or may cons t i tu te mixed en terpr ises w i th government pa r t ic ipa t ion of at least 25 per cent. The Gov e rnm ent may g r ant to m i n i ng concessionaries ( i n i t i a t i ng large-scale inve s tment programs) tax incen t ives and guaran teed ava i l- a b i l i ty of fore ign exchange for t r an s f e rs for ( 1) recovery of inv e s tm en t, (2) interest paymen ts if the ra te does not exceed the p reva i l ing ra te for s im i l ar loans in the f inan- cial m a rk et f rom which the loans o r ig ina te, (3) pay- men ts for ju s t i f ied services, and (4) reasonab le p ro f it rem i t tances, together w i th gua ran teed access to the most favo rab le exchange ra te. M ixed m i n i ng enterprises may receive all the benef i ts and incen t ives which may be granted by special con trac t, and, in add i t ion, special tax reduc t ions. Gold The export of gold and silver in the fo rm of agglom- erated or na t ive me ta ls is the monopo ly of M INERO PERU, wh i le the ir export in the fo rm of precious me ta ls is the monopo ly of the Banco M ine ro del Peru. The au tho r i t ies do not make fore ign exchange ava i lab le for impo r ts of gold other th an by or on beha lf of the mone ta ry au tho r i- ties and au thor ized indus t r ial and p ro fess ional users. Domestic sales and purchases of gold may be carr ied out by indu s t r ial and professional users, provided that they hold licenses issued by the Banco M ine ro del Peru, but on ly M INEROPERU is au thor ized to make the i n i t i al pu r- chase of newly m ined gold and other precious me ta ls. Exchange certificates denominated in U.S. dollars would be valid for three wo rk ing days. If not utilized w i th in three days, the certificates would be canceled and the corresponding amount in soles would be credited to the bearer at the average buy ing rate at the close of the preceding busi- ness day, m inus a discount of 2 per cent. All perm i t ted foreign exchange payments and transfers wou ld be effected either by means of these certificates, represent- ing a claim on the Central Reserve Bank, or by the direct purchase of foreign exchange f rom the b ank ing system. The Central Reserve Bank would have the right to purchase exchange f rom the bank ing system, such pur- chases being effected at the average buy ing rate of the preceding business day (Exchange Reso lu t ions Nos. 001- 77-EF/90 through 004-77-EF/90). Such specific licenses would be granted automatically by the Import Depar tment of the Directorate of Foreign Trade of the M in is try of Commerce provided ( 1) the importer was listed in the National Registry of Importers, (2) the product was included in the List of Permitted Imports, and (3) the product did not compete w i th domestic products listed in the National Register of Manu fac tu red Products.
