Not for Redistribution SOUTH AFRICA (Position on December 31,1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.04550 grams of fine gold per South African Rand. Since June 27, 1975 South A f r ica has followed a policy of keeping the buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar constant. As at December 31, 1977 the South Afr ican Reserve Bank quoted a middle exchange rate for the U.S. dollar of US$1.1500 per R 1, unchanged since September 22, 1975. Exchange rates for other currencies are based on the Reserve Bank's rates for the U.S. dollar against rand and the London market rates for the curriencies concerned against the U.S. dollar. The commercial banks' spot public rates for the U.S. dollar on December 31, 1977 were US$1.1529 buy ing, and US$1.1471 selling, per R l. Subject to certain limitations, authorized dealers are permitted to conduct fo rwa rd exchange operations among themselves and w i th overseas banks. The Reserve Bank provides fo rwa rd cover for private sector transac- tions in U.S. dollars only; such cover is given to author- ized dealers at a charge of 1 per cent per a n n um, for import and export t ransac t ions and for fore ign loans raised in their own names. There is also a market in which securities rand (the local sale and redemption proceeds of South A f r ican securities and other inves tmen ts in South A f r ica owned by nonresidents other than fo rmer residents of South A f r i c a) may be negotiated at free ly de te rm ined rates, usua l ly incu r r ing a d iscount on the o f f ic ial ma rket ra te; at the end of 1977, that discount was about 38 per cent, the middle closing rate on December 31 being R 1 = US$0.72. South Afr ica fo rma l ly accepted the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agree- ment, as of September 15, 1973. Exchange Control Territory There are v ir tua l ly no exchange or trade restrictions between the Republic of South Afr ica (def ined for exchange control purposes as inc lud ing South West A f r i c a ), Bophuthatswana, Lesotho, Swaziland, and Transkei, and these are regarded as fo rm ing, w i th the Republic of South A f r ica, a single exchange control territory, the Rand Mone tary Area. Administration of Control Import and export licenses are issued by the Director of Imports and Exports ac t ing on behalf of the Secretary for Commerce. Exchange licensing is the responsibility of the Treasury, which has delegated this au thor i ty to the South A f r ican Reserve Bank; in tu rn, the Reserve Bank has delegated to the authorized dealers much of its l icens ing power. Exchange for licensed impor ts is made available by the au thor ized dealers upon proof of sh ipment or, where advance p a ym e nt is proposed, upon presentation of other do cum en t a ry evidence, wh ich must include the prior approval of the Reserve Bank. Prescription of Currency All countries outside the Rand Monetary Area consti- tu te the Nonresident Area. Settlements w i th in the Rand Monetary Area take place in rand only.1 Swazi bank- notes and coins are convertible into rand at par without res tr ic t ion, but they are not legal tender in South A f r ica. Settlements by residents of the Rand Monetary Area w i th the Nonres ident Area, except Botswana and Rho- desia, may be made in rand to and f rom a Nonres ident Account and in any specified currency 2 and, for out- going payments only, in any other foreign currency.3 Settlements with Botswana may be made in rand to or f rom a local Bo tswana Account, in Botswana cur- rency, in rand f rom a local Nonresident Account to a Botswana Account ( for outgoing payments on ly ), in rand f rom a local Nonresident Account ( for inward paymen ts o n l y ), or in any specified currency ( f or inward paymen ts on ly ). Settlements w i th Rhodesia may be made in rand to and f rom a local Rhodesian or other nonres ident account, in Rhodesian currency and, for inward payments only, in any specified currency. Nonresident Accounts The rand accounts of persons resident outside the Rand Mone ta ry Area are divided into Bo tswana Accounts, Rhodesian Accounts, Nonresident Accounts, Securities Rand Accounts, and Blocked Accounts. Botswana Accounts are held by persons, firms, or companies ( inc lud ing bank s) resident, domiciled, or registered in Botswana. They may be credited w i th all authorized payments by South A f r ican residents, w i th the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South Afr ica of Botswana currency and of any specified cur- rency, and w i th payments f rom local Nonresident or Botswana Accounts. They may be debited for payments for exports to Botswana and other payments due by Botswana residents to South Afr ican residents, for pay- ments to the account holder while temporarily resident in South Afr ica for short periods, for payments to other local Botswana Accounts, and for the cost of purchases of Botswana currency. Rhodesian Accounts are held by persons, firms, or companies ( inc lud ing banks) resident, domiciled, or registered in Rhodesia. They may be credited w i th all 1 In September 1974 Swaziland issued its own currency, the lilangeni (p lu ral emalangeni), to replace the rand. Lilangeni bankno tes are free ly convertible into rand, at par, at the Monetary Au tho r i ty of Swaziland, but they are not legal tender in South A f r i c a. Checks and other bills of exchange drawn by Swazi residents for payment in South Africa and Lesotho must be denominated in rand. 2 Australian dollars, Austrian schillings, Belgian f ranc s, Canad ian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, Fiji dollars, French f rancs, Hong Kong dollars, Indian rupees, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Kenya shillings, Malagasy f rancs, Malawi kwacha, Ne the r lands guilders, New Zealand dollars, Norwegian kroner, Pak is tan rupees, Po r tugue se escudos, pounds sterling, Seychelles rupees, Spanish pesetas, Sri Lanka rupees, Swedish kronor, Swiss francs, Uganda shillings, U.S. dollars, zaires, and Zamb ian kwacha. 3 Foreign currency is any currency other than cu r rency that is legal tender in a country in the Rand Mone tary Area. 365 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SOUTH AFRICA authorized payments by South African residents, with the proceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South Africa of Rhodesian currency and of any specified cur- rency, and with payments from local Nonresident or Rhodesian Accounts. They may be debited for payments for exports to Rhodesia and other payments due by Rhodesian residents to South African residents, for pay- ments to the account holder while he is temporarily resi- dent in South Africa for short periods, for payments to other local Rhodesian Accounts, and for the cost of purchases of Rhodesian currency. Nonresident Accounts are held by persons, firms, or companies (including banks) resident, domiciled, or registered outside Botswana, Rhodesia, and the Rand Monetary Area. They may be credited with all author- ized payments by South African residents, with the pro- ceeds of sales to authorized dealers in South A f r ica of specified currency, and with payments from other Non- resident Accounts in South Africa. They may be debited for payments to South African residents for any purpose; for payments to nonresidents for any purpose, i.e., by transfer to a local Nonresident, Botswana, or Rhodesian Account or for remittance to any country outside the Rand Monetary Area; for the cost of purchases of any fore ign currency; and for payments to the account holder while he is temporarily resident in South Africa for short periods. Securities Rand Accounts are the accounts of nonresi- dents of the Rand Monetary Area, other than emigrants f rom that Area, to which exchange control restrictions have been applied. Such accounts are maintained with authorized banks. They must be credited w i th the local sale and redemption proceeds of South Afr ican securities and other investments in South Africa, owned by non- residents, excluding former residents of South Africa, and by imm ig ran ts within three years of arrival. Johan- nesburg Stock Exchange dealers are permitted to quote prices for securities rand and its members are permitted to buy and sell securities rand as agents, acting on behalf of nonresidents. Authorized banks are freely permitted to t rans fer securities rand balances f rom one Securities Rand Account in their books to another, in their own books or in the books of another authorized bank. In addition to transfer to another Securities Rand Account, funds in these accounts may be used freely for reinvest- ment in locally quoted securities (which may be exported and sold abroad); to acquire central government, muni- cipal, or public u t i l i ty stock with a ma tu r i ty of five years or more (the redemption proceeds of which are trans- ferable abroad when held for a continuous period of at least five years to redemption); and to tender for five-year nonresident bonds issued by the Treasury (the redemption proceeds of which are also t rans fe rab le ). The proceeds of South African securities held by immi- grants prior to their arrival in South Africa or acquired abroad within three years of their arrival, are also credited to Securities Rand Accounts, with the excep- 366 tion of funds of persons who had been South African residents. Blocked Accounts are the accounts of emigrants f rom the Rand Monetary Area to which exchange control restrictions have been applied.4 They must be credited with that part of an emigrant's assets which exceeds the amount that is transferable on departure. Such funds may not be transferred from South Africa or to another Blocked Account in South Africa, but may be retained on deposit with an authorized dealer, used within certain limits for the holder's living expenses while visiting South Africa, or invested in any securities which are quoted locally; such securities may not, however, be exported and sold abroad. Blocked rand may also be used, within a limit of R 30,000 for each emigrant fam i ly un i t, or R 10,000 for an individual, to subscribe to a special issue, made available by the Government to non- residents of South Africa only, of five-year nonresident bonds offered by tender on a discount basis and repay- able at face value. The redemption proceeds are trans- ferable in the currency of the monetary area in which the holder is resident. Imports and Import Payments All importers of goods requiring import licenses must be registered with the Director of Imports and Exports. Most licenses allow the importation of a range of com- modities, but they are, in general, to be used for goods as prescribed on the relevant import permit. Import licenses are valid for imports from any country. Imports free of license include (1) all goods imported f rom Botswana, Lesotho, or Swaziland and (2) all goods imported from Rhodesia, Malawi, and Zambia that were grown, produced, or manufactured in those countries. The Import Control Regulations for 1978, as announced in December 1977, distinguish generally between the following broad categories of imports: ( 1) Goods which may be imported without an import permit. This free list contains 524 tar iff headings or subheadings and corresponds to some 31.7 per cent of 1977 imports. (2) Goods which may be imported only under permit but subject to automatic licensing for bona fide mer- chants and manufac turers. These fall under an unspeci- fied number of tar iff headings or subheadings and corre- spond on a value basis to 57.3 per cent of 1977 imports. (3) Goods which may be imported only under permit and for which global quotas are determined f rom time to time. These account for about 5.2 per cent in value of 1977 imports. (4) Goods which may be imported only under permit and for which specific permits authorizing the import of these goods individually are issued. Generally these are issued when the imported goods are not available in 4 The local sale proceeds of South African assets, including South African securities, owned by residents of Botswana must be credited to a Securities Rand Account. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution South Africa. They cover some 5.8 per cent of 1977 imports. Upon presentation to his bank of the necessary con- signment documents (proof of impo r ta t ion ), and an import permit where required, an importer is automa- tically granted exchange to pay for the import. Pay- ments prior to the date of shipment or dispatch are not normally allowed except for certain capital goods, and provided that the terms are customary in the trade concerned. There is an import surcharge of 15 per cent on the value of all imports except those subject to a GATT binding and other agreements to which South Africa is a party. Payments for Invisibles There are no restrictions on payments and transfers for current international transactions. All payments to nonresidents of the Rand Monetary Area for current invisibles require exchange licenses. Authority is dele- gated to the authorized dealers to approve certain cur- rent invisible payments without limitation and others up to established limits. Applications for larger amounts are considered on their merits by the Reserve Bank. For current income payments, such as declared dividends, profits, royalties, etc., that accrue in South Africa, approval is given by the authorized dealers without ref- erence to the Reserve Bank, provided that the relative royalty agreement was approved by the Department of Industries and the Reserve Bank and the profits or divi- dends to be remitted by nonresident-owned branches and subsidiaries are based on profits earned since Decem- ber 31, 1974 and their remittance does not involve the use of local credit facilities. Favorable consideration is, however, given by the Reserve Bank to such transfers where the use of local credit facilities is not regarded as excessive. Income derived f rom securities acquired with blocked funds or securities rand, or otherwise held by nonresidents is freely transferable at the official market rate of exchange to the owner's country of residence. Limited amoun ts of exchange to pay for membership fees, fam i ly maintenance, etc., are authorized. The basic allowance for tourist travel in a year is R 2,000 for an adult and R 800 for a child under the age of 12. Separately, there is another annual basic exchange allocation of R 500 for an adult (R 200 for a child under 12) for travel to Angola, Botswana, Malawi, Mozambique, Rhodesia, Zaire, and Zambia. In addition to the tourist allowances, authorized dealers may grant allowances for business trips overseas at a rate not exceeding R 100 a day, with a m a x im um of R 3,000 in a calendar year. The applicable allowance for business trips to the neighboring territories mentioned above is R 500 a year. Residents leaving South Afr ica for destinations outside the Rand Monetary Area may take out not more than the equ iva lent of R 200 in banknotes. The amount of South Afr ican Reserve Bank notes, however, may not SOUTH AFRICA exceed R 50 but these are not regarded as being part of the basic travel allowance. Foreign visitors leaving South Africa within 12 months after arrival may take with them up to R50 in Reserve Bank notes and any amount of foreign notes which they brought into the country or obtained from the disposal of instruments of exchange that they brought to and exchanged in South Africa. These limitations on the export of Reserve Bank notes do not apply in the case of contract workers returning to neighboring countries, who are permitted to take with them reasonable amounts in banknotes repre- senting their earnings in South Africa. There are no limitations on the export of domestic currency to Bophuthatswana, Lesotho, Swaziland, and Transkei. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of commodities considered as being in rela- tively short supply, or for which domestic prices are substantially lower than those obtainable overseas, require licenses irrespective of destination (with the exception of exports to Bophuthatswana, Botswana, Lesotho, Swaziland, and Transke i). Certain other goods are controlled for strategic reasons only, and permits are required for their export to all destinations but no import certificate is required where the goods are exported to the United Kingdom, any Commonwealth country, any British colony, protectorate, or trust territory, or the United States. The re-export of imported goods to coun- tries outside the Rand Monetary Area other than Bots- wana is controlled to prevent commodity and exchange arbitrage. Unless otherwise permitted, all export proceeds must be remitted to South Africa and surrendered within six months f rom the date of shipment and /or seven days from the date of accrual. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered within seven days from the date of accrual, unless exemption is obtained. Upon entry from countries outside the Rand Monetary Area, residents and nonresidents may bring in R 50 in South African Reserve Bank notes. There are no limitations on the import of domestic currency from Bophuthatswana, Lesotho, Swaziland, and Transkei. Outward t rans fe rs of capital by residents to destinations outside the Rand Monetary Area require the approval of the South Afr ican Reserve Bank and are usually not allowed; transfers to Bophuthatswana, Lesotho, Swaziland, and Transkei do not require prior approval. Local borrowing by nonresident-owned or nonresident-controlled firms is subject to limitation. Transfers by residents for the purchase of South Afr ican (or o ther) shares on external stock exchanges are gen- erally not permitted (except in amounts not exceeding R 2,000 for each shareholder, to allow South Afr ican residents to exercise rights arising f rom existing holdings of shares in foreign companies quoted only on foreign stock exchanges), although South A f r ican stockbrokers may engage in arbitrage transactions in securities, sub- ject to certain conditions designed to prevent any net outflow of exchange. Applications by South Afr ican residents to retain in, or transfer to, neighboring coun- tries (excluding Bophu tha tswana, Lesotho, Swaziland, and Transkei) funds for bona fide long-term investment in specific development projects or for the expansion of existing projects that are owned or controlled by South A f r icans are considered by the South A f r ican Reserve Bank and the Treasury on their merits. For three years af ter their arrival in South Africa, imm igran ts (excluding former South A f r ican residents) may dispose of their foreign assets (including foreign cash f u n d s) held outside the Rand Monetary Area or otherwise invest them (including by purchase of South A f r ican securities ab road ). The proceeds f rom the sale of all South A f r ican securities brought in by immigrants must be credited to Securities Rand Accounts; there are no restrictions on the free use of such funds locally for the first three years of the immigrant's residence on amounts up to R 20,000 or, subject to Reserve Bank approval, on additional amounts, to enable the immi- grant to set up a home and to meet current living expenses. The proceeds of the sale of South African securities by nonresidents of South A f r ica to residents must be credited to Securities Rand Accounts (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). The following payments related to nonresident capital may be carried out by the authorized dealers without reference to the South A f r i- can Reserve Bank: transfers to nonresidents of South Afr ica of the proceeds on ma tu r i ty of government, muni- cipal, and public utility bonds and national savings certi- ficates (except those issued on October 1, 1974), pro- vided that they were registered in the name of the nonresident transferee (who was not an em ig ran t) on June 16, 1961, or, if the stocks were acquired after June 16, 1961, provided that they were registered con- tinuously in the beneficial owner's name for a period of not less than five years to redemption; normal capital repayments to nonresidents of South Afr ica by certain 368 "dying" mines in regular periodic installments not exceeding in any one year 10 per cent of the nominal value per share; transfers to nonresident owners of any balance of up to R 50 left over from the reinvestment of securities rand balances; and transfers of up to R 2,000 to a nonresident beneficiary from the proceeds of legacies f rom estates in South Africa where the total inheritance does not exceed R 2,000. Emigrant families whose net assets do not exceed R 20,000 may t ran s fer R 10,000 outside South Africa as a settling-in allowance, and those with larger assets may t rans fer 50 per cent of the total, up to R 30,000 for fam i l ies or R 10,000 for individuals; any balance exceeding the permissible transferable amount must be credited to a Blocked Account, and the value of any foreign assets is deducted from the applicable settling-in allowance. Em igran ts may, however, utilize such blocked funds up to an amount of R 30,000 a fam i ly unit, or R 10,000 for individuals, to subscribe to the five-year nonresident bonds issued by the Government on a tender basis (see section on Nonresident Accounts, above). The free transfer of income f rom an emigrant's blocked assets a n d / or a South Afr ican Trust is limited to a maxi- mum of R 100,000 for a fam i ly un it a year. An emi- grant fam i ly or a person can export only one motor vehicle, with a maximum value of R 10,000, provided that it was purchased at least one year prior to emigration. The South Afr ican Reserve Bank approves transfers of repayments at ma tur i ty to nonresident holders of mortgage bonds registered in their names on or before June 16, 1961. Favorable consideration is given for the transfer by nonresident-owned branches and subsidiaries of open or approved loan account balances or undistri- buted cu r rent prof i ts, or for the t rans fer of any dividends by them, provided that the remittance does not involve the excessive use of local credit facilities. The physical export from South Africa of nonresident-owned securi- ties is permitted, except by emigrants in excess of their settling-in allowance. There are normally four ways in which holders of securities rand ( inc lud ing holders resident in Botswana) can repatriate funds f rom South A f r ica: (1) by tak ing up special nonresident bonds issued by the Government (see above) —these mature in five years, when the redemption proceeds may be withdrawn at the official rate; (2) by holding certain government, municipal, and public utility bonds and national savings certificates (except those issued on October 1, 1974) for at least five years to redemption, when the proceeds can be transferred abroad at the official rate; ( 3) by exporting South A f r ican shares bought on the Johannesburg Stock Exchange, provided that they have been restrictively endorsed, and selling them outside South Africa at a price which may involve a premium or a discount on the South African quotation; and (4) by selling the funds to another nonresident for foreign currency. On ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution December 31, 1977, the discount on securities rand in terms of the official exchange rate was about 38 per cent. Gold Residents of South Africa may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in South Africa for numismatic and investment purposes. With this exception, residents of South Afr ica other than the monetary authorities, author- ized dealers, registered gold producers, and authorized industrial and professional users are not allowed to pur- chase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. All exports of gold require the prior approval of the Reserve Bank; the approval authority has been delegated to authorized dealers in respect of exports of jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler (subject to a written declaration to the effect that the jewe lry will be brought back to South Afr ica on the traveler's re tu rn) and in respect of exports of gold jewelry by manu fac tu r ing jewelers (except for exports to Botswana, Malawi, Rhodesia, and Z amb i a ), subject to a written declaration that the articles are in fu l ly manufac tured fo rm and that the gold content of each does not exceed 75 per cent of the selling price to the u l t ima te consignee. Furthermore, authorized dealers may, without reference to the Reserve Bank, allow resi- dents to export for sale to numismatists currency coins, including gold coins, up to R 300 for each applicant dur ing a calendar year; they may also allow residents to export one Krugerrand coin du r ing a calendar year to a nonresident in lieu of a monetary g i f t. The gold m in ing industry must sell its output to the Reserve Bank, within one month of production. As a special conces- sion mines may retain some of the production for the purpose of m in t ing gold coins. The Mint from time to time strikes gold coins and the Krugerrand without a face value, that are legal tender but do not circulate in South A f r ica; these are made available in limited numbers to resident collectors, while the bulk is sold abroad. Not for Redistribution SPAIN (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.0126953 gram of fine gold per Spanish Peseta. Spain avails itself of wider margins. The official intervention limits for the U.S. dollar have been suspended since January 22, 1974. The official buying and selling rates of the Bank of Spain on December 30, 1977 were Ptas 80.782 and Ptas81.042, respectively, per US$1. Official buy ing and selling rates for specified currencies l are fixed daily by the Bank of Spain ac t ing in consultation with the authorized banks. Purchases and sales of clearing currencies are centralized in the Bank of Spain, which publishes the rates at which it settles direct transactions. These rates are the same as the prevailing rates for the U.S. dollar. The Bank of Spain also quotes each week buying and selling rates for bank- notes in specified foreign currencies. Authorized banks are allowed to operate in fore ign markets for spot and forward transactions related to commercial operations for up to 360 days; forward trans- actions with customers are restricted to currencies ad- mitted to the Madrid fore ign exchange market and to permitted import and export transactions with a maturity up to 180 days. The forward peseta position of an individual bank must not reflect a net buy ing or selling balance at the close of each day. Exchange Control Territory The Peninsular Territories of the Spanish State, the Canary Islands, the Balearic Islands, Ceuta, and Melilla constitute a single exchange control territory. Administration of Control The guidelines on foreign exchange policy are formu- lated by an interministerial commission. The Ministry of Commerce is in charge of adm in is t ra t ive fun c t ions con- nected w i th exchange control. The Bank of Spain is in charge of operations, in particular, the hand l ing of external reserves. It is also responsible for the authoriza- tion of foreign currency loans to residents for nontrade purposes. Trade controls are adm in is tered by the Ministry of Commerce. The M in is t ry also is in charge of the con- trols over Spanish investment abroad, private Spanish lending abroad, fore ign financing of trade, and the regis- tra t ion of fore ign inves tmen ts in Spain. Contracts re la t ing to technological ma t te rs must be registered w i th the M in i s t ry of Indus t ry. Prescription of Currency Settlements on account of merchandise transactions and invisibles other than those with bilateral payments 1 Aus tr ian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deu... ' e ma rk, Finnish ma rkkaa, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Swedish kronor, Swiss f rancs, and U.S. dollars. 370 agreement countries may be made in any specified cur- rency1 but they are usually made in the currency of the coun try of origin or destination. Settlements w i th bilateral paymen ts agreement coun t r ies2 are made through agreement accounts expressed in U.S. dollars. Nonresident Accounts There are six types of nonresident accounts: Foreign Accounts in Pesetas for Payments in Spain (A Accoun ts), Foreign Accounts in Convertible Pesetas (B Accoun ts), External Accounts in Internal Pesetas, Nonresident Ac- counts in Convertible Foreign Currencies, Bank Ac- counts in Pesetas with Andorra, and Emigrants' Accounts. A Accounts may be freely credited w i th (1) the countervalue in pesetas of convertible currencies sold on the foreign exchange market; (2) amounts transferred f rom other A Accounts; ( 3) amounts transferred f rom B Accounts; and (4) any interest payable on the account. These accounts may be freely debited for ( 1) any pay- ment in pesetas in favor of Spanish juridical persons and Spanish or foreign physical persons legally resident in Spain ( inc lud ing payments relating to foreign invest- ment in Spa in ); and (2) transfers to other A Accounts. Debits for the purchase of foreign currency for remit- tance abroad are not permitted. B Accounts may be free ly credited with (1) any peseta collections generated in Spain that under existing rules are transferable abroad under powers delegated to authorized banks; (2) amounts transferred f rom other B Accounts; and (3) any interest payable on the account. The crediting of amounts originating f rom A Accounts is prohibited. B Accounts may be freely debited for (1) the countervalue in pesetas of foreign currency acquired on the foreign exchange market; (2) any payments in pesetas in favor of Spanish juridical persons and Spanish or foreign physical persons legally resident in Spain, including those relating to foreign investment in Spain; (3) transfers to other B Accounts; and (4) transfers to A Accounts. All other transactions on A or B Accounts require the prior authorization of the Ministry of Commerce. Private banks are required to make special noninterest- bearing deposits in cash at the Bank of Spain, in an amount equal to 100 per cent of the increases af ter October 18, 1971 in nonresident-held deposits in A and B Accounts (demand deposits, savings account deposits, or t ime deposits at less than three months' notice), and in an amount equal to 50 per cent of the increases in such deposits when held for three months or more (100 per cent of any increase after February 7, 1973). Fur- thermore, banks are prohibited from pay ing interest on any nonresident-held peseta deposits in A or B Accounts, whether demand, time, or savings deposits. 2 Colombia and Equatorial Guinea. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution External Accounts in Internal Pesetas are designed to hold funds accruing in Spain to nonresidents that are not transferable abroad ("blocked pesetas"). Prior approval is needed to open such an account. Balances are freely negotiable between nonresidents holding such accounts. These accounts may be credited freely with (1) the fu ll proceeds of the sale by a nonresident to a resident of Spanish real estate originally acquired with pesetas from an External Account in Internal Pesetas; (2) the full proceeds of the sale by a nonresident to a resident of Spanish shares and fixed-interest securities that have been acquired with pesetas from an External Account in Internal Pesetas and have been held for less than three years consecutively by the same owne r ;3 (3) receipts from the National Lottery; (4) any nontransferable wages, salaries, pensions, rents, or dividends accruing to the account holder; (5) interest received on balances held in these accounts; and (6) transfers f rom any other External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. They may be debited freely for (1) payments of any amount of personal expenses in Spain of the account holder and his close relatives (manager's personal expenses if the account is opened in the name of a juridical person); (2) the purchase of shares quoted on the stock exchange and of Spanish fixed-interest securities; (3) the purchase for the use of the account holder (provided that the account holder is a nonresident physical person) of urban and rural properties that do not represent invest- ment for commercial, industrial, or agricultural purposes (applicable to rural properties only if the account holder is of Spanish na t iona l i ty); (4) the purchase of National Lottery tickets; and (5) transfers to any other External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. All other entries on these accounts require prior authorization. The accounts may not be overdrawn. Nonresident Accounts in Convertible Foreign Cur- rencies may be held by nonresident foreign nationals, nonresident Spanish nationals, and nonresident firms or banks; resident foreign nationals may maintain such accounts only if opened before January 1, 1968. The deposits may be either sight or time. The accounts may be credited with convertible currencies quoted in the Spanish exchange market and with any amount of interest. They may be debited freely for reconversion into the currency initially deposited, for the purchase of other convertible currencies quoted in the Spanish exchange market, and for conversion into pesetas, includ- ing the transfer to an A Account. Overdrafts are pro- hibited except for mail credits in favor of foreign banks. Emigrants' Accounts—Since October 29, 1970, com- mercial banks have been authorized to open savings accounts in convertible pesetas for Spanish citizens working abroad. 3 The proceeds of such securities that have been held for at least three years consecutively are transferable abroad. SPAIN Imports and Import Payments All imports from Rhodesia are prohibited. Most im- ports are admitted under the following arrangements: ( 1) free imports, (2) global quotas, (3) state trading, and (4) individual licensing, also referred to as the "bilateral import regime." All imports require either an import license or an "import declaration" issued by the Directorate-General of Tariff Policy and Imports. Pro- vided that import prices are not considered abnormal, import declarations are issued freely for a large number of goods (mostly foodstuffs not under state trading, raw materials, capital goods, and spare parts, and also some consumer goods) included in an import free list that applies to most countries with which Spain has no bilateral payments agreements; the free list also applies to specified imports from Iran and Japan.4 All other imports require licenses. There are global quotas for specified imports f rom countries to which the free list applies, but licenses are usually granted for larger amounts.5 With certain excep- tions, the global quota regime also applies to goods of Japanese origin. Licenses for imports from Bulgaria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R. are issued freely. Imports of raw cotton, cer- tain other agricultural products, some raw materials, petroleum products, and tobacco are state traded; some goods formally listed as being subject to state trading, such as feedgrains, may be freely imported by private traders. Imports of certain agricultural products that are free of quantitative restriction and previously were state traded are subject to variable import levies. Import subsidies are paid on certain foodstuffs and specified other essential commodities. Exchange in the appropri- ate currency to pay for authorized imports is granted freely. Except for capital goods, suppliers' credit for imports is not normally permitted to exceed 90 days. All import transactions must be domiciled with an author- ized bank, and the import payment must be made through the intermediary of the bank of domiciliation; exempt f rom domiciliation are transactions whose value is less than Ptas 500,000 provided that payment is to be made within one year. Payments for Invisibles Some transfers abroad and payments by residents in favor of nonresidents on account of current invisibles are subject to individual authorization, for the purpose of checking capital transactions. Payments up to Ptas 5,000 for any purpose may be made freely. For a large propor- tion of invisibles, the banks are authorized to sell foreign exchange freely, provided that the request is supported by appropriate documents. For certain services, trans- 4 The import f r ee list does not apply to the payments agreement countries or to Afghanistan, Albania, Andorra, Bhutan, People's Republic of China, North Korea, Lao People's Democratic Republic, Mongolia, Nepal, San Marino, Tibet, U.S.S.R., and Viet Nam. 5 There are separate global quotas for imports of the same com- modities from EEC countries. 371 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN fers may be made freely up to a pre-established amount; for transfers which exceed that amount licenses are required. Holders of Spanish securities (excluding securities issued by private companies and acquired through direct subscription) may freely transfer abroad accrued interest, dividends, and proceeds from the disposal of subscription rights; the securities must have been purchased with con- vertible pesetas, with pesetas resulting f rom the sale of foreign exchange, or with pesetas released from External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. Profits and dividends on direct investments are also transferable abroad w i thout restriction. Rents on nonresident-owned real estate are transferable, provided that the purchase price has been paid in full and the owner has no outstanding tax liabili- ties applicable to the property. A general license permits the reinsurance abroad of risks insured in Spain with Spanish firms or with foreign insurance companies operating in Spain. Insurance contracts abroad may not be concluded, except where they concern exports and imports of goods. The basic exchange allowance for tourism is Ptas 50,000 a person a year, but additional amounts are approved freely for bona fide tourist expenses. The authorized banks are also permitted to sell the equiva- lent of Ptas 2,000 a day for business trips, up to the equivalent of Ptas 100,000 a person for each trip. For larger amounts, the banks must apply for approval. Travelers may take with them Ptas 3,000 in notes of the Bank of Spain (Ptas 10,000 for persons going to Ando r ra ). Exports and Export Proceeds All exports are subject to prior licensing by the Directorate-General of Exportation. All export proceeds must be sold in the exchange market or to the Bank of Spain through authorized banks. Certain agricultural exports are subject to an export tax. Proceeds from Invisibles All exchange proceeds from invisibles must be sold in the exchange market or to the Bank of Spain through authorized banks. Travelers may bring in a maximum of Ptas 50,000 in notes of the Bank of Spain. Capital Direct foreign investment for the purpose of establish- ing Spanish companies is authorized except in those cases where prior administrative authorization is required; for participation in public service companies in general such investment is allowed only up to 40 per cent of the capital participation. Foreign investments must be made f rom abroad in the form of foreign capital, equipment manu fac tu red abroad, technical assistance, and other means approved by the Spanish authorities. The paid-up capital must not be less than Ptas 100 million and the Spanish company may not make payments in respect of technology to the foreign investor or to its subsidiary or 372 associated companies (except for duly specified and justified services) and in no case may the payments be regular or related to the level of activity of the Spanish company. The company in question must create at least 100 jobs for a permanent staff at the time of coming into operation and must maintain a positive balance of for- eign currency after one year of operation. The capital of the company may be less than Ptas 100 million provided that ( 1) af ter one year of operation total exports repre- sent at least 50 per cent of turnover and the turnover figure is not less than Ptas 100 million and (2) the company creates at least 1,000 jobs at the time of com- mencing production. Foreign direct investments are also authorized in Spanish companies that are in the process of increasing their capital. This may be effected through the purchase of shares or investment in the capital provided that the company creates 100 permanent jobs, that the foreign currency account shows a positive balance after one year of production, that the total capital and reserves of the company is increased by at least 30 per cent and that at least Ptas 100 million is invested in the purchase of shares. Special foreign participation ratios and regulations apply to certain specific activities.6 Foreign investment in Spanish companies manufacturing capital goods that are listed in the Appendix List of the Customs Code requires registration only; within 30 days the registra- tion may be deemed an authorization if no notification to the contrary has been received. Foreign investment is not permitted in Spanish enterprises whose activity is directly connected with national defense, while invest- ment in firms dealing with public information and in certain public services is subject to specific regulations. Foreign investment for the purpose of modernizing, expanding, and establishing Spanish enterprises may be effected by transferring currencies that are negotiable in the Madrid exchange market, by using convertible pesetas, by bringing in capital goods, by reinvesting profits or capital transferable under the Foreign Investment Law, or by providing know-how, patents, or licenses. Proceeds, including capital appreciation, f rom the liquidation of foreign direct investments made for the purpose of establishing, modernizing, and expanding Spanish enterprises may be transferred freely. Purchases by nonresidents of shares in most Spanish companies are permitted freely up to the percentages applicable to direct investment. This applies to shares acquired by Spaniards resident abroad, as well as by resident or nonresident foreigners, either with convertible 6 The foreign content of investment by Spanish companies with foreign participation is determined in the following manner: (1) if foreign participation exceeds 50 per cent, the investment is considered 100 per cent foreign; (2) if foreign participation is over 25 per cent but equal to or less than 50 per cent, the investment is considered foreign to the extent of such participation; nevertheless, if foreign investors enjoy a position of dominance, the investment is considered 100 per cent foreign; and (3) if foreign participation is 25 per cent or less or if there is Spanish Government participation, the investment is considered as domestic. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution pesetas or with pesetas resulting f rom the conversion of foreign currencies negotiable in the Spanish exchange market. Proceeds, including capital gains, f rom the liquidation of such shares may be transferred abroad at any time, or used for fur ther purchases of shares.7 Purchases by nonresidents of bonds and other fixed- income securities representing debts of either Spanish companies or the Spanish Government and its agencies are unrestricted when financed as indicated in this para- graph, and the fu ll sales proceeds are transferable. Investment in Spanish real estate by nonresidents is, within certain limits,8 freely permitted if financed with pesetas derived from convertible currencies or f rom balances in nonresident peseta accounts (A or B Ac- coun ts). The Ministry of Commerce has empowered authorized banks to provide the investor with a docu- ment certifying that he owns such pesetas; this is the only requirement for official registration of the change in ownership. Certain investments in real estate may also be financed from External Accounts in Internal Pesetas. Irrespective of the method of financing, rural properties purchased may not exceed 4 hectares of irrigated land or 20 hectares of unirrigated land. When Spanish real estate is sold to a resident, the fu ll sales proceeds are trans- ferable if the initial purchase was financed with con- vertible foreign currency or with pesetas f rom an Ex- ternal Account in Convertible Pesetas, an A Account, or a B Account. If the initial purchase was financed with pesetas f rom an External Account in Internal Pesetas, no part of the sale proceeds is transferable. Outward capital transfers by residents require ap- proval. Requests by firms to invest abroad in the same line of business are granted rather liberally, provided that the investment contributes to the expansion of Spanish exports; this includes participation in foreign enterprises. No formal authorization is required for such invest- ments when under taken by Spanish firms which have been granted an ind iv idual "export card" and have net assets in Spain of at least Ptas 100 million, provided that the firm's total foreign investments do not exceed 40 per cent of its assets in Spain. Other direct investments are subject to more severe restrictions. Portfolio invest- ments by all residents and purchases of real estate abroad by private persons are severely restricted. However, registered investment funds with assets of at least Ptas 1 billion are permitted to place up to 10 per cent of their assets in foreign securities that are officially quoted on specified stock exchanges abroad. There are separate regulations for the purchase of business premises. SPAIN to those applied to residents' requests to make direct investments abroad. Suppliers' credits from Spanish residents to nonresidents require authorization by the Ministry of Commerce. There has been no experience with the issuing of bonds in the Spanish capital market by nonresidents, nor with short-term credits granted by Spanish banks to non- residents other than certain export credits granted directly to foreign importers. Credits to nonresidents for trans- actions with Spain may, however, be authorized by the M in is try of Commerce. Also, authorized banks may extend various types of credit to nonresidents, provided that this credit is financed with funds deposited in Spain in nonresident convertible currency accounts; some forms of such credit do not require prior approval by the Ministry of Commerce. Local bank credit extended at medium term or long term to Spanish firms with foreign participation in excess of 25 per cent is subject to special directives, but domestic bank credit for up to 18 months may be granted, irrespective of the degree of foreign participation, on the same conditions as to wholly Spanish-owned firms. For transfers abroad of bona fide inheritances and dowries, authorizations are granted liberally. Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Spain for numismatic purposes. Otherwise, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any fo rm other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Only the Bank of Spain is allowed to import or export gold, and indus- trial requirements are met by imports effected by the Bank of Spain. There is a global quota for imports of gold f rom member countries of the EEC. Changes during 1977 January 19. The suspension of import duties on raw cocoa beans was extended to March 1977 by Royal Decree No. 3093/76. January 21. Royal Decree No. 3099/77 concerning foreign investment was published. Its purpose was to facilitate the entry of foreign capital by means of a general automatic authorization that freed certain invest- ments f rom the formalities previously enforced. Under the provisions of the Decree, direct fore ign investment for the purpose of establishing Spanish companies with more than 50 per cent of foreign capital was authorized auto- matically except in those cases where prior administra- tive authorization was required for the installation. Such foreign investments must be made from abroad by means of foreign capital, equipment manufac tured abroad, technical assistance, and other means approved by the Spanish authorities. The paid-up capital must be not less than Ptas 100 million and the Spanish company should not make payments in respect of technology to the for- eign investor or to its subsidiary or associated companies (except in respect of du ly specified and justified services) 373 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SPAIN and in no case should payments be regular or related to the level of activity of the Spanish company. To benefit from the Royal Decree, the company must create at least 100 permanent jobs at the time of coming into operation and must ma in ta in a positive balance of foreign currency a f ter one year of operation. The capital of the company might be less than Ptas 100 million pro- vided that ( 1) after one year of operation its exports would not be less than at least 50 per cent of turnover and the turnover figure would represent not less than Ptas 100 million and (2) the company would have created at least 1,000 jobs at the time of commencing production. Foreign direct investments were also authorized in Spanish companies that were in the process of increas- ing their capital through the purchase of shares and investment in the capital, provided that the company created 100 permanent jobs, that there would be a posi- tive balance of foreign currency in the first year of production, that the total capital and reserves of the company were increased by at least 30 per cent, and that at least Ptas 100 million was invested in the purchase of shares. Previously, authorization was limited to 50 per cent or less of the capital of a new company, all investments in excess of this limit requiring the specific authority of the Council of Ministers. January 27. A resolution of the Ministry of Com- merce liberalized the import of certain pharmaceutical and household goods. February 2. Global import quotas were announced for 1977. February 22. The Council of Ministers adopted a short-term economic program to revitalize the Spanish economy. Some fiscal reforms were introduced. April 12. Royal Decree No. 612/77 of the Ministry of Commerce extended the temporary 20 per cent tariff surcharge for six months, with effect f rom April 8. April 15. Royal Decree No. 653/77 of the Ministry of Commerce established quotas for 1977 on steel products that were free of import duties. April 25. The Bank of Spain announced new regula- tions (effective May 2) to ensure that the forward ex- change market was used only for covering the exchange risk incurred under authorized transactions. Forward transactions were limited to six months, although con- tracts could be renewed. Foreign currency contracted forward could be used only to collect or pay the princi- pal transaction. At the close of each day, the forward peseta position of each bank might not reflect a net selling balance and the foreign currency position might not show a net buying balance. July 12. The peseta was allowed to float downward in the exchange market. The opening buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were set at Ptas 87.30 and Ptas 87.50, respectively, per US$1, representing a depre- ciation of the peseta against the U.S. dollar of 19.7 per cent compared with the final fixing of the previous business day (July 8). July 19. A Royal Decree stipulated that the prices of goods and services in the next three months could be increased only in line with rises in production costs. July 23. The 20 per cent temporary tariff surcharge was eliminated. July 28. Spain formally applied for full membership in the EEC. October 25. The Government's new economic pro- gram was announced, which included a ceiling on wages of 22 per cent for 1978, a limitation of the budget deficit to Ptas 73 billion, a 17 per cent limit on the growth of the money supply, and a number of other fiscal measures. October 28. The Government reduced from 60 to 30 the number of items whose prices may be increased only with cabinet approval. Items still subject to price con- trols included milk, coffee, sugar, cooking oil, bread, frozen fish, fertilizers, cement, gasoline, electricity, and train fares. November 14. A bill on urgent tax measures was approved by the Senate. The bill provided for increased tax receipts, heavier taxation on upper-income brackets, and certain other taxes. 374 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution SRI LANKA (Position on December 31,1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.149297 gram of fine gold per Sri Lanka Rupee. Since November 15, 1977 the official exchange rate for the Sri Lanka rupee has been permitted to float. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar, and the Central Bank of Ceylon intervenes in major currencies to prevent erratic movements in the exchange rates. On December 31, 1977, the spot buying and selling rates for telegraphic transfers were SLRs 15.53 and SLRs 15.59, respectively, per US$1. The Central Bank quotes daily rates for deutsche mark, French francs, Indian rupees, Japanese yen, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars, on the basis of demand and supply conditions in Sri Lanka and movements in the international exchange markets. The Central Bank has established margins between buying and selling rates equivalent to SL Rs 3 per US$100 (1.875 per mill) and SL Rs 5.50 per £ stg. 100 (1.893 per m i l l ). Equivalent margins have been established for the deutsche mark, the French franc, the Japanese yen, and the Indian rupee. No other charges are made by either the Central Bank or the commercial banks. The Central Bank stands ready to provide forward cover to commercial banks in U.S. dollars only. The forward rate reflects the difference between U.S. interest rates and local interest rates. At the end of 1977 the Central Bank sold U.S. dollars forward at a premium over spot rate of SL Re 1 per US$100 a month, and purchased U.S. dollars forward at a discount against spot of SLRe 1 per US$100 a month. The option for delivery during the max imum period of two months is permitted at an added marg in of SLRe 1 per US$100 for the first month and SL Rs 2 per US$100 for the second month. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Department of Exchange Control of the Central Bank as agent of the Government. All remittances of foreign exchange in Sri Lanka must normally be made through commer- cial banks authorized to carry out operations in foreign currencies in accordance w i th the exchange control pro- cedures prescribed by the Controller of Exchange. Remittances may also be made through post offices, under permits issued by the Controller of Exchange. Prescription of Currency Settlements with countries with which Sri Lanka has bilateral payments agreements l and with Egypt must be made through the relevant special accounts. Pay- ments in respect of trade w i th Pak is tan also are effected through special accounts. Payments to, and receipts 1 People's Republic of China, Syrian Arab Republic, and U.S.S.R. from, member countries of the Asian Clearing Union other than Pakistan (i.e., Bangladesh, Burma, India, Iran, and Nepal) in respect of current transactions (other than those relating to petroleum, natural gas, and their products) must be effected in Asian monetary units or in the currency of a member of the Asian Clear- ing Union; for settlements with Pakistan, these arrange- ments are applicable to invisibles only. For settlements with all other countries (except Rho- desia) payments for imports may be made in any for- eign currency or in Sri Lanka rupees. Other payments may be made either in the currency of the country to which the payment is due or by crediting Sri Lanka rupees to an External Rupee Account. Proceeds from exports must be received in designated foreign curren- cies.2 Other receipts may be accepted in Sri Lanka rupees from an External Rupee Account or in any designated foreign currency.2 Special procedures apply to settlements with Rhodesia. Nonresident Accounts Nonresident accounts may be held in Sri Lanka by foreign banks, firms, and companies registered outside Sri Lanka and by persons residing abroad. A local credit to these accounts, which is tantamount to approval for remittance abroad, and debits in respect of remit- tances abroad require the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. Nonresident blocked accounts are used for holding funds that have not been accepted for transfer abroad, usually funds owned by nonresidents, repatriates, and emigrants. Such funds may be used in Sri Lanka for certain investments, subject to the prior approval of the Controller of Exchange. Proceeds from the liquidation of such investments must be credited to blocked accounts. A single initial remittance up to a maximum of SL Rs 10,000 is allowed, subject to prior approval of the exchange control authorities. Also retained in blocked accounts is a proportion of local currency earn- ings, derived from the exhibition of foreign-owned films, if the takings exceed the amount specified in the import license; such retained funds may be used by the owner for certain specified purposes, including the making of films in Sri Lanka. Sri Lanka nationals resident abroad are allowed to maintain nonresident foreign currency accounts in Sri Lanka in convertible currencies.3 Credits to the accounts are limited to the proceeds of remittances from abroad and money brought into the country by individuals at the t ime of arrival; also, interest payments in the two 3 Australian dollars, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish kroner, deutsche ma rk, French francs, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders. Norwegian kroner, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 3 At present in pounds sterling and U.S. dollars. 375 ©International Monetary Fund. These accounts may be freely debited without exchange control approval for payments outside or within Sri Lanka in foreign currency, while the account holder is outside Sri Lanka, and for a period of three years from the date of arrival of the account holder in Sri Lanka. Imports and Import Payments All imports of goods originating in or shipped from Rhodesia are prohibited. Except for a list of specified imports, no prior licensing is required. Imports that are subject to prior license include those subject to control for security reasons, precious metals, alcohols, and cer- tain consumer goods, in addition to several major food items (rice, sugar, flour, and wheat gra ins) and fertilizers. Imports of specified commodities 4 are restricted to government or state corporations; these commodities are referred to as "reserved items." Public sector imports shipped f rom places served by vessels of the Ceylon Shipping Corporation must be carried in vessels owned or chartered by the Corporation, if shipping space is available. Prior approval procedures apply to a list of imports of capital goods. The Local Investment Advi- sory Committee approves the import when the invest- ment is local and the Foreign Investment Advisory Committee handles applications relating to foreign investment. No prior approval is required if any single consignment does not exceed SL Rs 700,000 in value. Holders of balances in Convertible Rupee Accounts, which were abolished for new credits as of November 16, 1977, may use these funds to pay for certain imports, subject to approval by the Controller of Imports and Exports. Imports can be made only against sight letters of credit, except for specified transactions. An authorized dealer may approve an application to remit foreign exchange or to credit a Nonresident Account when the applicant furnishes a copy of the application for the opening of a letter of credit, and proof of a valid import license, when applicable. These requirements do not apply where the value of a consignment is less than SL Rs 2,500 and is for the direct use of the importer. Payments for Invisibles Certain payments for invisibles require exchange con- trol permission. For travel abroad, nationals of Sri Lanka are allowed a basic fore ign exchange allowance of SL Rs 2,000 an adult and SL Rs 1,000 a child under 12 years of age, once every two years, for travel to Bangladesh, Burma, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan, and Thailand. In addition, a basic allowance of £ stg. 500 an adult and £ stg. 250 a child under 12 years of age is allowed every four years for travel to other countries. Additional foreign exchange is pro- vided to pay for fares. The prior approval by the 4These include mainly rice, wheat flour (but not corn flour), unre- fined sugar, refined sugar, Maldive fish, dried fish, bidi leaves, petroleum products, and films. 376 Central Bank is not required for these sales of exchange. Allowances for official travel require a certificate from the head of the relevant institution. Banks can also provide foreign exchange for business travel when the request is accompanied by a letter from the chairman or director of the company recommending the particular trip abroad. In those cases, exchange is allowed at the rate of SL Rs 350 a day, up to a maximum of 30 days, for the above-mentioned neighboring countries and US$75 a day, also up to a maximum of 30 days, for other destinations. These limits apply to chairmen, directors, and partners of companies; other business executives may obtain up to SL Rs 225 a day for neigh- boring countries and up to US$50 a day, up to a maxi- mum of 30 days, for other countries. Foreign exchange may be released for medical treatment abroad, within certain guidelines, if a government specialist certifies that equally effective treatment is not available in Sri Lanka. Other types of travel allowances require prior consideration by the Central Bank. Exchange and passage for educational purposes at a recognized university or technical institute at under- graduate or postgraduate levels, or for specialized tech- nical t ra in ing not available in Sri Lanka and of use to the country, is allowed by the exchange control authori- ties. Foreign exchange is made available up to £ stg. 100 a month for subsistence for graduate students (£ stg. 75 a month for undergradua tes), in addition to actual fees and allowances for books. Indian and Pakistani nationals are permitted to remit for fam i ly maintenance a maximum of SL Rs 750 a month or one third of their gross monthly income, whichever is less. Other foreign nationals are permitted to remit £ stg. 85 a month for a wife, £ stg. 145 for a boy in a senior school, £ stg. 131 for a girl in a senior school, £ stg. 100 for a boy in a jun ior school, and £ stg. 90 for a girl in a jun ior school, up to a maximum of one third of the gross monthly income of the parent; any excess of the total of such remittances over one third of gross monthly income is treated as an antici- patory transfer against the non-national's entitlement to remit assets at the time of repatriation. When the amount claimed on this basis exceeds one third of the gross monthly income, the excess will be treated as an anticipatory transfer to be set off against the amount that may eventually be repatriated upon departure. Temporary residents on short-term contracts are allowed to remit up to two thirds of their gross monthly income. Nationals of Sri Lanka are not granted exchange for fam i ly remittances. Commissions up to 5 per cent of the c.i.f. value are allowed on export orders secured through agents abroad. No remittances for insurance on exports are permitted; these must be covered with the Insurance Corporation of Sri Lanka. Holders of funds in Convertible Rupee Accounts with credit balances outstanding as of November 15, 1977 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution may use these funds for travel expenditures and other current invisibles, subject to approval by the Controller of Exchange. Banks are authorized, without prior exchange control approval, to provide foreign exchange for subscriptions to professional institutions, fees in respect of foreign examinations held in Sri Lanka, and payments for the import of material for correspondence courses. Profit remittances may be effected through commer- cial banks without prior exchange control approval if they relate to a period of not more than two years from the date of application, provided the following docu- ments are furnished: (1) an audited copy of the com- pany's profit and loss account and the balance sheet for the year to which the remittance relates; (2) a certified copy of the minutes of the meeting of the company declaring the profit, a certificate f rom the auditors con- firming that the profit has been declared in respect of the year under review, less tax, and that it does not include any undistributed profits or any appreciation due to the sale of any of the company's reserves or any apprecia- tion due to the sale of any of the company's fixed assets; (3) a certificate of balance of all the accounts with commercial banks in Sri Lanka; (4) a certified copy of the names and addresses of nonresident shareholders and the amounts invested by each of them; (5) compu- tation of the remittable profits; and (6) a tax clearance certificate in respect of the profits to be remitted. Remittances of dividends to nonresident shareholders of rupee companies may be allowed without prior exchange control approval if such dividends are solely out of profits of the year in question, do not include any undistributed profits of previous years, do not include transfers f rom reserves and profits arising f rom the sale of fixed assets, and if the following documents are fu r- nished: (1) an audited copy of the company's profit and loss account and the balance sheet for the year to which the dividend relates; and (2) a tax clearance cer- tificate in respect of the dividend payment covering the full amount due to all nonresident shareholders of the company, along with a schedule indicating the names of the nonresident shareholders and the net amount of dividends due to each of them. Nonresident travelers may take out foreign exchange declared to the customs at the time of entry. Conver- sion is authorized up to SL Rs 500. Residents may take out foreign currency notes and coins not exceeding «£ stg. 20 a person (£ stg. 10 for children under 12) out of the exchange authorized for travel. All persons leaving Sri Lanka may take out domestic currency notes not exceeding SL Rs 250 a person. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports to Rhodesia are prohibited. Exports to countries with which Sri Lanka ma in ta ins bilateral pay- ments agreements are subject to the approval of the Director of Commerce. Most exports require an export license issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports; SRI LANKA licenses for tea are issued by the Commissioner of Tea Exports and those for coconut products by the Coconut Marketing Board. Rubber exports to the People's Republic of China, Poland, Romania, and the U.S.S.R. are effected under state trading. The State Gem Corpo- ration has control of exports of gems and jewelry. Private sector gem exports require prior approval and the Corporation handles exports in the name of gem miners who wish to export gems. Re-exports of non- monetary gold, silver, diamonds, and platinum are allowed only in special circumstances. Foreign exchange proceeds from exports must be surrendered, usually within six months of the date of shipment, except in the case of tea exports to London auctions when the prescribed period is four months. Payments can be made either in Sri Lanka rupees from accounts of a foreign bank maintained with a local bank, or from accounts of persons resident outside Sri Lanka that are maintained with authorized dealers and are approved by the Central Bank, or in designated foreign currencies. Special terms apply to exports made in respect to provisions of trade and payments agree- ments or to exports made to a member country of the Asian Clearing Union. Proceeds from Invisibles Foreign exchange proceeds from invisibles must be surrendered. A traveler entering Sri Lanka must declare his holdings, including currency notes and coins. The amount of foreign funds that may be carried into Sri Lanka in the form of travel credit instruments is not restricted. The import of Indian and Pakistan cur- rency is not permitted. A person entering Sri Lanka may bring in domestic currency notes not exceeding SL Rs 250. Other currency notes and coins may be brought in without restriction. Capital Investments of foreign capital are permitted in proj- ects which are specifically approved by the Government, or, where the capital is drawn from a Blocked Account in Sri Lanka, in certain investments in Sri Lanka that have been approved by the Controller of Exchange, including shares of public companies incorporated in Sri Lanka. Proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments in approved projects other than investments made from Blocked Accounts may be repatriated, along with capital appreciation. Proceeds from the sale or liquidation of investments not approved by the Govern- ment may not be transferred abroad, but may be rein- vested with the approval of the Controller of Exchange; the current income thereon may be remitted abroad. New foreign investments in Sri Lanka that are con- sidered and approved by the Foreign Investment Advi- sory Committee of the Ministry of Finance and Planning are also granted special facilities in respect of remit- tances and taxation. Investments abroad by residents are not normally permitted. 377 ©International Monetary Fund. Authorized dealers may grant allocations to em ig ran ts upon presentation of appropriate documentation. At the time of departure, emigrants can obtain passage to the country of migration by normal direct route and 10 per cent of passage fa re to cover excess baggage. Exchange equivalent to £ stg. 300 an adult and £ stg. 150 a child under 12 years of age can also be purchased at the time of departure. Personal effects (up to SLRs 5,000, and jewelry up to SL Rs 7,500) can be exported as well. The Department of Exchange Control can approve transfer of pension in fu l l, or £ stg. 100 a month, inc lud ing pension and other income, subject to production of an income-tax clearance certificate, if necessary, in respect of the amount to be remitted. Repatriates leaving Sri Lanka for residence in the country of their permanent domicile are permitted, at the time of their departure, to transfer assets represent- ing their retirement funds and a reasonable amount of savings as determined by the Government from time to time. Persons who have been in business in Sri Lanka are allowed to t ran s fer the capital they originally brought into the country plus a reasonable amount of savings, subject to certain limits. Special provisions, governed by an agreement between Sri Lanka and Ind ia, apply to Ind ian fam i l ies re turn ing to India. Gold Imports and exports of gold in any fo rm require licenses issued by the Controller of Imports and Exports w i th the approval of the Central Bank. The People's Bank, the sole importer of gold, has not imported any nonmonetary gold since July 1972. It sells gold in small quantities to licensed craftsmen and jewelers and also to hospitals. Commercial imports of jewelry and of other articles con ta in ing gold are severely restricted. Changes during 1977 February 1. For goods that require individual licensing, import licenses must be obtained f rom the M in is t ry of Finance and Na t ional Economy and be validated by the Ex- change Control Depar tment of the Bank of Sudan. These licenses, wh ich also requ i re va l ida t ion, are issued for a large number of consumer goods, raw ma ter ia ls, spare parts, and indus t r ial goods. Import insurance norma l ly must be taken out with local companies. Most private sector impor ts are subject to an advance deposit of 2 per cent of the c. & f. value, payable before va l ida t ion, and a surcharge of 5 per cent is levied on the c.i.f. va lue of all impor ts. Capital goods, heavy trucks, tires and tubes, medicines, spare parts, raw ma ter ia ls for factories, and commod i t ies imported either for government un i ts or on beha lf of government depar tmen ts are exempt from advance deposits. Not for Redistribution Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require exchange control approval. Remittances are permitted for fam i ly main- tenance (up to LSd360 a person a yea r ), educational expenses (up to LSd 1,200 a student a year for Western Europe, in addition to tuition fees; study in the United States is exempt from this ceiling), and for certain other purposes. Allowances for tourist travel to countries other than Egypt are authorized by the commercial banks up to a maximum of <£ stg. 60 every other year for an adult traveling to Western Europe and the United States, and <£ stg. 40 every other year for travel to other areas. Allowances for nonbusiness travel to Egypt, also authorized by the commercial banks, are the equivalent of US$90 an adult and US$50 a child, a year. Exchange for travel must be purchased at an effective exchange rate of LSd 1 = US$2.50. Sudanese nationals working abroad and certain spe- cified groups resident in Sudan having earnings abroad who have availed themselves of the special arrangement for remittances and other receipts at the rate of LSd 1 = US$1.74 may retransfer for such amounts abroad provided the exchange subsidy is forfeited. Salaried foreign nationals not permanently resident in Sudan, except Egyptian nationals, are permitted to remit their bona fide current savings to any country other than Israel, Rhodesia, or South Africa. Shipping charges, insurance premiums, profits, interest, and dividends earned by nonresidents may be remitted freely upon presentation of the required documents. The remittance of income accruing f rom blocked assets in Sudan (includ- ing income from Blocked Accounts) is prohibited, except for earnings from investments in government securities made before 1970. The exportation of Suda- nese currency is prohibited. Stamp duties are payable on the application forms for virtually all payments for invisibles. The duty is LSd 5 on applications for remittances of profits and dividends, for other transfers, and for foreign exchange for business travel, LSd 2 on applications for foreign exchange for tourism, and from LSd 1 to LSd 0.25 on applications for remittances for other purposes; government remittances and those by diplomats are exempt. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. With the exception of cotton and gum arabic, all exports require a license. Exporters must submit an export form to an authorized bank. Except for hides and skins, authorized banks may approve these forms only if payment is in the form of cash against documents or against sight letters of credit or if payment takes place in advance; exports on credit require the approval of the Bank of Sudan. All commodities are subject to m in imum export prices. The proceeds of exports must be repatriated and surrendered through an authorized bank. When the terms of payment are cash against documents or sight letter of credit, proceeds must SUDAN be surrendered on delivery of the shipping documents; in other cases a surrender date is usually specified. Some major export commodities are exported solely by public sector entities. At times exports of some commodities have been prohibited for supply reasons (including at the end of 1977 du r ra ). Certain, generally minor, exports may be sold on a full or partial barter basis or on consignment. Most exports are subject to a develop- ment tax of 5 per cent ad valorem. Proceeds from Invisibles Sudanese nationals working abroad may open accounts denom ina ted in Sudanese pounds by remittance of for- eign exchange with a subsidy on the official rate of 65 per cent yielding a rate of LSd 1 = US$1.74. Retrans- fer abroad of such amounts is freely permitted upon deduction of the exchange subsidy. Moreover, the foreign exchange may be utilized for purchases in duty- free shops in Sudan. The same facilities are granted to certain groups in Sudan who earn foreign exchange abroad, including lawyers, engineers, owners of con- su l tant houses, chartered accountants, pensioners receiv- ing pensions in foreign currencies, employees in inter- national and regional institutions in Sudan with earnings in foreign exchange, Sudanese diplomats and missions paid in foreign exchange, and Sudanese nationals who acquire properties abroad by inheritance or in other ways. Receipts from abroad in respect of other invisibles must be surrendered to authorized banks and are sub- ject to the general prescription of currency requirements. Travelers entering Sudan may bring in any amount in notes and coins of other countries but the importation of Sudanese currency is forbidden. Capital Incoming foreign capital for specified investment may be registered and may receive, among other advantages, a guarantee for repatriation of the original capital and profits thereon. Emigrants of Sudanese nationality may on departure transfer up to the equivalent of LSd 1,500 to their new country. Upon final departure from Sudan, resident foreigners may transfer up to the equivalent of LSd 2,500. Gold Residents may purchase, hold, and sell gold coins in Sudan for numismatic purposes. Subject to certain con- ditions, residents may also purchase, hold, and sell in Sudan domestically produced gold. With these excep- tions, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized industrial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require licenses issued by the Ministry of Commerce and Supply; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users.
