Not for Redistribution UGANDA (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 0.103133 gram of fine gold per Uganda Shilling. A central rate of U Sh 9.66000 = SDR 1 has been established, and Uganda avails itself of wider margins. The Bank of Uganda does not deal in foreign currencies l other than deutsche mark, pounds sterling, and U.S. dollars; its rates for the U.S. dollar are based on the Fund's daily calculation of the U.S. dollar-SDK rate, and its rates for deutsche mark and pounds sterling on the previous day's New York rates against the U.S. dollar. Authorized commercial banks in Uganda deal in all specified currencies 2 and base their rates on the previous day's closing rates against the U.S. dollar in New York, except for Kenya shillings and Tanzania shillings, which are dealt in at par. Authorized banks may freely deal forward with cus- tomers in sterling, U.S. dollars, and other currencies, provided that there is an underlying approved import or export contract and that the term of the forward con- tract does not exceed three months; contracts for longer periods require exchange control approval. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Uganda on behalf of the Minister of Finance. Import and export control is administered by the Ministry of Commerce. The Minister of Commerce has powers to prohibit imports and exports. Together with Kenya and Tanzania, Uganda formed part of the East Afr ican Community. However, the Community was dissolved, in effect, early in 1977. With a few exceptions, Uganda now treats residents of Kenya and Tanzania on the same basis as all other nonresidents for exchange control purposes. Prescription of Currency All payments to Kenya and Tanzania must be effected through U.S. dollar accounts held with banks abroad. Authorized payments, including payments for imports, by residents of Uganda to residents of foreign countries other than Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa may be made in Uganda shillings to the credit of an External Account in Uganda, or in any ether currency except Rhodesian currency that is appropriate to the country of residence of the payee. Receipts from such countries may be obtained in Uganda shillings from an External Account in Uganda or in any convertible currency. Pay- ments to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are pro- hibited. Certain settlements with Burundi, Rwanda, and Zaire are channeled through special accounts. 1 Foreign currencies are all currencies other than the Uganda shilling. 2 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, Danish and Faroese kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Japanese yen, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, Spanish pesetas, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, U.S. dollars, and all former Sterling Area currencies other than the Uganda shilling. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Uganda shillings held by residents of for- eign countries are designated External Accounts. They may be credited freely with authorized payments by residents of Uganda, with transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any for- eign currency and gold by nonresidents of Uganda to authorized dealers. They may be debited freely for pay- ments to nonresidents, for transfers to other External Accounts in Uganda, and for purchases of foreign cur- rencies from authorized dealers. Nontransferable funds of persons not resident in Uganda are credited to Blocked Accounts. Subject to prior approval, balances on Blocked Accounts may be used for the purchase in Uganda of specified bonds and shares issued in Uganda; the redemption proceeds of government bonds so acquired are transferable beginning five years f rom the date of purchase. Subject to indi- vidual permission, such balances may also be used for payments to residents not related to export transactions. All Blocked Accounts must be held with the Uganda Commercial Bank. Imports and Import Payments Imports are controlled through foreign exchange allo- cations and import licensing. A Cabinet Committee, under the chairmanship of the Minister of Finance, meets fortnightly and makes block allocations of foreign exchange on a ministry-by-ministry basis. The Bank of Uganda informs the Committee of the availability of foreign exchange, while the Industrial Assessment Com- mittee makes recommendations on import requirements for the industrial sector. On the basis of these recom- mendations a minimum guaranteed amount of foreign exchange is made available for the importation of indus- trial raw materials and spare parts. Import licenses, which are required for all imports, are issued to indi- vidual importers by the Uganda Advisory Board of Trade (UABT ), operating under the supervision of the Ministry of Commerce. For imports of industrial and commercial goods UABT also distributes among indi- vidual importers foreign exchange allocated to the M in is try of Industry and the Ministry of Commerce by the Cabinet Committee. With regard to imports of the goods that fall under the jurisdiction of the other ministries, each ministry directly concerned distri- butes the foreign exchange allocated to it; in this case, UABT issues licenses automatically. Upon approval of the application, the importer must deposit with the UABT a commission of 1 per cent of the amount of the license. All imports from Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohibited. Imports normally must be purchased direct from the country of origin. Some imports of manufactured goods from Kenya and Tan- zania are subject to transfer taxes. 421 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA Import payments normally are made under letters of credit opened in the name of the UABT for the account of the importer; the latter generally must make fu ll pay- ment to the authorized bank before the letter of credit is opened. Documentary evidence showing that the goods have been imported into Uganda must be for- warded to the exchange control authorities within six months f rom the date of payment. Since early 1977 a certain amount of foreign exchange has been set aside each month to liquidate payments arrears. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to all countries are subject to approval by the Bank of Uganda and those to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. The basic allowance for travel outside Uganda is the equivalent of U Sh 3,000 a person every three years, which may be taken out in travelers checks. The allowance is avail- able for travel to any country except Kenya and Tan- zania, for which holiday facilities of up to U Sh 1,000 a person a year normally are available, and Israel, Rho- desia, and South Africa, for which no allocation is granted. Salaried noncitizens recruited from outside East Afr ica may obtain allocations for travel outside East Africa at the time of their overseas leave. Foreign exchange is not released for nursery, primary, and secondary education abroad except for children of diplomats, technical assistance personnel, nonnationals working in Uganda on overseas terms, nonnational mis- sionaries, and other special cases. Facilities exist whereby salaried foreign nationals may remit to their country of origin up to 33!/3 per cent of their gross mon th ly earn- ings, to cover fam i ly maintenance, savings, etc., provided that they are on a contract of employment which includes a firm commitment to leave Uganda upon expiry of the contract. Transfers of dividends and profits are subject to special regulations; thus, foreign-owned companies must retain in Uganda at least 20 per cent of the profits made in any business year, and they are not allowed to remit interim dividends. The export of Uganda banknotes and coins by travel- ers is prohibited, except that travelers to Kenya and Tanzania may take out U Sh 100 in Uganda currency. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports require licenses and may be restricted to ensure sufficient supplies for consumption in Uganda. All exports to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Afr ica are prohibited. The Uganda Tea Board has a monopoly over the export of tea, the Coffee Marketing Board over the export of coffee, and the Lint Marketing Board over the export of raw cotton. Export proceeds in specified currencies (see foot- note 2) must be collected within six months of exporta- tion and offered to an authorized bank in Uganda for conversion into Uganda shillings. Coffee, cotton, copper, and hides and skins are subject to export duty. 422 Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in specified currencies (see footnote 2) must be sold to an authorized bank. The import of Uganda banknotes and coins by travelers is prohibited, except that returning residents may bring in U Sh 100 a person. Travelers may freely bring in bank- notes denominated in specified currencies and foreign currency travelers checks. Capital Capital transfers to all countries are restricted and those to Israel, Rhodesia, and South Africa are prohib- ited. Residents of Uganda, however, may be granted exemptions from the deposit and surrender requirements in respect of foreign assets for specified Sterling Area assets held prior to June 11, 1965. Capital transfers require individual exchange control approval. Residents of Uganda leaving permanently may normally transfer their assets up to the equivalent of U Sh 50,000. The allowance is reduced by the amount of insurance premiums remitted after 1965 outside the facilities for remittance of savings. A fur ther transfer of up to the equivalent of U Sh 20,000 upon each anniver- sary of the emigrant's departure is allowed. All remain- ing funds must be credited to a Blocked Account and may either be invested in certain approved securities or be held on deposit with the Uganda Commercial Bank; such funds become transferable after five years. The income f rom such investments is transferable dur ing the period when the funds are blocked. There is no restriction on the investment of foreign funds in Uganda; to secure guaranteed repatriation, however, it is necessary to obtain "approved status" for the investment in terms of the Foreign Investments (Protection) Act, 1964, as amended by the Foreign Investments Decree, 1977; in normal circumstances ap- proved s ta tus is given freely. Foreign and domestic invest- ment in specified types of production require approval under the East Afr ican Industrial Licensing Act and the Uganda Licensing Act, 1969. Dividends and profits due to nonresidents f rom normal trading operations and distributed by companies operating in Uganda are, in principle, transferable. All imports and exports of securities require approval. Approval is freely granted for the purchase by non- residents of Ugandan securities, provided that payment is received in an appropriate manner. The income from such securities is remittable, and the proceeds on resale are normally remittable also. Purchases of securities outside Uganda by residents are not normally permitted. A resident of Uganda may not send money abroad, for whatever purpose, without specific exchange control approval. With minor exceptions, prior exchange control ap- proval is required for loans or overdraft facilities granted to a nonresident or to a body corporate resident in Uganda which is controlled, directly or indirectly, by persons resident outside Uganda. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UGANDA Gold A commemorative gold coin with a face va lue of U S h SOO is legal tender but does not circulate. Resi- dents may hold and acquire gold coins in Uganda for num isma t ic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the mone tary authorities and authorized indus tr ial and professional users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in Uganda in any fo rm other than jewelry. Im- ports and exports of gold in any fo rm other than jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler require licenses issued by the M in is try of Finance. Export licenses are not normally granted except for exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. The import of the following f rom all sources is subject to individual licensing: jewelry of gold, silver, or p la t inum; goldsmiths' or silversmiths' wares, including set gems; bullion in the ingot, bar, or sheet; and gold coins. Import licenses for gold bullion, gold jewelry, and gold coins are issued restrictively and only to gold- smiths. Changes during 1977 October 13. Not for Redistribution UNITED ARAB EMIRATES l (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System On February 23, 1974, the United Arab Emirates established an initial par value with the Fund of 0.186621 gram of fine gold per U.A.E. Dirham, corresponding at the time to Dh 1 = SDR 0.21 or US$1 = Dh 3.94737. The U.S. dollar parity has since been maintained unchanged. The United Arab Emirates avails itself of wider margins. The United Arab Emirates Currency Board establishes daily quotations for the U.S. dollar only, within the limits of the wider margins. The Cur- rency Board deals with commercial banks, other financial institutions, governments, Rulers of Emirates, and quasi- government institutions. Commercial banks are free to transact at rates of their own choosing although in prac- tice their quotations are kept close to those of the Cur- rency Board. The amount of foreign exchange that the Board is prepared to sell to any one bank on any one day is US$250,000; transactions involving amounts above this limit can, however, be made at negotiated rates. Commercial banks' rates for currencies other than the U.S. dollar are fixed in relation to the U.S. dollar- dirham rate and the previous day's closing rates in New York, while taking into account market conditions in the Gu lf area and the Far East. On December 31, 1977 the Board's buying and selling rates were Dh3 .896 and Dh3.90, respectively, per US$1.2'3 The Board stands ready to make one-month, three-month, and six-month forward quotations, and the commercial banks are free to engage in forward exchange transactions. The United Arab Emirates formally accepted the obli- gations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement on February 13, 1974. Administration of Control There is neither exchange control legislation nor an exchange control authority in the United Arab Emirates, and there are no registration requirements for inward or outward transfers. Import and export licenses, where required, are issued by the authorities of the Em ira te concerned. Prescription of Currency All settlements with Israel and South Africa are pro- hibited. No other prescription of currency requirements are in force. There are no bilateral payments agreements. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between accounts held by residents and those held by nonresidents. 1The seven federated states of the United Arab Emirates are Abu Dhabi, Dubai, Sharjah, A jman, Umm al Qaiwain, Ras a l -Kha imah, and Fujairah. 2 There are fixed rates of Dh 1 = QR 1 for Qatar riyals and Dh 10 = BD 1 for Bahrain dinars brought in by travelers from Qatar and Bahrain, applicable up to limits of QR 5,000 and BD 500, respectively, a person. 3 On January 28, 1978 these were changed to Dh 3.876 buying, and Dh 3.88 selling, per US$1. 424 Imports and Import Payments Imports from Israel and South Africa are prohibited, as are imports of products manufactured by foreign companies blacklisted by the Arab League. Imports of a few commodities are prohibited f rom all sources for moral, health, or security reasons. Virtually all other commodities may be freely imported without an individual import permit, but only licensed parties can enter the import trade and an importer can import only the commodity or commodities specified in his license. There are no restrictions on the availability of foreign exchange for payments in respect of permitted imports. Payments for Invisibles All payments for current invisibles may be made freely, except to Israel and South Africa. Travelers may take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports and re-exports to Israel and South Africa are prohibited. Virtually all commodities may be exported freely, without an export license, to any other destination. Each Emirate establishes its own export regulations. There are no requirements attached to receipts from exports or re-exports; the proceeds need not be repatri- ated or surrendered and may be disposed of freely, regardless of the currency involved. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no requirements attached to receipts from current invisibles. Travelers may bring in any amount in foreign or domestic banknotes. Capital No exchange control requirements are imposed on capital receipts or payments by residents or nonresidents. Transactions and settlements involving Israel, South A f r ica, and companies blacklisted by the Arab League, however, are prohibited. Profits on foreign capital invested in the United Arab Emirates may be remitted freely. Gold With the exception noted below, residents and non- residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any fo rm, at home or abroad. They may also, without a permit, import and export gold in any form, but the import of gold for trade purposes may only be under- taken by licensed parties. Transactions involving Israel, South Africa, or blacklisted companies are prohibited. Gold bullion is exempt from import du ty but jewelry is not. Changes during 1977 January 29. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM (Position on January 1, 1978) Exchange Rate System The par value is 2.13281 grams of fine gold per Pound Sterling. Since June 23, 1972, the authorities have not ma in ta ined the exchange rate of the pound within announced margins, and therefore all transac- tions in the official exchange market, except those in currencies ma in ta in ing a fixed relationship w i th sterling, take place at a fluctuating exchange rate. The closing selling and buying rates in the fore ign exchange market for the U.S. dollar on December 30, 1977 were US$1.9140 and US$1.9170, respectively, per £1. Authorized banks are allowed to engage in spot and forward exchange transactions in any currency, except Rhodesian currency, subject to the observance of limits on open positions and the accumulation of spot fore ign exchange. Forward rates may fluctuate under the inf lu- ence of market forces; transactions with resident custom- ers may be entered into only for approved purposes, where there is an underlying commercial contract (or where an exporter is tender ing for an overseas export con trac t), and in the currency of the contract. There is also a market (referred to as the investment currency ma rke t) in which certain fore ign currency proceeds,1 resulting mainly f rom the sale outside the Scheduled Territories ( the United Kingdom, the Channel Islands, the Isle of Man, the Republic of Ire land ,2 and G ib ra l ta r) of fore ign currency securities held for port- folio investment purposes,8 and of most personal resi- dential property situated outside the Scheduled Terri- tories may be negotiated at freely determined rates, usually attracting a premium over the official marke t; at the end of 1977, that premium was 32.25 per cent calculated at the ru l ing U.S. dollar rate in the official exchange market, the middle closing rate on Decem- ber 30 being £1 = US$1.9245.4 These funds are normally available for reinvestment in marke tab le fo re ign currency securities, for approved purchases of personal residential property in countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia, and, although little used for this purpose, for approved direct investments in non- Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia. The authorized banks may deal among themselves and with residents and nonresidents in fore ign notes and 1 Under the U.K. exchange control regulations, fore ign currency comprises all currencies other than the currencies of the Un i ted King- dom, the Republic of I re land, and G ib ra l ta r. 2 The U.K. regu la t ions re fer to Ireland as the Repub l ic of I r e l and, and for the purpose of this su rvey the U.K. usage is be ing fo l lowed. 3 The te rm "foreign cu r rency securities" is generally to be read as mean ing securities payable or optionally payable in a c u r r e n cy of a coun t ry other than the United K ingdom, the Repub l ic of I re land, and G ibra l tar. Special regulations, however, are applicable to fo r e ign currency securities payable in Rhodesian currency. S te r l ing secu r i t ies are defined as securities payable solely in sterling, Ir ish pound s, or Gibraltar currency. The term "securities" inc ludes ce r t i f ica tes of deposit and t rea su ry bills. 4 On J anu a ry 3, 1978 at the opening of business the p r em ium was 30.625 per cent calculated at the ruling U.S. dollar rate. 426 coins (other than Rhodesian currency) at free market rates of exchange. The United Kingdom formally accepted the obliga- tions of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement, as f rom February 15, 1961. Exchange Control Territory In general, the United Kingdom does not impose restrictions on exchange transactions or payments and receipts between residents of the United Kingdom and residents of the Scheduled Territories. Exchange control applies ma in ly to transactions with residents of countries ou ts ide the Scheduled Territories. For administrative purposes, the non-Scheduled Territories are divided as follows: ( 1) the other member countries of the EEC, except the Republic of Ireland; (2) the Overseas Sterling Area (OSA ), i.e., the countries other than the Republic of Ire land and G ibra l tar which as at June 22, 1972 were treated as Scheduled Territories; 5 ( 3) Rhodesia; and (4) all other countries, usually referred to as the Rest of the Non-Scheduled Territories (RNST ). Administration of Control Exchange control in the United Kingdom is adminis- tered by the Bank of England on behalf of the U.K. Treasury. However, practically all commercial banks are authorized to approve most current payments re- qu i r ing exchange control permission. The licensing of imports and exports is handled mostly by the Department of Trade, but other departments also issue licenses in specialized fields. Prescription of Currency Receipts f rom Scheduled Territories may be obtained in sterling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency; those f rom other countries, with the exception of Rhodesia, must be in sterling f rom an External Account or in any fore ign currency (other than Rhodesian currency), wh ich must be offered for sale to an authorized bank unless permission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Payments to Scheduled Terri- tories may be made in sterling, Irish pounds, or Gibraltar currency; payments to other countries, w i th the exception of Rhodesia, may be made by crediting sterling to an External Account or in any foreign currency except Rhodesian currency. 5 The OSA thus comprises Australia, Bahamas, Bah ra in, Bangladesh, Barbados, Belize, Be rmuda, Botswana, British Ind i an Ocean Territory, B r i t i sh V irg in Islands, Brune i, Cayman Islands, Cyp rus, Falkland Islands and Dependencies, Fiji, The Gamb ia, G h a n a, G i lbe rt Islands, G r en ad a, G u y a n a, Hong Kong, Ice land, Ind ia and S ikk im, Jama ica, J o r d a n, Kenya, Kuwa i t, Leeward Is lands, Lesotho, Malawi, Malaysia, Maldives, Ma l ta, Mau r i t ius and Dependencies, N a u r u, New Zealand, Nigeria, Oman, Pakistan, Papua New Gu in e a, P i tca i rn, Qa ta r, St. Helena and Dependencies, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Singapore, Solomon Islands, South Africa, South West A f r ica (N am i b i a ), Sri Lanka, Swaz i land, Tanzania, Tonga, Trinidad and Tobago, Tu rks and Caicos Islands, Tuvalu, Uganda, United Arab Em ira tes, Western Samoa, Wind- wa rd Islands, People's Democratic Republic of Yemen, and Zambia. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Settlements with Rhodesia are subject to special regu- lations generally prescribing the use of Rhodesian Accounts, Suspense Accounts, or, in certain circum- stances, the Rhodesian Special Account with the Stand- ard Bank, London. However, unless specifically included among the permitted debits to Rhodesian Accounts, all commercial payments, except those in respect of exports, due f rom persons resident in Rhodesia to residents of the United Kingdom must be received either in a foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) or, with the specific permission of the Bank of England, in sterling from the Rhodesian Special Account; authorized payments for exports f rom the United Kingdom to Rhodesia must be received in advance of shipment in a foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency, or, with the specific approval of the Bank of England, in sterling f rom the Rhodesian Special Account. Persons normally resident in Rhodesia who are living temporar i ly in the United Kingdom as students or workers may open Temporary Resident Accounts in sterling with authorized banks in the United K ingdom; debits to such accounts are generally permitted only for living expenses w i th in the United Kingdom. Nonresident Accounts The sterling accounts of residents of other Scheduled Territories are treated in the same way as those of resi- dents of the Un i ted Kingdom. Thus, for transfers be- tween Scheduled Territories no U.K. exchange control permission is required; for payments to other countries by residents of any Scheduled Territory, the authorized banks are required to ensure that the payment has the approval of the exchange control au thor i ty in the ter- ritory concerned. External Accounts. With the exception of Rhodesian Accounts, Temporary Resident Accounts, and the Rho- desian Special Account (see be low ), the sterling ac- counts of nonresidents w i th authorized banks in the United K ingdom, i.e., those of residents of countries out- side the Scheduled Territories, are designated External Accounts. These accounts may be credited w i th author- ized payments by residents of Scheduled Territories, w i th transfers f rom other External Accounts, w i th the pro- ceeds f rom sales of gold or fore ign currency other than Rhodesian currency ( inc lud ing bankno te s ), and w i th sterling bankno tes mailed f rom outside the Scheduled Territories. External Accounts may be debited, subject to general or special permission, for payments to resi- dents of the Scheduled Territories; for t rans fe rs to other External Accounts; for transfers to Rhodesian Accounts other than in payment for certain goods exported f rom Rhodesia, provided that the bank has no reason to believe that the payment is for a purpose prohibited by the Southern Rhodesia (Un i ted Na t ions Sanctions) (No. 2) Order, 1968; for payments in cash in the Un i ted Kingdom; and for purchases of any fore ign currency other than Rhodesian currency ( inc lud ing bankno tes) or gold. UNITED KINGDOM Rhodesian Accounts. These accounts are applicable to residents of Rhodesia only. Permitted credits include transfers f rom External Accounts, under the circum- stances described above; payments by residents of Scheduled Territories other than the United Kingdom to residents of Rhodesia, subject to the approval of the exchange control authority in the territory concerned; and payments by U.K. residents to residents of Rhodesia in respect of (1) the sale of foreign currencies other than Rhodesian currency, (2) the discount or maturity proceeds of U.K. Treasury bills, (3) permitted imports f rom Rhodesia which have entered customs in the United Kingdom, (4) insurance and freight charges resulting f rom permitted trade between Rhodesia and any Scheduled Territory, (5) insurance claims directly related to such permitted trade, ( 6) pensions and widows' annuities where associated with the deceased husband's employment, (7) charges and fees relating to patents, designs, and trademarks registered in Rhodesia, Zambia, or Malawi, ( 8) ma tur i ty proceeds of certain endowment insurance policies, and (9) expenditure in gathering news material. Permitted debits include transfers to the Rhodesian Special Account in respect of pensions and widows' annuities; payments for living expenses in the United Kingdom of persons resident in Rhodesia and their fam i- lies; authorized purchases of U.K. sterling securities to be held for the account holder; purchases in the United Kingdom of treasury bills to be held for the account holder; payments to residents of the Scheduled Terri- tories for ( 1) interest on and repayment of outstanding personal loans, advances, and overdrafts granted before November 11, 1965, (2) patents, designs, trademarks, and royalties, (3) distributions f rom Rhodesian estates and trus ts, and (4) subscriptions to newspapers and other periodicals; and payments to U.K. residents for (a) expenses ar is ing out of property in the United Kingdom owned on or before November 11, 1965, (b) taxes, (c) educational expenses, (d) insurance premiums and capital and annu i ty payments on personal policies taken out on or before November 11, 1965, (e) medical fees, (f) g i f ts and maintenance not exceeding £250 for any one payment, to individuals and religious, medical, edu- cational, and charitable organizations, and subscriptions to such organizations, (g) contributions to pension funds provided the person was a member of the fund before November 11, 1965 or before tak ing up residence in Rhodesia a f t er that date, and (h) bank and safe custody charges. Payments in respect of educational and medical expenses in Rhodesia also are permitted. Transfers between Rhodesian Accounts and f rom Rhodesian Accounts to External Accounts are not normally allowed. Suspense Accounts. Unless eligible for credit to Rhodesian Accounts or to the Rhodesian Special Ac- count, payments to persons resident in Rhodesia must be withheld unless the Bank of England directs other- wise; the funds may be placed on Suspense Accounts and, 427 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM except with specific permission, may only be (1) used to meet U.K. tax payments and safe custody charges due on the monies in question, (2) used within specified limits for living expenses in the United Kingdom of residents of Rhodesia and certain other personal pay- ments, or ( 3) placed on deposit with banks or other financial ins t i tu t ions in the name of the U.K. resident by whom they are held. Permission is given for resi- dents of Rhodesia to use Suspense Account monies to purchase U.K. sterling securities on a recognized stock exchange in the United Kingdom and to purchase U.K. Treasury bills and savings bonds and certificates. Per- mission is only given for them to purchase Rhodesian or fore ign currency securities, however, when the f u n ds for the purchase are derived f rom the immediate sale proceeds of other Rhodesian or foreign currency securi- ties, respectively. The Rhodesian Special Account. This is an account operated by the Rhodesia Pensions Office s taff in London and ma in ta ined with the Standard Bank, London. Pen- sions and associated payments due to beneficiaries in Rhodesia f rom residents of the Scheduled Territories and the OSA, and pensions due f rom Rhodesia to residents of the United Kingdom, the Republic of Ireland, and most parts of the OSA are norma l ly settled through this account. Corresponding transfers f rom Rhodesian Ac- counts in the names of individuals to the Rhodesian Special Account are freely permitted. Permission is not norma l ly given for paymen ts of any other na ture to be credited to the Rhodesian Special Account. Subject to specific approval by the Bank of Eng land, any balance on the Special Account may be used to meet educational payments in the United K ingdom, the cost of permitted exports to Rhodesia from the Scheduled Territories and the OSA, and of services provided by residents of the Scheduled Territories and the OSA for account of persons resident in Rhodesia. With the exception of certain textile goods,16 most imports f rom countries other than Rhodesia are admitted under an Open General Import License without restric- tion, with the following exceptions as at the end of 1977: ( 1) from all countries, four commodities or groups of commodities;17 (2) from the Dollar Area only, one group of commodities; (3) from the non- CEFTA countries only, one commodity; (4) from Roman ia only, two groups of commodities; and (5) f rom the State Trading Area only, ten commodities or groups of commodities. Individual import licenses are required where goods cannot be imported under the authority of the Open General Import License; a number of items are subject to surveillance licensing under which import licenses are issued freely on demand to applicants providing certain information. Most articles subject to specific import licensing can be imported in limited quan- tities under bilateral or global quotas. A few articles may be imported under open individual licenses, i.e., w i thout limit as to quantity or value. Imports of cereals and cereal products, beef and veal, mutton and lamb, poultry meat, and dairy products other than butter and cheese are subject to minimum import prices enforced through autonomously imposed variable import levies. Imports of many other agricultural, horticultural, and livestock products are subject to EEC regulations. Once import licensing requirements have been met, U.K. residents may purchase foreign currency, other than Rhodesian currency, or credit sterling to an Exter- nal Account to pay for the import, Advance payments for imports are ap- proved by the Bank of England where the payment is considered necessary or conforms to cus tomary practice. Current administrative practice is not to allow advance payments for consumer goods. Exchange control fo rms are not required for payments to residents of the Sched- uled Territories; neither are they required for payments to residents of other countries, unless the payment repre- sents part or final settlement for goods for which the total amount payable exceeds £ 5,000, and evidence of importation cannot be presented to the bank before making the remittance. Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles to residents of other Scheduled Territories may be made freely. Paymen ts to residents of countries outside the Scheduled Territories require ex- change control authorization, which (except for pay- ments to residents of Rhodesia) 18 is granted freely for most purposes, subject to the presentation of supporting evidence. The completion of an exchange control form is required for payments exceeding <£ 1,000 or its equiva- lent. Authorized banks are permitted to approve appli- cations for transfers on account of many categories of current invisibles w i thout any l im i ta t ion, and for other categories up to established l im i ts. Applications for payments in excess of these limits or for purposes for which no delegation of au thor i ty has been granted are approved by the Bank of England, provided that no unau thor ized capital outflow is involved. Authorized banks may dispatch sterling banknotes to nonresidents except residents of Rhodesia against pay- ment in sterling from an External Account or in any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency. For any type of travel outside the Scheduled Terri- tories (except to Rhodes ia ), U.K. residents can obtain on demand f rom banks and authorized travel agents fore ign exchange up to the equivalent of <£500 a person a t r ip; for travel for business or professional reasons, an allow- ance of £100 a day up to a max imum of £3,000 for any one journey can be authorized by banks and certain authorized travel agents. Applications for add i t ional amoun ts for bona fide travel purposes are approved by the Bank of Eng land. The cost of accommodation, fares, etc., can be paid for without limit in the United Kingdom. Travel exchange purchased in the Un i ted K ingdom must normally be recorded in the traveler's passport. 18 Virtually all current payments to Rhodesia are prohibited, except when these result f rom permitted t rade in goods. Cons ide ra t ion is, however, given to remittances on a l im i ted basis to re l ieve ha rd sh ip and to remittances of a continuing n a t u re by cha r i tab le, r e l ig iou s, medical, and educational organ iza t ions for both c u r r e nt pu rposes or to meet capital expend i tu re in the educa t ional and medical fields. Small personal g if ts are also permitted. UNITED KINGDOM Under arrangements agreed with certain banks, per- sonal checks may be cashed abroad for travel purposes, up to <£50 a check, if backed by check cards. Credit cards may be used freely to settle travel expenses. Resident travelers may take out up to £500 in foreign currency notes. Any unused travel exchange expressed in foreign currency may be retained for a period of one month f rom the date of re turn to the United Kingdom. Banks have authority to approve applications by U.K. residents who wish to open foreign currency accounts outside the Scheduled Territories for the receipt of travel funds for use dur ing their stay abroad. Travel facilities expressed in sterling may be held for six months f rom the date of issue or for one mon th from the date of return to the United Kingdom, if later. In addition, resident travelers may take with them up to £100 in U.K. and other Scheduled Territory banknotes, which may be exchanged or spent abroad only for travel expenditure; but those traveling direct to the Republic of Ireland, the Channel Islands, or the Isle of Man may take out any amount. Visitors to the United Kingdom are, in addition, allowed to take out any notes that they brought in with them, other than notes in excess of £100 expressed in the currencies of the United King- dom or the Republic of Ireland. Authorized banks are permitted to approve, within certain limits and subject to the submission of appropri- ate documen ta ry evidence of the amoun ts due, applica- tions to pay fees, accommodation charges, and all incidental expenses arising from the education of U.K. residents outside the Scheduled Territories. Special regulations apply to all travel to Rhodesia. For approved official and essential business journeys the Bank of England will authorize the issue of foreign cur- rency at a rate of up to £ 10 a day with a max imum of £300. Facilities for private travel are authorized only where there are compassionate grounds. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Rhodesia are subject to licensing control and licenses are normally issued only for the permitted exceptions (medical and educational supplies, foods tuffs where these are special medical preparations, newsfilm and photographs, and documen tary and printed matter not more than 70 years old) and for equipment for the essential replacement needs of the Rhodesian Railways and the Cen tral A f r ican Power Corporation. V ir tua l ly all exports to other destinations are free of export con- trol and no exchange control fo rms are normally required. Exporters to countries outside the Scheduled Territories other than Rhodesia must normally obtain appropriate payment within six months of shipment; special exchange control permission to collect at a later date is required only where the exporter extends credit for more than six months without cover f rom the Export Credits Gua ran tee Department (ECGD ). Receipts in fo re ign currencies must be offered for sale to an author- ized bank unless the recipient has obtained specific 429 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM permission to credit them to a retained currency account (subject to supervision) or permission has been given for them to be used for some other purpose. Permitted exports to Rhodesia must be paid for pr ior to sh ipment in any fore ign currency other than Rhodesian currency or, if specific permission is granted by the Bank of England, in sterling f rom the Rhodesian Special Account. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts in foreign currencies on account of invisibles must be offered for sale to an authorized bank, unless recipients have permission to credit them to a retained currency account or to use them for some other purpose. British and other banknotes may be brought into the United Kingdom freely. Capital Residents of the United Kingdom who receive fore ign currency other than Rhodesian currency f rom certain capital account sources (ma in ly the sale or redemption of foreign currency securities held for portfolio invest- ment purposes and the sale of personal residential prop- erty situated outside the Scheduled Territories) may, in certain circumstances and with permission, use the exchange (which is regarded as investment currency once permission has been g iven) 19' 20 for the purchase of marketable foreign currency securities, the purchase of personal residential property outside the Scheduled Territories, or the mak ing of approved d irect inves tmen ts outside the Scheduled Territories; they may also sell the exchange for sterling to other residents to be used for the same purposes. If permission is not for thcom ing, the foreign currency must be offered for sale at the rates ru l ing in the official ma rket to an authorized bank in the United K ingdom. In certain circumstances, residents of the Un i ted K ingdom who possess the na t iona l i ty or citizenship of a coun try ou ts ide the Scheduled Territories or, in some cases, who are fo rmer residents of OSA countries but do not possess such na t iona l i ty or citizen- ship may be granted exemption f rom certain of their obligations under the Exchange Control Act in respect of assets denom ina ted in a fore ign currency other than Rhodesian currency. There are no restrictions on capital t rans fe rs by resi- dents of the United Kingdom into the benef ic ial owner- ship of residents of other Scheduled Territories. All capital t rans fe rs by residents to coun t r ies outside the Scheduled Territories requ i re approva l. For direct inves tmen ts in non-Scheduled Territories other t h an Rhodes ia, off ic ial exchange is norma l ly made av a i l ab le only for ce r ta in projects directly concerned w i th p romo t ing exports of goods and services where the prospec t ive bene f it to the U.K. ba lance of paymen ts is expected to equal or exceed the total cost of the invest- ment w i t h in 18 mon ths ( three years for direct inves tment in o ther EEC coun t r ies) and to con t inue the rea f te r; this bene f it w i ll no rm a l ly occur by way of add i t ional export rece ip ts, but may also arise f rom prof i ts and other foreign cu r rency receipts that would not take place w i thout the inves tmen t. For such projects ("super-criterion" proj- e c t s ), o f f ic ial exchange may be made available up to £250,000 (£500,000 for direct investment in other EEC coun t r i e s) or 50 per cent of the total inves tmen t, whichever is larger; any balance must be financed by fo re ign cu r rency borrowing, the use of investment cur- rency, the export free of payment of cap i tal equ ipment and stock-in-trade of U.K. m a n u f a c t u re f o rm i ng an in t eg r al part of the inves tmen t, by the issue or t ran s fer of shares to non res iden ts on app rop r ia te terms, by the c ap i t a l i z a t ion of an overseas subs id iary's current account indeb tedne ss to the U.K. parent company on appropr ia te te rms, by approved profit re ten t ion, or w i th foreign currency proceeds of d is inves tment in the context of a g roup reorgan iza t ion. Direct inves tment other than for "super-criterion" pro jec ts is considered on the basis that its capital cost should not f a ll directly upon the U.K. official foreign exchange reserves un t il an equivalent amount has been received in the Un i ted Kingdom by way of benefits a r i s ing f rom the inves tmen ts; such inves tmen ts can no rma l ly be financed by foreign currency borrow ing, the use of inve s tment currency, the export free of payment of c ap i t al e q u i pm e nt and stock-in-trade of U .K. manu- f a c t u re f o rm i ng an in teg ral part of the inve s tmen t, by the issue or t r an s f er of shares to nonresidents on ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution appropriate terms, by the capitalization of an overseas subsidiary's current account indebtedness to the U.K. parent company on appropriate terms, by approved profit retention, or with foreign currency proceeds of disinvestment in the context of a group reorganization. The permitted proportion of retained foreign currency earnings normally is one third of net earnings af ter taxes, applied, if desired, on a global basis where more than one subsidiary is involved. Applicants for permission to make an outward direct investment are required to provide details of estimated benefits over the 18 months (three years in respect of "super-criterion" investments in other EEC countries) following the proposed invest- ment and estimates of the benefits expected thereafter in all cases. In addition, investors seeking permission to repay foreign currency borrowings taken to finance out- ward direct investments have to give an explanation if the benefits received fall short of those originally esti- mated; the Bank of England also expects the investor to show, where possible, that these benefits derive f rom the particular injection of capital financed by the foreign currency borrowing being repaid. Benefits adduced for the purpose of repaying foreign currency borrowings have to be net of interest paid or payable on the borrowings. The purchase outside the Scheduled Territories of marketable fore ign currency securities for portfolio investment must be financed either with investment currency or w i th foreign currency borrowing. Such borrowing is freely permitted when under taken by or through U.K. professional security managers. Foreign currency loans taken up to purchase quoted securities issued by the EEC, the European Investment Bank, the European Coal and Steel Community, and the European Atomic Energy Community may be repaid with official exchange over a five-year period. Purchases of marke t- able foreign currency securities with investment cur- rency are freely permitted by virtue of certain general permissions granted to banks, stockbrokers, and other authorized depositaries. Purchases from other residents may also be effected with sterling on the Stock Exchange (sterling prices reflect the prevailing investment currency p rem ium ). The purchase by U.K. residents of a house or an apartment for personal use in countries outside the Scheduled Territories requires specific approval and must be made either from another Scheduled Territory resident for sterling or another Scheduled Territory cur- rency, or from a nonresident of the Scheduled Territories with investment currency; payment for a t tendant ex- penses and improvements, but not maintenance, must also be made with investment currency. (As an exception to this rule, residents temporarily employed in member countries of the EEC may be authorized to purchase necessary accommodation at current official market rates of exchange.) Approval is normally limited to one property a family; purchases of investment currency are UNITED KINGDOM normally limited to reasonable amounts and may be made before exchange control approval is received provided that the funds are held by an authorized depositary and that a formal application is lodged to purchase the property within six months. The approval authority for amounts up to £,30,000 for a residential property has been delegated to authorized banks. All proceeds from the realization, redemption, or ma tur i ty of sterling capital assets (including direct invest- ments) owned by nonresidents of the Scheduled Terri- tories other than residents of Rhodesia are remittable at the official market rate of exchange. Payments to non- resident beneficiaries, other than Rhodesian residents, are authorized freely in respect of inheritances due f rom the estates of deceased residents; capital payments under life and other insurance policies taken up by nonresidents with resident insurance companies are also authorized freely. Residents of the United Kingdom who leave with the intention of residing for at least three years in a country outside the Scheduled Territories and apply to transfer their assets are, on their departure from the United Kingdom, regarded for exchange control purposes as nonresidents, and, with the following exceptions, their assets are treated accordingly. Repatriates (non- Scheduled Territory nationals or citizens, other than Rhodesians, who having been resident in the United Kingdom re turn to take up residence in any country outside the Scheduled Territories) may normally transfer all their sterling assets abroad at the official market rate of exchange. Other residents leaving to take up residence in countries outside the Scheduled Territories except Rhodesia are allowed on departure to t rans fer for a f am i ly un it up to <£ 40,000 (£80,000 for emigration to another EEC coun try) through the official fore ign ex- change market and may export any foreign currency securities they hold; the remaining declared assets in excess of £40,000 or £80,000, as appropriate, are restricted for a four-year period from the date of the departing person's redesignation as a nonresident. U.K. residents tak ing up residence and employment in mem- ber countries of the EEC, however, may, with specific approval, t rans fer sterling assets at the official market rate of exchange in excess of the £80,000 limit where this is necessary in order to ensure their freedom to take up the employment in question. Du r ing the four-year period the restricted funds may be disposed of for foreign currencies other than Rhode- sian currency through the investment currency market, may be invested in sterling securities which are quoted on the Stock Exchange —the income therefrom be ing freely remittable through the official exchange market —or may be used, with general or specific permission, to meet certain expenses in the United Kingdom. Af ter the four-year period any rema in ing assets are transferab le in accordance with the rules then applicable to the assets of a nonres iden t; at present, the transfer at the official market rate of exchange is normally allowed. 431 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM The participation of foreign capital as a direct invest- ment in the United Kingdom is subject to individual authorization, which is normally granted, provided that adequate capital for the project is supplied in an ap- proved manner of payment (see section on Prescription of Currency, above) or by the import of goods and services; the foreign currency received must be sur- rendered at rates ruling in the official market unless permission has been given for the funds to be used for some other purpose. Cases involving the takeover of existing companies that by their size or na ture constitute a vital part of British industry are considered on their merits. Permissions given for direct investments in the United Kingdom by nonresidents are normally, unless otherwise agreed with the Bank of England, conditional on the consideration being paid in sterling f rom an External Account or in foreign currency (other than Rhodesian currency) and, in certain circumstances, on any subsequent finance being provided in foreign cur- rency or External Account sterling at least in proportion to the nonresident interest in the equity of the company. The acquisition in any manner by any person not resident in the United Kingdom of 10 per cent or more of the outstanding shares of a company registered in the United Kingdom requires prior exchange control approval. Nonresident firms and individuals must obtain ex- change control permission in order to raise capital in the United Kingdom, and all U.K. resident companies are required to obtain consent before issuing shares or other securities to nonresidents. U.K. residents also need permission to lend to U.K. companies controlled by nonresidents whether in the fo rm of direct lending or by way of bills of exchange, checks, promissory notes or certain other instruments. Such permission is normally given without restriction for sterling lending for the company's business in the United Kingdom. U.K. banks are prohibited f rom providing sterling loans or overdrafts to persons resident outside the Sched- uled Territories for the purpose of financing trade be- tween non-Scheduled Territories. Similarly, U.K. mer- chants, except certain commodity traders, may not finance such trade in sterling. They are, however, allowed to do so w i th foreign currency borrowed for the purpose. Borrowing by U.K. residents f rom nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories to finance expenditure in the United Kingdom is subject to restrictions. Private sector U.K. residents other than authorized banks normally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency from nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories for con- version into sterling for use in the United Kingdom, or to finance current payments to nonresidents of the Sched- uled Territories, unless the term of borrowing is at least two years; exporters, merchants, and certain commodity traders are, however, permitted to borrow fore ign cur- rency for shorter periods f rom authorized banks or f rom 432 nonresidents to finance their sales or, in some cases, stockholdings. Public sector bodies normally are not permitted to borrow foreign currency unless the term of the foreign borrowing is at least five years; for per- mitted foreign currency borrowing they may avail themselves of exchange cover provided by the Treasury. Authorized banks must not lend foreign currency to U.K. residents (other than authorized banks) for any other purpose without prior reference to the Bank of England. U.K. companies normally are not permitted to borrow External Account sterling f rom nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories unless the term of the borrowing is at least two years. Under certain permissions delegated to authorized depositaries, transactions in quoted securities of most types may generally be carried out freely between residents of the United Kingdom, except that transactions which involve loss of U.K. voting control of a company because the purchaser is itself nonresident-controlled require Bank of England consent, and transactions in Rhodesian securities may only be effected on the Stock Exchange. Residents are normally permitted, subject to certain conditions, to sell foreign currency securities outside the Scheduled Territories, and, in respect of those held for portfolio investment purposes, to reinvest the proceeds (investment currency) in marketable foreign currency securities, or to sell the exchange to other residents for such investments or for certain approved direct investment or approved purchases of property for private use outside the Scheduled Territories. The proceeds of sale of foreign currency securities held as direct investments must be sold at the official market rate of exchange or, where appropriate, may, with Bank of England permission, be retained in foreign currency for use for fu r ther outward direct investments in the context of a group reorganization. Investment currency may norma l ly be retained as investment currency for a max imum of 12 months, after which period any amount remaining must be offered for sale to an authorized bank at the current market rate in the official foreign exchange market.21 Professional security managers acting on their own behalf and for clients are permitted, subject to certain conditions, to borrow foreign currency for the purpose of making portfolio investments in marketable foreign currency securities. U.K. jobbers and other security dealers may, with permission, arrange day-to-day bor- rowing of foreign currency, whether from U.K. banks or from nonresidents, to finance a "book" in foreign currency securities, but not to finance holdings of such securities as investments. Residents of other Scheduled Territories are not prevented by the U.K. regulations f rom buying and selling sterling securities in the United Kingdom; they 21 Investment currency may be invested temporarily in short-term government bonds (with up to six months to run before final ma tur i ty) or in six-month treasury bills or other fo rms of recognized short-term money-market paper (including certificates of deposit). ©International Monetary Fund. Permission is required for all t rans fe rs of securities in the Un i ted Kingdom in which a nonresident of the Scheduled Territories is involved as either t rans fe ror or transferee, but most t rans fe rs are covered by a general authority. In most cases, U.K. companies may issue sterling securities ( inc lud ing bearer securities) under a general permission given by the U.K. authorities. Nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories except Rhodes ian residents may buy sterling securities on the Stock Exchange against payment in fore ign currency or in sterling f rom an External Account. Securities so purchased may be exported f rom the United Kingdom. Foreign currency securities may be bought and sold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Territories on the Stock Exchange for settlement in fore ign currency or, in certain circumstances, for settlement in sterling excluding the inves tment currency p rem ium. Nonres iden ts must obtain permission to buy and sell securities in the United King- dom other than through the med ium of a professional dealer in securities, whether or not the securities are quoted on a stock exchange. Nonresidents other than Rhodesian res iden ts may sell s ter l ing securities on the Stock Exchange for s ter l ing which may be held on External Account or, alternatively, may be t rans fe r red abroad at official market rates. Most t ransac t ions in securities by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia require the specific approval of the Bank of England; subject to cer ta in cond i t ions, however, authorized banks may approve applications by or on behalf of residents of Rhodesia to buy and sell sterling securities on the Stock Exchange. Except in respect of U.K. companies controlled by nonres iden ts of the Scheduled Territories (where Bank of England consent is r equ i r ed ), wa r ran ts issued by reg- istrars, company secretaries, and paying agents in respect of interest, dividends, and capital paymen ts on ma tured securities registered in the names of nonresi- dents other than Rhodesian residents may be dispatched freely to addresses outside the Scheduled Territories. These warran ts may be paid by cred i t ing sterling to an External Account. Authorized banks may freely accept foreign currency deposits and employ them in the ir fore ign currency business. They may also switch such deposits into sterling on a covered basis. Ind iv idual ceilings are set on each bank's overall open position in fore ign currencies and on the amount of spot assets which may be held aga inst forward liabilities in foreign currencies. Gold Gold bullion and gold coins are subject to control in the Un i ted K ingdom. Exemption under the Exchange Control Act, 1947 exists fo r: (1) the buying, selling, UNITED KINGDOM lending, and borrowing of gold coins minted in or before 1937; (2) the buying and selling of any gold coins minted a f ter 1937 and held in the United Kingdom, if the seller is a person resident in the United Kingdom and is not selling on behalf of a person resident outside the United Kingdom; and (3) the borrowing and lending of any gold coins minted af ter 1937 and held in the United Kingdom, if both the borrower and the lender are per- sons resident in the United Kingdom. Transactions both in gold coins not exempted above and in gold bullion may only be undertaken with permission. Permission is norma l ly given for the use of gold bullion for genuine indus tr ial and professional purposes. The sale of gold bullion for the manufac ture of gold coins, gold medals, etc., is prohibited unless specially authorized. Gold sovereigns are legal tender but do not circulate in the United Kingdom. Gold coins which are legal tender have also been issued in Jersey and the Isle of Man. Except under license granted by the Treasury, it is an offense to melt down or break up any metal coin which is for the time being current in the United Kingdom or which, having been current there, has at any time after May 16, 1969 ceased to be so. Bulk imports of gold coins, certain gold coins of num isma t ic interest minted a f ter 1937, and gold medals, medallions, tablets, or other pieces in pictorial relief or bear ing inscriptions and manufac tured after 1937, other than those of limited weight and value, are subject to ind iv idual import licensing, and such licenses are normally given only to authorized dealers in gold. The export of gold bullion and all gold coins requires prior exchange control approval. The export of gold bullion and of post-1937 gold coins to G ibra l tar and the Republic of Ireland is not normally permitted except with the approval of the local control authorities. Authority has been given to author- ized dealers in gold to issue licenses in respect of exports of gold bullion and coin purchased by any non-Scheduled Territory resident in the London gold market against payment in External Account sterling or foreign cur- rency. A license is required from the Department of Trade for the export of gold (and other) jewelry, etc., con ta in ing diamonds. The export of gold in manu- fac tu red fo rm over 100 years old and valued at .£4,000 and over also requires a license f rom the Department of Trade. Manufac tures of gold other than medals, etc., manu- fac tu red after 1937 may be imported without quanti- ta t ive restriction under Open General Import License f rom all sources except Rhodesia. There is a free gold market in London in which gold bars are freely traded among (1) authorized dealers in gold, and (2) any nonresidents of the Scheduled Ter- ritories. The U.K. authorities do not intervene in the market as either buyers or sellers. A commission of 0.25 per cent is charged on all purchases; there is no commission on sales. Authorized banks may enter into 433 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED KINGDOM forward transactions in gold without prior permission from the Bank of England. Banks may also finance pur- chases of gold by nonresidents of the Scheduled Terri- tories by lending foreign exchange and may accept gold as collateral for advances in foreign currencies or External Account sterling to nonres iden ts of the Sched- uled Territories. October 27. Exchange control rules were altered, as follows: 1. Inward direct investment —Permission would normally be given, on application to the Bank of Eng- land, to any nonresident-controlled m a n u f a c t u r i ng com- pany in the United Kingdom to borrow sterling w i thout restriction for its U.K. business. (This facility was already available to companies in the United Kingdom controlled by residents of the EEC or the OSA countries.) 2. Travel abroad —(a) A traveler on depa r tu re from the United Kingdom would be able to take out £100 instead of £25, in sterling notes, and £500, instead of £300, in foreign currency notes, ( b) Authorized banks and other authorized issuers of foreign exchange facili- ties for travel abroad were authorized to issue up to £500, instead of £300, per journey for private travel, and £100, instead of £75, a day w i th in the existing £3,000 max imum for business, professional, and official travel. Where a journey other than on business was to last two months or more, the limit on foreign currency facilities issuable without prior reference to the Bank of England was set at £ 1,000. 3. Cash gifts abroad—The total sum that might be remitted abroad by U.K. residents in the fo rm of cash gifts from their own resources would be £ 1,500 a donor a calendar year. (This replaced the two existing limits of £1,000 a donor a year for recipients in OSA coun- tries and £300 for recipients elsewhere. The total for allowances to dependents abroad remained unchanged at £2,000 a year.) 4. Basic allowance for emigrants—The max imum amount that might be taken out through the official foreign exchange market at the current ma rket rate of exchange on emigration from the Un i ted K ingdom to any destination (except Rhodesia) would be £40,000 UNITED KINGDOM a fam i ly un i t, instead of £20,000 for those going to OSA countries and for the elderly, and £5,000 for those going elsewhere. The period of restriction on transfer of sterling assets above the new limit remained unchanged at four years. Past emigrants whose assets were still restricted under the four-year rule would be allowed releases up to the new £40,000 limit. 5. Foreign currency retention—U.K. banks, mer- chants, and insurance companies were allowed to retain larger balances in foreign currencies for the financing of their fo re ign currency transactions. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES (Position on December 31,1977) Exchange Rate System The par value of the United States Dollar was estab- lished on October 18, 1973 at 0.736662 gram of fine gold, corresponding to US$42.22 a fine ounce or US$1.20635 = SDR I.1 The convertibility of the U.S. dollar into gold and other reserve assets has been suspended and exchange rates are not maintained within any stipulated margin f rom parity. The United States formally notified the Fund on December 10, 1946 that it was prepared to accept the obligations of Article VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4, of the Fund Agreement. Administration of Control The Department of the Treasury deals with license applications involving financial or commercial transac- tions directly or indirectly with Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, Rhodesia, and Viet Nam or their nationals, as specified under the Foreign Assets Control Regula- tions, the Cuban Assets Control Regulations, and the Rhodesian Sanctions Regulations. It also has admini- strative responsibility for the accounts of the People's Republic of China blocked under the Foreign Assets Control Regulations, and for accounts in the United States of Czechoslovakia, Estonia, the German Demo- cratic Republic, Latvia, and Lithuania, blocked since World War II under the Foreign Funds Control Regula- tions. The Bureau of Customs of the Department of the Treasury administers import quotas; such quotas, however, are generally established and allocated by other agencies. Import quotas on specified dairy products are administered by the Department of Agriculture through the issuance of import licenses. A global import quota on sugar has been ma in ta ined since 1974 at a nonrestric- tive level of 7 million metric tons annually. Allocations and licenses for imports of crude petroleum and petro- leum products are issued by the Department of the Interior. For items subject to export control —other than crude petroleum and petroleum products —the Department of Commerce is, in general, the responsible authority. There are no restrictions on foreign payments, except those imposed for security reasons on transactions involving the authorities or nationals of Cambodia, the People's Republic of Ch ina, Cuba, North Korea, and Viet Nam, and those imposed pursuant to UN Security Council Resolutions Nos. 232 and 253 with regard to Rhodesia. Most current payments involving the People's Republic of China, except those involving strategic goods, are authorized; however, assets of the People's Republic of China, which were blocked as of May 6, 1971, remain blocked.2 Imports and Import Payments Imports of Cambodian, Cuban, North Korean, Viet- namese, and Rhodesian origin are prohibited under Treasury regulations, unless specifically licensed. Import quotas are in effect for (1) cotton, certain cotton waste and products, most dairy products, and peanuts; (2) certain fish and certain potatoes ( ta r i f f - ra te quo tas ); (3) sugar; (4) certain meat; and (5) stainless steel and alloy tool steel products. Among the quantita- tive import quotas, all except those for peanuts, certain cotton and cotton products, butter oil, and sugar are on a country-of-production basis. In addition, imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products are subject to an import entitlement program, and import license fees. Certain dairy products which are subject to quotas are also subject to import licensing. The United States is a party to the GATT Arrange- ment Regarding International Trade in Textiles and to 18 bilateral textile agreements negotiated under the Arrangement's provisions. These agreements set the levels for the partners' exports of textiles and apparel to the United States. In 1977 the United States negotiated new bilateral textile and apparel agreements with seven of these countries. These agreements were negotiated in accordance with the terms of the Arrangement. The agreements provide for orderly expansion of trade while at the same time recognizing U.S. concerns in impacted categories. As at the end of 1977, no limitations were applied to imports of crude petroleum and petroleum products, but these were generally subject to import licenses and import license fees. Imports of fresh, frozen, or chilled beef, veal, and mutton are governed in principle by 12 bilateral agreements and one memoran- dum of understanding, as an alternative to the imposition of manda to ry quotas under the Meat Import Act of 1964. Imports of a number of manufactured products are also effectively restricted by bilateral agreements designed to provide temporary relief to certain distressed industries (shoes, televisions, and specialty steels). The transfer of funds to Rhodesia for all purposes is permitted only under license. Other payments and trans- fers abroad may be made freely, except for payments to or for the account of the authorities or nationals of Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, and Viet Nam, which are permitted only under license. 1 U.S. Public Law No. 94-564 provides that the par value of the U.S. dollar in terms of gold and SDKs will be repealed when the Proposed Second Amendment to the Fund's Articles of Agreement enters into force. 2 In addition, certain enemy and occupied area property blocked dur ing World War II remains blocked (Czechoslovakia, Estonia, Ger- man Democratic Republic, Latvia, and Lithuania). Payments restric- tions in respect of Cuba were eased to permit expenditures for travel purposes. 437 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES Exports and Export Proceeds Munitions may be exported only under license issued by the Office of Munitions Control in the Depart- ment of State. Licenses are not granted for exports of arms and ammun i t ion to Cambodia, the People's Repub- lic of China, Cuba, Eastern Europe, Nor th Korea, South Africa, the U.S.S.R., and Viet Nam. Most exports to Rhodesia require licenses and generally no licenses are issued except for educational, medical, or human i ta r ian items. All exports (except phonograph records, publica- tions, and, to Cuba, limited gift parcels) to Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, and Viet Nam are subject to indi- vidual validated licenses. Exports of designated strategic materials and equipment to all other countries (except Canada) also require individual validated licenses. For many commodities, when exported to countries other than CMEA members, certain Arab states, Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, and Viet Nam, single distribution licenses may be obtained to cover a fu ll year's ship- ment. The licensing requirements applicable to Poland, Romania, and Yugoslavia are less restrictive than those applicable to other Eastern European countries. From time to time, exports of certain commodities to all destinations have been subject to controls for reasons of short supply; as at the end of 1977 such controls were applicable to crude petroleum and petroleum fue ls. Export arrangements for wheat, corn, sorghum, soy- beans, and soybean oil are subject to reporting require- ments in order to avoid the need for controls. The proceeds of exports are not subject to exchange control. Payments for and Proceeds from Invisibles These are not restricted, except that they are prohi- bited to and f rom Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, Rho- desia, and Viet Nam. Individuals leaving or entering the coun try w i th more than US$5,000 in domestic or foreign currency, travelers checks, money orders, and /or bearer-form negotiable securities must declare these to the customs at the point of exit or entry. Capital Incoming or outgoing capital payments by residents or nonresidents are not subject to exchange control. In addition, inward and outward direct or portfolio invest- ment is generally free of any other form of approval requirements, although in certain instances compliance with specified bank ing regulations may be required; with a few exceptions, the United States does not impose special restrictions on inward investment. However, as noted above, there are restrictions on certain transactions with, or involving, Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, Rho- desia, and Viet Nam, and there are certain reporting requirements for travelers entering or leaving the country (as well as corresponding reporting requirements for shipment of currency or bearer assets through the ma i ls ). Federal Reserve member banks must meet reserve requirements of 4 per cent on net Eurodollar borrowings f rom their foreign branches and f rom foreign banks. In 438 add i t ion, the U.S. head office of a member bank must meet reserve requirements of 1 per cent against deposits that its fo re ign branches used for lending to U.S. non- bank residents. Also, at the request of the Federal Reserve Board, nonmember banks that are ma jo r i ty- owned by foreign banks and U.S. agencies and branches of fore ign banks vo lun ta r i ly ma in ta in reserves against increases above May 1973 levels in certain net liabilities to (or reduc t ions in net c la ims on) fo re ign bank s. Mem- ber banks are discouraged by the Federal Reserve Board f rom soliciting or encouraging placement of deposits by U.S. residents at their foreign branches, unless such deposits are placed to serve a def in i te, necessary purpose outside the United States. The fore ign currency posi- tions of banks, whether overall or with respect to indi- v idual currencies, are not subject to limitation. How- ever, the Federal Reserve Board stated in 1973 and again in 1975 that it would not be in the public interest for member banks to accept time deposits denominated in a fo re ign currency at their U.S. offices. Gold U.S. citizens or residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any fo rm, at home or abroad, except for gold transactions involving Cambodia, Cuba, North Korea, Rhodesia, and Viet Nam. Commercial banks may deal in gold bu l l ion and gold coins, w i th the same exceptions. Treasury licensing for importers, exporters, producers, refiners, and processors of gold is not requ ired, with the same coun try exceptions. Producers of gold may sell the ir ou tput in the f ree market, with the same coun t ry exceptions. Gold may be freely imported except f rom the countries mentioned above and except coun t e r f e it gold coins. U.S. gold coins are legal tender at the ir face value. Commercial impor ts of gold jewe l ry are f ree of quan- t i ta t ive restriction but are subject to import duty at a rate of approximately 12 per cent. There is no duty on gold ore, bu l l ion, or coins. All fo rms of gold must be declared at the point of entry into the United States. Changes during 1977 January 5. Public Law No. 95-223 was enacted revising Presidential wartime and national emergency economic powers. Title I made Section 5 (b) of the Trading with the Enemy Act applicable only in wartime. However, existing authorities of that Act being exercised by virtue of a national emergency may continue to be ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UNITED STATES exercised. Title II created a new International Emer- gency Economic Powers Act, applicable in time of "national emergency" declared by the President to deal with an unusual and extraordinary threat to the national security, foreign policy, or economy of the United States. The new Act included essentially the same powers as Section 5 ( b ); however, the authority to regulate the importing, exporting, hoarding, melting, or earmark ing of gold or silver coin or bullion was deleted. In addition, the authority to vest foreign property, included in Section 5 ( b ), was not included in the new Act. Title III amended the Export Administration Act of 1969 to pro- vide authority for the regulation of non-U.S. origin exports by any person subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.
