Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange System No par value or central rate for the currency of Upper Volta has been established with the Fund. The un it of currency is the CFA Franc,1 which is officially maintained at the rate of CFAF 1 = 0.02 French f ranc. Exchange transactions in French francs, the in- tervention currency, between the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de TOuest (BCEAO) and commercial banks take place at the rate of CFAF 1 = F 0.02. The BCEAO levies a commission of 0.10 per mill on trans- fers from countries outside the West A f r ican Monetary Union and one of 2.50 per m i ll on transfers to such countries.2 Exchange rates for foreign currencies are based on the fixed rate for the French f r anc and the Paris exchange market rate for the currency concerned, and include a commission. Banks levy a commission on transfers to all countries outside the West A f r ican Mone- tary Union, part of which must be surrendered to the Treasury. Administration of Control With the exception of measures relating to gold, Upper Volta's exchange controls do not apply to ( 1) France (and its Overseas Departments and Territories) and Monaco; and (2) all other countries whose bank of issue is linked with the French Treasury by an Opera- tions Account (Benin, Cameroon, the Central A f r ican Empire, Chad, the People's Republic of the Congo, Gabon, Ivory Coast, Mali, Niger, Senegal, and Togo). Hence, all payments to these countries may be made freely. All other countries, except Upper Volta i tse lf, are considered foreign countries. Exchange control is administered by the External Finance Bureau in the Directorate of the Treasury and of Public Accounts in the Ministry of Finance. The approval authority in respect of exchange control (except for imports and exports of gold, forward exchange cover, and business travel allocations in excess of CFAF 400,000) has been delegated to the BCEAO and, w i th in l im i ts specified in the exchange control regula- tions, to authorized intermediaries. The BCEAO also is authorized to collect, either direct or through banks, financial institutions, the Postal Adm in is tra t ion, and notaries public, any informa t ion necessary to comp i le balance of payments statistics. All exchange transac t ions relating to fore ign countries must be effected through authorized banks, the Postal Adm in is tra t ion, or the BCEAO. Import and export licenses are issued by the iThe CFA f ranc is issued by the Banque Centrale des Etats de 1'Afrique de 1'Ouest (BCEAO) and is the common currency in Benin, Ivory Coast, Niger, Senegal, Togo, and Upper Volta. 2 Transfers between member countries of the Union are subject to a flat commission of CFAF 100 for each transfer. The commissions are not levied on transfers ordered by public treasuries and similar institutions or by the Postal Administration of Upper Volta. 442 Directorate of Commerce in the Ministry of Commerce, Indus tr ial Development, and Mines. Import certificates for liberalized commodities and export attestations are made out by the importer or exporter himself and, when settlement takes place with a country outside the French Franc Area, are visaed by the customs. Prescription of Currency Upper Volta is an Operations Account country of the French Franc Area, since the BCEAO maintains an Operations Account w i th the French Treasury; settle- ments with France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries are made in CFA francs, French francs, or the currency of any Operations Ac- count country. Settlements with The Gambia, Ghana, Liberia, Nigeria, and Sierra Leone are normally made in West A f r ican accounting units through the West Afri- can Clearing House. Certain settlements w i th Ghana are made through special accounts. Certain settlements w i th the People's Republic of China and the Federal Republic of Germany are also channeled through special accounts. Settlements w i th all other countries are usually made either through correspondent banks in France or the country concerned in any of the currencies of those countries or in French francs (or other Franc Area cur- rencies) through Foreign Accounts. All settlements with Rhodesia and South A f r ica are prohibited. Nonresident Accounts The regulations per ta in ing to nonresident accounts are based on those applied in France. BCEAO banknotes may be credited to Foreign Accounts in Francs when they have been mailed direct to the BCEAO agency in Ouagadougou by authorized banks' foreign correspond- ents. Otherwise, the crediting to nonresident accounts of BCEAO banknotes, French banknotes, or banknotes issued by any other institute of issue that ma in ta ins an Operations Account is prohibited. Imports and Import Payments Imports originating in or shipped f rom Rhodesia and South Afr ica are prohibited. Imports f rom countries in the French Franc Area may in principle be made freely, although exceptionally, special regulations may be issued. Imports shipped from and originating in EEC countries, with minor exceptions, are liberalized and require only an import certificate. Most imports f rom other countries are subject to licensing. Imports f rom non-EEC coun- tries outside the French Franc Area are adm i t ted in accordance w i th an annual import program, determined each year by the Directorate of Commerce. Under this program, global quotas are established up to which import licenses are issued for specified commodities. Imports from Ghana are subject to special regu- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution lations. Most imports are subject to a customs s tamp tax of 6 per cent and an import surcharge of 6 per cen t. All import transactions relating to foreign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when the ir va lue exceeds CFAF 500,000. The import licenses or import certificates entitle importers to purchase the necessary exchange, but not earlier than eight days before shipment if a documen tary credit is opened or eight days before the payment is due if the commodities have already been imported. Payments for Invisibles All payments to Rhodesia and South Afr ica are pro- hibited. Payments for invisibles to France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries are permitted freely; those to other countries are subject to exchange control approval, which for many invisibles has been delegated to the authorized banks. Authorized banks and the Postal Adm in is t ra t ion are empowered to make payments to foreign countries, on behaif of residents, up to CFAF 50,000 a t rans fe r. Paymen ts for invisibles related to trade are permitted free ly when the basic trade transaction has been approved or does not require au thor iza t ion. Transfers of income accru ing to nonresidents in the form of profits, d iv idends, and royalties are also permitted. Residents traveling for tourism to countries other than France (as def ined above ), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries may ob ta in an exchange allocation of an amount equivalent to CFAF 175,000 a person a t r ip (CFAF 87,500 for children under ten) for any number of trips a year; any fore ign exchange in excess of CFAF 5,000 rema in ing a f ter re tu rn to Upper Volta must be surrendered. The basic allocation for travel abroad for business purposes is the equivalent of CFAF 20,000 a day, with a max imum of CFAF 400,000 a trip. Resi- dent travelers going to foreign countries may take out up to a max imum of CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO bank- notes, French banknotes, and banknotes of other Opera- tions Account countries. Resident travelers to other countries of the French Franc Area may take out any amount in BCEAO banknotes, but if going to a country that is not a member of the West Afr ican Monetary Union, they must declare to the customs the amount taken out if it exceeds CFAF 150,000. Nonresident travelers may freely take out foreign banknotes up to the equ iva lent of CFAF 175,000 or any larger amoun t, if declared upon entry or acquired by d raw ing on a Foreign Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency or by exchange of foreign travelers checks, etc. They may also take out any foreign means of payment other than banknotes acquired in Upper Volta by debit to a Foreign Account in Francs or an Account in Foreign Currency, subject to submission of documen ta t ion. F ina l ly, they may take out freely up to CFAF 25,000 in BCEAO banknotes, French bank- notes, and banknotes of Operations Account countries. UPPER VOLTA Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to countries of the French Franc Area may be made freely but for statistical purposes certain agri- cu l tural products require a license from the Directorate of Commerce. Exports to Rhodesia and South Africa are prohibited. Exports to all other countries are per- mitted free ly but some also require a license. Certain commodities can be exported in special circumstances only. Exports to Ghana are subject to special regula- tions. Export proceeds received in currencies other than those of France or another Operations Account country must be surrendered within two months of the date on which the payment falls due (the due date stipulated in the commercial contract, which must not, in principle, be later than 180 days af ter arrival of the goods at their de s t ina t ion ). All export transactions relating to fore ign countries must be domiciled with an authorized bank when their value exceeds CFAF 500,000, and the ex- porter must sign a foreign exchange commitment and subm it a customs certification. Most exports are subject to a customs stamp tax of 6 per cent and a statistical duty of 3 per cent. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds f rom transactions in invisibles w i th France (as defined above), Monaco, and Operations Account countries may be retained. All amounts due f rom resi- dents of other countries in respect of services and all income earned in those countries f rom foreign assets must be collected and surrendered w i th in two months of the due date. Such proceeds and earnings may not be received in or f rom Rhodesia or South A f r ica. Resident and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount of banknotes and coins issued by the BCEAO, the Bank of France, or any bank of issue ma in ta in ing an Opera- tions Account, as well as any amount of foreign b ank- notes and coins (except gold coins) of countries outside the French Franc Area. Resident travelers must declare to the customs any foreign means of payment in excess of CFAF 5,000 that they bring in and within eight days a f t er re turn surrender these to an authorized bank. Capital All capital movements between Upper Volta and Rho- desia and South Afr ica are prohibited. Capital move- ments between Upper Volta and France (as defined above), Monaco, and the Operations Account countries are free of exchange control; capital transfers to all other countries require exchange control approval and are restricted, but capital receipts f rom such countries are permitted freely. Special controls (additional to any exchange control requirements that may be applicable) are maintained over borrowing abroad, over inward direct investment and all outward investment, and over the issuing, adver- tising, or offer ing for sale of foreign securities in Upper Volta. Such operations require prior authorization by 443 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution UPPER VOLTA the Minister of Finance. Exempt from authorization, however, are securities operations in connection with (1) loans backed by a guarantee from the Upper Volta Government and (2) shares that are similar to or may be substituted for securities whose issue, offering for sale, or sale in Upper Volta have previously been author- ized. With the exception of controls over foreign securi- ties, these measures do not apply to France (as defined above), Monaco, member countries of the West Afr ican Monetary Union, and the Operations Account countries. Special controls are maintained also over imports and exports of gold, over the soliciting of funds for deposit with foreign private persons and foreign firms and institutions, and over publicity aimed at placing funds abroad or at subscribing to real estate building operations abroad; these special controls also apply to France, Monaco, and the Operations Account countries. All the special provisions listed in this paragraph apply only to transactions and not to the payments or collections connected with them. All investments abroad by residents of Upper Volta require prior authorization by the Minister of Finance.3 Foreign direct investments in Upper Vo l ta4 must be declared to the Minister of Finance before they are made. The Minister has a period of two months from receipt of the declaration during which he may request the postponement of the projects. The total or partial liquidation of either type of investment also is subject to prior declaration to the Minister. Both the mak ing and the liquidation of investments, whether these are Upper Volta investments abroad or foreign investments in Upper Volta, must be reported to the Minister of Finance and the BCEAO within 20 days following each operation. Direct investments are defined as investments implying control of a company or enterprise. Mere par- ticipation is not considered as direct investment, pro- vided that it does not exceed 20 per cent in the capital of a company whose shares are quoted on a stock exchange. Since October 30, 1975, foreign firms operat- ing in Upper Volta are obliged to "Voltaize" their capi- tal within two years, up to at least 51 per cent in vital or priority sectors and up to at least 35 per cent in all others. The sale to residents of Upper Volta of securities of foreign companies operating in Upper Volta requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance, who establishes the sales value. Borrowing by residents from nonresidents requires prior authorization by the Minister of Finance. The following are, however, exempt from this authorization: (1) loans constituting a direct investment, which are 3 Including those made through foreign companies that are directly or indirectly controlled by persons in Upper Volta and those made by branches or subsidiaries abroad of companies in Upper Volta. 4 Including those made by companies in Upper Volta that are directly or indirectly under foreign control and those made by branches or subsidiaries in Upper Volta of foreign companies. 444 subject to prior declaration, as indicated above; (2) loans taken up by industrial firms to finance transactions abroad, by any type of firm to finance imports into or exports from Upper Volta, or by international trading houses previously approved by the Minister of Finance to finance international merchanting transactions; (3) loans contracted by authorized banks; (4) loans other than those mentioned above, when the total amount out- s tand ing of these loans, including the new borrowing, does not exceed CFAF 100 million for any one bor- rower, provided that the annual interest rate does not exceed the normal market rate and that the proceeds are immediately surrendered by the sale of foreign cur- rency on the exchange market or debited to a Foreign Account in Francs. The repayment of loans not consti- tu t ing a direct investment requires the special authoriza- tion of the Minister if the loan itself was subject to such approval, but is exempt if the loan was exempt from special authorization. Lending abroad is subject only to exchange control authorization by the BCEAO, acting on behalf of the Minister of Finance. The Investment Code provides preferential treatment for foreign investment in Upper Volta. Two preferen- tial categories (A and B) are established, in accordance with which preferential treatment with respect to stable rates of taxes, duties, and other fiscal charges may be accorded to specified enterprises for periods of up to 25 years. The benefits under Category B are far more liberal than those under Category A; they are negotiable between the investor and the Government, and the enterprise accorded such benefits must be of exceptional importance to the development of the country. Gold Residents are free to hold, acquire, and dispose of gold in any form in Upper Volta. Imports and exports of gold f rom or to any other country require prior authorization by the External Finance Bureau in the Ministry of Finance. Exempt from this requirement are ( 1) imports and exports by or on behalf of the Treasury or the BCEAO; (2) imports and exports of manufac- tured articles containing a minor quantity of gold (such as gold-filled or gold-plated articles); and (3) imports and exports by travelers of gold objects up to a combined weight of 500 grams. Both licensed and exempt imports of gold are subject to customs declaration. Changes during 1977 June 16. The customs tar iff was modified by Order No. 77-23. September 26. The prohibition on all transactions with Portugual was lifted by Decree No. 77-374. December 29. Goods originating in the member coun- tries of the EEC became subject to customs duties (Decree No. 77-496). ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System No par value or central rate has been established for Uruguay's currency, the New Peso. Exchange trans- actions take place in a dual exchange market, consisting of a commercial market and a financial market. Payments and receipts in respect of imports other than books (except when the exchange is purchased more than 120 days af ter the due d a t e ), exports other than books, freight and insurance on imports, and most public sector exchange operations are settled in the commercial market, where the exchange rates are fixed (a l though adjusted f rom time to t im e ). All other exchange trans- actions take place in the financial market, in which the exchange rate fluctuates freely. On December 31, 1977 the buying and selling rates in the commercial market were NUr$5.40 and NUr$5.41, respectively, per US$1, and those in the financial market were NUr$5.385 and NUr$5.390, respectively, per US$1. ' Various additional effective exchange rates arise f rom the following: ( 1) the application of exchange taxes to the proceeds from certain traditional exports; (2) the payment of subsidies through tax credit certificates on proceeds f rom certain exports; ( 3) a 40 per cent tax on certain profit remittances; and (4) the sale in the finan- cial market of the excess (sobreaforo) of the actual f.o.b. value over the assumed value (aforo or m in imum sur- render va lue) on wool exports. The Central Bank of Uruguay supplies foreign exchange to the commercial banks for imports, and the proceeds f rom exports (valued at the officially assessed price or the aforo where applicable) must be surrendered to the Central Bank. There are no restrictions on exchange transactions in the financial market; exchange houses, whose principal business is mak ing exchange transactions, must be authorized by the Central Bank. Administration of Control Exchange transactions in the commercial ma rket are carried out through authorized banks, bank ing houses, and the Bank of the Republic. Any person or firm may conduct exchange transactions in the financial market. The Bank of the Republic collects import surcharges, export taxes, and consular charges and accepts export and import registrations. Prescription of Currency Payments between Uruguay and the countries w i th which Uruguay has concluded reciprocal credit agree- ments may be made through accounts maintained with each other by the central banks, within the f ramewo rk of the LAFTA multilateral clearing system; these coun- tries are Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Ecuador, Mexico, Paraguay, Peru, and Venezuela. There are separate arrangements for trade in specified goods with Argentina and Brazil. Settlements with other coun- tries in the commercial market are made in U.S. dollars or other convertible currencies. Most transactions in the financial market take place in U.S. dollars, Argentine pesos, or Brazilian cruzeiros. Imports and Import Payments All imports are subject to registration prior to the placing of orders abroad. The registrations are gener- ally valid for 180 days, within which period goods must be cleared through customs. An import declaration must be submitted to the Bank of the Republic before the goods are shipped. Imports of fu l ly assembled auto- mobiles are temporarily prohibited. Most imports are subject to import surcharges. Goods are classified into eight categories and are subject to surcharges of 10, 30, 40, 55, 65, 90, 110, or 150 per cent, payable at the time of registration. Imports from LAFTA countries receive fu ll or partial exemption from these surcharges. Most imports are subject, in addition to any customs duty required and the above-mentioned import sur- charges, to an additional import duty of 18 per cent of the c.i.f. value, and a number of other miscellaneous fees, payable upon customs clearance. All imports are sub- ject to consular charges payable in new pesos and cal- culated on the f.o.b. value at the commercial market rate. These charges are 3.5 per cent for private sector imports of petroleum and petroleum products, alcohol, and tetraethyl lead; 0.25 per cent foi imports of the same commodities by the state oil, alcohol, and cement enter- prise ( A N C A P ); 4 per cent for all other private sector imports; and 0.5 per cent for other imports by ANCAP. l Import duties and surcharges are in most cases cal- culated either on assumed c.i.f. prices (aforos) estab- lished for many commodities or on the actual c.i.f. value. In a few cases, the calculation is based on an officially assessed price, which usually is expressed in U.S. dollars per kilogram. Importers may purchase foreign exchange in the commercial market at any time from 5 days before to 120 days after payment falls due. Purchases at any later date must be made in the financial market unless they are refinanced within 120 days. Purchases with an exchange rate guarantee require a peso deposit at the time of application; the exchange is provided on the due date and the applicable exchange rate is the commercial market rate on the date of application for the guarantee. The facility is available for private sector imports, except imports of capital goods. 1 A unified custom tax (imaduni) was introduced with effect from Janua ry 1, 1978. 445 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution URUGUAY Payments for Invisibles Freight and insurance on imports are settled in the commercial market. Payments for all other invisibles may be made freely through the f inanc ial market. Profit remittances exceeding 20 per cent of the invested capital are subject to a tax of 40 per cent. There are no limita- tions on the export of foreign or domestic banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds The proceeds of the principal traditional exports are subject to taxes, which are withheld by the Bank of the Republic on the basis of either the f.o.b. value or the aforo value of the commodity concerned. The tax is levied in pesos per unit of export commodity (as a per- centage of the f.o.b. value for woo l ), but it may not be more than 50 per cent or less than 0.01 per cent of the peso proceeds of the export; for exports of wool the permitted limits are 2 per cent and 35 per cent of the f.o.b. value. The exchange proceeds of all exports must be surrendered in fu ll to the Central Bank upon receipt. At the end of 1977 the prescribed max imum surrender period was generally not later than 60 days af ter the date of the shipment authorization request for trad i t ional exports (240 days for unwashed woo l ). D i f fe rent periods were applied for non trad i t ional exports. For wool exports, m in imum f.o.b. values (m i n im um surrender prices or aforos) expressed in U.S. dollars per kilogram have been established for various grades and types. There is an export pref inanc ing arrangement for the advance surrender of the exchange proceeds f rom all exports. Surrender must be effected before the export is registered. Export subsidies are granted in the fo rm of tax credit certificates of up to 36 per cent of the f.o.b. va lue of ce r ta in ( p r im a r i ly n o n t r a d i t i o n a l) exports. Exports of cattle on the hoof (except when specially au tho r ized ), specified minerals ( inc lud ing iron, copper, zinc, a l um i n um, and n i c k e l ), and sheepskins are pro- hibited. Proceeds from Invisibles There are no surrender requirements on the proceeds from invisibles. Any individual or firm may accept for- eign currencies at the rate prevailing in the financial market. There are no limitations on the import of fore ign or domestic banknotes. Capital Inward and outward private capital transfers by either residents or nonresidents may be made freely through the financial market, with the exception of certain inward and ou tward transfers relating to investments registered under the Foreign Investment Law. However, certain borrowing abroad is controlled, and the amortization or liquidation proceeds of foreign capital registered under the Foreign Investment Law cannot normally be trans- ferred abroad until three years after the date on which the investment was approved. 446 Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form in Uruguay or abroad, provided that the trans- actions are registered. Gold may be exported only if accompanied by evidence of prior importation. Any private purchases abroad for nonindustrial use, however, must either be financed f rom the buyer's own exchange holdings or settled through the financial market. Imports and exports of gold for industrial use are settled through the commercial market. During the year, the buy ing and selling rates in the financial m a rk et moved f r om NUr$3.990 and NUr$3.995 per US$1 to NUr$5.385 and NUr$5.390 per US$1. Not for Redistribution VENEZUELA (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The currency un it of Venezuela is the Bolivar. The exchange rate is Bs 4.2925 per US$1, except that a rate of Bs 4.20 per US$1 applies in any exchange transactions arising in connection w i th the discharge of liabilities by former foreign owners or concessionaries in the Vene- zuelan hydrocarbon and iron ore industries. The Cen- tral Bank's buying rate for all transactions other than those of the public sector and international organizations is Bs4 .28 per US$1. The Central Bank's buy ing rate for the public sector and international organizations and the selling rate between the Central Bank and the com- mercial banks is Bs 4.2925 per US$1.1 The commercial banks purchase fo re ign exchange from the public at rates close to Bs 4.28 per US$1. Com- mercial banks must sell exchange to the public at Bs 4.30 per US$1 for all transactions; foreign banks may only sell foreign exchange that has not been obtained f rom the Central Bank. Exchange houses are permitted to deal only in banknotes, coins, and travelers checks. Venezuela forma l ly accepted the obligations of Arti- cle VIII, Sections 2, 3, and 4 of the Fund Agreement, as f rom July 1, 1976. Administration of Control There is no exchange control mechanism. Import and export licenses, when required, are generally issued by the Ministry of Development or the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock, depending on the commodity; for certain agricultural products, the prior approval of the Agr icu l tural Ma rke t ing Corporation must be obtained before applications for export licenses are submitted to these ministries. The Superintendency of Foreign Investments (SIEX) is charged with supervision over foreign investment in Venezuela, over contracts for the importation of fore ign technology and the use of foreign patents and trademarks, and over borrowing abroad. Prescription of Currency No prescription of currency requirements are in force. Payments between Venezuela and Argen t ina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Cuba, the Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Mexico, Peru, and U ruguay may be made through accounts ma in ta ined w i th each other by the Central Bank of Venezuela and the central banks of the countries concerned. Imports and Import Payments Imports f rom Rhodesia and South Afr ica are pro- hibited. In addition, the import of certain goods is either prohibited or reserved for the Government; these include fu l ly assembled automobiles, certain textiles, 1 The Central Bank does not sell fore ign exchange to the public but does sell minor amoun ts to its s ta ff and cer ta in gove rnment officials, for travel expenses, at the rate of Bs 4.30 per US$1. 448 coffee, citrus fruit, bananas, pineapples, melons, salt, opium, cigarette paper, natural pearls, and matches. Many other commodities also require import licenses. For protective purposes, quan t i ta t ive restrictions are ma in ta ined on some of these items, irrespective of origin. Licenses are valid for all countries except Rhodesia and South Afr ica. Import licenses for some products are issued on the condition that the importer has purchased domestic products equal to a prescribed percentage of the quan t i ty imported. All other commodities are free f rom import licensing. Import payments may be made freely. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles may be made freely; private sector purchases of exchange for this purpose are made f rom commercial banks or exchange houses. Transfers of profits and dividends are limited in prin- ciple to 20 per cent per annum of registered foreign capital, in accordance w i th Decision No. 103 of the Andean Pact. Resident and nonresident travelers must pay on departure a travel tax of Bs 80 a person a trip; exemptions exist for children under seven, foreign tourists, Venezuelan and foreign diplomats, and person- nel of in terna t ional organizations. Travelers may freely export domestic and foreign currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports of certain fu rs and hides, scrap metal, and a few other commod i t ies are prohibited. Licenses are required for the exportation of many other commodi- ties. Export licenses for most commodities are issued by the M in is try of Development, but those for coffee, cacao, rice, and sugar are granted by the Ministry of Agriculture and Livestock. The export of gold and precious stones requires an export license issued by the Ministry of Finance. There are no surrender requirements for export proceeds or other exchange receipts. Exporters of coffee and cacao may receive an export subsidy calcu- lated to prevent the f .o.b. bolivar prices of these products in Venezuelan ports from fa l l ing below specified mini- mum amoun ts regardless of external prices. Eligibility for this subsidy is maintained even if the exchange proceeds are not surrendered. In principle, the benefit of these arrangemen ts based on guaranteed minimum prices may be extended to firms processing domestic coffee or cacao for export. Non trad i t ional exports, as well as certain agricultural exports, are eligible for freely negotiable tax certificates, as an export incentive, provided that the value added nationally is at least 30 per cent. All exports to Rhodesia and South Afr ica are pro- hibited, as are exports of petroleum and military equip- ment to the People's Republic of China and Nor th Korea. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Proceeds from Invisibles Exchange receipts from invisibles are freely dispos- able. Travelers may freely import domestic and foreign currency, with the exception that the Currency Law prohibits the importation for commercial purposes of foreign coins other than gold coins. Capital All inward and outward capital transfers are permitted freely. Brokerage activity in Venezuela, however, in shares or units of foreign investment trusts or mu tual funds is prohibited. Foreign capital imported for invest- ment purposes and all foreign credits must be registered with SIEX. Natural gas and iron mining operations are reserved for the State, and foreign investment in the petroleum sector is prohibited. The Central Bank regu- lates bank credit to nonresidents and companies whose capital is more than 50 per cent owned by physical persons or companies that are resident or domiciled abroad. The General Banking Law authorizes the Government to regulate bank credit to companies whose capital is more than 40 per cent owned by nonresident or foreign physical persons or companies. This law also provides special regulations for foreign banks operating in Venezuela. Gold Venezuelan gold coins are legal tender but do not circulate. Residents may hold, acquire, and sell gold coins in Venezuela for numismatic and investment pur- poses. The Central Bank does not deal in gold with the public, but gold coins, medallions, and bars are freely negotiated among licensed importers, exchange houses, and the public. Commercial banks may freely negotiate gold coins among themselves and with other residents but do not norma l ly deal in gold w i th the public. Imports and exports of monetary gold are reserved for the Central Bank, as is the import of gold coins that are legal tender in Venezuela. Other imports and exports of gold require licenses. Imports require licenses from the Ministry of Finance and in certain cases also f rom the Ministry of Development, while exports are licensed by the Ministry of Finance only. The law prescribes a license for all imports and exports of gold by anyone not registered at the Ministry of Development as an industrial user, but in practice im- ports and exports by private persons are permitted free of license. Imports of gold coins and of gold bars and ingots weighing more than 12 kilograms are free of VENEZUELA customs duty; all other gold imports are subject to duty at varying rates. All imports of nonmonetary gold are subject to consular duties ranging from 2 per cent to 3.5 per cent ad valorem. Changes during 1977 February 1. Decree No. 2023 provided that the Cen- tral Government and state agencies must buy products of local manufacturers provided these are not more expensive than imports on which the duty is more th an 20 per cent. February 8. Such authorization would be required to obtain a letter of credit, financing, and exemption from import duties. For 1978 the Commis- sion asked all public sector institutions to submit annual import programs, which could be modified subsequently only w i th the concurrence of the Commission. July 18. Free importation of a broad range of food products was extended to October 23. August 15. National enterprises were permitted to increase foreign participation f rom 20 per cent to 49 per cent, provided this ratio was achieved by increased capitalization and not by purchases of existing equity by foreign investors. International financial institutions would be considered as neutral investors and would be excluded f rom calculations to determine whether a company was national, mixed, or foreign. September 6. Not for Redistribution VIET NAM (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System 1 Viet Nam has two currency areas corresponding to the former North and South Viet Nam. No par value has been established with the Fund for the South Viet- namese Dong, which is the currency used in Fund transactions. A representative rate has been established for the South Vietnamese dong of SD 2.130857 = SDR 1. This rate is used for noncommercial transactions in the South. On December 31, 1977 the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were SD 1.85 and SD 1.90, respectively, per US$1. A premium of 25 per cent applies to all inward private transfers and receipts from tourists in Aus tra l ian dollars, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, French francs, deutsche mark, Hong Kong dollars, Japanese yen, Malaysian ringgit, pounds sterling, Singa- pore dollars, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. The exchange rate of the North Vietnamese dong is determined periodically on the basis of a currency basket whose composition and weights are adjusted to changed circumstances, including expected developments in major currencies. On December 31, 1977 the buy ing and sell- ing rates for the U.S. dollar were ND 2.45 and ND 2.47, respectively, per US$1. Exchange rates for the other currencies quoted by the State Bank are based on the daily average exchange rate of the respective currency in terms of the U.S. dollar during the previous mon th. A premium of 50 per cent applies to all inward private transfers and receipts from tourism in Australian dol- lars, deutsche mark, French francs, Hong Kong dollars, Malaysian ringgit, pounds sterling, Singapore dollars, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars.2 Nontrade transactions with countries w i th which Viet Nam has bilateral pay- ments agreements 3 take place at exchange rates specified in those agreements. For foreign trade transactions an accounting exchange rate is used, determined as the rate which equates the cost of total exports in local currency with the corre- sponding foreign exchange earnings dur ing a base period. This rate is reviewed periodically in the light of internal and external cost and price developments. The same rate is applied to imports. Trade transactions with the CMEA countries, Albania, the People's Republic of China, and North Korea are settled in "bilateral rubles" at an ex- change rate of ruble 1 = ND 3.27. The exchange rate between the North Vietnamese 1 On May 2, 1978 the Government announced the introduction of a new currency and a comprehensive reform of the exchange rate system designed to un ify the two currency areas. 2 The Canadian dollar and the Japanese yen were added with effect f rom February 15, 1978. 3 At present Viet Nam has bilateral payments agreements with ten countries that are not members of the Fund —Albania, Bulgaria, People's Republic of China, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, Hungary, Mongolia, North Korea, Poland, and the U.S.S.R. and with five Fund members —Guinea, Mali, Romania, Syrian Arab Republic, and Yugoslavia. 450 dong and the South Vietnamese dong is ND 1 = SD 0.80. The only transactions permitted between the two regions are trade transactions conducted by state enterprises, and officially authorized travel for which max imum amounts of exchange transactions are set by the authorities. There are restrictions as to the nature and amount of goods that can be carried by a traveler. Administration of Control Viet Nam does not yet have a common exchange con- trol law. All exchange and trade regulations applying in the South before May 1975 have been repudiated and new legislation similar to that prevailing in the Nor th has been introduced progressively. Exchange control is administered by the State Bank. All foreign trade is a state monopoly and is administered by the M in is t ry of Foreign Trade which authorizes the foreign trade transactions carried out by specialized state import- export corporations. Import and export licenses issued by the Ministry of Foreign Trade upon application by the import-export corporation are granted only for im- ports and exports contained in the foreign trade plan. All foreign exchange transactions are effected by the Bank for Foreign Trade. Nonresident Accounts Nonresidents are permitted to ma in ta in nonresident accounts either in foreign currencies or in North or South Vietnamese currencies. Nonresidents can freely reconvert into foreign currency and transfer abroad unused balances in Vietnamese currencies that have been acquired against foreign currency. Imports and Exports An import and export plan is drawn up annually for the entire country based on import needs and export possibilities. Import and export transactions are carried out by about 15 state export-import corporations. Some of these corporations have their own producing units, while others contract with supply enterprises. In prin- ciple, the price received by the producing enterprise bears no relation to world prices, since the sale from the producer to the trad ing corporation is a domestic transaction at prices set by the authorities. Nonetheless, given that goods for export are usually of higher quality than those for the domestic market and that a policy of export incentives is being followed, goods for export command higher prices than s im i lar ones oriented to the domestic market. Imports effected by the state trad ing corporations are sold in the domestic market at prices set by the authorities. Profits and losses of state trading enterprises are transferred to, or covered by, the state budget. All payments for trade transactions need the authorization of the State Bank and are made through the Bank for Foreign Trade. Export receipts are nor- ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution mally channeled through the Bank for Foreign Trade and any other receipts f rom foreign trade have to be surrendered to the State Bank. Invisibles All transactions in invisibles require ind iv idual au thor- ization by the State Bank. Foreign exchange is made available upon authorization of the t ransac t ion. All travel abroad needs ind iv idual authorization and is pres- ently limited to official business for which a ll foreign exchange expenses are covered. Students abroad in non- socialist countries who had left the coun try before April 1975 may receive foreign exchange allocations the amount of which is determined by the State Bank for each individual case. Receipts f rom invisible trans- actions have to be surrendered to the State Bank w i th in seven days. The export and import of Vietnamese currency and of securities denominated in Vietnamese currencies needs the special permission of the State Bank. Capital The Foreign Investment Law provides for the estab- lishment of three forms of foreign inves tmen t: ( 1) in- vestment in the production of goods intended solely for VIET NAM exports; (2) jo int ventures between a fore ign investor and a Vietnamese state economic organization; and ( 3) production sharing partnerships for the exploitation of na tu ral resources. The share of foreign capital per- mitted ranges f rom 30 per cent to 49 per cent in the case of jo int ventures, and up to 100 per cent in enter- prises specializing in production for exports. There are guarantees of repatriation of profits and of proper com- pensation in the event of nationalization. Gold The State Bank alone has authority to purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form, at home or abroad. Physical persons are permitted to own jewelry and artistic and cultural objects of gold for domestic and personal use. Changes during 1977 March 29. The bilateral payments agreement w i th Egypt was terminated. April 18. The new Foreign Investment Law was approved. May. Viet Nam became a member of the In terna- tional Bank for Economic Cooperation and the Inter- na t ional Investment Bank. 451 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution WESTERN SAMOA (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System No par value for the Western Samoa Tala has been established with the Fund. A central rate of WS$1 = US$1.67736 was established in 1973. The intervention currency is the U.S. dollar, and Western Samoa avails itself of wider margins. The external value of the tala is determined daily on the basis of the basket of cur- rencies used by New Zealand. Since December 20, 1976 the rate for the New Zealand dollar has been WS$0.76 = $NZ 1. Exchange rates for other currencies are deter- mined on the basis of their rates against the New Zea- land dollar. On August 25, 1977 the Government intro- duced an exchange profit levy of 1 per cent on gross sales of foreign exchange. Subsequently, spreads between buying and selling rates for all traded currencies ex- ceeded 2 per cent. On December 31, 1977 the buying and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were WS$0.7379 and WS$0.7600, respectively, per US$1. Administration of Control The overall responsibility for the administration of exchange control rests with the Monetary Board, but the authority for the daily administration of the exchange controls and the exchange allocation system is entrusted to the Treasury Department, subject to the control and the instructions of the Minister of Finance and the broad guidelines laid down by the Monetary Board. The Minister of Finance may delegate his authority to the Financial Secretary, who in turn may delegate part of his powers to the Secretary of the Monetary Division of the Treasury and to authorized banks. All payments to nonresidents of Western Samoa require the approval of the Ministry of Finance. The Ministry, however, has delegated to the Bank of Western Samoa and the Pacific Commercial Bank —the only authorized banks —author- ity to approve certain payments up to any amount, and certain other payments up to specified amounts. Prescription of Currency There are no prescriptions as to the currencies in which payments to or from nonresidents of Western Samoa must be made or received. Nonresident Accounts No distinction is made between the accounts of resi- dents and nonresidents of Western Samoa. Imports and Import Payments The import of a few commodities is prohibited from all sources for reasons of security or health. Other com- modities may be imported from any source. Each licensed commercial importer receives an annual alloca- tion of foreign exchange, to be taken up on a semiannual basis, which may be used freely for the import of any 452 commodity that is not prohibited, except automobiles.1 The allocations are made by the Ministry of Finance and communicated to the authorized banks which auto- matically provide the foreign exchange required for import payments upon submission of documentary evi- dence. Persons who are not licensed importers may import any commodity freely up to WS$100 a person a year but require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance for imports of higher value. Private buyers of motor vehicles are required to lodge a downpayment of 50 per cent of the retail value with the importing agency. Payments for Invisibles Payments for certain invisibles, such as overseas con- tractual obligations and insurance, are approved auto- matically by the authorized banks up to any amount or within limits determined by the Ministry of Finance. Payments in excess of these limits as well as payments for all other invisibles require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance. Remittances for study abroad are freely authorized. The Ministry of Finance approves up to any amount the transfer of genuine income derived locally from pensions, rents, interests, and divi- dends by persons permanently resident overseas. Resi- dents traveling to American Samoa, whether for busi- ness or private purposes, are entitled to a foreign currency allowance equivalent to US$200 a person a quarter; an additional allowance of US$50 a day is provided to cover hotel expenses. The basic travel allow- ance for other countries is equivalent to WS$50 a person a day, subject to a limit of WS$ 1,000 a year. The Ministry of Finance grants supplementary allocations when evidence of genuine need is provided. Resident travelers may take out foreign banknotes, as part of their foreign currency allowance Travelers may not take out any domestic currency. Exports and Export Proceeds Virtually all exports require the prior approval of the Ministry of Finance. Exports may be prohibited by the Director of Agriculture on grounds of low quality, or by order of the Head of State to alleviate domestic shortages. Copra exports are controlled by the Copra Board, cocoa exports by the Cocoa Board, and banana exports by the Banana Board. An export levy of 7 per cent is imposed on the f.o.b. value of cocoa and copra exports.2 Export proceeds must be surrendered to the authorized banks within a reasonable time after ship- 1 Rice, flour, sugar, milk products, canned fish, mutton flaps, and spare parts for engines may be imported freely outside the allocation system. Proceeds from Invisibles All receipts from invisibles must be surrendered to the authorized banks. Resident travelers must on return sell to the banks all foreign currency brought in. Resi- dent and nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign banknotes, but no domestic banknotes. Capital All outward capital transfers by residents require the specific approval of the Ministry of Finance and capital received by residents must be surrendered. Inward capital remittances do not normally require approval, but bor- rowing abroad by nonbank residents does require ap- proval. The transfer of legacies from estates of deceased local residents due to beneficiaries permanently residing overseas is approved up to a limit of WS$ 10,000 a year. The authorized banks approve transfers of gifts to rela- tives and dependents, either for special fam i ly occasions or by way of maintenance, up to WS$200 a year for each family group. Foreign investments in specified activities WESTERN SAMOA in Western Samoa are encouraged. The Enterprises Incentive Act provides for the granting of certain relief of customs duties, income tax, and business license fees to persons engaged in approved enterprises. Both the repatriation of capital and profit remittances on foreign capital are subject to approval by the Minister of Finance; such approval is normally granted. Gold Residents may freely purchase, hold, and sell gold in any form. There are no restrictions on imports or exports of gold. Changes during 1977 August 22. Not for Redistribution YEMEN ARAB REPUBLIC (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The currency of the Yemen Arab Republic is the Yemen Rial, which is issued by the Central Bank of Yemen. No par value has been established. All trans- actions take place in a free market at an exchange rate which in principle is a fluctuating one but since Febru- ary 1973 has remained unchanged. On December 31, 1977, the rate for the U.S. dollar was YR1 1 = US$0.22. Exchange rates for other currencies are fixed daily by the Central Bank on the basis of London cross rates against the U.S. dollar. Administration of Control There is no exchange control. The Ministry of Supply and Trade grants licenses for imports and exports. Transactions in invisibles are supervised by the Central Bank for statistical purposes only. The only commer- cial banks which deal in foreign exchange are the Yemen Bank for Reconstruction and Development and branches of seven foreign commercial banks. Prescription of Currency There are no prescription of currency requirements.1 Settlements are usually made in pounds sterling or U.S. dollars. Imports and Import Payments Imports f rom Israel are prohibited. Imports of petro- leum and petroleum products are reserved for the Yemen Petroleum Company. All other imports require licenses, which, generally, are issued freely. In addition to a license, the importation of certain commodities requires the permission of certain government agencies. The importation of certain textiles requires the approval of the Sanaa Textile Factory. Imports that are financed by the importer with his own foreign exchange held abroad also require an import license. Importers who have obtained an import license may obtain the neces- sary fore ign exchange f rom the local banks or the free market. A m in imum ma rg in deposit of 20 per cent is prescribed against letters of credit opened for imports of foods tu f fs (o ther than canned f r u i t s ), construction materials, indus t r ial and agricultural inpu ts, medicines, and medical equipment. The rates of margin deposits applicable to imports of other products are between 30 per cent and 100 per cent. The au thor i ty to determine individual ratios is delegated to the commercial banks. Payments for Invisibles Payments for current invisibles may be made freely. Travelers may freely take out any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Exports and Export Proceeds Exports to Israel are prohibited. For statistical pur- poses only, all exports require registration forms, which are issued freely by banks; export licenses are not required. Exporters are not required to surrender their foreign exchange proceeds, which may be retained in foreign currency accounts with domestic banks. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds from invisibles need not be surrendered but may be retained in foreign currency accounts with domestic banks. Travelers may freely bring in any amount in domestic or foreign banknotes. Capital No restrictions are imposed on inward or outward capital transfers, except that the commercial banks are required to obtain the approval of the Central Bank before contracting foreign loans or providing guarantees against foreign credits extended to residents and non- residents. Domestic and foreign investment is regulated by Law No. 18 of 1975. Foreign investors in the Yemen Arab Republic are free to transfer abroad any desired proportion of their net profits af ter taxes or of their capital. Gold Residents are free to purchase, hold, and sell gold in any fo rm in the Yemen Arab Republic and to import or export gold in any form without an import, export, or exchange license. Not for Redistribution PEOPLE'S DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF YEMEN (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The currency of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen is the Yemeni Dinar, which is issued by the Bank of Yemen (the central bank) and is defined as equiva- lent to 2.13281 grams of fine gold. No par value for the Yemeni dinar has been established with the Fund. Since February 1973, the central rate has been YD 1 = US$2.89523 or US$1 = YD 0.345395. On Decem- ber 31, 1977, the National Bank of Yemen's buy ing and selling rates for the U.S. dollar were YD 0.343 and YD 0.350, per US$1. Administration of Control The administration of exchange control is carried out by the Bank of Yemen's General Department for Exchange Control through the Foreign Exchange Com- mittee, which has delegated certain powers to the Director of Exchange Control, a member of the Com- mittee. The Ministry of Trade and Supply issues import and export licenses; those for gold and other precious metals require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Exchange transactions must be carried out through the intermediary of authorized dealers (licensed commercial banks approved by the Director of Exchange Control); at present the only commercial bank and authorized dealer is the National Bank of Yemen. Except for payments for imports against letters of credit or documents, which may be approved by the authorized dealer, all payments for imports ( inc lud ing those of precious metals) require the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control. Certain public cor- porations are engaged in foreign trade (see section on Imports and Import Payments, below). The oil refinery, which was transferred to government ownership in May 1977, is treated as a resident entity. Prescription of Currency Exchange transactions must be carried out through the intermediary of authorized dealers in accordance with prescription of currency regulations that are in certain respects similar to those applicable in the United King- dom. All payments to Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. Export proceeds and certain receipts from invisibles must be received in prescribed currencies l and surren- dered to authorized dealers. Payments for imports must be made in prescribed currencies. External Accounts in Yemeni dinars may be credited with proceeds from convertible foreign currency transferred from abroad, with bank interest payable on such accounts, and with balances f rom other External Accounts. Transfers f rom abroad must be in the form of bank d ra f ts; the accounts cannot be credited with pay- ments in the form of foreign banknotes (unless they have been declared to the customs on en t ry ), or with locally raised or locally earned funds (except in certain specified cases). External Accounts may be debited for any pay- ments to residents, for transfers to other External Ac- counts, and for payments abroad in any convertible currency. Transfers abroad from Nonresident Accounts in Yemeni dinars require the prior approval of the Exchange Control Department. The Foreign Exchange Committee may direct any payment to a nonresident to a Blocked Account. Except with the Committee's prior approval, Blocked Accounts may be debited only for purchases of specified securities. Subject to certain conditions, Yemeni nationals work- ing abroad may establish nonresident accounts in foreign currencies; balances in these accounts earn interest and are convertible into foreign currency on demand. Imports and Import Payments With minor exceptions, all imports other than those of the oil refinery require ind iv idual licenses. Goods originating in the Yemen Arab Republic are exempt f rom the licensing requirements. Imports f rom Israel and Rhodesia are prohibited. An import program is drawn up annually. In addition, importers may import certain goods with their own exchange; such imports require prior approval by the Ministry of Trade and Supply. Payments for imports on a c. & f. basis against letters of credit or documentary drafts can be made by authorized dealers w i thout the prior approval of the Director of Exchange Control; most other forms of payment for imports require approval. Insurance on imports must be effected locally. The Na t ional Company for Foreign Trade has a monopoly over imports of flour, sugar, wheat, rice, ghee, cooking oil, tea, and cigarettes. The Na t ional Company for Home Trade is the sole importer of automobiles and other vehicles, all government requ i remen ts, and most requirements of the public hospitals, as well as other specified items. Imports into and exports f rom the free port zones within the port of Aden are free of exchange and trade controls (except in respect of trans- actions between these zones and the rest of the People's Democratic Republic of Yemen) and are exempt from customs duties. Payments for Invisibles All payments for invisibles require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. The basic exchange 455 ©International Monetary Fund. Foreign employees of approved enterprises are allowed to remit abroad up to 50 per cent of their total earnings (net of taxes); other foreign employees, if receiving their salaries from abroad, are allowed to remit 70 per cent of their total earnings. All insurance is nationalized; existing policies have been transferred to the National Insurance and Reinsurance Company, and payments abroad in respect of premiums are not per- mitted. Most of the proceeds of exports or re-exports to the Yemen Arab Republic may be surrendered in the national currency of the importing country. Proceeds from Invisibles All claims of residents for services rendered to non- residents must be collected in foreign currency (or received from an External Account) when due and surrendered to authorized dealers. However, Yemeni nationals working abroad are allowed to establish non- resident foreign currency accounts. Travelers may freely bring in foreign banknotes; imports of more than YD 5 in domestic currency are subject to a tax of 50 per cent. Tourists are required to spend in foreign exchange an amount equivalent to YD 50 a month or US$10 a day if the duration of their stay is less than one month. Capital Virtually all capital payments and transactions require prior approval. All remittances abroad of interest and profits require prior approval by the Director of Exchange Control. Profit remittances abroad by foreign firms should not normally exceed 50 per cent of the accrued net profit in any one year. Beginning five years after production has started, the net value of the enterprise (calculated on the basis of actual or book value, or surrender or liquidation value, whichever is less) is transferable at the rate of 25 per cent a year; if an expatriate national or a foreign investor encounters difficulties, however, his capital may be retransferred six months after entry. Interest due on any loans obtained abroad after the firm concerned has been established may also be remitted, provided that all duties, taxes, and other government dues have been paid. Other residents may hold gold only in the form of ornaments or numis- matic coins. Exports and imports of gold by registered goldsmiths require licenses issued by the Ministry of Trade and Supply (General Department for Foreign Trade); in certain cases, the consent of the Foreign Exchange Committee must also be obtained. Administration of Control The Federal Executive Council prescribes the general provisions in respect of foreign trade and exchange transactions. The Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade establishes rules and regu la t ions, makes decisions gov- e rn ing commercial t ransac t ions, and issues impo rt and export licenses when requ ired. It is also charged w i th securing balanced trade w i th paymen ts agreement coun- tries. The Federal Secretariat for Finance prescribes the specific provisions governing exchange t ransac t ions. This Secretariat and the Na t ional Bank of Yugoslavia administer the exchange controls. The Na t ional Bank prescribes the methods of payment to and f rom fore ign countries; it also licenses compensation transac t ions. All fore ign exchange transactions must be carried out through the Na t ional Bank or an authorized bank. The latter are of three types. Fully authorized banks, which must have a m in imum credit f u nd of Din 500 million and deposits of at least Din 1,000 m i l l ion, may engage in all foreign exchange transac t ions in Yugoslavia and abroad, as well as in foreign credit operations ( in c lud ing the gran t ing of gua ran tees ). Limited au thor ized banks, which must have a m i n im um credit f u nd amoun t ing to Din 100 million and deposits of at least Din 200 m i l l ion, may conduct foreign exchange operations in Yugoslavia only; they may neither keep fore ign exchange accoun ts abroad nor engage in fore ign credit operations, except through the intermediation of a fu l ly authorized credit bank. Authorized exchange offices may only deal in fo r- eign banknotes and travelers checks; this status is open to all commercial and savings banks, hotels, and spe- cifically authorized tourist agencies. Commercial exports and imports may be effected by all economic organizations (both produc ing and t rad ing unde r tak ing s) registered for this purpose. Reg is tra t ion is effected automatically, provided that certain condi- tions, inc lud ing the provision of m in imum work ing capital for trade enterprises, are fu l f i l led. Economic organ iza t ions that are not registered to conduct foreign trade channel their orders through economic organiza- tions wh ich export and /or import on the ir own behalf. Prescription of Currency Paymen ts to and from countries w i th which Yugo- slavia has bilateral payments agreements are made in the currencies and according to the procedures set forth in those agreements. If no agreement exists, settlement is u sua l ly made in a convertible currency. Yugoslavia has paymen ts agreements requ ir ing settlements through bilateral accounts as fo l lows: (1) in U.S. dollars w i th A lban ia, Czechoslovakia, the German Democratic Re- public, Mongolia, and the U.S.S.R.; and (2) in pounds sterling with Viet Nam. Certain settlements with Bang- ladesh, Colombia, Ghana, Mexico, and Pakistan take place through special accounts. Imports and Import Payments Commercial imports may be effected only by eco- nomic organizations registered as par t ic ipa t ing in foreign trade. In addition to economic organizations specializ- ing in foreign trade, most ma jor indus tr ial producers are registered. The import of cer ta in basic foods tu f fs, such as wheat, rice, coffee, lard, and sugar, is carried out by economic organizations that have been selected by the Federal Office for Food Reserves, on the basis of public bids. 2 Albania, Czechoslovakia, German Democratic Republic, and U.S.S.R. 458 For most commodities import licenses are not re- quired. All commodities included in the foreign trade nomenclature are classified in four categories, largely in accordance with the manner in which exchange is made available: LB —liberalized goods; GDK—goods im- ported under global exchange quotas; RK and DK— goods subject to individual quotas (RK if individual quotas are fixed by quantity and DK if they are fixed in d i n a r s ); and D —imports subject to ad hoc licensing. Goods in the LB category are mainly raw materials, foods tuffs, and spare parts, but they also include some consumer goods. Protective equipment for workers and all other goods not specifically included in the GDK, RK, DK, or D lists are also liberalized and free from any quan t i ta t ive restriction. Exchange for payments for LB imports f rom the convertible currency area is made available freely in any convertible currency appropriate to the exporting country. Payments for imports of liberalized goods f rom payments agreement countries must be made in the manner prescribed in the relevant payments agreement and may be restricted according to the availability of funds in the appropriate clearing account. The GDK list comprises raw materials, other repro- duction materials, most capital equipment, and most of those consumer goods not liberalized under the LB regime. Such imports can be effected under several dif- ferent procedures. For nonconsumer goods each im- porter of raw materials and other reproduction materials receives a global foreign exchange quota and may use the exchange so allocated to purchase any such goods listed as GDK. Payment for imports of capital goods on the GDK list may be financed f rom specific exchange allocations; a considerable portion may be freely financed f rom retention quota funds (see section on Exports and Export Proceeds, be low ), funds originating in depreciation allowances, and credits obtained abroad, inc lud ing suppliers' credits. The specific exchange allo- cations are limited mainly to large investment projects, inc lud ing public utilities; the amounts are determined by the Federal Assembly. Economic organizations may acquire foreign exchange at a predetermined proportion of their annual depreciation allowance, a ratio that varies from 10 to 100 per cent according to the eco- nomic sector involved. For consumer goods, trading enterprises agree within the Chamber of Economy on the distribution of GDK quotas among themselves; if the enterprises are unable to agree among themselves on a GDK allocation, the Federal Secretariat for Market and Prices will allocate this quota among them. A part of the GDK quotas is reserved for imports f rom speci- fied developing countries. Imports under commodity quotas (list RK or list DK ), ma in ly selected agricultural and mineral products (such as wheat, sugar, rice, coffee, and salt) but also machine tools and certain plastics, are subject to quotas established for each commodity and cannot be imported ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution under any other procedure. The quotas are established either in physical quantities ( RK) or in dinars (DK ). There are separate quotas in each case for imports f rom convertible area countries and payments agreement countries; their allocation among importers is decided by negotiations among the economic organizations.3 Additional quotas may be allocated dur ing the year if the enterprise to which the quota is allocated under takes to increase exports. Exchange is provided au toma t ica l ly for payments for imports of goods subject to the RK and DK regime, but only up to a predetermined quan t i ty or amount for each item. Goods in list D comprise gunpowder, ammun i t ion, opium, motor vehicles, tractors, railway rolling stock, aircraft, na tural gas, and bitumen. Import licenses are required only for list D commodities. These licenses automatically entitle an enterprise to purchase the requisite foreign exchange. For certain goods there is an add i t ional requ iremen t, irrespective of those set out above, of a special import license ("accordance") issued by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. At the end of 1977 these goods were 65 LB items, 5 RK items, 2 DK items, and 1 D item. The items include a wide range of tropical foods tu f fs and fru i ts, raw materials, cocoa butter, fa ts and oils, raw cotton, textiles, and t in, and the Secretariat may prescribe direct importation f rom the coun try of origin. Private persons who are Yugoslav na t iona ls and hold foreign exchange accounts with Yugoslav banks may use these funds freely to import goods for their own use or for the use of close relatives residing with them, regardless of the import regime for the goods. Self- employed Yugoslav nationals may freely and at any time import machinery for small fa rms or equipment for hand icraft production, up to Din 80,000 a shipment. Also, Yugoslavs re turn ing f rom work abroad and non- residents residing in Yugoslavia for more than three months may import goods up to Din 80,000 for their personal needs or the needs of their own household, provided such goods were paid for f rom the savings f rom their foreign earnings; such savings may be held abroad or in fore ign exchange accounts w i th Yugoslav banks. As an exception to the foregoing, owners of fore ign exchange accounts and Yugoslav na t iona ls wo rk ing abroad may import automobiles, trucks, motorcycles, mopeds, and bicycles, together with mounted motors and essential spare parts for these vehicles, provided that importation is effected through a registered enter- prise and payment is made through a fore ign exchange account held at a Yugoslav bank. YUGOSLAVIA nationals are exempt f rom this prescribed manner of payment and method of importation, however, under the following circumstances: when they re turn for per- manent residence in Yugoslavia, provided that they have spent at least five years abroad; when a vehicle is in- herited; when a motor vehicle is purchased out of an insurance indemn i ty received for a motor vehicle that has been destroyed and had originally been paid for in foreign currency; and if they have spent at least two years abroad continuously and have owned a vehicle for at least two years. A 1 per cent special tax for customs evidence and a 6 per cent tax equalization charge are payable on all commodities not exempt f rom customs duty.
