Payments for Invisibles Payments for invisibles related to merchandise trans- actions, including transpor ta t ion, are fu l ly liberalized. Exchange to cover export promotion expenses abroad is made free ly available to exporters. Pensions, wages, and salaries are transferab le under certain conditions. Pay- men ts in respect of royalties and alimony granted by court order are freely transferable, but if a payment is to be made to a country with which Yugoslavia ma in- ta ins bilateral payments arrangements, then such pay- ments may be made only if the agreement in question provides for this to be done on a reciprocal basis. Authorized banks may sell foreign currency up to the equivalent of Din 1,000 for remittances for court and other fees abroad and for specified personal expenses. The Na t ional Bank may authorize the sale of any amount of foreign exchange for the foregoing and for unspecified purposes when justified in light of the circumstances. Purchases of services abroad, as well as spare parts, fue l, etc., by Yugoslav enterprises involved in international fre ight and passenger t ranspo r ta t ion are liberalized. There is no basic exchange allowance for tourist travel abroad. However, travel agencies may sell orga- nized tours abroad against payment in d inars up to an amount equivalent to 100 per cent of their ind iv idual 459 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution YUGOSLAVIA retention quotas. The Na t ional Bank may also au thor ize travel agencies to sell foreign exchange for both group and individual travel abroad. Payments for other inv is i- bles may be made from the remitter's own fo re ign exchange funds (e.g., f rom retention quotas, or, when made by various social and sociopolitical o rgan iza t ions, from specific annual allocations). Not more than Din 1,500 in domestic currency, in denom ina t ions of Din 100 or less, may be taken out by travelers. Foreign travelers may bring in and take out any amount in for- eign exchange w i thout declaring it. Exports and Export Proceeds In principle, exports are free of control, except for certain raw materials that are in short supply on the domestic market (including petroleum and petroleum derivatives and certain livestock) and- certain other materials such as gunpowder, weapons, and narco t ic drugs. Exports to countries with which Yugoslavia has a bilateral payments agreement are subject to approval by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade ("accord- ance"). Such approval may be given for a group of commodities or for all commodities to be exported within a certain period (global approva l). Permission to export to bilateral countries may be made conditional on an undertaking to import f rom such countries or to export to other countries. Proceeds f rom exports must be repatriated w i th in 90 days from the date of exportation, unless specific approval is granted to deviate from this rule. The sur- render of these proceeds is not required. The f u ll export proceeds may be credited to foreign exchange sight deposit accounts which the exporter ma in ta ins w i th an authorized bank of his choice; separate accounts must be established for each currency. Exchange on these accounts may either be used, subject to the relevant regulations, for payments for imports and invisibles, or be sold to an authorized bank. Retention quotas may be used to pay for imports of certain consumer goods if such imports are made by economic organizations that are in the catering and tourist industries or are engaged in setting up trade fairs, and by film enterprises; such imports are also permitted as consignment stocks. The part of the export proceeds that rema ins at the free disposal of the exporter for payments abroad is referred to as the retention quota; the rema inder may be retained indefinitely or used for certain paymen ts abroad, but cannot earn interest. The permitted reten- tion rate is 20 per cent for all export earnings f rom goods and services, with the exception that a rate of 45 per cent applies to tourist organizations and a rate of 100 per cent applies to foreign exchange earnings of Yugoslav enterprises operating abroad and to Yugoslav enterprises operating under long-term cooperation agree- ments with foreign companies. (Enterprises with long- term cooperation agreements may in any case import up to the value of their production which is a result of that cooperation.) In some instances (services rendered to 460 fore ign tourists and sales of newly m ined go ld ), sales against payment in dinars are regarded as exports for retention quota purposes. Producing enterprises selling specified consumer goods in Yugoslavia for fore ign cur- rency may re ta in 20 per cent of the foreign exchange thus earned. Proceeds from Invisibles Proceeds f rom invisibles must be repatriated w i th in 90 days f rom the date on which the claim is payable. The performance of construction and engineering serv- ices in paymen ts agreement countries is subject to an "accordance" issued by the Federal Secretariat for For- eign Trade. Receipts f rom services are eligible for reten- t ion quotas; the quota for hotels and tourist agencies is 45 per cent. Exchange proceeds may be used for pay- ments abroad connected with the activities of the eco- nomic organization concerned, inc lud ing paymen ts for purchases of equipment and other ma te r ial for its own needs. The retained exchange is not transferab le to economic organizations other than those w i th which the recipients are cooperating in technical and business ma t- ters, but it can always be sold to authorized banks. If the exchange is used to pay for imports, the usual import procedures apply. Residents who, wh i le employed abroad, deposited their savings in foreign savings banks and obtained a "savings book," may withdraw their balances in the form of foreign exchange when in Yugoslavia. Residents may hold interest-bearing foreign currency accounts in Yugoslavia. The accounts may be credited with the fu ll amount of a person's savings in foreign exchange. These accounts may be used freely for the personal needs of the account holder and of his imme- diate f am i ly; they are not t rans fe rab le to other persons or accounts and may be retained for an indef in i te period of time. Authorized trade organizations may sell manufac tured goods to foreign tourists in Yugoslavia against payment in foreign exchange at a discount freely established by the trade organizations themselves. This discount is granted only on purchases in authorized shops against checks expressed in foreign currencies or against certain foreign banknotes. Not more than Din 1,500 in Yugoslav banknotes, in denominations of Din 100 or less, may be brought in by travelers. Capital Foreign loans and credits may be freely contracted by fu l ly authorized banks and economic organizations, except that consumer goods may not be imported on deferred payment terms and that there is no provision for foreign financial credits whose repayment terms include a grace period of less than two years.4 All other 4 When enterprises issue bonds abroad, they may use 80 per cent of the fore ign exchange proceeds for the import of equ ipment and spare par ts for their own needs. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution inward or outward transfers of a capital na ture by resi- dents or nonresidents require individual licenses. Foreign loans and credits must be recorded w i th the National Banks of the republics. Loans must ordinarily be repaid with foreign exchange that is either obtained by the economic organization concerned as export reten- tion quotas and foreign exchange amortization (depre- ciation) allocations or acquired f rom banks according to the regulations governing the foreign trade regime. Credits in the former category are subject to prior dinar deposit requirements; the deposits are noninterest bearing and are held with the National Banks of the republics until full repayment of the foreign credits. For financial credits and foreign exchange deposits received by business banks for the account of nonresi- dents, the five basic rates of deposit introduced in April 1972 range from 1 per cent for maturities over ten years to 40 per cent for maturities of less than two years. However, as a temporary measure beginning in mid- December 1972, a dinar deposit of 75 per cent was required for all financial credits and foreign exchange deposits by nonresidents, regardless of maturity. For credits for the importation of capital goods, the deposit rates at the end of 1977 were 20 per cent for credits with a maturity of up to three years; 10 per cent for credits of between three and five years; and 1 per cent for credits with a maturity of over five years. However, if the capital goods were imported for investments in underdeveloped regions of Yugoslavia, the deposit rates were 10 per cent for credits with a maturity of up to three years and 1 per cent for credits with a longer maturity and also for all credits for the import of specially produced capital equipment. Certain foreign credits are specifically exempted f rom the foregoing deposit requirements; these include credits f rom specified international financial organizations, credits contracted for or on behalf of the Federal Gov- ernment or the National Bank, and credits contracted for the importation of equipment intended for high- priority sectors and activities as defined by Decisions of the Federal Executive Council. Foreign credits repayable with foreign exchange acquired according to the regulations governing the for- eign trade regime are trade credits for raw materials and intermediate goods, usually with a ma tur i ty of up to 360 days. These are exempt from deposit require- ments. As an exception, if the goods imported on credit are under the LB regime, 25 per cent must normally be deposited with the National Banks of the republics or the autonomous provinces as a downpayment and the remaining 75 per cent is payable at maturity. Foreigners may invest in Yugoslav economic organi- zations but only through jo int ventures; such foreign investment is limited to 49 per cent of the organization's capital. Profit transfers abroad may be financed f rom the retention quota and, in addition, profit transfers are permitted up to one third of the joint venture's foreign YUGOSLAVIA currency earnings from exports of goods and services. If the law governing joint ventures were to be amended, the legal provisions in force on the date of registration of a joint venture would continue to be applied during the entire life of the investment contract, if the foreign investor so desires or, at the latter's option, any more favorable provisions of the amended legislation would be applied. Foreign firms are permitted to establish representational offices in Yugoslavia. The investment income earned abroad by Yugoslav economic organizations must be repatriated within 90 days; however, when repatriated the profits are governed by the regulations for retention quotas. Residents are obliged to repatriate and, with the exception of inherit- ances, to surrender all foreign exchange held or accruing abroad on capital account. Outward capital transfers by residents who are physical persons are not approved. Economic organizations wish- ing to participate in foreign enterprises may be allowed to export the necessary capital under special conditions set by the Federal Secretariat for Foreign Trade. Also, a Decision of the Federal Executive Council requires the Yugoslav authorities to continue to permit the remittance of inheritances to citizens of the United States, provided that the remittance is requested within three years from the date of distribution of the estate. Gold The National Bank has issued certain commemorative gold coins, which are not legal tender. Foreign travelers are freely permitted to import and export these coins, subject to customs declaration and, for exports, subject to proof that they have been purchased in Yugoslavia. Residents who are private persons may hold gold coins in Yugoslavia, which may be sold to the National Bank or to any authorized bank, and they may freely hold, purchase, import, and sell gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Domestic economic organizations that have been registered as trading in gold may import gold jewelry under the GDK import regime; they may freely export gold jewelry and other articles of gold. Authorized banks may freely export gold coins. Sales of newly mined gold to the National Bank against payment in dinars (calculated by applying the rate of Din 17 per U.S. dollar to a price of US$42.22 an ounce) are regarded as exports and entitle the seller to a retention quota of 20 per cent in convertible foreign exchange. Other domestic sales of newly mined gold by the producers may be made at a price which equals the average quota- tion in free gold markets abroad. Domestic economic organizations using gold for their normal activities may purchase gold from domestic producers or abroad on the basis of quotas allocated to each such organization individually. 461 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE (Position on December 31, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.77734 grams of fine gold per Za'ire. A central rate of Z 1 = SDR 1 has been established, and Zaire avails itself of wider margins. The Bank of Za ire (the central bank) determines the exchange rates be- tween the zaire and other currencies on the basis of the Fund's daily calculations of the SDR rate. Forward exchange transactions are prohibited. Administration of Control The Bank of Zai're, by virtue of its charter, has regu- latory authority over all foreign trade and payments. Specifically, the Bank has discretionary power to author- ize payments and receipts in foreign exchange by residents of Zaire, and to permit the import, export, and transit of goods. Prescription of Currency Payments from nonresidents must be received in listed convertible currencies quoted daily by the Bank of Zai're.1 Special authorization for the acceptance of other currency may be given only in respect of currencies that can be exchanged freely without a discount. Payments to nonresidents must be made in the listed currencies. However, certain settlements w i th Burund i, Rwanda, and Uganda are made through special accounts established under arrangements concluded by the Bank of Zai're with the central banks of the countries concerned. Nonresident Accounts There are three categories of nonresident accounts: Nonresident Accounts in Zai'res, Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts, and Convertible Accounts in Zai'res. Nonresident Accounts in Zai'res may generally be debited only with the approval of the Bank of Zai're. Such accounts, when opened by diplomatic missions and in terna t ional organizations established in Zai're, may be debited freely but may be credited only w i th the proceeds of sales of foreign currency and with payments made by the Government. Nonresident Foreign Currency Accounts may be credited for any permitted payment in foreign currency; they may be debited freely for transfers to accounts abroad or to Convertible Accounts in Zai'res maintained by residents or to Nonresident Foreign Currency Ac- counts, for sales of foreign currency, and for sales of foreign currency against domestic currency. Nonresident Zairian nationals require special authorization f rom the Bank of Zai're to open these accounts with authorized banks; nonresident foreigners may open them freely. 1 Austrian schillings, Belgian francs, Canadian dollars, CFA francs, Danish kroner, deutsche mark, French francs, Italian lire, Netherlands guilders, Norwegian kroner, Portuguese escudos, pounds sterling, Swedish kroner, Swiss francs, and U.S. dollars. 464 Convertible Accounts in Zai'res may be credited with amounts converted from foreign currency at the official rate, transfers f rom another Convertible Account in Zaires, or authorized payments by residents to nonresi- dents and may be debited freely for conversion into foreign currency or for any payments in domestic cur- rency. Such accounts may be held by both residents and nonresidents but must not be credited with payments for exports of goods or services. Imports and Import Payments The importation of a number of goods is prohibited on grounds of public policy; these are mainly arms, ammunition, narcotics, and jukeboxes. The importation of specified luxury items (including certain automobiles, jewelry, and fu rn i tu re) is prohibited for reasons of economic policy. For the import of most commodities other than certain priority items (mainly foodstuffs, Pharmaceuticals, raw materials, and industrial spare pa r t s ), import licenses must be submitted to the Bank of Zai're for prior approval. The importation of certain textiles and clothing is prohibited for protective reasons, while import licenses for other items produced do- mestically, but in insufficient quantities, are issued spar- ingly. For most goods subject to license the importer must obtain a credit of at least 180 days af ter shipment, while for specified priority items the importer must obtain a credit of at least 90 days. Imports paid for aga inst resident foreign currency accounts held by exporters are also subject to these requirements. Those imports not subject to import licenses approved by the Bank of Zaire are subject to import declarations, which do not require the approval of the Bank. The Bank issues a general import and payments license for such goods which guarantees the availability of foreign exchange2 when payments fall due, provided that the importer files an import declaration with his bank following the actual placing of the order and provided that the invoice price and qua l i ty have been verified and found acceptable by the foreign correspondents of the Office Zairois de Controle. Such verification is also required for all other imports. Applications for import licenses, whether requiring foreign exchange or not, are made out at authorized banks, which, after certification, forward the applications to the Bank of Zai're for approval. The import license application is then returned to the authorized bank for validation. Import licenses validated by the authorized banks remain valid for customs clearance for six months. Foreign exchange is, in principle, made avail- able for all licensed imports, the validated license con- stituting at the same time an exchange license. The licenses may be extended beyond the term of six months, for a fu r ther six-month period. 2 This guarantee has been suspended. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution Imports effected under bilateral arrangements between Zaire and certain countries (Belgium, the Federal Re- public of Germany, and the United States) are governed by separate, specific provisions. Imports in general are subject to a statistical tax of 3 per cent ad valorem and some are also subject to a tu rn- over tax of 9 per cent. In add i t ion, most imports, irrespective of origin, are subject to a temporary import surcharge of either 5 per cent or 20 per cent ad valorem on the c.i.f. value. Certain import payments have been delayed. Payments for Invisibles Policy related to payments for invisibles is formu la ted by the Bank of Zai're. Certain payments are subject to authorization by the Bank of Zaire; the approval author- ity for other current payments has been delegated to the authorized banks. The Bank of Zai're will not authorize exchange for the payment of commissions in favor of shippers, or purchasing agents, or for insurance on imports except for imports payable on arrival, and pro- vided that the supplier has arranged the insurance. Im- ports and exports between Zai're and ports in Belgium, the Federal Republic of Germany, the Netherlands, and the Scandinavian countries must be shipped in vessels participating in the conference of the Associated Central West A f r ica Lines. Banks are not authorized to pay in foreign currency the maritime freight on shipments that do not meet these regulations, unless an immediate discount is obtained on the invoice, and, in the case of exports, banks are not authorized to validate export declarations unless these are marked accordingly. Banks may effect maritime freight payments in foreign cur- rency at the time of shipment only for imports payable upon arrival. Mar i t ime freight charges may be paid in Zaire in local currency when goods are transported entirely by the Compagnie Maritime Zairoise. All other payments relating to services performed by nonresidents are, in principle, permitted. However, the transfer abroad of salaries of foreign nationals is subject to limits. Transfers pertaining to certain ad- ministrative expenses that firms incur abroad, interest on private loans, and payment of certain portions of insurance premiums are generally permitted. Transfers of net profits of firms with foreign participation have been suspended except where the transfer of such profits is expressly guaranteed by the Investment Code. Fares for travel abroad may be paid in Zaire in local currency. Zairian nationals traveling abroad may buy foreign exchange in amounts that depend on the dura- tion of the journey, up to the equivalent in zaires of BF 30,000 a trip for no more than four trips a year. The export of domestic banknotes and coins is pro- hibited. Nonresident travelers may take out any foreign means of payment declared upon entry. Certain current payments have been delayed. ZAIRE Exports and Export Proceeds All exports not covered by general license require individual declarations. Banks are normally authorized to approve such declarations, in which exporters under- take to collect the exchange proceeds. The declaration must specify the nature of the merchandise to be ex- ported, the price, and the currency in which payment is to be received. Export declarations are normally valid for three months; within this period, the proceeds must be received and surrendered. However, exporters may, upon receiving authorization from the Bank of Zaire, retain up to 10 per cent of their export proceeds in special foreign currency accounts opened with the authorized banks for this purpose; such accounts may be debited only for payments for merchandise imported for use in the export activity. Special provisions apply to mineral production of the Generate des Carrieres et Mines du Zaire (GECAM INE S ), which is marketed ex- clusively by the Societe Zairoise de Commercialisation des Produits Miniere (SOZACOM). On shipment, SOZACOM credits the account of GECAM INES with a pro- visional payment of a portion of the shipment's estimated value, and with the balance of the proceeds upon execu- tion of the sales contract. GECAMINES is allowed to retain up to 45 per cent of its export proceeds w i th banks abroad or in Zaire for meeting its own payments abroad, and must surrender the remainder of its proceeds to the Bank of Zaire. For diamond exports, two th i rds of the value established at a preliminary exam ina t ion in Zaire must be surrendered before the shipment is dis- patched. Export proceeds from coffee must be sur- rendered within 45 days after shipment, which must take place within a period of three months f rom the signing of the sales contract. Receipts f rom other agricultural exports must generally be repatriated w i th in three months of validation. Minimum export prices have been established for coffee, tea, ivory, papain, rauwolfia, and cinchona. All exports are subject to a statistical tax of 1 per cent ad valorem, and all commodities except cement are subject to export duties. Proceeds from Invisibles All exchange receipts from invisibles must be sur- rendered. The import of domestic banknotes and coins is prohibited. Nonresident travelers may bring in any amount in foreign means of payment and may take out on departure the amount declared on entry less the equivalent of the expenses incurred during their stay in Zaire. Capital The repatriation of new foreign capital brought in under the provisions of the Investment Code is guaran- teed, as is the transfer of profits and dividends on such capital. With minor exceptions, other transfers abroad of capital owned by residents or nonresidents are not 465 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAIRE permitted. Gratuitous transfers of real estate are subject to approval by departmental ordinance. The foreign currency assets of the authorized banks are not per- mitted to exceed their short-term liabilities in foreign currencies. Certain capital payments have been delayed. Gold Residents other than the monetary authorities, pro- ducers of gold, and industrial users are not allowed to purchase, hold, or sell gold in any form other than jewelry, at home or abroad. The import and export of gold in any form, except jewelry constituting the personal effects of a traveler, require the prior approval of the Bank of Zai're. Producers are not required to sell their production to the Bank. All newly produced gold is exported, with the exception of small quantities used domestically for the manufacture of jewelry. Com- mercial arrears for which the importer had not deposited the zai're equivalent by March 1 were not covered by this measure. Applications for transfers of such medical expenses incurred abroad would be authorized in March and September of each year (Letter No. 8821). 467 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA (Position on December 57, 1977) Exchange Rate System The par value is 1.14592 grams of fine gold per Zambian Kwacha. Since Ju ly 9, 1976 the central rate for the kwacha has been maintained in terms of the SDR at a rate of K 1 = SDR 1.08479,1 and Zambia continues to avail itself of wider margins. The U.S. dollar is the intervention currency, and the rates of the Bank of Zambia for the U.S. dollar are based on the Fund's daily calculation of the U.S. dollar-SDR rate. The Bank of Zambia deals with the Government and with authorized banks normally in U.S. dollars and sterling. Authorized banks are free to deal in other cur- rencies at rates based on daily rates provided by the Bank of Zambia or on the basis of cross rates with the U.S. dollar prevailing in the international foreign exchange markets. In its dealings with the commercial banks the Bank of Zambia applies a margin of 0.25 per cent for purchases of foreign exchange and 0.50 per cent for sales. Administration of Control Exchange control is administered by the Bank of Zambia under powers delegated to it by the Minister of Finance. Much of the authority for approving normal current payments is in tu rn delegated to commercial banks authorized to deal in foreign exchange. The con- trol of trade is the responsibility of the Minister of Commerce, who also issues import and export licenses. Overall import policy is made by a committee on which the Ministry of Commerce, the Ministry of Finance, and the Bank of Zambia are represented. Prescription of Currency Authorized payments, including payments for imports, by residents of Zambia to residents of countries other than Rhodesia may be made in Zambian currency to the credit of an External Account, or in any foreign cur- rency other than Rhodesian currency. Payments f rom residents of countries other than Rhodesia may be received in sterling or in Zambian currency f rom an External Account, or in any foreign currency freely exchangeable for U.S. dollars or sterling. Special regu- lations apply to settlements with Rhodesia. All permitted payments to residents of Rhodesia must be made in Rhodesian currency, in Zambian currency to an External Account earmarked Rhodesia, in sterling to a Rhodesian Account in the United Kingdom, in U.S. dollars, or in Canadian dollars. Proceeds from exports to Rhodesia must be received in U.S. or Canadian dollars. Nonresident Accounts Accounts in Zambian currency held w i th authorized banks by residents of countries other than Rhodesia are 1W i th e f fect f rom March 1, 1978, the exchange ra te for the kwacha was changed to K 1 = SDR 0.976311. 468 designated External Accounts.2 These accounts may be credited with authorized payments from residents of Zambia, w i th transfers from other External Accounts, and with the proceeds from sales of any foreign currency except Rhodesian currency by nonresidents to authorized banks. They may be debited for payments for any pur- pose to residents of Zambia, for transfers to other Exter- nal Accounts, and for purchases of any foreign currency other than Rhodesian currency from authorized banks. Blocked Accounts in Zambian currency held with authorized banks by residents of any country other than Zambia are credited with nontransferable capital sums in Zambian currency. All debits and credits to such accounts require the prior approval of the exchange con- trol authorities, except that the accounts of emigrants may be debited every year for the permitted anniversary allowance for remittances to the country of residence of the account holder. Normally, approval is given for the investment of balances on Blocked Accounts in Zambian securities, provided that these are held in Zambia to the order of an authorized dealer. The interest on Blocked Account balances is freely transferab le to the account holder's country of residence, except interest due to a resident of Rhodesia, which also is blocked. Imports and Import Payments Virtually all imports from Rhodesia are prohibited, as is the import from all countries of certain specified com- modities for health, safety, or moral reasons. Personal and household effects, samples, diplomatic shipments, and means of transportation entering Zambia temporarily do not require individual import licenses, nor do any other goods for personal use and consumption, provided that the person importing them does not import more than K 50 worth of such goods in any period of 90 days. The two major mining companies and the Ministry of Health are granted priority for bona fide requirements. The Controller of Customs is authorized to admit emer- gency goods imported without prior reference to the Ministry of Commerce. All other imports require indi- vidual import licenses. Import licensing aims at containing imports within a ha l f -yea r ly exchange allocation3 established by the Ministry of Commerce in consultation with the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Zambia. All imports under ind iv idual licensing are first divided into three-digit groups following the Standard International Trade Clas- sification system (SITC) and fu r ther subdivided into end-use groupings. Exchange allocations are specified 2 Au tho r ized banks are requ ired to obtain prior permission of the exchange control au thor i t ies before designating any new Ex ternal Account except where the account is to be opened for a temporary visitor. 3 U n t il J u ne 30, 1977 impo rt licenses were issued on a qu a r t e r ly basis. ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution for each of these categories. Normally, raw materials, intermediate goods for fur ther processing in Zambia, Pharmaceuticals, and fuel and electricity are licensed liberally; alcoholic beverages, tobacco, durable consumer goods, and other consumer goods are licensed restric- tively. No licenses are being issued for specified luxury consumer goods or for items that are produced locally. In principle, foreign exchange for import payments is automatically made available once an import license has been obtained, subject to presentation of the relevant documents to an authorized bank. Prior approval by the Bank of Zambia, however, is necessary for payments to South Africa in excess of K 20,000; imports from Rho- desia and South Africa are not normally permitted unless no alternative source of supply is available. Most imported goods are subject upon customs clear- ance to sales tax, at a rate of 25 per cent, calculated on the sum of 120 per cent of the customs value plus the applicable import duty. Certain import payments are in arrears. Payments for Invisibles Exchange to pay for invisibles related to imports, and also, up to certain limits, for other purposes, such as business travel, is provided by the commercial banks without prior reference to the exchange control authori- ties, except when payments and transfers in excess of K 20,000 to South Africa are involved. Transfers to Rhodesia are prohibited except in respect of pensions due to residents in that country and school fees of chil- dren whose parents are resident in Zambia. Authorized dealers are not permitted to make foreign exchange available for travel to Rhodesia. For other countries, exchange is granted as follows: The basic exchange allowance for business travel is K 50 a day for up to 15 days a person a calendar year. Exchange is provided, subject to certain limits, for other purposes such as edu- cation and medical treatment. Applications for amoun ts exceeding the limits may in certain circumstances be granted by the exchange control authorities if they are satisfied that exceptional trea tment is jus t i f ied. There is a tourist travel allowance of K 300 an adult for each calendar year. Applications for remittance abroad of part or all of payments for advertising, managemen t, accounting, adm in is tra t ive, engineering, and consulting services ren- dered to residents by nonresidents are subject to ind i- v idual approval by the Bank of Zamb ia, which gene ra l ly grants the required permission, provided that the fees charged are reasonable, that they relate to existing con- tracts, and that these services cannot be provided domestically.4 Profits and dividends of subsidiaries and branches of companies whose head offices are s i tua ted outside Zambia may be t ran s fe r red abroad up to 15 per cent of the nonres ident share of the equ i ty cap i tal or * Services rendered by a parent company abroad to its branch or wholly owned subsidiary in Zambia are not generally approved. ZAMBIA 50 per cent of net profits accruing to the nonresident owners of incorporated companies, whichever is smaller.5 Expatriate farmers are permitted to remit 12.5 per cent of their after-tax profits. A fu r ther 10 per cent may be held to their credit every year for eventual remittance when they leave Zambia. Such remittances are allowed once a year a f ter the end of the accounting year. The rem i t tance of depreciation allowances is not permitted. Foreign nationals employed in Zambia on a contract made after December 4, 1971 are allowed to remit one third of their annual earnings to the country nomi- nated when the contract was registered with the exchange control authorities. Foreign nationals recruited before December 4, 1971 and still employed on a contract entered into prior to that date are allowed to remit to their coun try of domicile one half of their annual earn- ings. Foreign nationals availing themselves of these arrangements are not entitled to the regular allowances for travel, education, maintenance, etc.; their leave salary, gratuity, and other terminal benefits are trans- ferable only on completion of the contract period and are subject to a ceiling of K 8,000 on departure and K 5,000 as a subsequent annual allowance. Remittances of up to K 20 a year are normally approved by the exchange control authorities for fam i ly maintenance. Travelers leaving Zambia may take out a maximum of K 10 in Zamb ian currency. Certain current payments are in arrears. Exports and Export Proceeds All exports valued at over K 50 require a license excepting those covered by an open general license; minerals are exported under general agreements with the m in ing companies. The export of certain metals is reserved, in principle, for an official agency, the Metal Marke t ing Corporation. Exports to Rhodesia are pro- hibited. Certain commodities are subject to licensing mainly to ensure domestic supplies of needed goods and of certain strategic materials, such as implements of war, lead in any form, certain minerals, petroleum products, certain rough and uncut precious stones, scrap and old metals, and ju te bags. For most goods, however, export licenses are issued freely. Export proceeds in foreign currency appropriate to the country of destination must be offered for sale to an authorized bank within six months of the date of shipment; the foreign exchange proceeds of copper exports, however, must be credited to a Bank of Zambia account in London upon receipt. Proceeds from Invisibles Receipts from invisibles in any currency must be offered for sale to an authorized bank. There is no limi- ta t ion on the amount of foreign currency notes that may 3 An aud i to r 's c e r t i f i c a te mu st be subm i t ted to the effect that the amount sought to be transferred represents bona fide realized profits derived from the year's operations a f ter fu ll provision has been made for local taxation. The profit and loss account and balance sheet for the year in respect of which application is being made must also be submitted. 469 ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA be imported by travelers, except that travelers from Zaire are allowed to import only up to the equivalent of K 20. Travelers arriving in Zambia may bring in a max imum of K 10 in Zambian currency. Capital Inward transfers of capital are not restricted but, with the exception of overseas short-term financing of imports other than certain capital goods, all borrowing outside Zambia requires the approval of the exchange control authorities. Outward transfers of capital are controlled, but nonresidents are normally permitted to repatriate their investments when they have satisfied the authorities that the original investment was made with funds brought into the country from sources outside Zambia. Local borrowing by companies controlled either directly or indirectly from outside Zambia is restricted to a debt- equity ratio of 1 to 2.6 However, the Bank of Zamb ia permits borrowings in excess of this limit for certain priority sectors of the economy, provided the borrowings secure higher employment opportunities and /or savings of foreign exchange. In general, residents are not permitted to t rans fer capital abroad and, with certain exceptions, are required to offer for sale to an authorized bank any foreign exchange which accrues to them. As a special measure, however, residents may purchase Zambian securities quoted on recognized stock exchanges abroad, provided that the securities so acquired are registered in the names of specified nominees and that in the event of subsequent disposal of these securities the sales proceeds are repa- triated. All income earned from these investments must be repatriated. Emigrants are granted exchange as follows: (1) Per- sons 50 years of age and over are allowed K 8,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of K 5,000. (2) Married persons under 50 are allowed K 4,000 on departure, together with K 250 for each child, up to a maximum of K 5,000 for a fam i ly unit. Thereafter, annual transfers of K 3,000, together with K 250 for each child, up to a maximum of K 4,000 for a fam i ly unit are permitted. (3) Unmarried persons under 50 are allowed K 2,000 on departure, and subsequent annual transfers of K 1,500. In addition to their emigra- tion allowance, emigrants may remit gratuities, compen- sation payments, and terminal benefits up to a max imum of K 8,000 on departure, and up to K 5,000 as annual transfers. In addition, there are special facilities for expatriate farmers for the transfer of profits up to certain limits (see section on Payments for Invisibles, above). Gold Residents may hold and acquire gold coins in Zambia for numismatic purposes. With this exception, residents other than the monetary authorities and authorized indus- 0 This was changed to a debt-equity ratio of 1 to 3 in accordance with A.D. Circular No. 6/78. 470 trial users are not allowed to hold or acquire gold in any fo rm other than jewelry, at home or abroad. Imports and exports of gold in any form other than jewelry require exchange control approval as well as import or export licenses issued by the Minister of Commerce; such licenses are not normally granted except for imports and exports by or on behalf of the monetary authorities and industrial users. Gold-bearing slime is exported by copper companies as a by-product for refining and sale abroad. Foreign exchange for imports of gold may be provided w i th the permission of the Bank of Zambia. Changes during 1977 January 31. The instruction issued on July 26, 1976 that authorized dealers must apply to the exchange con- trol authorities for prior approval to open letters of credit was withdrawn. February 1. The restriction introduced on Septem- ber 16, 1975 prohibiting the issue of foreign currency for tourism was withdrawn, and residents were allowed allocations of foreign currency up to the equivalent of K 300 per adult per annum; there was no provision for a travel allowance for children. February 1. The restrictions, imposed in 1975, on purchases of foreign currency notes and travelers checks from travelers by hotels and travel agents were withdrawn. March 28. The restriction, issued in July 1975, ban- ning the remittance of rentals to nonresidents who own property in Zambia was lifted. Provided tax had been paid, remittance of 50 per cent of the rentals received was permitted. April 1. The limit on annual transfers abroad by expatriate farmers was raised from 10 per cent to 12.5 per cent of their audited net profits after tax. In addi- tion, 10 per cent of the audited net profits after tax could be held to their credit every year and the entire accumulated sum would be remitted on emigration from Zambia together with other allowances enjoyed by emi- grants. This concession was limited to expatriate (non- Zamb ian) farmers and only profits derived from their fa rm ing activities would be covered by this arrangement. April 18. The authority delegated to authorized deal- ers to allow remittances up to K 20 a person a year as a gift or for maintenance purposes was withdrawn. May 16. Authorized dealers were prohibited from remitting proceeds of usance import bills before the ma tu r i ty dates. May 16. Authorized dealers were advised that the leave salary of foreign nationals employed in Zambia on a contract basis would be transferable only on comple- tion of the contract along with terminal benefits, subject to overall ceilings of K 8,000 on departure and K 5,000 as a subsequent annual allowance. May 17. The authorities withdrew the facility granted in September 1976 to foreign-controlled firms and com- panies operating in Zambia to invest unremittable profits or dividends in government stocks of not less than ©International Monetary Fund. Not for Redistribution ZAMBIA two years on the understanding that the principal plus interest on maturity would become remittable. May 20. Authorized dealers were prohibited from making any remittances to or entering into any transac- tion with persons, firms, or banks in Rhodesia. June 24. Authorized dealers were permitted to make remittances to Rhodesia in respect of pensions due to residents in that country and of school fees of children whose parents were resident in Zambia. June 27. Travel agents and airline companies were prohibited from selling tickets for round-the-world trips without the prior approval of the exchange control authorities. June 30. It was announced that remittance of profits and dividends would be allowed up to either 15 per cent of the nonresident share of the equity (instead of 30 per cent) or 50 per cent of the profits, whichever was smaller. July 8. The requirement that all export proceeds should be received through irrevocable letters of credit was withdrawn. September 22. Authorized dealers were empowered to provide travel allowance of up to K 70 a child to school children attending full-time courses outside Zambia, except in Rhodesia. 471 ©International Monetary Fund.
